description: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the writer and T contributor Bret Easton Ellis, who shares his list exclusively with T.

title: Tell Us: Is It Important to Elect a Woman as President?
description: A generation gap is emerging over the importance of electing a woman to the White House. We invite you to share your opinion. The Times may follow up with you.

title: A Trip to Vietnam Inspires Tender Pork Ribs
description: I love pork ribs, but when it comes to how best to cook them, I dont necessarily take the expected approach.

title: Both the Democrats and Republicans Want Radical Change:  Readers on the New Hampshire Primary
description: Readers dissected the influence of gender, generation and political agenda in response to recent columns and editorials about Senator Bernie Sanderss lopsided victory over former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton in the New Hampshire primary.

title: Hillary Clinton Sharpens Focus After Democratic Debate Tussles
description: DENMARK, S.C.  Hillary Clinton forcefully attacked Senator Bernie Sanders before a heavily black audience Friday, highlighting his criticism of President Obama, the Affordable Care Act and for what she suggested was a single-minded focus on economic fairness at the expense of racial justice.

title: Inside the List
description: Prophets of Doom: Some authors so thoroughly dominate their genre that rivals may want to invoke the Sherman Antitrust Act. Malcolm Gladwell, for instance, is the king of pithily titled, sociologically inflected narrative nonfiction with a vaguely entrepreneurial self-help feel; his Outliers has spent 208 weeks on the paperback nonfiction list and is currently No.7 on the monthly business list. So it seems almost cheeky that the Wharton School professor Adam Grant has settled, for his latest addition to the field, on the pithy title Originals. Grants book, which debuts at No.2 on the hardcover nonfiction list  and comes with a front-cover endorsement from Gladwell  overlaps with Outliers in substance as well as style: Both propose to explain why some people rise above their peers to change the world. (Gladwell emphasizes practice; Grant, passion and nonconformity.) Readers of the Book Review may be particularly interested in one study Grant cites, in which a psychologist gave subjects an actual New York Times book review, modified to make it either extremely positive or extremely negative, then asked them to rate the critics intelligence. Which version makes the reviewer sound smarter? Grant asks. People rated the critical reviewer as 14 percent more intelligent, and having 16 percent greater literary expertise, than the complimentary reviewer. People think an amateur can appreciate art, but it takes a professional to critique it. Or, as the original researcher put it, Prophets of doom and gloom appear wise and insightful, while positive statements are seen as having a nave Pollyanna quality.

title: John Kasich Says He, Too, Made Big Money in Speaking Fees
description: FLORENCE, S.C.  Hillary Clinton isnt the only presidential candidate who found paid speeches to be a lucrative source of income after leaving public office.

title: Death Becomes Them
description: I dont want to achieve immortality through my work, Woody Allen once said. I want to achieve it through not dying. One sympathizes. But for fictional characters, paradoxically, dying is often the best method of never really fading away. In this weeks issue, we look at a variety of books, both fiction and nonfiction, about the subjects of love and death.

title: Salt to the Sea, by Ruta Sepetys
description: A group of teenage refugees meet on the road in the chaotic countryside of East Prussia in winter 1945. The Nazi Reich is collapsing all around them, and they, like hundreds of thousands, are fleeing the wrathful Soviet advance. They are trapped between their German conquerors and their terrifying Russian liberators. Their story is told through the voices of Joana, a pretty Lithuanian nurse; Florian, a Prussian with a mysterious letter of passage from a high-ranking Nazi officer; and Emilia, an idealistic but damaged Polish girl in a pink knit cap. Thrown together, struggling to survive, they at first hardly trust one another enough even to exchange names, and so they often just use epithets: the knight, the nurse, the Polish girl, the wandering boy, the shoe poet. (The last, an old cobbler, gets his name from his philosophy: The shoes always tell the story.) Each has secrets  the galling histories that haunt anyone who has lived through war, flight and deprivation.

title: The Borden Murders, by Sarah Miller
description: Lizzie Borden took an ax,Gave her mother forty whacks.When she saw what she had done,She gave her father forty-one.

title: The Heart, by Maylis de Kerangal
description: We open this novel with the understanding that there will be death. It is a certainty. A story about a heart transplant is impossible without this inevitable equation: One body must give, and one must receive. From the first line of the French writer Maylis de Kerangals layered, meditative novel, we know that 19-year-old Simon Limbres will lose his heart.

title: Jakobs Colors, by Lindsay Hawdon
description: After World War II, even as West Germany began to pay reparations to Jewish death camp survivors, one of its ministries denied the very basis of a collateral holocaust, arguing that the Nazis had persecuted the European Roma not for any racial reason but because of their asocial and criminal record. In fact, the murder of up to half a million Roma in camps like Auschwitz-Birkenau and Treblinka is comparable to the Shoah on every level except that of scale. Yet the atrocity has never received comparable attention and acknowledgment.

title: $18.87 Million for a Greenwich Village Penthouse
description: A former wife of the South African hotel magnate Sol Kerzner paid $18,867,059.42 for a duplex penthouse at the Greenwich Lane, a nearly blocklong condominium complex rising at the site of the former St. Vincents Hospital campus in Greenwich Village. The transaction was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city property records.

title: The Photographers Wife, by Suzanne Joinson
description: Despite its title, Suzanne Joinsons dreamlike second novel belongs not to Eleanora Rasul, the British wife of an Arab photographer, but to a complex, willful and sometimes off-putting woman named Prudence Ashton. First encountered in 1920 as a lonely 11-year-old trapped in the Holy Land by her fathers government job, Prue is allowed to wander the desert with her own Kodak. There she runs into Willie, the shellshocked aviator her father has hired to survey Jerusalem and help modernize the city  that is, to make it more like London, with tidy public parks and signs of Arab habitation removed.

title: Flight of Dreams, by Ariel Lawhon
description: On its doomed flight in early May of 1937, the silver-skinned zeppelin Hindenburg sailed 600 feet above the earth, from Frankfurt, Germany, to Lakehurst, N.J. Traveling at just under 80 miles an hour, carrying 97 passengers and crew, it would take four days on its trans-Atlantic voyage.

title: Romance
description: MY AMERICAN DUCHESSBy Eloisa James Avon. Cloth, 389 pp., $25.99; paper, 422 pp., $7.99.

title: Review: An Intense yet Pastoral Mahler, Cowbells Included
description: Mahlers Sixth Symphony, which Semyon Bychkov is conducting with the New York Philharmonic at David Geffen Hall this week, achieves a remarkable synthesis of Classical structure and Romantic freedom. In the opening performance, on Thursday night, Mr. Bychkov gave full scope to those conflicting impulses.

title: Awakening the Bowerys Ghosts
description: One afternoon in October 2013, as work at a construction site in Chinatown was winding down for the day, an amateur historian known for his renegade research tactics, Adam Woodward, slipped through an open gate wearing a suit and tie. After nosing around in the pit, which was to accommodate the foundation for a 22-story luxury hotel, he sounded the alarm, a Paul Revere of the Bowery.

title: Gibney Dance Announces Premiere and Expansion for 25th Anniversary
description: New and restaged works by Gina Gibney, the founder and artistic director of Gibney Dance, are planned for the companys 25th anniversary celebration, along with a 10,000-square-foot expansion of its home.

title: New York City History, as Told by 50 Bowery
description: The address in Lower Manhattan has been a lodestone for the cultural, political and demographic changes of the city.

title: Bookshelf: At Home in the Cold
description: New picture books include One Day on Our Blue Planet . . . in the Antarctic and Shh! Bears Sleeping.

title: The Man Without a Shadow, by Joyce Carol Oates
description: Joyce Carol Oatess latest novel makes for uncomfortable reading. Even before the narrative begins, a hint of disquiet creeps in with the epigraph: The annihilation is not the terror. The journey is the terror. Forget the explicit reference to terror; a clammier sort of eeriness settles on the reader who pauses to research the identity of the epigraphs supposed source, Elihu Hoopes, who turns out to be the man without a shadow of the title. To enter these pages is to enter a world of smoke and mirrors, rendered all the more insidious by the realization that this purports to be a world of objective truth, a world of scientific inquiry.

title: Tender, by Belinda McKeon
description: Dark spirits inform the frantic heart at the center of Tender, Belinda McKeons second novel and a dead-on account of youthful obsession. Catherine Reilly is desperately in love with James Flynn. That James is gay seems no impediment to Catherine, and as their relationship grows ever more essential to her, she appropriates a line from Ted Hughes, a seducer-poet so powerfully attractive to women as to have made one throw up on sight of him: What happens in the heart simply happens.

title: Im Glad About You, by Theresa Rebeck
description: Theresa Rebecks tale of two star-crossed Midwesterners passed my screen test with flying colors. You know the one  you have a little pocket of time (15 minutes in the eye doctors waiting room, three minutes while waiting for the coffee to perk), and you have a choice: You can check your phone or dip into a book. When you pick the book, you know youre reading a winner. Im Glad About You is one of these novels  and not because my Instagram feed is all avocado toast, all the time.

title: The High Mountains of Portugal, by Yann Martel
description: A great void rises in Yann Martels new novel, and for the three men who act as the loose tethers of its three interwoven stories, the means of filling that void lies deep in the northern stretches of the Iberian countryside, among the scrubland and the stones. Spreading its action over the course of the 20th century, The High Mountains of Portugal probes the tender center of grief: Each of its three sections follows the fallout that results from the death of a mans wife.

title: Where My Heart Used to Beat, by Sebastian Faulks
description: Sebastian Faulkss latest novel explores the burden of Britains participation in the 20th centurys two major wars, as embodied in the experiences of Robert Hendricks, a psychiatrist and writer whose father died under murky circumstances during World War I and who is himself a lovelorn veteran of World War II. Readers of Faulkss fiction, most notably of the loose trilogy formed by Birdsong, The Girl at the Lion dOr and Charlotte Gray, know that his wartime plots tend to involve men and women finding and losing each other. Faulkss appeal and popularity come from his confident balancing of historically accurate detail with ardent, even over-the-top sympathy for passionate private lives.

title: Alive, Alive Oh! by Diana Athill
description: The title of Diana Athills 2009 memoir, Somewhere Towards the End, published when she was 91, acknowledged in her no-fuss, charming way that her final hours were drawing nigh. Somewhere was presumably a last glance backward at her romances with married men in her frequent role as the Other Woman, coupled with observations about caretaking her mother in her final days and insights on a variety of topics, from faith to fashion, from the perspective of advanced old age. Athill, a longtime London book editor, concluded her elegant narrative by musing on possibilities for her deathbed quotation, admitting, Foolish though it may be, I have to confess that I still hope the occasion on which I have to say it does not come very soon.

title: Pax, by Sara Pennypacker
description: Foxes are fable animals: Their fur carries the electric charge of literary history. As with cats, their faces suggest they have no need of us, and in literature they have all the power that goes with independence. There are the foxes in Machiavellis The Prince (One must therefore be a fox to recognize traps. ...) and Jean de La Fontaines verses, and theres Disneys Robin Hood, matinee idol that he was. For me the most memorable literary fox until now has been the baby fox in Ted Hughess poem Epiphany  a distilled ball of mannerless energy and old smell, and a test of the poets ability to bend his life and marriage to fit the presence of something so wild and destructive, and so beautiful. Pax, the eponymous fox of Sara Pennypackers new novel, is built on the model of Hughess cub, half wild and half domesticated, a galvanic presence fit to join the ranks of fictions great foxes.

title: The Red Hat, The Story of Snowflake and Inkdrop and More
description: Adults lug around a five-piece Samsonite luggage set of love and intimacy issues, but most small children have none, or at the most, a carry-on. They are unencumbered by personal history, commitment issues or self-doubt.

title: Six Perfumers Describe the One They Love, Through Smell
description: In honor of Valentines Day, T asked six great perfumers to describe the one they love  through smell  and how this has impacted their work.

title: The Narrow Door, by Paul Lisicky
description: How well do we know the ones we love? Not as well as we think. Not as well as we do when we lose them, to death or loss of love, and can see at last even what we never wanted to see. Paul Lisicky, in his new memoir, The Narrow Door, describes losing his old friend, the novelist Denise Gess, and his husband, the acclaimed poet and memoirist Mark Doty, within a year of each other: Gess to cancer, at the age of 57, and Doty to another man.

title: Weathering, by Lucy Wood
description: She made marmalade cake and soup with carrots and ginger; trying to replace the smell of damp with cooking smells. But still: damp shoes, damp clothes, the dank smell of river. The leak in the hall splitting the ceiling like the crust of a loaf. The snowed-in feeling of Lucy Woods captivating debut novel, Weathering, comes from such descriptions of the house Ada has inherited upon her mothers death, to which she has brought her young daughter, Pepper. This dampness so pervades the book that it almost swells the pages, and the imagery typifies Woods wonderful and energetic style, all the way down to the smallest detail: She found a silty smudge, like a handprint, on the outside of the kitchen window and a small pile of stones on the front steps. Lest you settle down too comfortably in this winter cabin of a novel: The handprint is that of her dead mother, Pearl.

title: How Cold Is It? Too Cold for an Ice Fest
description: The timing seemed perfect.

title: The Sexual Misery of the Arab World
description: ORAN, Algeria  AFTER Tahrir came Cologne. After the square came sex. The Arab revolutions of 2011 aroused enthusiasm at first, but passions have since waned. Those movements have come to look imperfect, even ugly: For one thing, they have failed to touch ideas, culture, religion or social norms, especially the norms relating to sex. Revolution doesnt mean modernity.

title: La misre sexuelle du monde arabe
description: ORAN, Algrie  Aprs Tahrir, Cologne. Aprs le square, le sexe. Les rvolutions arabes de 2011 avaient enthousiasm les opinions, mais depuis la passion est retombe. On a fini par dcouvrir  ces mouvements des imperfections, des laideurs. Par exemple, ils auront  peine touch aux ides,  la culture,  la religion ou aux codes sociaux, surtout ceux se rapportant au sexe. Rvolution ne veut pas dire modernit.

title: Founded for the Poor, Mass General Looks to the Wealthy
description: Can a hospital founded more than 200 years ago to treat the poor also adopt a form of medicine some criticize as health care for the rich?

title: A Partner in DDC Furniture on Living With the Elements
description: The Universe is what Babak Hakakian calls the long white-lacquer-and-glass hallway that runs from the front door of his loft to the living area overlooking Madison Square Park. Lined with his art collection, it is illuminated by four crystal-and-nickel Galaxy chandeliers designed by Jan Pauwels. I wanted the concept to really shine through, he explained.

title: What I Love | Babak Hakakian
description: Babak Hakakian, a partner in DDC, a high-end contemporary furniture business, practices the design he preaches at home.

title: For Some, Its Time to Look Overseas Again
description: Your portfolio of American stocks may have suffered lately but, to judge from major indexes, your portfolio of foreign stocks has probably done much worse for far longer.

title: A Savvy Breed of Winemaker Takes Business Sense to the Winery
description: Theres an old saying: If you want to make a small fortune in the wine business, start with a large one.

title: Troubled Dickstein Shapiro Law Firm to Merge With Blank Rome
description: After several years of turbulence, including the indictment of J. Dennis Hastert, a former House speaker who led its public policy practice, the once-prominent Washington law firm Dickstein Shapiro is folding and becoming part of a larger Philadelphia firm, Blank Rome.

title: 2 Female Students Killed in Shooting at Independence High School in Arizona
description: Two female students were fatally shot at Independence High School in Glendale, Ariz., early Friday, the authorities said.

title: Golden Leek and Potato Soup
description: Caramelized leeks, a bundle of fresh herbs and heavy cream build layers of flavor into this vegetable soup.

title: Vegetable Soups Built for Maximum Flavor
description: Soup season has us in its wintry grip, and now is the time to give in to its demands. Make more soup, the wind insists as the sleet pelts down from the hoary sky.

title: For Worlds Top Gymnast, a Body in Motion and a Mind at Rest
description: SPRING, Tex.  One Monday morning early in this Olympic year, on no particularly important day with nothing particularly important on the schedule, the worlds best female gymnast  perhaps the best gymnast in history  walked out of her bedroom and into the kitchen.

title: The Enduring Adolescence of Rivers Cuomo
description: Welcome to Social Capital, a series devoted to analyzing the social-media presences of celebrities.

description: Ms. Hearsts fall collection.

title: Legacy of Officer Peter Liangs Conviction Is Hard to Define
description: A police officer opened the door to a stairwell in a Brooklyn housing project, sidearm in hand, and squeezed the trigger. The gun, in its brutal simplicity, did exactly what it was designed to do. Far more complicated was how the racially charged atmosphere  in New York City and across the country  in which the shooting occurred might shape the legacy of what amounted to an accident in the dark.

title: Podcast: Drug Shortages, in America? Rationing Scarce Resources
description: Drug Shortages are the new normal in American medicine. How do doctors decide which patients get needed medicine? Sheri Fink talks about the issue.

title: Ex-Swedbank C.E.O. Referred to Prosecutors for Potential Market Abuses
description: LONDON  Michael Wolf, who was ousted as Swedbanks chief executive this week, has been referred to financial prosecutors in Sweden for suspicion of violating market abuse laws, the bank confirmed on Friday.

But on Friday morning, an embarrassing stain on the nation was erased. After 869 days, Norway finally has an ambassador.

description: In the big leagues of fashion, there is only one designer who has consistently challenged the paradox of power and sex  and shes done it with a laugh, a cigarette and a billion dollar business.

title: A Failed Auction? Might Be Nice.
description: Deutsche Bank is making investors an offer they should refuse. The German bank on Friday offered to buy back 5 billion euros of its senior unsecured bonds, after a week in which its shares went on a roller-coaster ride. A big takeup would generate more capital for Deutsche, but it could also imply a lack of confidence in the banks solvency. Given the potential for bond prices to snap back, it may be better for investors to sit on the sidelines.

Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Ted Cruz Mocks His Rivals in Comically Pointed Ads
description: He won Iowa, then placed third in New Hampshire, but Senator Ted Cruz has firmly established himself as the class of the Republican field in at least one respect: by producing humorous, barbed and biting political campaign ads.

title: Pope and Russian Orthodox Leader Meet in Historic Step
description: HAVANA  Pope Francis on Friday became the first pontiff to ever meet a patriarch of the Russian Orthodox Church, as the two Christian leaders set aside centuries of division in a historic encounter that was held in an unlikely setting: a room at the Havana airport.

title: ASAP Rocky Performs at the Guess Fashion Week Party
description: On the first night of New York Fashion Week, there were more than a dozen parties around town Thursday. ASAP Rocky celebrated his collaboration with Guess Originals at the Box, a cabaret club on the Lower East Side. Here are the photos.

title: PAC Is Backing Donald Trump, Despite Campaigns Policy
description: At first glance, the fund-raising email from TrumPAC could confuse a recipient. The solicitation that went out this week from what has been described in news media accounts as a super PAC, meaning it is barred from coordinating with the campaign, urges people to make a contribution of $5 that will go straight to Donald Trump  well eat all the processing costs so he gets 100 percent and YOU will show up on his F.E.C. report!

description: This season, the futuristic, techno, punk vibe is a powerful agent of change.

title: Watson Finalist B
description: Watson Finalist B had much internal support but was not ultimately chosen due to Finalist As strong test response. It is now available for use by developers and IBMs partners from Watson Services.

title: Watson Finalist A
description: Watson Finalist A was ultimated selected by IBMs researchers and marketers. It was used on the Jeopardy! show and appears in IBMs current television advertising.

title: Watson Finalist C
description: Watson Finalist C was also popular with the IBM researchers and marketers, but testing suggested it might be better suited for automated help desk and customer support applications. It too is available for use by developers and partners from Watson Services.

title: When Amateur Ironmen Pay for the Elite Treatment
description: When Marc Blumencranz had an opportunity to compete in the 2013 Ironman Triathlon World Championships in Kailua-Kona, Hawaii, he spared no expense in his preparations to go the distance.

title: Watson Exploratory D
description: During early testing, IBM researchers explored many voices with varying levels of synthesized expressiveness and intonation. Watson Exploratory D was designed to sound child-like but rejected when evaluators said it sounded creepy.

description: Trust the experts, the saying goes.

title: As Stocks Gyrate, Its Time to Measure Your Risk Tolerance
description: Its time you got to know yourself a little better.

title: Review: Badke, a Contemporary Spin on an Arabic Folk Dance
description: Badke begins in the dark, where signs of life are heard, not seen. But neither the setting nor the subject matter leaves you unaware for long. As the stage reverberates with the sound of punctuated stomps, claps and the occasional whoop, the lights slowly illuminate the scene: 10 dancers with their backs to us hopping in sync. Who doesnt love a good folk dance?

title: Your Daily Fashion Week Recap for Friday, Feb. 12
description: 1. Tens of thousands of people approached Madison Square Garden for Yeezy Season 3  and the premiere of Kanyes latest album, The Life of Pablo. Our Styles and Culture (real) friends live-blogged the event and we rounded up the highlights here.

title: Death of a Student, Giulio Regeni, Highlights Perils for Egyptians, Too
description: CAIRO  On the night he vanished, Giulio Regeni left his apartment and walked past four stores with surveillance cameras that might have provided vital information 10 days later, when his body turned up with welts, burns and fractures that were unmistakable signs of torture.

title: Latvia Has a New Leader, as Fears of Russia and Migration Rise
description: RIGA, Latvia  Two months after Latvias first female prime minister quit in frustration, this small but strategically located Baltic nation has a new government  but only after a drawn-out process in which a string of politicians declined the leaders job.

title: A Word With: John Oliver, Competing Against People Sleeping
description: On Sunday, John Oliver returns with the third season of Last Week Tonight on HBO, joining a late-night comedy landscape that is arguably more competitive than its ever been. With only so many viewers to go around, who can make the best Donald Trump joke, who can fill the void left by Jon Stewart and who can produce a segment that goes viral are all vital questions.

title: Review: In 11.22.63, an Appointment in Dallas
description: The streaming service Hulu needs a big score to keep pace with Netflix, and it has placed its faith in a couple of relatively sure things: Stephen King and the 1960s. The result, 11.22.63, which begins Monday, is a capable adaptation of Mr. Kings 2011 best seller, appealing enough to snag a general audience and yet different enough from the book to give hard-core King fans plenty to grouse about.

title: Review: Liliane Montevecchi, Still a Proudly Glittering Gamine at 83
description: If any entertainer could be described as Paris incarnate, it might be Liliane Montevecchi, a quintessential French gamine from another age whose autobiographical one-woman show, Be My Valentine, opened on Thursday night at Feinsteins/54 Below.

description: I HAVE spent much of my career as a diplomat. It is an occupation in which words and context matter a great deal. So one might assume I know better than to tell a large number of women to go to hell.

title: James Levine Cancels Philadelphia Concerts
description: James Levine, the longtime Metropolitan Opera music director whose health struggles recently brought him to the verge of retirement from that position, has canceled a series of concerts with the Philadelphia Orchestra next week. Mr. Levine, 72, who has Parkinsons disease, has been modifying his medication levels in an attempt to ease his condition, and the orchestra said in a statement that the physical demands of travel, rehearsal and concert performance would be detrimental to his current medical treatment.

title: Jeb Bush Supporters Run Brutal Ad Against Donald Trump
description: The super PAC supporting Jeb Bush is running a brutal ad against Donald J. Trump in South Carolina, the latest in a string of negative spots to take on the Republican candidate who is leading the polls.

title: Police Department Fires Partner of Ex-Officer Peter Liang

(Thanks, in large part, to the stylists Kate Young and Erin Walsh, who were early champions of the brand.) The week before the show, it was like, Oh my God, if we dont pull this off, its going to be really embarrassing, remembers Kim during a recent visit to the pairs SoHo studio.

description: There was a getaway car waiting outside. His family kept bags packed, ready to flee. And a fixer was on standby at the airport, waiting to book last-minute tickets if the need for escape should arise. Those precautions, among others, were taken by the filmmakers of the Oscar-nominated documentary The Look of Silence to ensure that its subject, Adi Rukun, remained safe during production.

title: Harry Reid Says Alan Grayson Should Drop Senate Bid
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Democratic leader, on Friday called for Representative Alan Grayson to drop his bid for the Senate, saying Mr. Graysons actions as a hedge fund manager arent just disgraceful to the Democratic Party; they disgrace the halls of Congress.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple is working on an original television show with Dr. Dre, the co-founder of Beats Music and an Apple executive, according to a person with knowledge of the project.

description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.  The Republican presidential race has erupted in an incendiary new round of attacks over immigration, laying the groundwork in South Carolina for a monthslong fight that is likely to amplify hard-line talk about border security and migrants before a national audience.

description: SAVANNAH, Ga.  It was standing room only at the annual conference of the American Mosquito Control Association this week.

title: A Valentines Date Idea for Astronomy-Loving Early Birds
description: Those who are looking for an unusual Valentines Day activity may want to take advantage of the narrowing window of opportunity to see five planets align. This time-lapse video, captured on Jan. 28, gives a sense of what is possible for those who rise very early  or stay up very late.

title: Meet the People Who Went to Kanye Wests Yeezy Season 3 Extravaganza
description: Fans of fashion and music discussed what they're wearing, how much they love Kanye and how they managed to get tickets.

title: Maryland University Reinstates Two Faculty Members Amid Outcry
description: The president of Mount St. Marys University in Maryland has reinstated two professors who were fired this week for what the administration called disloyalty, after the dismissals were widely denounced by advocates of academic and journalistic freedom and led to a faculty vote demanding his resignation.

title: Anxiety Rises in Mexico as the Peso Tumbles
description: MEXICO CITY  The voluble talk-show host Andrea Legarreta broke from her routine of celebrity chatter and household tips recently to give her television viewers an impromptu lesson in global economics and the Mexican peso.

title: How Ute Lemper, German Chanteuse, Spends Her Sundays
description: With her sultry stage persona and sharp vocal claws, as a review in The New York Times put it, the German chanteuse Ute Lemper doesnt project the vibe of an Upper West Side mom. But on Sundays  when shes not presenting cabaret classics by Kurt Weill or her latest song cycle, The 9 Secrets, a setting of Paulo Coelhos Manuscripts Found in Accra  shes just that. The rock-solid foundation of my life is my family, and I enjoy very much being with my kids and seeing them happy, Ms. Lemper said, adding, Its only onstage that I am the glamorous lady. Ms. Lemper, 52, lives in two apartments on different floors of a West 76th Street building with her husband, the percussionist and producer Todd Turkisher, 56; their children, Julian, 10, and Jonas, 4; and, when they are home from college, her two children from a previous marriage, Max, 21, and Stella, 19.

title: Tommy Kelly, Who Played a Hollywood Tom Sawyer, Dies at 90
description: If you were a producer casting The Adventures of Tom Sawyer, that enduring study of small-town, Middle American life, where would you be least likely to look for your star?

title: Fashion Week Today: Never Mind the Cold, Its Always Sunny on Instagram
description: Well be bringing you highlights from the shows, from the extravaganzas to the scrappy upstarts.

title: Friday Night Music: New Pornographers, Crash Years
description: I was thinking about the world economy, and realized this was running through my head:

title: Strange Fascinations in a Kitsch Hideaway
description: A bar in Chinatown is a ramshackle retreat full of psychedelic charm.

title: At a Chinatown Bar, Libations Sipped by the Light of Disco Balls
description: Trung Trang sat in his favorite booth at 169 Bar on East Broadway with his friend Allison Clark on a Saturday night last month. It was the night of the seasons first blizzard, and though Ms. Clark lived nearby, he had braved the trip to Chinatown from South Williamsburg, on foot. He was ready for a drink. A hodgepodge of disco balls, lasers and lanterns threw seizure-inducing hues of yellow, magenta and green onto their faces.

title: Drew Lewis, Transportation Secretary During Air Controllers Strike, Dies at 84
description: Drew Lewis, who as transportation secretary under Ronald Reagan in the early 1980s led contract negotiations with the air traffic controllers union and, when many of its members went on strike, put together a temporary system to keep planes in the air, died on Wednesday in Prescott, Ariz. He was 84.

title: Two-Thirds of the World Faces Severe Water Shortages
description: About four billion people, or two-thirds of the worlds population, face severe water shortages during at least one month every year, far more than was previously thought, according to Arjen Y. Hoekstra, a professor of water management at the University of Twente in the Netherlands.

title: Recalling the Past Lives of an East Village Bathhouse
description: A recent article about the Russian and Turkish Baths, a 124-year-old bathhouse on East 10th Street that thrives despite competition from more luxurious spots like Spa Castle, examined the baths odd business arrangement: For more than two decades, the two owners have split the business, operating it on alternate weeks.

title: Leading a 21st-Century 21 Club
description: The venerable 21 Club on West 52nd Street is famous  notorious, even  for its speakeasy heritage and its history of well-known, well-lubricated regulars.

title: Teatum Jones Wins the International Woolmark Prize
description: In 1954, two fashion world up-and-comers were honored by the International Wool Secretariat for their work in womens wear. Karl Lagerfeld, 21 at the time, won a prize for coats, and Yves Saint Laurent, 18, was rewarded for dress design. The designers Hubert de Givenchy and Pierre Balmain were among the judges bestowing the honors.

title: Take Me to the Pilot
description: Theres no mistaking the Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum among the recreational boats, yachts and water taxis anchored at the piers along the Hudson Rivers Manhattan docks. Its the aircraft carrier next to the space shuttle and the submarine.

title: Cosby Appeal Filed to Prevent Sexual Assault Case Prosecution
description: Bill Cosbys lawyers on Friday appealed a decision made by a judge in a Pennsylvania court last week that allowed prosecutors to proceed with a criminal sexual assault case against him.

title: At Yonkers Brewing Company, Beer Steeped in Local Pride
description: Until about a year ago, the name most associated with beer in Yonkers was probably that of the notorious racketeer Dutch Schultz, whose criminal domain once included a brewery in the city.

title: Jake Page, Editor Who Made Science Accessible, Dies at 80
description: Jake Page, an editor and columnist at Smithsonian magazine who brought the wonders of science to a general audience in dozens of books, and who channeled his interest in the Indians of the American Southwest into a series of popular mystery novels, died on Wednesday at his home in Lyons, Colo. He was 80.

title: New Donald Trump Ad Highlights Father of Teenager Killed by Illegal Immigrant
description: Abandoning a plan to run strictly positive ads in South Carolina, Donald J. Trumps campaign released one that focused on the 2008 murder of a black teenage athlete in Los Angeles by an illegal immigrant.

title: Review: Beneath the Rafters of the Barn, Steak and Seafood
description: Entering a new restaurant, you react to certain details semiconsciously, dcor features that skew your affections one way or another. The first thing I noticed at the Barn was the colored lights. Backlit areas glowed pink, yellow or green; a wooden lattice enclosed false marble panels that were lighted a luminous aqua from within. Wild, Gorgon-like chandeliers glimmered blue and yellow overhead. There was a vaguely disco-like quality to it all. Uh-oh, I thought.

title: Georgia: State to Pay Transgender Inmate
description: The State Department of Corrections has agreed to pay a settlement of more than $250,000 to Ashley Diamond, the transgender woman who sued officials last year for failing to provide her necessary medical treatment and safekeeping during her incarceration. Ms. Diamond, a nonviolent offender who was housed in male prisons until her release in August, alleged that she was raped multiple times and that she was denied hormone therapy until the Department of Justice intervened in her case and The New York Times wrote about it. As result of her federal lawsuit, Georgia changed its approach to transgender inmates and dozens have started receiving hormones, the Southern Poverty Law Center said Friday.

title: Review: The Stockton Inn, After a Revamp, Adopts a Modern Menu
Michigan: Snyder Will Testify on Poisoned Water
description: Gov. Rick Snyder will testify before a congressional committee on the water crisis in Flint, he said on Friday. In a statement, Mr. Snyder, left, said that he had asked Representative Jason Chaffetz of Utah, chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, for the opportunity to speak about the lead contamination that occurred in the Flint water supply in 2014 and 2015. Mr. Chaffetz has not set a date for the hearing, but said that six other witnesses were invited. They include Susan Hedman, a former regional administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency who resigned last week; Darnell Earley, a former emergency manager of Flint; Dayne Walling, a former mayor of Flint; and Gina McCarthy, the E.P.A. administrator. The witnesses will shed light on many of our remaining questions and help us propose reforms to the authorizing committees, Mr. Chaffetz said in a statement.

title: Syria Truce Deal Makes Aid a Political Tool, Critics Say
description: UNITED NATIONS  Leaders of humanitarian aid organizations have, over the last few months, repeatedly implored the warring parties in Syria and their backers not to use the delivery of food and medicine as a bargaining chip in their negotiations about war and peace.

title: Review: At ToA, a Familys Latest Foray Into Asian Fusion
description: Last September, ToA Asian Fusion became one of the newest fusion restaurants  and there are many from which to choose  to open on Long Island. Located opposite the Paramount theater in Huntington, it is owned by members of the Chen family, who also own MoCA Asian Bistro in Woodbury, Hewlett and Forest Hills, Queens, and MoCA Express in Inwood.

title: Brian Moynihan, Bank of America Chief, Got 23% Pay Raise in 2015
description: Bank of America gave its chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, a pay package last year that was 23 percent larger than in 2014, as the big bank generated higher profits and put its mortgage problems squarely behind it.

title: Art and Ceremony Intertwine at Hosftra University African Exhibit
description: While doing research for the exhibition Africa: Sub-Saharan Diversity at Hofstra University Museum, its curator, Karen T. Albert, wondered about the identification of one major object.

title: Bill Richardson Aids Effort to Free Student Held in North Korea
description: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio has asked former Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, a veteran diplomat and North Korea troubleshooter, to help in the effort to free an Ohioan arrested by the North Korean authorities six weeks ago, Mr. Kasichs spokesman said Friday.

title: While You Were Sleeping, They Made Art
description: It was 3 a.m. and Alexandra Rutsch Brock couldnt sleep. She was scrolling through her Facebook news feed when she was struck by an image of an abstract painting posted by Julia Schwartz. I fell in love with it, Ms. Brock said.

title: Review: In Nureyevs Eyes, a Bond Between a Painter and a Dancer
description: An unlikely but real friendship that developed between Rudolf Nureyev, the legendary Russian dancer, and Jamie Wyeth, the American realist painter, is imaginatively dramatized by David Rush in Nureyevs Eyes, his two-character play at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick.

title: Texas Panel Calls for an End to Criminal IDs via Bite Mark
description: An influential scientific commission in Texas called Friday for a halt in the use of bite-mark identifications in criminal trials, concluding that the validity of the technique has not been scientifically established.

title: The Moors at Yale Rep: Flights of Fancy and Tales of Deceit
description: A mastiff and a hen came to me in my sleep the other night, visitors from the play I had just seen in New Haven. I wonder if the writer Jen Silverman has had the same experience, because her inspired new play, The Moors, rolls out like the stuff of dreams, with telling passages heightened by surrealistic flights of fancy  including that mastiff and hen in an archetypally pleasing, you-really-ought-to-see-this parable.

title: Stranded at the Border
description: For Syrians fleeing airstrikes in Aleppo Province and hoping to find refuge in Turkey, it remains to be seen what the recent cease-fire agreement means. Most of them are still stuck at the border.

title: American Marathoners Can Reach the Olympics One Way: Going the Distance
description: LOS ANGELES  Americas top runners will gather on Saturday for the highest-stakes long-distance event in the nation: the Olympic marathon trials.

title: Creations That Capture Our Imaginations
description: While todays investment on infrastructure seems to prioritize repair, there are inspiring works to restore our faith in the power of great projects.

title: Many Asians Express Dismay and Frustration After Liang Verdict
description: As the jury read the verdict  guilty  in the manslaughter trial of a New York City police officer whose gunshot into the stairwell of a public-housing building killed an unarmed man, the officer, Peter Liang, crumpled in his seat in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, his face falling into his hands.

title: What Happened to the Great Urban Design Projects?
description: On any given day, painters are repainting some part of the [Golden Gate] bridge. They use 10,000 gallons of paint a year. It is crazy that people repaint a bridge all year  The Golden Gate Bridge, which is orange, is the best-known and best-loved bridge in the world. It is best known because it is bold and courageous and unusual and even strange. It is best loved because it is bold and courageous and unusual and even strange.

title: In Little-Man Era, Four Big Men Will Test Their Skills
description: In the early days of the N.B.A., big men ruled the league. Giants with names like Mikan, Russell and Chamberlain dominated the paint, leaving smaller players to scrap for tougher shots outside.

title: John Kasich Has Kinds Words for Chris Christie, but No Talk of Endorsement
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  After winning over one of Gov. Chris Christies leading supporters, Gov. John Kasich of Ohio offered kind words for Mr. Christie on Friday, but said he had not asked him for an endorsement.

title: Indie Bookstores Are Back, With a Passion
description: The decades of trauma suffered by independent neighborhood bookstores  damage from bargain megastores, the ascension of the e-book and Amazons flash delivery of cut-rate reading  hardly hindered Chris Doeblins search for the right place to open his fourth independent bookstore in Manhattan.

title: With a Slur for Ted Cruz, Donald Trump Further Splits Voters
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Donald J. Trump has defied conservative orthodoxy on policy, shunned traditional politicking and even insulted prisoners of war and the disabled, sacrosanct constituencies that other candidates would no more slur than they would accept a bag of cash with cameras rolling.

title: Another Season Gone Awry Hangs Over Carmelo Anthony, the All-Star
description: TORONTO  Carmelo Anthony, surrounded by many of his closest friends ahead of yet another appearance in the All-Star Game, said he was doing his best to forget about his full-time job, at least for a few fun-filled days.

title: F.E.C. Tells Sanders Campaign That Some Donors May Have Given Too Much
description: The Federal Election Commission has asked the presidential campaign of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont to re-examine contributions from more than a hundred donors who appear to have given more than the legally permissible amount.

title: Republicans, Widows and Porn
description: You cant possibly say its been a bad week when Ted Cruz has a problem with a soft-core porn actress.

title: When Conditions Become Terrifying, an Elite Contest Can Proceed
description: HALF MOON BAY, Calif.  The veteran big-wave surfer Ken Collins thought he was going to drown. Safely alive a few minutes later, standing on a small dock with gauze stuffed into a left ear that had a ruptured drum, he was out of the Titans of Mavericks.

title: Takata Discarded Evidence of Airbag Ruptures as Early as 2000
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  As the safety crisis surrounding Takatas airbags that are prone to rupture has mushroomed, the Japanese auto supplier has insisted that the propellant in its airbags is safe.

title: Sophie Theallet: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Ms. Theallet presents her fall collection.

title: Last Militants Who Occupied Oregon Wildlife Refuge Appear in Federal Court
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  The standoff at a remote federal wildlife refuge that pitted armed militants against law enforcement officials began its next chapter in a federal courtroom here on Friday, a day after the final occupiers of the refuge surrendered. But the tough talk and the posturing about the governments powers to oppress  the occupation groups main ideological thread  continued in the street outside the courthouse, undiminished but now in a new setting.

title: Prisoners Exonerated, Prosecutors Exposed
description: In 2015, 149 people convicted of crimes large and small  from capital murder to burglary  were exonerated. It is the highest yearly total since this grim form of record-keeping began, in 1989.

title: Mrs. Clintons Mixed Immigration Message
description: In Thursday nights Democratic debate, Hillary Clinton defended her past statements that Central American migrant children needed to be sent home from the border to send a message to other families: Dont come.

title: Glenwood Management, Developer Cited in Corruption Cases, Settles Disability Lawsuit
description: Glenwood Management, a politically influential developer of luxury high-rise apartment buildings in Manhattan that figured in two recent public corruption trials, has agreed to settle a civil rights lawsuit that claimed three of its residential complexes violated the Fair Housing Acts requirements for people with disabilities.

title: Monse: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Laura Kim and Fernando Garcia, alumni of Oscar de la Renta, present their second collection.

title: Dealing With Space and Time
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  This one by Peter Wentz was a fun solve and not terribly difficult, although I did jump around quite a bit to fill everything in.

title: Earth, Wind & Fires Musical Reintegration
description: THIS past weekend, radio stations across the country honored Maurice White, a founder of, singer for and driving force behind the band Earth, Wind & Fire, who died on Feb. 4, by playing marathons of his music. On Sunday, Mr. White and his band will be awarded the Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award, joining musicians like Frank Sinatra, Ella Fitzgerald, Johnny Cash and the Beatles.

title: U.S. Plans to Resume Commercial Flights to Cuba This Year
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Tuesday plans to complete an agreement with Cuba that will allow scheduled commercial flights to resume this year between the United States and the island nation for the first time in more than 50 years.

title: Head of Swedens Karolinska Institute Quits Over Transplant Scandal
description: The top administrator of one of Europes leading medical universities resigned on Friday, becoming the latest casualty of a scandal involving a prominent surgeon in the field of regenerative medicine.

title: Ah, Spring! What Could Go Wrong?
description: The best part of spring training, which opens for most teams by the end of this week, is the optimism. Every teams best-case scenario is still in play. Whatever jersey a player wears, he can slip it on with pride and channel his inner Lloyd Christmas, the nave dreamer from Dumb and Dumber.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: In the wake of unfortunately so many deaths of unarmed black men, some cops gotta hang. The sentiment in the Asian community is: Its easier to hang an Asian, because Asians, they dont speak up.

title: Experts Discuss the Success Academy Video
description: A group of scholars shared their thoughts on effective teaching methods after watching a video of a teacher reacting to a students math mistake.

title: Prostitute Found in Long Island Marsh in 2011 May Have Been Murdered, Pathologist Says
description: Shannan Gilbert had been missing for more than a year and a half when her remains were found in 2011 on Jones Beach Island, N.Y., in a marsh off an oceanside highway. Police officials in Suffolk County suspected at the time that Ms. Gilbert, 24, had drowned, and an autopsy by the county medical examiner left the cause of death undetermined.

title: Syrian War Could Turn on the Battle for Aleppo
description: Russia is bombing rebel-held areas in Syria at a furious pace. That is giving the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, the upper hand. Meanwhile, critics accuse the United States of dithering.

title: Readers Respond to Video of Success Academy Teachers Frustration With Student
description: Didnt Rutgers University fire its basketball coach for similar behavior?

title: On the Verge of Victory, the Rangers Let One Slip Away
description: A clash between the Rangers and the Los Angeles Kings stirs emotions for both squads.

title: Yankees Settle With Closer Aroldis Chapman
description: The Yankees avoided arbitration with the newly acquired closer Aroldis Chapman and agreed to a one-year, $11.325 million contract. Chapman made $8.05 million last season, when he was 4-4 with 33 saves in 36 chances for the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Corrections: February 13, 2016
description: THE ARTS

title: What to Watch Saturday
description: The Fast & franchise goes airborne  and says farewell to Paul Walker  in Furious 7. Meru follows some fearless types up a stomach-turning blade of granite in the Himalayas. And Rebecca Hall and Jason Sudeikis spar alongside a couple of cute dogs in Tumbledown.

title: North Korea Cancels Investigation Into Abductions of Japanese Citizens
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea has announced a halt to an investigation into the fate of Japanese citizens said to have been abducted by its agents decades ago, retaliating for sanctions Japan imposed this week after the Norths latest rocket launching.

title: John Dickerson, Molded by News Legends, Hones His Skills at CBS
description: WASHINGTON  By the standards of Sunday morning news shows, the handoff of the anchors position on Face the Nation on CBS was really quite peaceful.

title: Constant Tide of Migrants at Sea, and at Turkish Cemetery
description: IZMIR, Turkey  City workers shoveled dirt over the two coffins, one at a time, as an imam, in plaintive and meditative tones, sang prayers in Arabic.

title: Gearing Up for the Cloud, AT&T Tells Its Workers: Adapt, or Else
description: DALLAS  Thirty-four years ago, Kevin Stephenson got his younger brother, Randall, a job with the telephone company.

title: Layers a Ton, Loves Carolina Herrera
description: Name Kathleen Newman Bennetter

title: Fashion Week: Saturday Is Church Day for Alexander Wang
description: Remember Saturday? That mythical day to sleep in, loll over coffee, maybe take in a movie? Try again next week. Its New York Fashion Week, and the parade continues apace. Weekend or not, theres a full day of shows ahead.

title: The House D.J. of the Bernie Sanders Campaign
description: CONCORD, N.H.  Standing between a wall of retracted wooden bleachers and his turntables, Mel Sandico, a.k.a. Mel Cavaricci, a.k.a. D.J. Mel, looked up to survey the crowd filing into Senator Bernie Sanderss New Hampshire victory party last Tuesday night.

title: The New Celebrity Power Move: Keeping Secrets
description: The announcement of David Bowies death on Jan. 11 dealt a double blow. First was its finality. Then came the realization that barely anybody knew he had been sick, including an old ally like Brian Eno, with whom he had traded emails a week before.

title: What Is Paul Rudnick Doing Writing Young Adult Fiction?
description: It didnt take much to persuade Paul Rudnick to step inside P.S. 3 the other day to watch parents waiting to take their children home. After all, the gleefully transgressive humorist, who regularly launches little satirical missiles in The New Yorker, was about to publish his second young-adult novel. Observing a school pickup in his West Village neighborhood could be construed not so much as stalking as research, and also a good way to start this interview.

title: Peggy Siegal Through the Years
description: Peggy Siegal, the omnipresent New York film publicist and event planner, remains Hollywoods secret weapon in New York.

title: Peggy Siegal, Best Hostess in a Supporting Role
description: Hunched over her saumon marine, Peggy Siegal, the omnipresent New York film publicist and event planner, was sitting between Oliver Stone and Anne Hearst at the Manhattan restaurant La Grenouille last October, talking about the night she tried to ascend to the throne of England.

title: Chinas Exodus of Capital
description: As the economy stumbles, individuals and companies are pulling money out of China en masse, leaving the government scrambling to limit the outflows.

title: Chinese Start to Lose Confidence in Their Currency
description: HONG KONG  As the Chinese economy stumbles, wealthy families are increasingly trying to move large sums of money out of the country, worried that the value of the currency will fall and their savings will be worth less.

title: Rescue Efforts End in Taiwanese City Struck by Quake
description: HONG KONG  Rescue efforts ended on Saturday at the site of a 17-story apartment complex in Tainan, in southwestern Taiwan that collapsed in an earthquake a week earlier, as search crews pulled the last of 114 bodies from the rubble.

title: 1941: Germany Reported to Send Art to U.S. for Sale
description: LONDON  Fourteen world-famous paintings, having a total value of more than 2,000,000 ($8,000,000), are on their way from Germany to the United States by way of Siberia and the Pacific to be sold to bolster the Nazis dollar balances, the British Ministry of Economic Warfare said today [Feb. 12].

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took our followers from New Hampshire to San Pedro la Laguna in Guatemala.

title: Moonshot Metaphor on Cancer Is a Failure to Communicate
description: Can we agree to stop calling it the cancer moonshot?

title: Royal Caribbeans Smartship Avoids a Titanic Situation
description: Its the most technologically advanced cruise ship in the world, the Royal Caribbean sales agent told me over the phone when I booked a trip aboard the Anthem of the Seas, the cruise lines flashy new megaship, reported to be the third-largest cruise vessel ever built. Its what we call a smartship.

title: A Little Variety
description: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES  This weeks puzzles include:

title: AT&Ts History of Invention and Breakups
description: AT&T, once known informally as Ma Bell, is a storied American brand that goes back under a succession of names to the late 19th century, after Alexander Graham Bell invented the telephone.

title: Farhad and Mikes Week in Tech: Rethinking Twitter, and a Hurdle for Facebook
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

title: In Mets Manon Lescaut, Classic Love Story Gets Noir Twist
description: With courage, determination and a healthy measure of ambition, the tenor Roberto Alagna rescued the Metropolitan Operas new production of Puccinis Manon Lescaut, which opened on Friday night. The production was thrown into crisis last month when Jonas Kaufmann, the most sought-after tenor in opera, withdrew from the entire run because of an illness he did not specify. Hoping to line up a star tenor replacement as des Grieux, the Mets general manager Peter Gelb turned to Mr. Alagna, who had never sung the role. With just 16 days to prepare a major Puccini part for an important new production, Mr. Alagna, who had been appearing in Pagliacci at the Met, agreed to take it on.

title: Falling Asleep to Grenades: Mexicans Tell Pope How They Live
description: A young mother living in one of Mexicos most violent states said she had gone to sleep with the sound of grenades and guns outside her home. Another woman, in Mexico City, wrote that kidnappings had become so commonplace, they are spoken of like the weather. Many others complained about living under a corrupt government.

title: Jason Wu Takes On Red Velvet
description: The designers fall/winter collection featured subtle plays on texture, from wool and lace to swingy beaded fringe.

title: John Kasich Recalls Parents Death in Appeal to Religious Voters
description: ORANGEBURG, S.C.  About 15 minutes into his stump speech at a barbecue restaurant here on Friday, Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio turned to discuss the glue that keeps us all together.

title: Dreams of Creating a Duplex
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: How to Watch the Republican Debate
description: Join us for our coverage of the Republican debate.

title: At Chromat, a Powerful Cast in Electroluminescent Wares
description: The designer Becca McCharen presented athleticwear, lingerie and dresses  some of which lit up.

title: Taliban, Using Humvees Stolen From Army, Attack Check Post
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In an attack using a tactic long feared by Afghan officials, Taliban suicide bombers riding in two stolen Afghan Army Humvees clashed with security forces on Saturday in southern Helmand Province, killing six security personnel at a checkpoint, Afghan officials said.

title: Even in Impersonations, Donald Trump Likes What He Sees of Himself
description: There is only one Donald J. Trump, and yet as he has continued his campaign for the Republican presidential nomination, there has been a groundswell of would-be Donald Trumps  who are imitating him for laughs.

title: Francis Admonishes Bishops in Mexico to Begin Anew
description: MEXICO CITY  In a stinging rebuke to Mexicos church hierarchy, Pope Francis on Saturday told bishops that they had lost their way in gossip and intrigue, and challenged them to begin anew and tend to the churchs worshipers.

title: After Stormy Royal Caribbean Cruise, Seeking Answers
description: Royal Caribbeans Anthem of the Seas vessel returned earlier than scheduled to its port of origin, Cape Liberty, N.J., on Wednesday evening after facing 120 m.p.h. winds on Sunday off Cape Hatteras, N.C. The cruise ship departed last Saturday and was on its way to a port call in Port Canaveral, Fla., as part of a seven-day trip to the Bahamas when it ran into the storm.

title: Your Daily Fashion Week Recap for Saturday, Feb. 13
description: 1. The Chromat show was lit  in the truest sense, with certain garments incorporating wirelessly triggered lights. Its all body-based, said the designer Becca McCharen of her fall/winter 2016 collection. Were definitely interested in presenting the body in new juxtapositions. For sportswear, dresses and underpinnings, she took inspiration from conceptual artists like Dan Flavin and Robert Irwin. See more scenes from Fridays shows.

title: Rihannas First Collection for Puma
description: Photos from the show.

title: Roots of the Recent Violence Between Israelis and Palestinians
description: The geography of the issues surrounding the ongoing violence.

title: Fired for Cursing on the Job, Testing the Limits of Labor Law
description: Little did the managers of a Hooters restaurant realize that a bikini contest they sponsored in 2013 would end up testing the limits of labor law.

title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Solving a Puns and Anagrams puzzle feels, to me at least, kind of like cheating on a diet after a full week of eating only healthy food. Its not that the daily crosswords arent fun, because they are. But PandAs feel more like the doughnuts of the puzzle world. Theyre light, theyre entertaining and they sometimes have a sugary glaze and sprinkles on top. [Just  no.  Ed.]

title: Rihanna on Her New See-Through, Stiletto-Heeled Puma Collection: I Tried to Push the Envelope a Little Bit
description: Im on cloud nine, said Rihanna, the pop star turned brand ambassador and womens creative director of Puma, after her first fashion show for the label. An hour earlier, her first full collection, a street-inspired, Japanophile departure from Pumas usual sport-ready performance wear, had come down an L.E.D. runway to a crowd that included Naomi Campbell, Chris Rock, Travis Scott, Foxy Brown and Young Thug.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A Tired View Of Newton And His Role

title: Small Gifts to Bernie Sanders Challenge Hillary Clinton Fund-Raising Model
description: In the back of a Concord, N.H., school gymnasium, as Bernie Sanders gave a triumphant speech after winning the New Hampshire Democratic primary, Kenneth Pennington stood staring at his smartphone, watching the numbers climb. Mr. Pennington, 24, the campaigns digital director, saw thousands of people cramming onto the Sanders website at once, frantically trying to donate to his campaign. In one minute alone, 2,689 people had donated an average of $34.

title: Rihanna Brings Smoke, Mirrors and Transparent Tops to Wall Street For Her First Puma Collection
description: Trees, stark and faux in black and white, grew out of the floor and into a ceiling tiled with mirrors. At 23 Wall Street, the former House of Morgan had been converted into a forest from a digital-age fever dream  the Black Forest, one might almost say, since the stage had been set by Puma, the German sportswear behemoth, for the showing of its new collection designed by the pop idol Rihanna.

title: Dividends, Wall Streets Battered Status Symbol
description: Coca-Cola pays steady dividends. It has done so since 1920. In fact, it has increased dividends in each of the last 50 years.

title: Mark Dunkerley: Where You Can See Airplanes and the Aloha Spirit
description: 1. Project runway

title: Henry Kissinger: Sage or Pariah?
A Monthly Gift That Keeps on Not Giving
description: The Haggler does not go camping, nor does he hike. He should probably claim that he is too busy protecting consumers to engage in an activity as frivolous as tromping through the woods and gaping at trees. But it is simpler than that. He doesnt like the woods. He figures that his ancestors spent a lot of time in the woods wishing that they lived somewhere else. Like a city.

title: AT&Ts Strategy Is One Part Innovation, One Part Inspiration
description: SAN FRANCISCO  AT&T is pulling out the stops to persuade people about futuristic plans for its network  and itself. Sometimes that means pushing new technology, and sometimes it means that executives show a little vulnerability, something rare in corporate America.

title: Catholic Leaders Say Zika Doesnt Change Ban on Contraception
description: As the Zika virus spreads in Latin America, Catholic leaders are warning women against using contraceptives or having abortions, even as health officials in some countries are advising women not to get pregnant because of the risk of birth defects.

title: The Commute of the Future? Ford Is Working on It
description: On a brisk October day in Chicago, a few employees from the design firm Ideo left their office and headed to Knife & Tine, a restaurant about four miles away. The goal, besides lunch, was to complete the journey within 45 minutes, on a budget of just $10 for the whole group, all while carrying bulky shopping bags.

title: Rebecca Minkoff: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Ms. Minkoff, the latest to adapt to the see now buy now experiment, presents her latest looks.

title: At Rally in Rivals Home State, Donald Trump Boasts of Florida Jobs Record
description: TAMPA, Fla.  With Floridas March 15 primary looming, Donald J. Trump drew another of his massive crowds Friday night in Tampa, where he boasted of his rsum as a developer and job creator in Florida.

title: Scenes From Last Nights Dazed x Calvin Klein Party
description: Last night, as polar gusts persisted outside, the Calvin Klein and Dazed party  a celebration for the magazines 100 pop culture disruptors  raged in Bushwick. Inside, projectors bathed two rooms in gray (one wall showed a triptych of black and white video footage featuring the Dazed 100 recipients; on another, their names flashed at a spastic clip).

title: Inside the Dazed and Calvin Klein Party
description: Revelers braved harsh temperatures to attend the fashion week party in Bushwick.

title: War, Disease and Scandals Test Soccer Chief in Sierra Leone
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone  For the last two and a half years, Isha Johansen has been throwing punches, both real and metaphorical, as the president of Sierra Leones soccer association, one of just a handful of women in the world to have ever held such a post.

title: What to Look For in the Republican Debate
description: Join us for our coverage of the Republican debate.

title: Suno: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Max Osterweis and Erin Beatty, the finalists in the 2012 Vogue/CFDA fund, present their fall designs.

title: Facing Allies Doubt, John Kerry Voices Confidence in Syria Cease-Fire
description: MUNICH  Secretary of State John Kerry, facing both anger and skepticism from European allies about the willingness of the United States to intervene more deeply in the Syrian civil war, promised on Saturday to help close off the routes migrants were taking to Europe and warned Russia that its military effort to prop up President Bashar al-Assad of Syria would ultimately fail.

title: Jets Will No Longer Get a Free Ride on Carbon Emissions
description: It has been almost 50 years since the federal government began setting standards for automobile emissions. It is also about a half-century since the introduction of wide-body jets set off a runaway expansion of the aviation industry. About 3.8 billion people are expected to fly this year, 50 times as many as 50 years ago  making planes the fastest-growing source of carbon dioxide emissions, although they have faced none of the limits set on cars or trucks. That is, until last week, when the International Civil Aviation Organization, a United Nations agency, finally proposed the first binding limits on aircraft emissions.

title: The Orphaned 90s
description: IN one theory of Hillary Clintons candidacy, before political reality intruded, she was going to have the best of two worlds.

title: How We View Obesity
description: Readers discuss Americans obsession with weight and prejudices against fat people.

title: Narcissism Is Increasing. So Youre Not So Special.
description: MY teenage son recently informed me that there is an Internet quiz to test oneself for narcissism. His friend had just taken it. How did it turn out? I asked. He says he did great! my son responded. He got the maximum score!

title: When Hillary Clinton Killed Feminism
description: WASHINGTON  THE Clinton campaign is shellshocked over the wholesale rejection of Hillary by young women, younger versions of herself who do not relate to her.

title: Are You a Toxic Waste Disposal Site?
description: EVEN if youre not in Flint, Mich., there are toxic chemicals in your home. For that matter, in you.

title: Fixing Our Broken Water Systems
description: Underneath Americas streets lies a network of pipes that is supposed to bring clean water into homes, schools and businesses. But the news of lead poisoning in Flint, Mich., and the emergence of similar problems in Sebring, Ohio, and other cities have revealed a shocking truth: Some of these systems are so old and poorly maintained that they have become a major hazard to human health.

title: Time to Take North Korea Seriously
description: Since the first of the year, North Korea has conducted another nuclear weapons test and launched a satellite on a rocket. Both acts further advance North Koreas quest to acquire the ability to fire a nuclear-armed missile against another country, while serving as a reminder of the worlds lamentable failure to shut the program down.

title: Bill Cunningham | The Look
description: Theres an exhilaration to the opening of an international fashion season. The designer with the highest antennae will create, through clothes, the mirror image of our time. A look that defines a generation usually takes seven years to become visible. The rare exception: Christian Diors 1947 New Look, which arrived like a thunderclap. Shown here is the look that defined 2015: ankle boots, a long stretch of leg, a flowerlike blossom top and a fur pompom at the peak of knitted hats. Outside of this uniform, there were straws in the wind, above. Will shaping return to fashion through a cinched waist, a sculpted coat, a flared skirt? Or will it be an inflated silhouette, where the air between the cloth and the wearer creates the silhouette?

title: Death, the Prosperity Gospel and Me
description: Durham, N.C.  ON a Thursday morning a few months ago, I got a call from my doctors assistant telling me that I have Stage 4 cancer. The stomach cramps I was suffering from were not caused by a faulty gallbladder, but by a massive tumor.

title: Can Health Care Providers Afford to Be Ready for Disaster?
description: MORE than 200 people died in hospitals and nursing homes in Louisiana after Hurricane Katrina in 2005, leading to widespread agreement that health care preparedness in the United States needed dramatic improvement. One hospital, Memorial Medical Center, was so undone that two desperate doctors later said that they hastened the deaths of patients who had waited days in the heat for rescue.

title: Amid Tension, Met and James Levine Mull Last Bow
description: The question of when and how to say farewell to a leader is one that bedevils all kinds of institutions, from Viacom, where the aging chairman Sumner M. Redstone recently stepped down under pressure, to the Denver Broncos, who will soon have to decide whether to ease out their quarterback, Peyton Manning, if he does not retire willingly.

title: Not Their Mothers Candidate
description: If, as weve all now heard, theres a special place in hell for women who dont help each other, then a room on the Upper East Side of Manhattan has long been a piece of feminist heaven. Its the room that Gloria Steinem provided for years in her apartment as a residence for young women she mentored and encouraged and learned from.

title: Nikki Silva
description: Nikki Silva is one half of the Peabody Award-winning Kitchen Sisters, creators of documentary-style programming for public radio and for podcasts.

title: How New York Made Pre-K a Success
description: BORSCHT isnt found on most prekindergarten menus, but its what the cooks were dishing up for the 35 children at Iras Daycare in Briarwood, Queens, on a recent school day. Many families in this neighborhood are Russian migrs for whom borscht is a staple, but children from half a dozen countries, including a contingent from Bangladesh, are also enrolled here.

title: The Love Story Primary
description: MY mom, Fran, is wise and warm and helpful in many ways, but shes never been great at dispensing pithy nuggets of life wisdom. One year, for a Mothers Day feature, a magazine editor asked me to tell her the best piece of advice my mother ever gave me. All I could come up with was, Dont pick it.

title: At U.S. Olympic Trials, Two Marathoners Use Teamwork to Become Teammates
description: LOS ANGELES  At the United States Olympic marathon trials on Saturday, the runners confirmed that women are far stronger when they stay in formation.

title: Britain Aims to Strengthen Norths Cities
description: LIVERPOOL, England  London churns out so much wealth that its annual economic output is equal to Saudi Arabias. No other city in Britain comes close.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Hillary Clinton Emails Released by State Department
description: Three emails released by the State Department from Hillary Clintons private account were now considered secret, the governments second-highest classification.

title: More Hillary Clinton Emails Released, Including 3 Now Secret
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department released 551 more emails from the personal server of Hillary Clinton on Saturday, including 84 with some or all of the messages blocked out because they contained information that has now been deemed classified. Three of those are classified secret.

title: Tibi: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Amy Smilovics presents her fall collection.

title: Mets Jenrry Mejia Is Said to Deny Doping Claims
description: Each time Mets pitcher Jenrry Mejia has tested positive for performance-enhancing drugs, he has declined to discuss the results or has maintained his innocence. Even after his third failed test in less than a year, which was announced Friday and resulted in a lifetime ban from Major League Baseball, Mejia appears to be sticking to the message that he has not used P.E.D.s.

title: Bernie Sanders Tells Volunteers in Reno to Expect Victory in Nevada
description: RENO, Nev.  Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont told hundreds of volunteers gathered here on Saturday that his strong showings in Iowa and New Hampshire were not flukes.

title: Man Arrested in Fatal Stabbing of Staten Island Woman and Her 2 Daughters
description: The suspect wanted in the stabbing at a Staten Island motel that left a homeless woman and two of her daughters dead was arrested and charged with murder on Saturday, the police said.

title: Antonin Scalia, Justice on the Supreme Court, Dies at 79
description: Justice Antonin Scalia, whose transformative legal theories, vivid writing and outsize personality made him a leader of a conservative intellectual renaissance in his three decades on the Supreme Court, was found dead on Saturday at a resort in West Texas. He was 79.

title: New Study Finds Persistent Peril from Urban Coal Soot in China and Indoor Smoke in India
description: The latest report on the global burden of disease finds air pollution caused the premature deaths of 5.5 million people in 2013, with China just ahead of India in deaths and the two countries together accounting for more than half the global total. The findings were released Friday by scientists at the University of British Columbia and discussed today at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, in Washington.

title: Caught Between Costly Alternatives, Ferguson Residents Worry About Its Fate
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  When the City Council took the defiant gamble last week of challenging parts of an agreement it had negotiated with the federal government to overhaul its Police Department and courts, it argued that the costs of the deal would drive the city into bankruptcy.

title: The Death of Justice Scalia: Reactions and Analysis
All You Need
description: Nothing you can know that isnt knownNothing you can see that isnt shownNowhere you can be that isnt where youre meant to beIts easy   The Beatles, All You Need Is Love

title: A Tour of Rwanda, From Jungle to City
description: Rwanda, Jungle to City Gondwana Ecotours, founded by Jared Sternberg in 2013 when he was a law student at Tulane, has added Rwanda to its list of destinations. A highlight of the eight-day tour, departing from Kigali, is a trek into the jungle to view mountain gorillas, who live in a tropical rain forest in the Virunga Mountains. Guests also will have the chance to track chimpanzee and golden monkeys with a conservationist.

title: Russian Orthodox Church Blocks Funeral for Last of Romanov Remains
description: MOSCOW  Ever since the remains of the last czar, Nicholas II, and most of his family were exhumed 25 years ago from a dirt road in the Urals, investigators, historians and surviving members of the Romanov dynasty have anticipated the day when all the murdered royals would be laid to rest.

title: Erykah Badus Styling Debut
description: The R&B singer worked closely with the designer Kerby Jean-Raymond on his label Pyer Mosss fall/winter show, which was presented this afternoon.

title: At Pyer Moss, Erykah Badu Makes Her Styling Debut
description: For over a year, the mens wear designer Kerby Jean-Raymond, of Pyer Moss, had his sights set on collaborating with the R&B singer Erykah Badu. She and Jean-Raymond eventually met through a mutual friend and embarked on a partnership that would mark a first for Badu: her styling debut. And this morning, when Badu arrived at his studio  wearing platform Teva sandals, an oversize denim tunic and a black chauffeur hat embellished with handmade pins reading Acid and LSD  she greeted Jean-Raymond like an old friend.

title: Jordan Struggles Under a Wave of Syrian Refugees
description: AMMAN, Jordan  King Abdullah II made his people an extraordinary promise last week: For every job the government offered Syrian refugees, it would create five jobs for Jordanians.

description: NEW DELHI  The police have arrested the president of a student union here on a complaint of sedition, a news agency reported, the latest controversy to hit one of the countrys highly politicized universities.
