description: Mitch McConnell, Feb. 13, 2016:The American people should have a voice in the selection of their next Supreme Court justice. Therefore, this vacancy should not be filled until we have a new president.

title: By Phone, James Dobson Tells South Carolinians Ted Cruz Is Only Alternative to Donald Trump
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  In a recorded phone message made to South Carolina voters on Sunday night, James C. Dobson, the evangelical leader, called on Republicans to support Senator Ted Cruz for president as the only real alternative to Donald J. Trump.

title: A New Culprit in Lyme Disease
description: Mosquitoes may be receiving all the attention amid the Zika virus epidemic, but they are hardly the only disease vectors to worry about. Researchers at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., have discovered a new species of tick-borne bacteria that causes Lyme disease.

title: 40 Trillion Bacteria on and in Us? Fewer Than We Thought.
description: There are a lot of bacteria on us and in us  our microbiome, it is called. Calculating exactly how many microbes each of us carries is hard, and the most common number cited, both in popular and scientific literature, is almost certainly wrong.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Sies Marjan, New York Fashion Weeks Most Buzzed-About Debut, Turns Its Back on Black
description: It takes a certain amount of lan to make a goatskin coat, a double duchesse satin blouse, capri-length cargo pants and stamped-croc slip-ons in a yellow so bright it could make the sun blush.

title: Emmy Rossum is So Happy to Be Home, Despite the Dirt Floor
description: It was snowing Monday morning, but inside the Frick, where Carolina Herrera presented her fall 2016 collection that morning, a flurry of starlets were sporting barely-there clothes for far warmer climes. Emmy Rossum, for one, wore a sleeveless floral-print tea dress in pale pink from Mrs. Herreras spring 2016 collection, and answered some questions.

title: Cornells Plan to Merge Hotel School Gets an Icy Reception
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  They call themselves hotelies: students and alumni of the Cornell University School of Hotel Administration, the worlds oldest undergraduate program devoted to the hospitality industry and, many say, the best.

title: A Doubters Almanac, Ethan Canins Latest Novel, Has Real-Life Parallels
description: Ethan Canin was shopping at a grocery store in Iowa City recently, when he paused to marvel at a neatly stacked pyramid of oranges. To Mr. Canin, the pile of fruit perfectly illustrated the Kepler conjecture, a 17th-century mathematical premise about the most efficient way to stack spherical objects. Mathematicians have wrestled with the conjecture for centuries, but the store clerk had solved the problem intuitively.

title: Getting People to Exercise Requires the Right Incentive
description: People will exercise more if you give them money  but only if they are paid in the right way.

title: Yolanda Foster: Watching Her Daughter Gigi Hadid From the Front Row
description: Yolanda Foster, the mother of Gigi Hadid and a former model herself, was at the Park Avenue Armory on Monday, watching from the front row as her daughter walked in the Tommy Hilfiger show.

title: The Daily Jewel: Tommy Hilfiger
description: Tommy Hilfigers paste and pearl drop earrings look as precious as a family heirloom  but are a whole lot more fun.  MALINA JOSEPH GILCHRIST

title: North Korea Leader Should Be Told He Could Face Trial, U.N. Official Says
description: GENEVA  A United Nations human rights investigator said in a report released Monday that the organization should officially notify North Koreas top leader, Kim Jong-un, that he and subordinates could face trial for heinous crimes. The investigator also recommended the creation of an expert panel to identify ways of prosecuting them.

title: Steven Stucky, Composer Who Won a Pulitzer, Dies at 66
description: Steven Stucky, a Pulitzer Prize-winning American composer whose work was widely commissioned by major orchestras around the world and who earned respect as a conductor, teacher and author, died on Sunday at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 66.

title: Review: Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zanes Body Against Body, Through a Fresh Lens
description: Isnt it true, a woman seated behind me asked after a performance by the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, that the definition of dance is moving to music? Thats a question youre unlikely to hear at New York Live Arts, where the Jones/Zane troupe has its home, but the company was on tour  at Queens Theater, in Corona  a destination easily reached from Manhattan and yet distant enough from downtown to shift your perspective on Body Against Body, a program of duets created 20 to 30 years ago.

title: Champions League Returns With Teams Shifting Priorities Up a Notch
description: Paris St.-Germain has played 38 games in various competitions this season. But its current campaign shifts into a new stage  some would argue its most important stage  with the start of the Champions League knockout rounds on Tuesday.

title: Review: Art and Nature Blend in a Concert by Contemporaneous
description: A bitter wind off the harbor on Thursday evening kept making creaking and popping sounds emerge from the garage door that defines one wall of Pioneer Works, the Red Hook, Brooklyn, warehouse converted into a sprawling art space in 2012.

title: Unusual Molecules Shine Light on New Applications
description: Ben Zhong Tang was stumped. A chemist at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, he was looking at a powder that glowed bright green under ultraviolet light. But when the powder was dissolved in a clear solution, the glow disappeared.

title: Recalling Scalia, a Literary Stylist Who Scorned Jiggery-Pokery
description: The legal opinions of Justice Antonin Scalia, who died on Saturday after nearly 30 years on the Supreme Court, have long received attention as much for their elegant, learned and often scathing style as for their staunchly conservative substance.

title: Review: In Funny Girl, Sheridan Smith Does the Heavy Lifting
description: LONDON  When youre gifted, then youre gifted, sings Fanny Brice in the hit revival of Funny Girl, currently enjoying a sold-out run at the small but mighty Menier Chocolate Factory before transferring to the West End in April. Since Fanny is portrayed by Sheridan Smith in Michael Mayers dutiful production of this 1964 biomusical, no one is likely to challenge such a self-assessment.

title: Review: Maxwells Sensual R&B Makes a Big Room Intimate
description: From the stage of Barclays Center on Sunday night  Valentines Day  Maxwell urged, I want all of the couples who came tonight to procreate this evening, answered by cheers and laughter. Seven years after releasing his latest album and five years after his previous New York City concert, Maxwell was ready to resume his career as one of R&Bs most elegant accessories to seduction.

title: Embrace of the Serpent, Ciro Guerras Searching Tale About Invaded Amazon Cultures
description: BOGOT, Colombia  In 1979 the German director Werner Herzog set out into the Peruvian Amazon to begin filming Fitzcarraldo, the quixotic tale of an Irish rubber barons quest to build an opera house in the jungle.

title: Jeremy Scott: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Mr. Scotts latest collection.

title: Shoppers Recall Their First Barneys Purchases
description: As Barneys returns to its downtown Manhattan roots, notable shoppers reminisce about their first big purchase at the store.

title: Off the Runway: Feb. 15
description: Scenes from the fifth day of New York Fashion Week.

title: Slide Show: Grammys Red Carpet
description: The looks  and the stars who wore them  from the music industrys big night.

title: Review: The Right Kind of Crazy, on the Team That Landed the Mars Rover Curiosity
description: When the Mars rover Curiosity stuck its landing on the red planet on Aug. 6, 2012, it not only opened a new era of space exploration and a bright new door to NASAs future, but it also signified a triumph of human ingenuity over staggering odds.

title: Romee Strijd Transforms at Jeremy Scott
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in New York.

title: Low Oil Prices Claim New Victim, an Offshore Drilling Company From Texas
description: Yet another oil company has filed for bankruptcy, as the energy industry and its lenders brace for a prolonged slump.

title: Grammy Winners 2016
description: Read our full report on the Grammys | A critics notebook on the show

title: No Mention of Birther Debate as Donald Trump Woos Blacks in South Carolina
description: Donald J. Trump, looking to amass as many votes as possible in the South Carolina primary, is increasingly trying to appeal to the states black voters. In doing so, he appears to hope that any memory of his 2011 demand to see the birth certificate of the nations first black president is a distant one.

title: The Row: Fall 2016 RTW
description: The Olsen twins are back in New York to present their latest fall collection.

title: 3.1 Phillip Lim: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Mr. Lim who just celebrated his 10th anniversary, presents his fall collection.

title: Slide Show: Grammys Red Carpet
description: Check out some of the shows most glittering outfits, including many that will be cited by the fashion police in the days to come.

title: Bernie Sanders Meets With Residents of Flint Before Campaign Rally in Michigan
description: YPSILANTI, Mich.  Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont held a boisterous campaign event at Eastern Michigan University here on Monday with about 9,400 supporters cheering along to his hour-long speech.

title: Rush Limbaugh Sees Strategy Behind Donald Trumps They Lied Claim
description: As Donald J. Trump on Monday avoided repeating his recent debate claim that the George W. Bush administration had lied in the buildup to the invasion of Iraq in 2003, the conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh said that Mr. Trump had used the language of Democrats to attack the former president.

title: Review: Vox Luminis Explores Bachs Family Tree
description: That Bach came from hardy compositional stock is well known. But the actual music of his forebears remains obscure.

title: Police Investigating Claim Eliot Spitzer Choked Woman in Plaza Hotel
description: Eliot Spitzer, who resigned as governor of New York in 2008 amid reports that he was a client of a high-priced prostitution ring, is now at the center of a new criminal investigation, according to officials, after a 26-year-old woman said he choked her when they were alone in a room at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Group Backing Ted Cruz Makes $573,000 Ad Buy in Nevada
description: The most prominent super PAC supporting Ted Cruz said on Monday that it was placing a $573,000 ad buy in Nevada and boosting its field operations in the state.

title: Review: In Drunken With What, a Streamlined Mourning Becomes Electra
description: Eugene ONeill had some difficulty settling on a form and a style for the trilogy of plays that would constitute Mourning Becomes Electra, his 1931 adaptation of Aeschylus The Oresteia. He tried verse, he tried masks; he tried abandoning the play entirely and writing a life of Aeschylus instead. The script ultimately blended Greek tragedy with Yankee mythos, Freudian theory with melodrama. Hailed as a masterpiece in its day, it is a lot less popular now.

title: R.N.C. Disputes Donald Trumps Claim on Debate Being Stacked With Donors
description: The Republican National Committee is pushing back against Donald J. Trumps claim that the jeers that serenaded him during the presidential debate on Saturday were from an audience stacked with big money donors.

title: In Supreme Court Vacancy, Ted Cruz Senses an Opening
description: AIKEN, S.C.  A conservative titan. A judicial morass. A Senate showdown with President Obama.

title: U.S. Closing a Loophole on Products Tied to Slaves
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will sign legislation this week that effectively bans American imports of fish caught by forced labor in Southeast Asia, part of a flurry of recent actions by the White House, federal agencies, international trade unions and foreign governments to address lawlessness at sea and to better protect offshore workers and the marine environment.

title: What Planners of Brooklyn-Queens Streetcar Line Can Learn in New Jersey
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  With Mayor Bill de Blasio proposing a streetcar line from Brooklyn to Queens, city planners do not have to search far for an example of a similar system to help guide them.

title: Yemen: Embattled City at Risk of Famine, United Nations Warns
description: Residents of Taiz, a city that has come under siege in the nearly year-old Yemen conflict, are one step away from famine because combatants have prevented aid groups from delivering emergency supplies, the United Nations said on Monday. The World Food Program, the organizations anti-hunger agency, said it had managed to send some aid into Taiz over the weekend, but described the shipment as a one-off delivery that would feed only 3,000 families for a month. Taiz residents are now among roughly 7.6 million people in Yemen who are classified as severely food insecure  a condition in the five-point Integrated Food Security Phase Classification scale just above famine level.

title: Bahrain: 4 Journalists Detained
description: Press freedom advocates protested to Bahrain on Monday over the arrest of four American journalists who had been reporting on the fifth anniversary of the political opposition uprising in the Gulf monarchy, an ally of the United States. The Bahrain authorities, who seized the four on Sunday, did not identify them by name, but the family of one identified her as Anna Therese Day, a freelance journalist and Fulbright Fellow who has reported for The Huffington Post and other media outlets. The Bahrain police website said the four were suspected of having entered Bahrain illegally and participating in an unlawful gathering. The Committee to Protect Journalists in New York called for their immediate release.

title: Israel: Ex-Prime Minister Begins Prison Term for Bribery Conviction
description: Describing his fall as painful and strange, Ehud Olmert became on Monday the first former Israeli prime minister to enter prison, beginning a 19-month term for bribery and obstruction of justice. In a video released by his office shortly before the armored car carrying him swept through the prison gates, Mr. Olmert, 70, who was convicted in 2014, acknowledged that he had made mistakes, but he insisted that he had done nothing criminal. Looking somber and fatigued, Mr. Olmert remarked: I accept the sentence with a very heavy heart. Nobody stands above the law.

title: Lincoln Memorial to Get Major Renovation
description: WASHINGTON  The Lincoln Memorial will undergo some of its most extensive renovations to date, the National Park Service said on Monday, including efforts to wash away dirt and debris, repair damage sustained during a 2011 earthquake, and build a substantial space for educational programs under the memorial.

title: Zero + Maria Cornejo: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Ms. Cornejos latest looks.

title: Thom Browne: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Mr. Browne presents his latest designs.

title: Leo Van Munching Jr., Empire Builder for Heineken, Dies at 89
description: Leo Van Munching Jr., whose stewardship of the importing company started by his father made the Dutch-brewed beer Heineken and its low-calorie sibling, Amstel Light, familiar brand names in the United States, died on Sunday at his home in Darien, Conn. He was 89.

title: An Asia Summit Meeting Is Overshadowed by Scalia
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  President Obama welcomed the leaders of 10 Southeast Asian countries to this desert oasis for a summit meeting on Monday, giving him another chance to shine a spotlight on one of his most ambitious geopolitical projects: the pivot to Asia.

title: In Queens, Broadcasting Banter From a Bar in a Garage
description: It was Friday night again, and the men trickled in  Brian, Ryan, Pat and Tommy  and joined their friend John at a bar lined with ashtrays, shot glasses and bottles of Irish whiskey.

title: At Mass, Pope Francis Embraces Misunderstood of Mexico
description: SAN CRISTBAL DE LAS CASAS, Mexico  Pope Francis came to the highlands of Mexicos southern frontier on Monday to offer a pastoral embrace to the regions impoverished indigenous people, expressing shame over discrimination and exploitation and honoring the legacy of a beloved local bishop who once clashed with the Mexican government  and the Vatican.

title: Saying Farewell to David Frei, Westminsters Nuzzling Voice
description: David Freis voice has become as familiar as the woof of a beloved family pet during his 26 years as the lead commentator of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. Clad in a tuxedo, he re-enters the lives of dog enthusiasts each February for two nights of prime-time canine analysis and storytelling.

title: The X-Files Season 10, Episode 5: Mulders Magic Mushrooms
description: The X-Files took inspiration from a variety of sources this week in a slow-starting episode that ended up being quite enjoyable and ultimately a little heartbreaking. We saw Mulder dancing shirtless and communicating with the near dead and Scully mentoring a younger agent who bore more than a passing resemblance to Mulder.

title: A Crisis Every Day for the Mayor Trying to Rescue Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Even a short list of the troubles that have befallen this fading seaside resort since Donald Guardian was elected mayor would make anyone wonder why he got himself into this mess.

title: Kendrick Lamar Sweeps Rap Field at Grammys; Taylor Swift Wins Best Album
description: LOS ANGELES  The 58th annual Grammy Awards on Monday celebrated a young generation of chart-dominating pop stars, with Taylor Swift winning album of the year for 1989 and Kendrick Lamar sweeping the rap categories, even as the show devoted much of its airtime to lionizing musical heroes of decades past.

title: Real Clothes on Real Girls: Diane von Furstenbergs Immersive Experience
description: Real clothes on real girls. That was how Diane von Furstenberg described the idea behind her fall  well, call it an immersive experience: the fashion equivalent of the theatrical trend embodied by Then She Fell and Sleep No More.

title: Jeb Bush, With Assist From George, Goes After Donald Trump
description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  The Bush family, a dynasty that defined Republicanism for decades, clashed on Monday with the new and irreverent face of the party, Donald J. Trump, in one of the most vivid and powerful confrontations in the presidential primary campaign so far.

title: A New Season for the Mets Matt Harvey, but One Pitch Is Hard to Shake Off
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Matt Harvey had a quiet off-season, for the most part. He took some time to rest, attended a bunch of Knicks and Rangers games and began working out at Scott Borass training facility in California, trying to make sure his right arm would be strong and durable as he heads into his second full season following Tommy John surgery.

title: Dispute With New York City Threatens Success Academys Pre-K
description: A critical deadline passed on Monday in a dispute between Success Academy charter schools and the de Blasio administration over the charter school networks prekindergarten program, leaving its fate in doubt.

title: How to Bring the Supreme Court Back Down to Earth
description: Seven of the eight justices on the Supreme Court today all come from the federal appeals courts. (So did Justice Antonin Scalia, who died Saturday.) Only Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, who was a judge in California, served outside the East Coast cities of Boston, New York, Philadelphia and Washington. All eight attended law school at Harvard or Yale. None ever held elected office. Todays court is in some ways the most insulated and homogenous in American history, as Adam Liptak wrote in 2009.

title: Before Scalias Death, a Clash Between G.O.P. and Obama Over Appellate Judges
description: WASHINGTON  The vow by Senate Republicans to block whomever President Obama nominates to fill the sudden vacancy on the Supreme Court presages a prolonged election year struggle, but the clash is less a new front against the White House than an escalation of a battle that had begun at the appeals court level before Justice Antonin Scalia died.

title: No Corrections: February 16, 2016
description: No corrections appeared in print.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: This fight has been fought by both sides for decades.

title: Carved Decoration on a Ships Prow
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Some of you out there are beginning solvers, and I will be talking directly to you today. Those of you who are veteran solvers will no doubt find this fairly easy, but if you are a beginner who is just challenging yourself to push past Monday solving, its helpful to learn how to recognize different types of themes.

title: Organic Meat and Milk Higher in Healthful Fatty Acids
description: Organic meat and milk differ markedly from their conventionally produced counterparts in measures of certain nutrients, a review of scientific studies reported on Tuesday.

title: Zac Posen: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Mr. Posen presents his fall collection.

title: Rag & Bone Menswear: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Mr. Wainwright and Mr. Neville present their latest designs in mens wear.

title: November's Referendum on Justice
Man Waving Gun Is Shot by Officers in the Bronx, Police Say
description: A man who had been seen waving a gun and pointing it at people was shot and wounded by police officers outside a playground in the South Bronx on Monday afternoon, the authorities said.

title: Rag & Bone: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Mr. Wainwright and Mr. Neville who met at a british boarding school, present their latest designs.

title: Better Call Saul Season 2 Premiere: No Seriously, Call Saul
description: The debut episode of Season 2 of Better Call Saul ends with Jimmy McGill warily checking out his swish new office at the Santa Fe law firm of Davis & Main. Near a window, Jimmy finds a light switch with a stern warning: Always leave ON!!! Do NOT turn OFF!

title: Opera Philadelphia Will Mount Breaking the Waves Adaptation
description: Breaking the Waves, a new chamber opera by Missy Mazzoli with a libretto by Royce Vavrek that is based on the psychosexual 1996 Lars von Trier film of the same name, will be given its world premiere in September by Opera Philadelphia, the company announced Tuesday.

title: Borzoi, Bulldog, German Shepherd and Shih Tzu Are Group Winners
description: The first night of judging at the 140th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show produced winners in four groups Monday at Madison Square Garden. A borzoi named Lucy was first among the hounds; Panda, a Shih Tzu, was named the top toy; Annabelle, a serene bulldog, was selected as the best in the nonsporting group; and Rumor, a German shepherd who was the top dog heading into the show, won the herding group.

title: A Good Hair Day, at Least for the Nonhumans
description: It was snowy and windy in Manhattan, but the competitors were perfectly primped for judging at the 140th annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

title: At the Grammys, Big Voices, Pretty Faces and Bitter Truths
description: To belt, to dance, to rap or to mourn? The 58th annual Grammy Awards cycled through those modes on Monday night in its live broadcast from the Staples Center.

title: What to Watch Tuesday
description: No time to read? Catch up on The New Yorker with a new series drawn from its pages. Meanwhile, on American Crime Story, Robert Shapiro assembles the Dream Team. And Gonzaga Universitys mens basketball players hustle toward March Madness.

title: 2016 Grammy Awards
description: At this years biggest music award ceremony, performers were honored, stars paid tribute to legends and artists spoke out about social injustices.

title: A Frequent Flyers Photos of Air Travel
description: For the past ten years, Mindaugas Kavaliauskas has been zipping through airports, traveling extensively to produce photography events. He eventually slowed down, capturing the beauty in moments of familiarity. The following captions for the slideshow were provided by the photographer.

title: E-Commerce: Convenience Built on a Mountain of Cardboard
description: Ruchit Garg, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur, says that he worries that something isnt right with his Internet shopping habit. With each new delivery to his doorstep  sometimes several in a day  he faces the source of his guilt and frustration: another cardboard box.

title: Transgender Patients Face Challenges at the Hospital
description: After a skiing accident in January left him with a smashed knee, Beck Bailey, a transgender man in Greenfield, Mass., spent 15 days in a Vermont hospital undergoing a handful of surgeries. As part of his normal routine, Mr. Bailey gives himself regular shots of testosterone. But the endocrinologist on duty in Vermont told him that patients should not take testosterone post surgery.

title: A Frequent Flyers Photos of Air Travel
description: Mindaugas Kavaliauskas grew up in Lithuania when it was still a part of the Soviet Union and he remembers flying as a teenager to Moscow to see his grandmother in the 1980s. Air travel seemed a matter of privilege, luxury. And now? Well, he has used the word bus more than once.

title: Clemency for Crack Offenses
description: To the Editor:

title: The Roosevelt Approach
description: Dear Hillary, Jeb, Marco and John,

title: Should We Break Up the Big Banks?
description: To the Editor:

title: Visas for Interpreters
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharing Health Data Online
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Poor Water Quality
description: To the Editor:

title: The Chirp Heard Across the Universe
description: The faint chirp detected by what must be two of the largest and most sensitive microphones ever made  a brief, rising tone from gravitational waves generated by an immeasurably powerful collision of two black holes a billion years ago  has engendered a number of articles about why we should concern ourselves, and by extension dedicate so many resources, to exploring an event so distant in time and space. Various justifications have been offered, from lists of the practical benefits of past discoveries that seemed useless when they were made, to the metaphysical notion that the better we understand our universe, the better we understand ourselves.

title: In Election Years, a History of Confirming Court Nominees
description: MEMPHIS  THE American people should have a voice in the selection of their next Supreme Court justice, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican majority leader, announced after news of Justice Antonin Scalias death. Therefore, this vacancy should not be filled until we have a new president. Many of the Republican presidential contenders have heartily endorsed this argument.

title: How the Coal Industry Flattened the Mountains of Appalachia
description: As the destructive coal mining process known as mountaintop removal ebbs in Appalachia, it is leaving behind what amounts to its own grim field of tombstones: A grossly disfigured landscape pocked with decapitated mountains standing flat as mesas and inhospitable to forest restoration.

title: Let Ohio Vote First
description: We, as voters and election-obsessed bystanders, made it past the first two contests in this eons-long presidential primary, but seven candidates werent so lucky.

title: A College Education for Prisoners
description: States are finally backing away from the draconian sentencing policies that swept the country at the end of the last century, driving up prison costs and sending too many people to jail for too long, often for nonviolent offenses. Many are now trying to turn around the prison juggernaut by steering drug addicts into treatment instead of jail and retooling parole systems that once sent people back to prison for technical violations.

title: A Hidden Cost to Giving Kids Their Vegetables
description: WHY do poor children have poor diets?

title: Medicines to Keep Addiction Away
description: Second of two articles

title: Denise Matthews, Pop Singer Known as Vanity, Dies at 57
description: Denise Matthews, the singer, model and actress known as Vanity, who toured with Prince in the 1980s before eschewing her wild persona for life as a minister, died on Monday in Fremont, Calif. She was 57.

title: John Slaney Has a New Shot at Glory, 25 Years After His Moment
description: The calls came to John Slaney for more than two decades, typically right before Christmas. Canadian sports media outlets would request interviews, asking Slaney to wax nostalgic about what remains the highlight of his hockey career: his dramatic goal against the Soviet Union on Jan. 4, 1991, which earned Canada a gold medal at the world junior hockey championships.

title: New York Schools Wonder: How White Is Too White?
description: How white is too white? At the Academy of Arts and Letters, a small K-8 school in Brooklyn founded in 2006 to educate a community of diverse individuals, that question is being put to the test.

title: How a Reporters Quest for Online Bargains Led to a Network of Syrian Contacts
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  As the Syrian war erupted in 2011, Hwaida Saad, a Lebanese journalist in The New York Timess Beirut bureau, rummaged through her contacts, looking for phone numbers.

title: Fashion Week: Eveningwear, With a Chance of Showers
description: Dont rain on my parade? Dont ask for the impossible. The forecast for today calls for two things: Showers and runway shows. Skip the suede boots and pack the umbrellas. Through inclement weather, New York Fashion Week soldiers on.

title: Your Tuesday Morning Briefing.
description: Heres what you need to know to start your day.

title: Morning Agenda: Stock Markets Spring Back
description: STOCK MARKETS SPRING BACK | Asian and European stocks extended their gains on Tuesday, bouncing back from last weeks rout, Reuters reports.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Antonin Scalia, George W. Bush, Grammy Awards
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Celebrity Stylist Lindsey Dupuis Shows Her Southern Style
description: Name Lindsey Dupuis

title: Why Poland Needs American Support
description: WARSAW  SITTING next to Barack Obama at a luncheon during the United Nations General Assembly session in 2009, President Lech Kaczynski of Poland gave his counterpart a copy of The Peasant Prince, a biography of Thaddeus Kosciuszko, the Polish military commander who joined George Washingtons army in 1776 and drew up the strategy for the Battles of Saratoga, the turning point of the American Revolution.

title: Democrats See Chance to Bolster Enthusiasm in G.O.P. Pledge to Block Scalia Replacement
description: Republican senators who are thought most susceptible to a political backlash for blocking any new Supreme Court nominee appear to be shaking off concern and joining the call to wait for the next president to fill the vacancy caused by Antonin Scalias death. And that is just fine with some Democrats.

title: New York Today: The Great Indoors
description: Updated, 7:43 a.m.

title: Review: Premiere of Wheeldons Strapless at the Royal Ballet
description: LONDON  A new ballet by the British choreographer Christopher Wheeldon is an event, and one with a score by Mark Anthony Turnage (Anna Nicole) even more so. On Friday night, the great and the good had turned out at the Royal Opera House here to see the premiere of Strapless, part of a Royal Ballet all-Wheeldon bill that included After the Rain, created for New York City Ballet in 2005, and Within the Golden Hour ( San Francisco Ballet, 2008).

title: Bernie Sanders, Seeking to Court Black Voters, Will Visit South Carolina and Georgia
description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont will head south on Tuesday to court voters in South Carolina, where a recent poll shows him trailing Hillary Clinton, and to host a rally in Georgia as part of his campaigns tour of black colleges and universities.

title: Fat Cats on a Diet: Will They Still Love You?
description: Maya has had a tough time slimming down. After 16 months of dieting, shes dropped 10 pounds and 6 ounces.

title: Belgian Police Charge 3 in Investigation of ISIS Network
description: PARIS  The Belgian police raided nine homes and arrested 10 people in Brussels as part of an investigation into an Islamic State recruitment network, a spokesman for the federal prosecutors office said on Tuesday.

title: A Fight in the Trenches, From South Carolina to Nevada
description: As the race for the South Carolina Republican primary winds down to the final five days, it has become a fight for the soul of the party  between Donald J. Trump and the partys last president, George W. Bush. The fight for votes, however, is between Mr. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, with Jeb Bush, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio right behind them.

title: Republicans and Hispanics: The Extent of the Damage Done
description: The Republican Party has ended up someplace where many of its leaders didnt want it to be  divided about how much it cares about Hispanic voters.

title: The Quietly Subversive Fictions of Dana Spiotta
description: When Dana Spiotta was working on her fourth novel, Innocents and Others, she sat beneath a huge bulletin board pinned with her sticky notes and research materials: lists of relevant words (passion, transformation, intimacy) and seeing devices (zoetrope, stereoscope, camera obscura), and photographs of Orson Welles, Jean-Luc Godard and the Maysles brothers. Its like walking into the book, Spiotta told me. You feel it all around you.

title: Xinjiang Region of China Bans Glacier Tourism, Citing Risk to Ecosystem
description: BEIJING  Glaciologists in China and elsewhere have said for years that climate change is the main cause of glacier erosion, which threatens the water sources of much of humanity.

title: Israeli Officers Briefly Detain Two Journalists
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli authorities issued statements of regret on Tuesday after police officers briefly detained The Washington Posts bureau chief in Jerusalem and a colleague while they were conducting interviews at the Damascus Gate into the Old City, a site of frequent attacks by Palestinians against Israeli Jews in recent months.

title: At the Grammys, a Muted Night for Fashion
description: Maybe designers just hit overload. Maybe with the current fashion season, the coming Oscars and the British Academy of Film and Television Arts awards last Sunday, they just thought: We cant handle another awards show. Maybe the musicians attending thought: Enough with the fashion credits; we want the focus to be on us and our art. Leave the crazy clothes to the MTV Video Music Awards; make this about the music.

title: Chinese Writer Says Hes Forbidden From Traveling to U.S. for Harvard Prize
description: HONG KONG  The author of a landmark book documenting the millions of deaths from Chinas Great Famine said on Tuesday that his former employer, the official Xinhua News Agency, had forbidden him from traveling to Harvard University next month to receive an award honoring his courage and integrity.

title: Oil Output Freeze Has a Catch: Attracting OPEC Unity
description: MOSCOW  As prices have dropped ever lower, smaller oil producing nations on precarious financial ground have regularly pushed their bigger brethren to stop pumping at record levels and help calm the markets.

title: Want Viagra? Proposed Kentucky Law Would Require Note From Spouse
description: A Kentucky state representative believed that a new law requiring women to have a medical consultation 24 hours before having an abortion smacked of sexism.

title: Table for One: Pulling Up a Chair for Solo Diners
description: Table for one? Done.

title: Gefilte Fish and Gumbo in Buenos Aires
description: On a recent Friday night, a small group stood outside Mishiguene in Buenos Aires, chatting and sipping digestifs after an opulent 12-course tasting menu. Not five minutes had passed when a fellow diner opened the door and bellowed: Come back in, you have to see this! The restaurants chef, Toms Kalika, had momentarily stopped dinner service to introduce an accordionist and a clarinetist who began to play joyous klezmer songs, eventually bringing patrons to their feet.

title: ADT in $6.9 Billion Deal to Sell Itself to Apollo Buyout Firm
description: The ADT Corporation, which provides home and business security systems for 6.5 million customers, is being acquired by the private equity firm Apollo Global Management for $6.9 billion in the largest leveraged buyout so far this year.

title: U.N. Rights Official Urges China to Release Detained Lawyers
description: GENEVA  The United Nations top human rights official called on China on Tuesday to immediately and unconditionally release a group of lawyers detained starting last summer, and he expressed concern over a very worrying pattern of arrests and disappearances.

title: 1916: Oath Binds Allies to Belgium
description: HAVRE  Great Britain, France and Russia, the guarantors of the independence of Belgium, which Germany, another guarantor, has so ruthlessly violated, have entered into a solemn pact that they will not lay down the sword until the integrity of King Alberts Kingdom has been re-established, its political and economic independence have been restored and generous compensation has been paid for the wrongs which it has suffered. Italy and Japan, although these Powers were not signatories to the original treaty, have associated themselves in the undertaking of the Triple Entente, their Ally.The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 17, 1916

title: Rubio Tax Cut Got Bigger and Bigger
description: If you want an insight into what Senator Marco Rubios instincts on policy are, just look at what happened when he got his hands on another senators tax cut plan: It became about three times larger, and way more tilted toward the rich.

title: Why Angela Merkel Could Lead the U.N.
description: LONDON  Filed away at the back of an office at United Nations headquarters in Turtle Bay, in New York, is a small collection of yellowing letters, containing appeals from the organizations first secretary general, a former Norwegian minister named Trygve Lie, to be allowed to relinquish his post. To this day, his motive is unclear: Was he desperate to escape the burdens of high office? Or did he believe in his own indispensability and wish to evoke pleas from member states for him to remain?

title: Matchmaking at a 7-Eleven
description: Dear Diary:

title: Eagles of Death Metal Return to Paris for Concert
description: PARIS  The sold-out concert by Eagles of Death Metal here Tuesday night was at once a tribute to those who died in the November terrorist attacks during a performance by the band and a celebration of those who survived.

title: Ugandas Least Equal Voters: The L.G.B.T.I.
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As an attorney and Uganda human rights activist, Americas elections thrill me. It is breathtaking to witness democracy in full roar, as candidates vie for the nations highest office.

title: Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton to Meet Civil Rights Leaders
description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont will meet with the heads of several civil rights organizations in Washington on Thursday morning, an effort that comes as he continues to court black voters ahead of Saturdays Democratic caucuses in Nevada and the partys Feb. 27 South Carolina primary.

title: Moving Music Between iPads
description: Q. How do I transfer music from my old iPad to my new one?

title: After 25 Years of U.S. Role in Iraq, Scars Are Too Stubborn to Fade
description: BAGHDAD  It was once a well-kept memorial for hundreds of Iraqi civilians who were killed by American bombs while they slept, a powerful symbol of suffering embraced by a dictators propaganda machine.

title: 1941: British Mine Singapore Coast
description: LONDON  The laying of a new mine field off Singapore, already one of the most strongly fortified naval and air bases in the world, was announced today [Feb. 16] by the British government. Any vessel wishing to pass through the area off the east coast of the Malay Peninsula must apply to British naval authorities at Singapore for a route, the announcement said, while any ship disregarding these instructions would do so at its own peril. The announcement made clear that Great Britain fully realized the gravity of the Far Eastern situation and was preparing for any eventualities. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 17, 1941

title: Taking Creepiness Out of Computer Voices
description: As machine learning and the use of artificial intelligence spread, technologists are running into questions over when A.I. can get too real  and too creepy.

title: A Warning on the Federal Reserves Limits
description: Inside the hurricane-force partisanship swirling around the capital, Washington has retained a singular bulwark for mainstream consensus: Federal Reserve stewardship of economic policy.

title: A Possible Preview of Next Years Oscar Race
description: Too early to talk about next years Oscar race? Never!

title: My Unicorn Problem
description: It has been an interesting few months on the progressive side of the political debate, and I mean that in the worst way. A significant number of progressives are very, very excited by the unexpected support for Bernie Sanders, and are shocked and horrified to find many  I think most  liberal policy wonks rather skeptical. For me this is somewhat familiar territory: I was skeptical about Barack Obamas promises of transcendence back in 2008, too. And then as now a fair number of enthusiasts took no time at all to declare that I was a corrupt villain, a tool of the oligarchs, desperate for a job with Hillary etc.. OK, this too shall pass. But I thought it might be worth saying a bit more about where people like me find ourselves.

title: Dispatcher in Deadly German Train Crash Faces Investigation
description: BERLIN  A dispatcher is under investigation for involuntary manslaughter following the deaths of 11 people after the German authorities concluded human error led two trains to collide in Bavaria last week, prosecutors said on Tuesday.

title: The War After Scalia
description: In the wake of Antonin Scalias death, two lines of critique are circulating concerning Senate Republicans immediate declaration that they wont approve any replacement before the next president is elected and inaugurated. The first, offered by David Frum, Chris Cillizza and others, holds that Mitch McConnell and Co. would have been better served politically by pretending to consider an Obama nominee and then simply using a sixty-vote threshold to avoid approval, rather than coming across as baldly intransigent from day one. The second one, offered by Slates Mark Joseph Stern (who wrote one of the more generous liberal eulogies for Scalia), goes further and argues that Senate Republicans are gambling significantly by declining to approve a moderate-liberal nominee, since if they lose the Senate and the White House this fall they could end up with a more radical, precedent-overturning liberalon the court instead of a compromise choice. Heres Stern:

title: Pact on U.S.-Cuba Flights Reopens Battle for Seized Property
description: MIAMI  The Obama administrations top transportation officials joined Cuban dignitaries at the Hotel Nacional in Havana on Tuesday to sign an agreement that will restore commercial airline service between the two countries for the first time in more than 50 years.

title: Pittsburgh Exchanges Macys for Mixed-Use Giant
description: PITTSBURGH  A plan to convert Pittsburghs 12-story landmark Macys department store into a one-million-square-foot mixed-used behemoth has become one of the latest votes of confidence in the decade-long resurgence of the citys downtown.

title: France Weighs Limits of Liberty, Equality and Citizenship
description: How proposed changes to Frances Constitution to fight terrorism compare with laws in other countries.

title: Boutros Boutros-Ghali, Former U.N. Secretary General, Dies at 93
description: Boutros Boutros-Ghali, an Egyptian diplomat who led the United Nations in a chaotic 1990s tenure that began with hopes for peace after the Cold War, but failed to cope with genocide in Rwanda and Bosnia and ended in angry recriminations with Washington, died on Tuesday in an Egyptian hospital. He was 93.

title: Tory Burch: Fall 2016
description: Ms. Burchs fall collection.

title: New York Fashion Week: Tommy Hilfiger and Jeremy Scott in Pictures
description: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented yesterday.

title: The Best and Worst of the Grammys
description: Kendrick Lamars marquee performance, Lady Gagas tribute to David Bowie  and other Grammy moments that had us cheering and cringing.

title: Catherine Opie in Conversation With Rodarte
description: The photographer Catherine Opie is the focus of several new shows on both coasts. A current exhibition at Lehmann Maupin in New York, split between the gallerys Chelsea and Lower East Side locations, showcases a wide assortment of her work  including landscapes, portraits and pieces from her 700 Nimes Road series, photographs of Elizabeth Taylors belongings.She is also currently the subject of three shows in Los Angeles  at LACMA, MOCAs Pacific Design Center and the Hammer. She spoke to the Rodarte designers Laura and Kate Mulleavy, her frequent collaborators who will show their fall/winter 2016 collection today, for T.

title: Pizza Moto @ John Grace Bakery
description: A mobile pizzaiolo sets up permanent shop on the border of Carroll Gardens and Red Hook.

title: Pizza Moto Comes to Rest in Brooklyn
description: David Sclarow built his first wood-burning pizza oven so he could feed guests at the wedding of two cheesemakers. They were getting married some distance from Brooklyn, where he lived, so he layered the bricks and concrete on top of a flatbed trailer that he could hitch to the back of his Volkswagen Doka. The next time he took his mobile pizza oven for a spin, it collapsed, but by that point, he liked it so much that he rebuilt it.

title: New York Police Still Struggle to Follow Street-Stop Rules, Report Finds
description: A review of hundreds of street stops by the New York Police Department last year found that in over one-quarter, officers failed to document the suspicion that prompted them to stop someone for questioning. In most instances, sergeants signed off on the stop-and-frisk paperwork even when the forms filled out by officers omitted required information.

title: N.H.L. This Week: Blackhawks Visit Rangers, Then Go Outdoors
description: Every Tuesday, The New York Times will look at the week ahead in the N.H.L., highlighting hot  or not so hot  teams and players. (All times Eastern.)

title: The Daily Bag: The Row
description: Only The Row could make a piece of lustrous chartreuse satin without straps or hardware the most simple-yet-desirable handbag weve seen yet.  MALINA JOSEPH GILCHIRST

title: James Truman, Cond Nast Alumnus, Is Now Editing Restaurants
description: It would be an understatement to say that James Truman has given some thought to how his new restaurant, Nix, will look.

title: University of Arizona Students Hurl Insults, and Litter, at Mosque in Tucson
description: TUCSON  Rania Kanawati, a Syrian immigrant, was walking to her car after Friday Prayer last month at the Islamic Center of Tucson when a beer can landed right behind her, then another one fell by her side.

title: At Thom Browne, Revisiting New York Citys Not-so-Roaring 20s
description: A misty Washington Square Park set the scene for the designers fall/winter 2016 show, inspired by the melancholy of the Depression.

title: Facts & Figures: South Carolina Trump Supporters on the Civil War
description: Thirty-eight percent of Donald Trump supporters in South Carolina wish the South had won the Civil War, according to a new poll by Public Policy Polling. Another 38 percent are undecided, and 24 percent are glad the North won.

title: Two Poems by J.R.R. Tolkien Found in School Publication in England
description: Grim was the world and grey last night/The moon and stars were fled. So begins Noel, one of two previously unseen poems by J. R. R. Tolkien, discovered in a 1936 school annual in England. Stephen Oliver, the headmaster of Our Ladys School in Abingdon, Oxfordshire, found the poems after being contacted by Wayne Hammond, a Tolkien scholar, who had discovered a note by the author mentioning their publication.

title: What I Learned From Justice Scalia
description: When I first met Antonin Scalia, I was a small child with one brown ponytail atop my head. Which is odd, because I was a full-grown woman and my hair was short and blond. Still, sitting on the black leather sofa in his chambers, I remember shrinking. Overpowered by his intellect and his enormous personality, I felt that my feet no longer touched the floor. I had become Lily Tomlins iconic character, Edith Ann, in that great big rocking chair. And now I had to convince this giant of a man to hire me as his law clerk.

title: Feds Neel Kashkari Says Banks Are Still Too Big to Fail
description: WASHINGTON  During the 2008 financial crisis, Neel Kashkari worked tirelessly to save the nations largest banks. As a senior Treasury Department official in the George W. Bush and Obama administrations, he helped those banks grow larger than ever.

title: 3 Americans Kidnapped in Baghdad Are Released
description: BAGHDAD  Three Americans who were kidnapped from a Baghdad apartment by Shiite militiamen last month were released unharmed on Tuesday after the Iraqi authorities negotiated their freedom, State Department officials confirmed. After showers, medical checkups and a meal at the American Embassy, they were quickly put on a plane out of the country.

title: Italian Lawmakers Vote on Same-Sex Civil Unions Stalls
description: ROME  The Italian Senate began voting Tuesday afternoon on a contentious bill that for the first time would allow civil unions for same-sex couples.

title: Rag & Bone Marches to Its Own (Two) Drummers
description: The best way to appreciate Rag & Bones fall show, held Monday night in a cavernous open-plan studio over truffled popcorn and designer chocolate, was to shut one eye, then the other.

title: Where Do You Draw the Line Between Commercial and Literary Fiction?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, James Parker and Rivka Galchen on where they draw the boundary  if they do  between commercial and literary fiction.

title: In N.F.L.s Trying 2014, Roger Goodell Earned $34.1 Million
description: Roger Goodell, the commissioner of the N.F.L., was paid $34.1 million in 2014, a year in which the league was tarnished by how it handled domestic violence cases involving several of its star players.

title: Playing the Game at Tory Burch
description: Demonstrating her firm belief in the future of athleisure, and the fact that women are increasingly inclined to wear their gym clothes to lunch (and work, and play, and what have you), Tory Burch mixed her main line and her new Tory Sport line in a 1970s-inflected show on Tuesday morning to relatively seamless effect.

title: U.N. Says Aid Delivery Near in Syria for 5 Towns
description: UNITED NATIONS  Five days after world powers announced that aid would soon reach starving Syrians trapped behind front lines, the United Nations was still negotiating with the government in Damascus on Tuesday over lifting blockades to humanitarian convoys, announcing by days end that it hoped to start sending 80 trucks to deliver food and lifesaving medicines on Wednesday.

title: Come From Away, a Sept. 11 Musical, Is Coming to Broadway
description: The events of Sept. 11, 2001, do not seem to be the most obvious fodder for a Broadway musical. But after successful runs at La Jolla Playhouse and Seattle Repertory Theater, Come From Away  tracing how the residents of Gander, Newfoundland, took in thousands of diverted airline passengers that terrible day  will come to New York in the spring of 2017.

title: South Street Seaport Museum Ready for First Exhibition Since Hurricane Sandy
description: The South Street Seaport Museum is set to open its first exhibition since 2012, when Hurricane Sandy destroyed its electrical system and computer network, left oily residue on the premises and created yet another hurdle for an institution that had experienced years of difficulties.

title: Ted Cruz Outlines Plan to Strengthen Military
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C.  Senator Ted Cruz of Texas outlined his plans to strengthen the military in an address aboard the U.S.S. Yorktown on Tuesday, advocating what he called a more tooth, less tail approach.

title: Review: In Please Continue, Human Nature Gets a Lab Test
description: The first time I heard about the Milgram experiments, back in Sociology 101, I was stunned. The results seemed to prove that humans were inherently bad. The subjects behavior explained Nazi Germany.

title: Kosher Fish Sauce From Vietnam
description: An Orthodox rabbi from Vietnam was there to certify it, so Red Boats new fish sauce (nuoc mam) is kosher. It is clear amber, properly funky, richly anchovied and without additives or preservatives. It would lend umami to gefilte fish or chopped liver. Its also kosher for Passover: Red Boat Kosher Fish Sauce, $14.99 for 8.45 ounces at Kalustyans, 123 Lexington Avenue (East 29th Street), 212-685-3451, kalustyans.com.

title: Nicholas Kristof: Three Decades of Covering the World
description: Welcome to Times Insider Events  live programming for Times Insiders and their guests.

description: Ms. Wang presents her fall collection.

title: Hungary Assails Human Rights Advocates in the Country, U.N. Expert Says
description: LONDON  A United Nations expert warned on Tuesday that human rights advocates in Hungary faced threats and political pressure, citing attempts to silence dissenting voices in a country that has taken a sharp right-wing turn since 2010.

title: Plan by Institute in Princeton Clashes With a Parks Revolutionary War Past
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  The Battle of Princeton, which some historians say changed the course of the Revolutionary War, unfolded on Jan. 3, 1777, when Gen. George Washington rallied his troops to defeat the British Redcoats. The battle was fought in difficult conditions, and though it was fierce, the fighting ended quickly.

title: President Raises Stakes in Supreme Court Nominee Battle
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  President Obama on Tuesday challenged Republicans to offer a plausible rationale for refusing to consider a Supreme Court candidate to replace Justice Antonin Scalia, and he pledged to nominate someone with an outstanding legal mind who cares about democracy and the rule of law.

title: Hillary Clinton, Seeking to Solidify Blacks Support, Meets With Civil Rights Leaders
description: Hillary Clinton met with the National Urban League on Tuesday in New York, where she thanked the group for the extraordinary advice that they have given to her campaign as both she and Senator Bernie Sanders seek to shore up support among blacks as the Democratic battlefield heads to South Carolina.

title: Coming at the Graduate Center
description: At 6:30 this Thursday; will be streamed at this link.

title: Second Sedition Arrest in India as Former Lecturer Is Held
description: NEW DELHI  The police in New Delhi arrested a former university lecturer on suspicion of sedition early Tuesday, the second arrest in a week on the colonial-era charge, as student and teacher protests against the government continued.

description: The Rodarte sisters present their latest designs.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Sound and the Furry
description: Barking is rarely encouraged in or asked of well-mannered pooches, but The Times recently took portraits and recorded the barks of various show dogs. Try to match the barks with the portrait.

title: Europe Seeks Alternatives to Russian Gas Imports
description: BRUSSELS  European Union authorities on Tuesday stepped up efforts to reduce reliance on Russian natural gas as the two sides face off over a litany of geopolitical disputes, from the conflict in Ukraine to the civil war in Syria.

description: To the Editor:
