description: On the occasion of his fall/winter 2016 presentation, which will be held in New York today instead of Paris, A.P.Cs President & Creative Director Jean Touitou spoke to T about his recent investment in the active wear brand Outdoor Voices, fashions shift in delivery schedules  and his definition of beauty.

title: The Daily Shoe: The Row
description: Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen love a flat, mens wear-inspired shoe with just about everything, from fluid trousers to evening dresses. That this handmade, caramel-color boot was shown with so many looks in their intimate fall collection yesterday only solidified its versatile perfection.

title: Where to Eat in Atlanta
description: A selection of restaurant options for the discerning diner.

title: The Battle Lines Over the Supreme Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Funeral for Scalia Will Be Held Saturday
description: Details about a memorial and funeral for Justice Antonin Scalia  and the Supreme Courts week ahead  began to surface Tuesday, three days after Justice Scalia, a lifelong Roman Catholic, was found dead in his room at a Texas ranch.

title: Atlanta Restaurants Rise Up
description: As the nations infatuation with Southern food matures, Atlanta is coming into its own.

title: Atlanta Pulls a Chair to the Table for Culinary Greats
description: ATLANTA  Atlanta has long been considered the capital of the New South. It boasts the worlds busiest airport and 16 Fortune 500 companies. It is a black entertainment mecca. So many movies are shot here that people call it Yallywood.

title: Young Saudis See Cushy Jobs Vanish Along With Nations Oil Wealth
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  In pressed white robes and clutching crisp rsums, young Saudi men packed a massive hall at a university in the capital city this month to wait in long lines to pitch themselves to employers.

title: Prosecutors Have Deal With Second Dewey & LeBoeuf Figure
description: The criminal case arising from the collapse of the once-prominent law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf has been cut in half, with Manhattan prosecutors agreeing to a deferred prosecution agreement with another of the four original defendants.

title: Next Supreme Court Justice Will Be Crucial to Climate Change
description: The United States sure knows how to throw cold water on international harmony.

title: Hillary Clintons Candidacy Reveals Generational Schism Among Women
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  In the sun-drenched student center on the Pennsylvania State University campus here, a few days after Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont trounced Hillary Clinton in the New Hampshire Democratic primary last week, Renee Tillman, Melanie Suarez and Kamryn Sandidge were picking at their lunchtime salads when they were asked if they considered themselves feminists.

title: Nigerian Women Freed From Boko Haram Face Rejection at Home
description: DAKAR, Senegal  A new crisis is emerging as the Nigerian military liberates droves of women and girls from their Boko Haram captors: Many of the newly freed are being rejected when they return to their communities, according to a report released Tuesday.

title: U.S. Had Cyberattack Plan if Iran Nuclear Dispute Led to Conflict
description: BERLIN  In the early years of the Obama administration, the United States developed an elaborate plan for a cyberattack on Iran in case the diplomatic effort to limit its nuclear program failed and led to a military conflict, according to a coming documentary film and interviews with military and intelligence officials involved in the effort.

title: Bedford & Co. Fires Up a Wood Grill
description: Bedford & Co. The latest decorative statement in New York restaurants is a woodpile. Increasingly, chefs are installing wood-fired grills and ovens and, like John DeLucie in this new venture, putting stacks of split logs on display. And not just for show. I saw this grill in Argentina, he said of the wood-fueled contraption in his open kitchen. I knew I had to have one. He features wood-grilled dishes like oysters, lamb ribs, artichokes, beets and whole fish. This restaurant represents a fresh start for Mr. DeLucie, who the last few years has closed all his others, including Crown, the Lion and Bills Food & Drink, which he owned with partners. Bedford & Co., done in dark browns and olive green, is on two levels in the new Renwick hotel: (Opens Wednesday): 118 East 40th Street, 212-634-4040, bedfordandco.com.

title: We Asked, You Answered: Is It Important to Elect a Female President?
description: The Times asked readers for their opinions, and thousands responded. Here is a sampling of the replies.

title: Purple Magazine and Jeremy Scott Keep the Fashion Party Going
description: Olivier Zahm, Hari Nef and Zachary Quinto gather at Narcissa; Jeremy Scott celebrates his new collection at Flash Factory.

title: Purple Magazine and Jeremy Scott Keep the Fashion Party Going
description: Purple magazine held its annual fashion week party at Narcissa in the Standard, East Village hotel, where diners were treated to a throwback party favor: disposable cameras. The famed photographer Ellen von Unwerth takes a selfie.

title: How Mansur Gavriel Turned a White Box Into a Cozy Home
description: A sometimes overlooked part of fashion week (by showgoers, at least) are sets, but designers can spend months transforming a space for their collection. For their fall/winter 2016 presentation, Rachel Mansur and Floriana Gavriel of the New York City-based accessories brand Mansur Gavriel enlisted a handful of collaborators to turn the Swiss Institute in Soho into a domestic scene. The final result displayed their pieces amid a cozy living room and kitchenette  complete with fresh food. As designers, we think in terms of a world, Mansur says. Although weve only been able to express shoes and bags, so far, were always thinking about the emotional aspect  and not product-driven  and thats what we want to roll out. Scroll over the images above and below to go inside the presentation.

title: Music by Fashions Most In-Demand Sound Director  for Chlo Sevigny
description: This season, the French sound illustrator Michel Gaubert is scoring New York Fashion Week shows for Lacoste, Adam Selman, Proenza Schouler, Diane Von Furstenberg, Rodarte, Michael Kors, Jeremy Scott and Tory Burch. But on Sunday afternoon, he traded the runway for an East Village furniture store, to celebrate a different kind of creative collaboration: Prayer to Saint Thrse  an original audio work spoken by Chlo Sevigny, and turned into song. Ive been a fan of Chlo for a long time, said Gaubert. Part of Rgime des Fleurs Artefacts program, which pairs exquisite old objects with original artistic works, the song honors the patron saint of flowers  a fitting ode to the fragrance brands handmade perfumes, which are heavily inspired by art history.

title: Indentured, by Joe Nocera and Ben Strauss
description: The N.C.A.A., the nonprofit organization that once governed college athletics and now more closely resembles a sprawling sales team for high-end workout gear, was, like so many despots before it, meant to be a force for good. Its first executive director, a former sportswriter named Walter Byers, built the organization as a buffer against creeping capitalism and shady gambling interests  a way to protect student-athletes from the rampaging hordes of greed charging in from the sidelines. It was meant to be a place of purity.

title: The Right Sauces for Whole Wheat Pasta
description: Whole wheat pasta just doesnt work with all sauces. Its nutty, somewhat assertive flavor can overpower a subtle sauce, and its texture, which can be granular, doesnt work with others.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: $3.275 million

title: Apollo Builds In Safeguards for Its ADT Deal
description: Leon D. Black is giving new meaning to secured loans. Apollo Global, the private equity firm he helps run, has agreed to buy the home safety and fire protection company ADT for about $7 billion. Its a buyout of alarming size given the fear coursing through credit markets, but the deal comes with plenty of safeguards.

title: West of Eden, by Jean Stein
description: Oral history looks all too easy. When the Belarussian writer Svetlana Alexievich won the 2015 Nobel Prize in Literature for her oral histories of humanitarian crises, it seemed an overdue confirmation of the genres literary nature  not just its capacity to tell sweeping, timeless human stories, but also the craft and cunning involved in its artful assemblage of specific, individual voices. In this country the form has proved to be both a serious vehicle for popular history and a reliable producer of best sellers, beginning with Studs Terkels Working in 1974. But it was Jean Steins 1982 book Edie: American Girl, edited with George Plimpton, that gave oral history the particular shimmer that comes when lofty literary aims happen to coincide with sheer entertainment value. Edie conjured the tragic life of Edith Sedgwick, who was born into a patrician New England family, grew up with seven siblings on isolated ranches near Santa Barbara under the yoke of a semi-deranged father, came east and after a stint in a mental hospital became Andy Warhols arm candy and a figure in New York counterculture, before being cast out by him and dying at 28 of an overdose. In many ways Steins new book, West of Eden, continues the larger project she began in Edie: chronicling a trickster promise embedded in our national consciousness  something shining and elusive and at its center not just ugly but quite often deadly.

title: Conspiracy Theories About Zika Spread Through Brazil With the Virus
description: SALVADOR, Brazil  The Zika virus, some Brazilians are convinced, is the inadvertent creation of a British biotech company that has been releasing genetically modified mosquitoes to combat dengue fever in Brazil. Others here and elsewhere see it as a plot by global elites to depopulate the earth and install a one-world government.

title: New York Fashion Week: Street Style
description: Street style scenes in New York City during New York Fashion Week.

title: Mets Bullpen Will Be Deep. The Question Is When.
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  One sweltering day last August, Jerry Blevins remembered he had left his iPad in his car outside his hotel. The Mets were beginning to pick up steam, but he was stuck here, rehabilitating a broken forearm.

title: Penetrating Every Stage of Afghan Opium Chain, Taliban Become a Cartel
description: ZARANJ, Afghanistan  Shortly after sunrise, an Afghan special operations helicopter descended on two vehicles racing through the empty deserts of southern Afghanistan, traversing what has become a superhighway for smugglers and insurgents.

title: As Marijuana Sales Grow, Start-Ups Step In for Wary Banks
description: When Lamine Zarrad was not at his job as a federal banking regulator in recent months, he was spending a lot of time at Denvers marijuana dispensaries.

title: Vice Bets on an Unlikely Food Star: Action Bronson
description: The mountainous rapper Action Bronson was hanging around in the lounge at the Manhattan offices of Goliath Artists, a hip-hop-focused talent management company, lovingly describing his Albanian grandmothers culinary specialties, like flija, a multilayered pancake. Very intricate peasant dishes, he said as he rolled a very, very large joint.

title: Dueling Headlines
description: NBC News: Clinton Maintains National Lead Over Sanders

title: Your Daily Fashion Week Recap for Tuesday, Feb. 16
description: Thom Brownes 20s-something

title: NATO and Europes Refugee Crisis
description: The announcement last Thursday that NATO would send ships to patrol the Aegean in an effort to break up the smuggling rings ferrying desperate refugees and migrants from Turkey to Greece is, at this point, more a symbolic show of solidarity than anything else. Even so, it reflects a heightened sense of urgency about the refugee crisis and sends a strong signal that the Western alliance stands ready to help Europe cope with it.

title: Bernie Sanders Pledges to Focus on the Plight of Disenfranchised Blacks
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Senator Bernie Sanders spent Tuesday courting black voters in South Carolina with promises that he would combat institutional racism, reform police departments across the country, and make getting an education and a well-paying job easier.

title: Woman Arrested After Stabbing Death at a Brooklyn Restaurant
description: A 35-year-old woman has been arrested in the stabbing death of a man after an argument in a Chinese restaurant in Brooklyn, the authorities said on Tuesday.

title: Grammys Ratings Hold Steady as Awards Move to a New Night
description: The Grammys on CBS drew 25 million people on Monday night, roughly in line with last years show, when 25.3 million people tuned in.

title: 2 More Top Executives to Step Down at A.I.G.
description: After joining the American International Group nearly two decades ago, Brian Schreiber became a major executive in building the insurance giant up  and then, after the financial crisis, in helping it shrink.

title: Gypsy Sport: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Rio Uribes latest looks.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Manny Pacquiao Apologizes for Calling Gays Worse Than Animals
description: Manny Pacquiao, the Filipino world champion boxer turned politician, apologized Tuesday after calling people in gay relationships worse than animals during an interview with a local broadcaster, setting off a torrent of criticism.

title: Donald Trump Is a Conundrum for Political Comedy
description: In all of political comedy, there may be one person who truly understands Donald J. Trump. And that person is a dog.

title: Review: A Look Into the Life of Henry James, in His Own Unsimple Words
description: I hate American simplicity, Henry James (1843-1916) said to his niece Peggy, who had the sense to write his comment down. I glory in the piling up of complications of every sort. If I could pronounce the name James in any different or more elaborate way I should be in favor of doing it.

title: Review: So Percussion, Glenn Kotche and Shara Worden Join in Making a Joyful Noise
description: Its a good thing the sirens that wailed through Zankel Hall on Friday didnt signal an emergency: The auditorium was so densely packed at the start of So Percussions late-evening concert that it would have taken a while to evacuate. But there was no danger mistaking these piercing sounds, produced on hand-cranked sirens by the ensembles members, Eric Cha-Beach, Josh Quillen, Adam Sliwinski and Jason Treuting, for anything other than the opening fanfare of a performance that would prove entertaining, virtuosic, occasionally lyrical, but most often joyfully loud.

title: Review: Climate Control, Where Hot and Cold Mix It Up in a Pas de Deux
description: They come from different tribes. She, in her fur-trimmed hood, could be a Native American of the far north, though her pointe shoes are puzzling. He, with his chest bare above what looks like a grass skirt, might be Polynesian, though the skirt is made of silvery tinsel and his crown suggests ice. She wields a small electric fan; he, a flashlight. But this woman and man join together in a traditional ballet pas de deux.

title: A.P.C.: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Jean Touitou presents his first NYFW show.

title: Photos of the Day: Mexico and Elsewhere
description: Mexico and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Fighting Abortion Restrictions With a Bill on Viagra
description: I want to protect these men from themselves.

title: Feb. 16, 2016  Photos of the Day
description: Photos from Mexico, North Korea, Gaza City and the United States.

title: After a Rocky Start, Ted Cruz Had Success Before Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON  On the first Monday in October 2003, as the Supreme Court began a new term, a 32-year-old lawyer who then called himself R. Edward Cruz made his first appearance before the justices. It did not go well.

title: They Held Power. They Stole Millions.
description: The Justice Department has led an effort to recover assets that it says were stolen by foreign officials  dictators, politicians and ruling elites  and laundered in the United States. Here is a look at some of the cases it is pursuing:

title: Wanted by U.S.: The Stolen Millions of Despots and Crooked Elites
description: Its hard to imagine a public official with more toys than Teodoro Nguema Obiang Mangue, who spent $300 million on Ferraris, a Gulfstream jet, a California mansion and even Michael Jacksons Thriller jacket. The buying spree is all the more remarkable since this scion of the ruling family of Equatorial Guinea, one of Africas smallest countries, bought all this while on an official salary of $100,000 a year.

title: Michael Moore Says No, Donald Trump Is Not Like Him
description: Donald J. Trumps rivals are trying to tar him as a Michael Moore Republican after his lampooning of George W. Bush as a president who lied to America and failed to keep the country safe. But Mr. Moore, the liberal filmmaker, does not see much similarity between himself and Mr. Trump.

title: German Police Raid Property of Group Linked to ISIS
description: BERLIN  More than 200 police officers and intelligence agents raided an office and 12 homes in the northern German city-state of Bremen on Tuesday to enforce a ban on a Salafist group linked to a previously outlawed group that sent at least 15 people to join the Islamic State in Syria, the authorities said.

title: The Art and Fashion of Lynn Wyatts Paddle8 Auction
description: The auction site will sell pieces of couture owned by the Texas socialite and her friends.

title: A Famous Texan Socialite on Feeling Comfortable in Couture
description: The legendary Houston socialite Lynn Wyatt likes to describe her couture gowns as old friends. The sentiment refers to her penchant for re-wearing the same custom outfits on multiple occasions  and the fact that many of the dresses were designed by close friends. This week, Wyatt, 80, will auction off 17 of her most iconic couture outfits from the 70s, 80s, and 90s  including designs by Chanel, Valentino, Yves Saint Laurent and Givenchy  on Paddle8. A portion of the proceeds will go to benefit the Rothko Chapel in Houston.

title: Kirsten Dunst and Jennifer Jason Leigh Bask in Rodartes Spell
description: On the damp, drizzly afternoon of Rodartes show, Kirsten Dunst, a longtime friend of the designers, was seated front row in a sheer, feathered Rodarte dress. It was hardly the thing for inclement weather, though Ms. Dunst cut through all questions of pragmatism and practicality with the plain-spoken truth about doing fashion week as a celebrity: In a car, out of a car, she said.

title: John J. Riccardo, Former Chairman of Chrysler, Dies at 91
description: John J. Riccardo, who as chairman and chief executive of Chrysler recruited Lee Iacocca before stepping aside as the automaker neared bankruptcy, died on Saturday in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 91.

title: Prado Museum Rescinds Loan of Downgraded Hieronymus Bosch Works
description: AMSTERDAM  The Prado museum in Madrid has rescinded the loan of two works to a major retrospective of Hieronymus Bosch after researchers downgraded the attribution of the paintings to Boschs workshop or followers rather than to the 16th-century Dutch master himself.

title: Apple Plans $12 Billion Bond Sale for Buybacks and Dividends
description: Apple announced plans on Tuesday to sell up to $12 billion in bonds to pay for share buybacks and dividends, as blue-chip companies test investors appetite for debt after two weeks of turbulent markets.

title: In Speech on Ending Racism, Hillary Clinton Offers $125 Billion Plan to Help Poor Minorities
description: In a wide-ranging speech on ending systemic racism, Hillary Clinton presented a $125 billion plan to assist poor and minority communities with job training, education and re-entering society after incarceration, part of an effort to speak directly to African-American voters as the Democratic primary contest heads to South Carolina.

title: A Tenacious Team of Two in the Cosby Case
description: NORRISTOWN, Pa.  Of the dozens of women who have said Bill Cosby sexually assaulted them, Andrea Constand is the only one whose complaint has led to criminal sexual assault charges. And Kevin Steele is the prosecutor who is now bringing her case to trial.

title: Accessories Designers Grab Some Fashion Week Heat
description: With the cameras trained mostly on the catwalks, it is easy to forget that the accessories designers who show during fashion week also have the power to turn heads.

title: Review: Embrace of the Serpent, Where Majesty Meets Monstrosity
description: The horror! The horror! The terminal valediction of Kurtz in Joseph Conrads Heart of Darkness is deconstructed with a raging eloquence in the Colombian director Ciro Guerras majestic, spellbinding film, Embrace of the Serpent. Is the unspeakable savagery evoked by his dying words really beyond the reach of the civilized imagination? I doubt it.

title: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton Easily Top New Poll in South Carolina
description: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton hold commanding leads in South Carolina ahead of the primary election there, according to a poll released Tuesday.

title: Virtual Reality Companies Look to Science Fiction for Their Next Play
description: Tech companies have spent years developing better, cheaper devices to immerse people in digital worlds. Yet they are still figuring out how to make virtual reality the kind of technology that people cannot live without.

title: A Patient Shot in His Hospital Room? Evolution of a Times Story
description: A student I know at the Icahn School of Medicine got in touch to say that a young man with bipolar disorder had been shot in a Houston hospital room by off-duty police officers moonlighting on the security staff. I was skeptical.

title: The Daily Jewel: Rodarte
description: A cuff of climbing silver calla lilies clipped to the upper arms of models at Rodartes romantic show made for the chicest of corsages.  MALINA JOSEPH GILCHRIST

title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing: Hillary Clinton, Cuba, Grammy Awards
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: John Kasich Hopes for Another Success Story in Michigan
description: LIVONIA, Mich.  Four days before the South Carolina primary, Gov. John Kasich stepped off his campaign bus into a crowded Republican Party office near Detroit on Tuesday morning and marveled at how many people had shown up to see him.

title: Ukraines Prime Minister, Arseniy Yatsenyuk, Survives No-Confidence Vote
description: MOSCOW  The pro-Western government that took power in Ukraine after street protests two years ago barely survived a no-confidence vote in Parliament on Tuesday amid infighting and widespread disappointment over its failure to deliver on promises to root out corruption.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: A Conversation With Brian Ezra
description: Mr. Ezra, 34, is a founding principal of Avery Hall Investments, a residential developer focused on Brooklyn. The company, which was started in 2013, is working on several projects, including residential and mixed-use developments in Boerum Hill, Cobble Hill and Park Slope. Mr. Ezra grew up in Park Slope.

title: At Film Comment Selects, Period Pieces Lead the Way
description: Even when it looks backward, Film Comment Selects is not a festival that you would ever accuse of dwelling in the past. The editors of Film Comment, the magazine of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, have programmed their annual February showcase with a combination of under-the-radar art house entries and idiosyncratic revivals that reliably deliver an atmosphere of cutting-edge eclecticism.

title: Review of New York Police Department's Street Stops
description: A review of hundreds of street stops by the New York Police Department last year found that in over one-quarter, officers failed to document the suspicion that prompted them to stop someone for questioning.

title: Off the Runway: Feb. 16
description: Scenes from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.

title: Rosie Assoulin: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Ms. Assoulin, who recently dressed Amal Clooney, presents her fall collection.

title: Deconstructing the Westminster Dog Show
Off the Runway: Fashion Week, Day 6
description: Kate Bosworth, front row at Tory Burch, talks about her latest film; A.P.Cs first New York show; Gypsy Sports finale, complete with a model and her 6-week-old daughter, Rain, clutched to her chest; and more from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.

title: Coach: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Stuart Vevers presents his fall collection as Coach celebrates its 75th anniversary.

title: Rodartes Fall Show
description: Rodartes new collection included a heady mix of frilled leather and sheer lace.

title: Rosie Assoulin Sees the Light
description: If the varicolored candles lighting the way to Rosie Assoulins presentation in the meatpacking district on Monday posed a fire hazard, no one seemed to mind. Most visitors milling around the otherwise austere space on Gansevoort Street were far too busy taking in Ms. Assoulins romantically inclined collection of floor-length coats, dresses and jumpsuits, some effusively ruffled, others pointedly underadorned.

title: Puerto Ricos House of Representatives Passes Bill to Restructure $9 Billion in Debt
description: A plan to restructure about $9 billion of Puerto Ricos debt, hailed as a model for the rest of the islands debt-laden government, moved toward the desk of Gov. Alejandro Garca Padilla to be signed into law on Tuesday, after winning approval by Puerto Ricos House of Representatives.

title: Bill Clinton Makes Case for Hillary Clintons Candidacy in South Carolina
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  Former President Bill Clinton stumped for his wife, Hillary, on Tuesday at community center packed with a diverse crowd of some 1,000 undecided voters, supporters and even a few conservatives.

title: A Fight Over Argentinas Debt Produces No Winners
description: The battle over Argentinas debt is at the end stage, as the hedge funds and the country enter into negotiations to resolve the dispute.

title: Review: Bolaos Mysterious 2666, Distilled to 5 Hours by the Goodman Theater
description: CHICAGO  The obvious challenge in adapting a novel to the stage is how to make a story lying flat on the page leap to three-dimensional life. The task is particularly confounding in the case of 2666, Roberto Bolaos magnum opus, published after his death at 50 in 2003. The book spans two continents, nearly a century, two converging story lines  each dangling digressions like an overtrimmed Christmas tree  and runs to around 900 pages of dense prose.

title: A Fluffy White Dark Horse at Westminster
description: In the bleachers behind Ring 6 of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show at Pier 94 on Tuesday, Janice Lynch and Brenda Mantz of Falls Church, Va., were taking turns chatting up their Samoyeds while waiting for judging in the breed to begin. More important, the two dozen Samoyeds were biding their time until the Doberman pinschers got out of the ring.

title: Former U.N. Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali
description: Boutros Boutros-Ghali served as the United Nations secretary general during the chaotic 1990s.

title: President Obama Criticizes G.O.P. Field, Particularly Donald Trump
description: President Obama on Tuesday offered an extended critique of the Republicans running to replace him, describing them as troubling to people around the world and singling out Donald J. Trump as someone who would not be a serious president.

title: Viral Student Loan Nightmare Is Not What It Seems, Authorities Say
description: In a country where 40 million people owe upward of $1.2 trillion on their student loans, its not hard to imagine why a tale about armed federal agents showing up at the door of a Texas man to arrest him over unpaid student loans set the Internet abuzz.

title: Behind the Scenes at the Dog Show
description: The Westminster dog show, which had 199 breeds and varieties in competition, concluded Tuesday night. C. J., a German shorthaired pointer, was named best in show.

title: Suitor on Tinder App Is Accused of Theft From 2 Women
description: The women liked the way the man looked in his picture on the dating app Tinder, so they swiped right to indicate interest in getting together. He said that his name was Tristan Acocella, that he was in finance and that his sister had cancer.

title: Jerome Weinrib, ABC Carpets Old-School Proprietor, Dies at 86
description: Jerome Weinrib, an old-school rug merchant who helped build ABC Carpet into one of New Yorks most successful home furnishing brands, died on Saturday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 86.

title: Embattled Pennsylvania Attorney General Says That She Will Not Seek Re-election
description: Attorney General Kathleen G. Kane of Pennsylvania said on Tuesday that she will not seek re-election this fall, the latest twist in a political potboiler that has shamed a succession of state officials, destroyed several careers and left Ms. Kane facing felony charges and impeachment.

title: Alabama: Spill Recovery Money Wont Go to Hotel
description: A federal judge in Mobile, Ala., on Tuesday blocked the use of more than $58 million of BP oil spill recovery money for construction of a hotel and conference center along the Gulf of Mexico. Senior Judge Charles R. Butler Jr. said government officials had not appropriately determined whether there were reasonable restoration alternatives to the project, which supporters have called crucial to attracting visitors after the spill in 2010. The projects executive director, Cooper Shattuck, said that there are other funds available for the continued work on the lodge that do not include taxpayer dollars. Robert Wiygul, a lawyer for the Gulf Restoration Network, which challenged the plan, praised the decision.

title: Zimbabwe: Owner of Impounded Jet Says Body on Board Was a Stowaway
description: The American corporate owner of the cargo jet impounded in Zimbabwe after the bloodied body of a man was discovered aboard during a refueling stop confirmed on Tuesday that man was a stowaway found in a compartment adjacent to the nose landing gear. The owner, Western Global Airlines of Estero, Fla., also said that it was working with the Zimbabwean authorities to investigate the matter. The MD11 aircraft, en route on Sunday to Durban, South Africa, from Munich, Germany, was carrying a diplomatic shipment for the South African Reserve Bank, the company said. Officials quoted in Zimbabwe news accounts said the shipment was a large amount of South African currency. Western Global Airlines, which specializes in cargo flights to Africa, said that the identity of the body had yet to be established but that there was no indication that his presence is related to the company or this specific cargo shipment.

title: Pope Francis Entreats Mexicos Youth to Resist Call of Drug Cartels
description: MORELIA, Mexico  Pope Francis delivered his most searing indictment of the Mexican underworld Tuesday, encouraging the nations youth to value themselves and resist the temptation to join forces with criminal organizations that sow terror.

title: Long After Bergdahls Release, His Hometown Is Still Under Siege
description: HAILEY, Idaho  It was the third text message from the unfamiliar number  the one that made direct reference to Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl  that frightened Sherry Horton. It was written in nearly unintelligible gibberish, but its tone was unmistakably menacing.

title: F.D.A. Issues Zika Virus Guidelines for Blood Supply
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday issued new guidelines for blood banks intended to help prevent the contamination of the nations blood supply with the Zika virus.

title: Spaniard to Face U.S. Trial in Art Scandal
description: MADRID  The national court on Tuesday ordered the extradition to the United States of a Spanish businessman accused in a major art market scandal that involved the sale of nearly $70 million in forged paintings through Knoedler & Company, once New Yorks oldest gallery.

title: George Gaynes, a Versatile Character Actor, Dies at 98
description: George Gaynes, who played a grouchy foster parent on the 1980s sitcom Punky Brewster, the beleaguered commandant in seven Police Academy films and a soap opera star with a crush on Dustin Hoffman in drag in the Hollywood hit Tootsie, died on Monday at his daughters home in North Bend, Wash. He was 98.

title: At Oscar de la Renta, an Innocent, Idyllic Beauty Look
description: The beauty look at Oscar de la Rentas fall/winter 2016 show today was evocative of Edwardian beauties  with a touch of coquettishness. Hair was a soft, romantic bun achieved by separating manes into three portions. A bottom layer was left slightly limp at the neck, the hairline loose, lending a pastoral, lived-in quality. The choice to leave knots in a hairnet, noted the hairstylist Guido Palau, nods to another time and is very contained and proper, but still very easy, with softness around the face. Nails were also reminiscent of another era. Inspired by 18th-century manicures, which entailed buffing nails to a shine, models were given a coating of sheer pink polish, followed with Essie Matte About You topcoat for a satin finish.

title: Eyeing South Carolina, Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Vie for Crucial Voters
description: Scrambling for the support of black voters as a crucial primary in South Carolina nears, Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont made appeals on Tuesday to corral their backing. Mrs. Clinton used an address in Harlem to propose $125 billion in new spending to reinvigorate poor and minority communities, and Mr. Sanders barnstormed the South, pledging to combat institutional racism and reform police departments nationwide.

title: Now Is the Winter of Odd Mets Content
description: When last seen, the Mets magic had come undone. The second baseman with the golden bat turned fumble-fingered; the staff ace became hittable in his moment of redemptive glory; the alchemist manager mixed the wrong potions and mistimed the summoning of relievers.

title: Oscar de la Renta: Fall 2016 RW
description: Peter Coppings last ready-to-wear collection as creative director.

title: Giants Coaching Changes Start and Nearly End at Top
description: Fans of the Giants might have been hoping for some kind of leadership overhaul under the new head coach Ben McAdoo, but the team announced Tuesday that 12 assistant coaches from the former coach Tom Coughlins staff had been retained.

title: Sarah Parcak to Use TED Prize Money for Crowdsourcing on Archaeological Sites
description: If someone gave you $1 million to fulfill a dream, what would it be?

title: Christie Calls for End to Partisan Politics in State Budget Address
description: After spending much of the past year engaged in partisan politics as he campaigned for the Republican presidential nomination, Gov. Chris Christie asked New Jersey lawmakers on Tuesday to put aside their petty political differences as they worked to solve some of the states most pressing problems.

title: Obamas Options for a Supreme Court Nominee, and the Potential Fallout
description: The death of Justice Antonin Scalia immediately prompted lofty-sounding pronouncements from leaders of both parties. But behind the public statements, the two parties are engaged in raw political calculations about how to best leverage the vacancy, underscoring the countrys deep polarization and the reality of how elections are waged nowadays.

title: N.S.A. Discloses Inspector General Reports on Surveillance Program
description: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by the New York Times, the N.S.A. has partly declassified and disclosed these inspector general reports. They primarily relate to its warrantless surveillance program under the FISA Amendments Act.

title: N.S.A. Gets Less Web Data Than Believed, Report Suggests
description: WASHINGTON  A newly declassified report by the National Security Agencys inspector general suggests that the government is receiving far less data from Americans international Internet communications than privacy advocates have long suspected.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Its nice that science fiction exists because these are really creative people figuring out what the ultimate use of any technology might be. They come up with a lot of incredible ideas.

title: Mexicos Kingpin Strategy Against the Drug Cartels
description: A look at the Mexican governments decade-long effort to break up drug cartels by targeting their leaders.

title: Who I Am Inside
description: Administrivial Will Shortz Ask Me Anything Alert! Have a question about the New York Times crossword  or editor Will Shortz  or anything about puzzles? Will is taping an Inside The Times podcast next Tuesday, Feb. 23. If you have a question for him, you can leave it here. Will will answer as many questions as he can during 30 minutes. A further announcement will be made when the podcast is ready, which should be soon after Feb. 23.

title: Nicolas Sarkozy Placed Under Investigation on 2012 French Election Charges
description: PARIS  Former President Nicolas Sarkozy was placed under formal investigation by French judges on Tuesday on preliminary charges of illegal overspending during his failed 2012 bid for re-election.

title: Paris St.-Germain Wins but Rues What Might Have Been
description: PARIS  Zlatan Ibrahimovic waved his hands in the air. ngel Di Mara fell to his knees and swiped at the ground in frustration. Laurent Blanc shook his head.

title: De Blasio Says Idea of Closing Rikers Jail Complex Is Unrealistic
description: It began as a dream on Thursday, in a speech by the New York City Council speaker: closing the Rikers Island jail complex.

title: An Underground Brook, Gallons of Sewage and a Century-Old Problem
description: One day, Steve Duncan dropped about eight feet down into an arched brick tunnel that runs below Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, and waded into icy cold water in a culvert.

title: C. J., a German Shorthaired Pointer, Wins Best in Show at Westminster
description: As each of the seven competitors for best in show at the 140th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Tuesday approached Richard Meen, the judge, he told them, Relax. But you wonder if any one of the four-legged champions, let alone their handlers, could heed the advice, even if they were aware that his non-canine work is psychiatry.

title: The People v. O.J. Simpson Episode 3: The Dream Team Assembles
description: O.J. Simpson appears in this weeks episode for maybe five minutes. The rest of it focuses on his lawyers and the stage they are setting for one of the most spectacular public trials of the modern era.

title: Judge Tells Apple to Help Unlock iPhone Used by San Bernardino Gunman
description: WASHINGTON  A judge in California on Tuesday ordered Apple to help the F.B.I. unlock an iPhone used by one of the attackers in the assault in San Bernardino that killed 14 people in December.

title: Political Backlash Grows in Washington to Chinese Takeovers
description: HONG KONG  As Chinese companies try to snap up American tech businesses, they are setting off ripples of unease in the Obama administration and in Congress, inciting a backlash that has stopped the latest acquisition attempt.

title: Hong Kong Students Who Protested Government Now Seek to Take Part in It
description: HONG KONG  A group of young students seeking greater autonomy for Hong Kong is forming a political party to participate in local elections this year, a move that is likely to unsettle a Chinese leadership fighting multiple separatist movements within its borders.

title: China Deployed Missiles on Disputed Island, U.S. Says
description: HONG KONG  The Pentagon has evidence that the Chinese military has deployed surface-to-air missiles on a disputed island in the South China Sea, a United States official has said.

title: Narciso Rodriguez: Fall 2016 RTW
description: The latest designs from Mr. Rodriguez, who recently dressed Michelle Obama.

title: University of Chicago to Get $50 Million From Venture Capitalist
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Nearly four years ago, the venture capitalist Michael Moritz donated $115 million to his alma mater, the University of Oxford, to bolster the British universitys financial assistance efforts.

title: What to Watch Wednesday
description: Been there, done that  though not quite the same way: Broad City begins a third season. Also, Jon Voight and Dustin Hoffman roam the streets in Midnight Cowboy. And Ice-T explores the art of rap in Something From Nothing.

title: Corrections: February 17, 2016
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Looking Beyond the Scripts of the Campaign Trail
description: Six Times photographers have blanketed the early presidential campaign states for the last three weeks, challenged by carefully constructed stagecraft.

title: Killer Mike Defends Himself After Uterus Comment at Sanders Rally
description: Killer Mike, a rapper and much-used surrogate for Bernie Sanders, ignited a controversy on Tuesday after he said that a uterus doesnt qualify you to be president during an event hosted by the Vermont senator at Morehouse College in Atlanta.

title: Veto Likely to Block Renaming of China Embassys Street After Liu Xiaobo
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese Embassys stationery seems safe for now.

title: Six Photographers View of the Campaign Trail
description: Photographing presidential campaigns takes patience and endurance: 18-hour days are the norm, and getting beyond the carefully constructed stagecraft and tightly scripted events can be a challenge.

title: Love Scandal May Doom Bolivian Leaders Push for a Fourth Term
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia  Shortly after President Evo Morales of Bolivia quashed rumors last month that he had shelled out $200 for haircuts, a more serious allegation has transfixed the country, one of the poorest in South America, and now threatens his bid for a fourth term.

title: Who Are We?
description: I find this election bizarre for many reasons but none more than this: If I were given a blank sheet of paper and told to write down Americas three greatest sources of strength, they would be a culture of entrepreneurship, an ethic of pluralism and the quality of our governing institutions. And yet I look at the campaign so far and I hear leading candidates trashing all of them.

title: A Tale of Horror at the United Nations
description: The United Nations is failing some of the most vulnerable children it is supposed to protect. A decade ago, the organization acknowledged that some of the peacekeepers sent to international conflict zones were sexually abusing local women and children, and it promised corrective action. The scourge continues, prompting one senior United Nations official to recoil at what he called the constant horror story of allegations against the peacekeepers.

title: The Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Trump
description: Donald Trump has been recognized for his mastery of the media, his fascination with gilt and his bold advocacy for baffling hair.

title: Hillary Clinton Should Just Say Yes to a $15 Minimum Wage
description: On the campaign trail, Hillary Clinton has eloquently defined workers rights as human rights. She could assert both more forcefully by championing a stronger federal minimum wage of $15 an hour.

title: Donald Trumps Secret? Channeling Andrew Jackson
description: SINCE Donald J. Trump shot to the top of Republican polls last fall, pundits have tried to make sense of his popularity. He has been described as a modern-day product of reality-TV narcissism, or the second coming of European fascism. But as he cruises into the South Carolina primary after beating his rivals by double digits in New Hampshire, its clear that neither idea quite explains his strength.

title: Prosecuting Doctors in Overdose Deaths
China Telescope to Displace 9,000 Villagers in Hunt for Extraterrestrials
description: BEIJING  More than 9,000 Chinese villagers are leaving their homes to make way for aliens  or for the possible echoes of them, at least.

title: Fashion Week: A Night at the Museum
description: The end is nigh. New York Fashion Week has rounded the proverbial bend and is careening toward its seasonal close. Dont worry  London, Milan and Paris still await. And before that, two more days of shows.

title: Can You Book the Cheapest Flight?
description: Think you know all the tricks for getting the lowest airfare and the most out of your miles programs? Test your knowledge, based on Stephanie Rosenblooms weekly Getaway column.

title: Airlines to Offer Cheaper Flights, but Are They Worth the Savings?
description: Rock-bottom fares once unique to low-cost carriers like Spirit and Frontier may, in the coming months, be offered by all three of the nations legacy airlines, American, United and Delta.

title: Big Risks as Landmarks Preservation Commission Moves to Prune Proposed Gems
description: What makes a landmark?

title: The Consequences of Our Consequence-Free Society
description: Lately Ive been thinking about the notion of false courage. It was introduced to me by an unlikely philosopher king: the Dallas Cowboys owner, Jerry Jones, whom I interviewed for an article on the N.F.L. that ran in the Feb. 7 issue of the magazine. We were talking about proposals on how to improve player safety in football. Jones mentioned to me a counterintuitive idea that Lamar Hunt, the founding owner of the Kansas City Chiefs, once suggested.

title: The More Donald Trump Defies His Party, the More His Supporters Cheer
description: NORTH AUGUSTA, S.C.  Mark Jebens, a veteran of 22 years in the Marine Corps, found no fault with Donald J. Trumps scathing criticism that President George W. Bush lied about weapons of mass destruction while leading the United States into war in Iraq.

title: Muslims in France Say Emergency Powers Go Too Far
description: PARIS  Depending on who is telling the story, Daoud Muradyan, a blind 21-year-old, is either a potential terrorist or a harmless immigrant who embodies everything that is wrong with Frances broad new antiterrorism powers.

title: Remembering a Vile Civil War Act, on Fifth Avenue
description: Were more hateful words ever howled by a mob in New York history?

title: Obama Plans Visit to Cuba, as Talks on Expanding Trade Begin
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will travel to Cuba within weeks, a senior administration official said on Wednesday, making a historic visit as part of an effort to end more than a half-century of estrangement and forge normalized relations with a Cold War adversary.

title: Living in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn
description: This changing neighborhood, known for its vintage townhouses, is also seeing large-scale development.

title: Prospect Heights, Where Historic Meets Brand New
description: Rebecca Saltman, 41, an instructor at Teachers College, Columbia University, and her husband, Benjamin, 39, a doctor, were enthusiastic about the sense of community and the cultural amenities of Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, when they bought their townhouse there in 2010 for just over $1 million, with help from Ms. Saltmans parents, who live in the garden apartment.

title: Apple Fights Order to Unlock San Bernardino Gunmans iPhone
description: WASHINGTON  Last month, some of President Obamas top intelligence advisers met in Silicon Valley with Apples chief, Timothy D. Cook, and other technology leaders in what seemed to be a public rapprochement in their long-running dispute over the encryption safeguards built into their devices.

title: Ginny Gall, by Charlie Smith
description: When Delvin Walker, the protagonist of Charlie Smiths novel Ginny Gall, is deep into his prison sentence for a crime he did not commit, a fellow inmate introduces him to the work of Zora Neale Hurston. The inmate quotes a line memorized from Hurstons essay How It Feels to Be Colored Me: I do not belong to that sobbing school of Negrohood who hold that nature has somehow given them a lowdown dirty deal. Delvin lets out a low whistle of disbelief in response. Well, no wonder I never heard of that woman, he says, and the inmate posits that, unlike them, Hurston must be somebody whos found a way out of the general disrespectfulness.

title: The Queen of the Night, by Alexander Chee
description: In opera, voice is everything. The narrator of The Queen of the Night, Lilliet Berne, is a star of the Paris Opera. She possesses a rare and delicate Falcon soprano range, named for Marie-Cornlie Falcon, whose voice famously shattered in the middle of a performance and never recovered. Lilliets world is one of silence and sound, of risk and fragility, and the balance between vocal power and expression.

title: Instead of Democracy, Uganda Moves Toward Dictatorship Light
description: KALUNGU, Uganda  For eight hours, under a beating sun, thousands of people stood in an open field, waiting patiently.

description: FROM MOXY, TWO NEW U.S. HOTELS

title: Which Type of Exercise Is Best for the Brain?
description: Some forms of exercise may be much more effective than others at bulking up the brain, according to a remarkable new study in rats. For the first time, scientists compared head-to-head the neurological impacts of different types of exercise: running, weight training and high-intensity interval training. The surprising results suggest that going hard may not be the best option for long-term brain health.

title: Morning Agenda: Feds Neel Kashkari Says Banks Still Too Big to Fail
description: FEDS NEEL KASHKARI SAYS BANKS STILL TOO BIG TO FAIL | Neel Kashkari, the new president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, worked tirelessly to save the nations banks during the 2008 financial crisis. But now he thinks it is time to consider breaking them up,

title: National Poll Shows Donald Trump With Big Lead and Democrats in Virtual Tie
description: Donald J. Trumps popularity continues to rise nationally, according to a new Quinnipiac University poll that shows him with more than double the support of his closest Republican contender.

title: Pope Francis Wades Into U.S. Immigration Morass With Border Trip
description: CIUDAD JUREZ, Mexico  Stepping to the concrete edge of the Rio Grande, Pope Francis on Wednesday went to a militarized divide of the United States-Mexican border and prayed for compassion toward immigrants. He never set foot in the United States, but he did step directly, and deliberately, into the acrimonious American debate over immigration.

title: New York Today: A Dog Has His Day
description: Updated, 10:07 a.m.

title: In Battle Over Scalia Replacement, Obama Takes Advantage of Far-Flung Senate
description: President Obama is back in Washington, but the Senate remains out of town on the Presidents Day holiday recess  and that has its benefits and disadvantages as the Supreme Court fight heats up.

title: Palau vs. the Poachers
description: Late on a January 2015 evening in Shepherdstown, W.Va., a data analyst named Bjorn Bergman, surrounded by whiteboards scribbled with computer code, was orchestrating a high-stakes marine police chase halfway around the world. Staring at his laptop in a cramped ground-floor office, he drank from his sixth cup of coffee and typed another in a long series of emails: Try and cut them off rather than making for the last known position. Nearly 9,000 miles away, the Remeliik, a police patrol ship from the tiny island nation Palau, was pursuing a 10-man Taiwanese pirate ship, the Shin Jyi Chyuu 33, through Palauan waters. Bergman, working for a nonprofit research organization called SkyTruth, had mastered the use of satellite data to chart a ships most likely course. Instead of pointing the police to where the pirate ship was, he would tell them where it was about to be. He took another sip of coffee, studied his screen, then typed again: It may be advisable for the Remeliik to turn southeast.

title: Do Women Need Legislative Protection?
description: In September 1905, a laundress named Emma Gotcher reported Curt Muller, the owner of Portland Grand Laundry, for making her work more than 10 hours  the states legal limit for women  on, of all days, Labor Day. Gotcher was a labor activist, married to a leader of the Shirtwaist and Laundry Workers Union. The court found Muller guilty of violating Oregon law and fined him $10. He refused to pay, and on appeal to the Supreme Court, his lawyer drew national attention by making a feminist argument: Limits on womens work hours actually discriminate against them. Two years earlier, in the well-known case Lochner v. New York, the Supreme Court struck down a state law that restricted bakers, most of them men, to the same 10-hour day. The bakers were in no sense wards of the state, the court said. Why, Mullers lawyer asked, should women be treated differently?

title: Jon Taffer Sees Shakespeare in Reality TV
description: On your reality show Bar Rescue, you do speedy overhauls of failing bars. Do you ever worry that moving so quickly sort of undermines the owners? Theres an independent website called Bar Rescue Updates that we have nothing to do with, and they track us. According to them, we have a 70 percent success rate  the highest in all of transformation television.

title: Are We Doomed to Slow Growth?
description: One day in 1980, when I was 10, I sat in my great-grandmothers living room and poured out questions about what life was like for her as a girl in Belarus. At 90, she was still sharp and could answer my questions. But she didnt betray any of the emotion I hoped for. Born in 1890, in a tiny village powered by horses and the sun in a manner hardly changed from the time of ancient Rome, she grew up to witness the invention of the airplane and the adoption of electricity and the telephone. I wanted her to join me in marveling at this series of world-changing transformations, which I knew were beyond anything her girlhood self could have imagined. She just answered my questions calmly, politely. No, I dont remember the first airplane I saw. No, I dont remember the first person I called on a telephone.

title: Reinvention in Walla Wallas Wine Country
description: There are only so many occasions on which a responsible adult can justify consuming alcohol and food nonstop for an entire week. Turning 40 is one of them.

title: Leaving Full House Was His Biggest Regret. So He Rebuilt It.
description: In one of the valleys between the peaks of his career, Jeff Franklin had an idea for a TV series. Called House of Comics, it would follow three aspiring stand-ups living together in Los Angeles. It was three single guys trying to cause trouble, and then turning it into material for their act, Mr. Franklin explained. That was the show I wanted to do.

title: Judge John Hodgman on a Home Cellphone Ban
description: Denise writes: We are expecting our first baby, and I want her to grow up in a home where people still pay attention to one another. Id like to put a friendly sign on our door that asks guests to use phones in our home only in the event of an emergency. My husband cringes at the thought.

title: Should I Speak Up for a Pet Pig?
description: I am in a profession where I often go to peoples houses to work with their children. I have one client whom I like very much and who has requested my services a number of times, but whenever I leave that clients house, I find myself troubled. This family has a teacup pig, which lives with them in a medium-size apartment. I consider myself an animal lover, and it so happens that I have looked into the fad of teacup pigs. I know that they are really piglets of a larger variety, the potbellied pig, which are unintentionally underfed by owners who have been led by dishonest sellers to believe that the pigs need to eat less than they really do. Right now the pig is small, perhaps 10 to 15 pounds, but I know it will keep growing and that the lowest healthy weight for a full-grown teacup pig is about 60 pounds; a potbellied pig can easily grow to more than 100 pounds. I asked the family how big the pig would get, thinking perhaps they knew the facts and had some plan. They told me that they expect it to remain the size it is now. The worst part? They often remark that the pig is acting hungry; I imagine they feed him the too-small amount they were directed to by the seller. I believe that this family loves their pig very much and that I am witnessing an unintentional act of animal cruelty, but I am in a quandary: Should I tell them that they are unwittingly mistreating their beloved pet? I worry that I would be overstepping my professional bounds. People can be very touchy when it comes to their pets, and I want to maintain cordial relations with them for the sake of my continued employment. Do I have an ethical obligation to tell them the truth about teacup pigs? Name Withheld

title: Clinton, Sanders and the Underrated Power of the Black Voter
description: If you were asked to assess African-American voting power, you might think about the long history of disenfranchisement that still lingers today, in troubles in Ferguson, Mo.; in efforts to roll back the Voting Rights Act; or in recent moves to limit voting access around the country.

title: Final Days Before Crucial Votes Offer Viewers a Full Television Lineup
description: The 2016 presidential campaign has played out largely on television, whether in the form of ads or news conferences or the reams of Donald J. Trump coverage. So its only fitting that the final days of the Republican primary in South Carolina and the Democratic caucuses in Nevada will play out in televised town-hall-style meetings.

title: Where the Senate Stands on Nominating Scalias Supreme Court Successor
description: Should the Senate vote on a nominee from President Obama to fill the Supreme Court vacancy left by the death of Justice Antonin Scalia, or should the next president decide? Were asking each senator his or her position.

title: Bombardier to Cut 7,000 Jobs as New Airliner Struggles to Draw Buyers
description: OTTAWA  Bombardier, the Canadian transportation company, said on Wednesday that it would lay off about 7,000 employees over the next two years, as it struggles to find buyers for a new series of planes that for the first time put it in direct competition with the aviation giants Boeing and Airbus.

title: Arguing Before Justice Scalia
description: A few years back, during oral argument, Justice Antonin Scalia asked me when I thought the bad old days  when the Supreme Court routinely looked beyond the text of statutes  had ended?

title: Boutros-Ghali: Outspoken Diplomat
description: Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the former U.N. secretary general, died at the age of 93. His tenure was defined by tragedies in Somalia, Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia as well as friction with the Clinton administration.

title: Threes a Trend: Edgy Sequins
description: What do we associate with sequins? Glamour  even gaudiness? This season, three designers used them in new, unexpectedly edgy ways. First, Joseph Altuzarra closed his show with a floor-length boho gown that was toughened up with sequins. Derek Lam showed a beaded black V-neck paired with an armor-like metallic skirt. And yesterday on the dreamy Rodarte runway, Kate and Laura Mulleavy added a sparkly touch to their signature, intricate gowns.

title: Hamilton Tops Box Office Again With Nearly $1.8 Million
description: The juggernaut that is Hamilton, the hip-hop-flavored musical about the founding fathers, shows no signs of slowing down, once again winning the weekly Broadway box-office derby. And given the prime showcase for the musicals opening number on the Grammys broadcast on Monday night, that dominating run could continue for quite a while.

title: A Young Sneaker Brand Enlists an Octogenarian South African Artist
description: When the Swedish sneaker and accessories brand Eytys approached the South African artist and teacher Esther Mahlangu about a partnership, she had a full schedule. I was working on a major exhibition at the UCT Irma Stern Museum at the time, she says, referring to the University of Cape Town institution, as well as celebrating my 80th birthday. But perhaps drawn in by the lack of specific direction or by the promise of a different material (in her decades-spanning career, she has painted on surfaces like clay pots, museum walls, skate decks, a BMW and her own house), she agreed.

title: 1916: Germanys Defensive Guns
description: WASHINGTON  Just when a merchant ship is armed for defence and not for offence must be explained to the German Government by the United States before assurances are given that the first-named class will not be regarded as warships and sunk without warning by submarines. This request was handed to Mr. Robert Lansing, Secretary of State, by Count von Bernstorff to-day [Feb. 17], following the protest at Germanys Memorandum that after March 1 its submersibles would begin the new campaign.The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 18, 1916

title: Noah Haidles Smokefall Comes to New York
description: Arriving on the winds of great notices in Chicago, where it received two productions from the Goodman Theater, Noah Haidles Smokefall makes its New York premiere this month. Mr. Haidles previous plays have toyed with fantasy and form, and Smokefall is no exception. Although it nominally tells of four generations of a Michigan family, the play has elements of surrealism: a character named Beauty, for instance, never speaks and prefers subsisting on dirt and paint to regular food. A novel diet, certainly, if not the most sensible.

description: Twenty-four hours after her David Bowie tribute act at the Grammy Awards in Los Angeles, Lady Gaga had returned to New York still sporting an electric orange Ziggy Stardust do.

description: The sons of two of Americas most influential evangelical figures are establishing their own identities, and often take different approaches to faith and politics.

description: The actress Diane Lane is funding a grant for arts educators to honor the composer, writer and director Elizabeth Swados, who died in January. The grant is being created in partnership with the Ziegfeld Club and will award $5,000 to an influential female educator in New York.

description: What do you call a soccer team that wins three games out of three by a total score of 16-0?

description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in New York.

description: SOFIA  Nazi diplomacy scored a notable triumph today [Feb. 17] when the governments of Bulgaria and Turkey issued a joint declaration pledging themselves to mutual friendship and good-neighborly relations and affirming their will to refrain from aggression.

description: On paper, Martyna Majok looks like so many other young playwrights, with a masters degree from the Yale School of Drama.

description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

description: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented yesterday.

title: The Daily Shoe: Oscar de la Renta
description: Unapologetically ladylike and elegant, these black Oscar de la Renta heels look simple  except theyre not. True to form, Peter Copping added a delicate twist: a platform and a tiny cluster of jewels on the heel, almost like a little wink as the model walked by.

title: Over-Scheduled Andrew, by Ashley Spires
description: There are some picture books that reach for timelessness, offering no details that give away exactly when the story is taking place, or when it was written. And there are some that speak directly to their moment. Over-Scheduled Andrew is (you guessed it) firmly in the latter camp, taking aim at the current vogue for jam-packing childrens days with adult-run activities. This book represents the backlash against the frantic pursuit of whats often known as enrichment, a term that can seem most apropos for the wallets of the adults who teach and coach all these after-school classes, teams and activities. Spiress message is not subtle: She writes as an unapologetic champion of the idea that, rather than pushing elementary-schoolers into organized, goal-oriented pursuits, we would enrich their lives more by offering them, say, a couple of unstructured hours with a giant cardboard box, some scissors, packing tape and markers, and no grown-ups chirping directions at them.

title: Jeb Bush, Going for Broke in South Carolina, Embraces Legacy
description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  In his early days as a presidential candidate, Jeb Bush appeared to campaign in a defensive stance: Sensitive about his political patrimony, he insisted he was his own man and struggled to address the conduct of the Iraq war under his brother, President George W. Bush.

title: When Harry Truman Nearly Doubled the Minimum Wage
description: One of the arguments against raising the federal minimum wage from $7.25 an hour today to $15 an hour over five years is that the United States has never had an increase that large. There is solid research to show that modest increases in the minimum help low-wage workers without harming low-wage employers. But there is no similarly rigorous research on the effects of large increases.

title: Zenefits Scandal Highlights Perils of Hypergrowth at Start-Ups
description: If youve never heard of the human-resources start-up Zenefits, get ready to never forget it.

title: Why America Turned Off Al Jazeera
description: WASHINGTON  The closing of Al Jazeera America, expected in April, is a sad conclusion to a project that was by turns uplifting and inspiring as well as troubling and depressing. Its demise offers a lesson in both the limitations of public diplomacy and the obstacles to providing high-quality television journalism.

title: Italian Senate Puts Off Vote on Civil Unions Bill
description: ROME  The Italian Senate has postponed a vote on a contentious bill that would recognize civil unions for same-sex couples, after a boisterous discussion that risked defeating the law.

title: Jeb Bush Pushes Back At Marco Rubio on Foreign Policy Experience
description: BEAUFORT, S.C.  Jeb Bush has largely refrained from attacking Senator Marco Rubio of Florida by name on the campaign trail. But fighting for his political life ahead of the primary Saturday in South Carolina, a state with a large population of active military members and veterans, Mr. Bush took issue with comments Mr. Rubio made questioning his foreign policy experience.

title: Marin Mazzie to Return to Broadway in The King and I
description: Back in December, when Marin Mazzie went to see The King and I with her mother, she was just there for fun, not to scope it out as a job prospect. For one thing, she had no idea Kelli OHara would be leaving the show.

title: Florida Teenager Is Accused of Posing as a Doctor. Again.

title: Vegas on the Cheap? Get Off the Strip
description: Things were in full swing when I arrived at the Fremont Street Experience, a covered outdoor street fair that functions as the throbbing party vein of downtown Las Vegas. Occasional screams emanated from above as kids whizzed by on a zip line that runs the length of the street 12 stories up. I grabbed a draft beer at one of the casino bars and walked by an Elvis impersonator and his backing band blasting through a solid rendition of Hound Dog.

title: Should Obama Pick Nominee? Your Answer May Depend on How Much History You Know
description: The Senate is preparing for a no-holds-barred battle over whether it should even consider President Obamas choice to replace Antonin Scalia on the Supreme Court. Not surprisingly, Americans are divided by political party about whether Mr. Obama should be the one to nominate the replacement, a new online poll shows. But there is also a fascinating wrinkle.

description: An opera composed by a woman will appear at the Metropolitan Opera for the first time in more than a century next season, when the house presents the Finnish composer Kaija Saariahos ethereal LAmour de Loin, one of the most acclaimed operas of the 2000s.

description: HONG KONG  China has apparently deployed surface-to-air missiles on a disputed island in the South China Sea, escalating regional tensions with Chinas neighbors and the United States.

title: Free Tools to Keep Those Creepy Online Ads From Watching You
description: SAY youre doing a web search on something like the flu. The next thing you know, an ad for a flu remedy pops up on your web browser, or your video streaming service starts playing a commercial for Tylenol.

title: Bill Simmons Names His New Website the Ringer
description: The sports personality Bill Simmonss much anticipated new website has a name: the Ringer.

title: Should the Authorities Be Able to Access Your iPhone?
description: WASHINGTON  As a legal matter, the showdown between the Obama administration and Apple touched off Tuesday by the ruling of a federal magistrate judge in California turns on an 18th century law. More practically, though, it boils down to this question: Should you be able to lock your phone so securely that even the F.B.I. cannot open it?

title: Afghanistans Crippled Power Grid Exposes Vulnerability of Besieged Capital
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  When saboteurs crippled the Afghan capitals power supply last month, the tailors in Najeebullahs clothing shop had to abandon their electric sewing machines for hand-cranked models. Their output fell by half.

title: Prado Explains Decision to Withhold Works from Bosch Show
description: AMSTERDAM  The Prado museum in Madrid on Wednesday made public its reasons for revoking its loan of two paintings to a major Hieronymus Bosch retrospective in the artists hometown, s-Hertogenbosch, the Netherlands.

description: Donald J. Trump on Wednesday blamed Mitt Romneys selection of Paul Ryan as his running mate for costing Republicans the 2012 presidential election.

title: Taliban Used Child Soldiers in Kunduz Battle, Rights Group Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Child soldiers recruited by the Taliban were used in the battle to overrun the northern city of Kunduz last year, a prominent human rights organization said on Wednesday.

title: Car Bomb Strikes Military Convoy in Ankara, Killing 28, Officials Say
description: ISTANBUL  Turkey reeled on Wednesday from a deadly bombing of a military convoy in the capital, plunging its leaders deeper into crisis mode and underscoring the countrys vulnerability to the Syrian war and revitalized Kurdish insurgency.

title: Hillary Clinton Donors Hear Concerns About Nevada Outcome
description: Hillary Clintons campaign manager briefed some of her most loyal and active fund-raisers this morning about the upcoming Nevada caucuses and responded to frustrations among some of her donors that the campaign needed to do a better job of demonstrating its successful mobilization of grassroots activists and small donors.

title: Liberal Economists Raise More Red Flags on Bernie Sanderss Spending Plans
description: A group of leading liberal economists who served in the Obama and Clinton administrations have assessed the proposals of Bernie Sanders and concluded that the Vermont senators rosy economic projections do not add up.

title: In Neanderthals DNA, Ancient Humans May Have Left Genetic Mark
description: In 1997, scientists found the first scrap of Neanderthal DNA in a fossil. Since then, they have recovered genetic material, even entire genomes, from a number of Neanderthal bones, and their investigations have yielded a remarkable surprise: Today, 1 to 2 percent of the DNA in non-African people comes from Neanderthals.

title: Donald Trump Stays Away From Nevada as Caucuses Near
description: Donald J. Trump is not going this week to Nevada, where Republicans will hold their caucuses on Tuesday. While theres a dearth of reliable polling there, Mr. Trump is not worried about his prospects in the state.

description: Josep Font presents his latest fall designs for the Madrid based label.

description: Mr. Kors presents his latest fall looks.
