description: The dispute between Donald J. Trump and Pope Francis spilled onto the campaign trail on Thursday, turning the final days before the South Carolina primary into a surprising clash involving religion and politics.

title: Apple vs. Washington Over Encryption
description: To the Editor:

title: Woof. Woof. And Other Notes From the Dog Show.
description: I spent Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, attempting to make sense of the insane spectacle that is the annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

title: Ex-Official Says Medical Examiner Forced Her Out Over DNA Technique
description: A former official of the New York City medical examiners office sued the city on Thursday, claiming that she had been forced from her job, in part, for raising questions about the offices use of a novel form of DNA testing whose reliability had come under question.

title: Federal Reserves Risky Decision to Loosen Bank Capital
description: The Federal Reserve is playing with fire on bank capital.

title: Bernie Sanders Takes His Turn Meeting With Civil Rights Leaders
description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, aiming to cut into Hillary Clintons lead among black voters, met with the heads of nine civil rights organizations Thursday  two days after Mrs. Clinton met with the same group in New York.

title: Video Review: The 2016 MKX Aims Lincoln in the Right Direction
description: After years of indifference (and killing Mercury), Ford is putting serious effort into the Lincoln brand. Polarizing ads have raised awareness (no Matthew McConaughey jokes here, I promise), and new product is filling showrooms.

title: Finding Ways to Get Live TV on a Mac
description: Q. Do they still make USB television tuners for Mac? I cant seem to find any that work in this country. What are other options for cord-cutters and people without TVs to watch live television on a Mac?

title: Scout Willis (Quietly) Becomes a Designer
description: Were doing it all ourselves at this point, said Scout Willis, the 24-year-old daughter of Bruce Willis and Demi Moore. Yesterday, she held the first presentation for her new brand, Scouts General, on the third floor of the bistro Tinys in TriBeCa  and without any pushy, iPad-wielding publicists or doormen in sight, the atmosphere was serene. Its like a little respite from fashion week where people can come and have a few drinks, have some scones, chill out, she said.

title: Scout Willis Makes Her Fashion-Week Debut
description: The musician and daughter of Bruce Willis and Demi Moore showed the first collection for her new line, Scouts General.

title: Yankees Aroldis Chapman Vows to Resist a Potential Ban
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Aroldis Chapman, sweat beading on his forehead after an early morning workout on Thursday, stood at his locker in the Yankees clubhouse with his muscular, tattooed arms folded.

title: Rose McGowan Parties with Galore, Glenn OBrien Signs Book of Tweets
description: Galore magazine hosts a dinner and party in SoHo, while the longtime fashion columnist shares his favorite Twitter moments.

title: W.H.O. Recommends Contraception in Countries With Zika Virus
description: The World Health Organization issued a strong call on Thursday for the use of contraception in countries with the Zika virus, and said that women who had unprotected sex and feared infection should have access to emergency contraception, a recommendation that may not sit well with the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Bill Cosby Sues to Recover Money From Andrea Constand
description: Bill Cosby is seeking the return of money he gave in a confidential financial settlement to a woman who accuses him of drugging and sexually assaulting her in 2004, according to a complaint filed Thursday.

title: A Forgotten Master and a Curious Teenager
description: His paintings were exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art. His circle of friends included Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning and Milton Avery. The New York Times and other publications reviewed his work regularly.

title: Michigan Democrat Opposes Trans-Pacific Pact
description: WASHINGTON  A senior House Democrat who is among his partys top voices on trade came out against the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership on Thursday, further darkening the congressional outlook for the landmark agreement.

title: Rose McGowan Parties with Galore, Glenn OBrien Signs Book of Tweets
description: With fashion week winding down, there were still opportunities for intrepid revelers on Wednesday. At Parlor, a private club in SoHo, Galore magazine hosted a mobbed party. Rose McGowan, the actress and singer, described a recent film project. I broke into an abandoned drug dealers house, she said, wearing Helmut Lang and vintage Balenciaga. There was a copy of Mein Kampf in the stairwell.

title: A Brassy Concept Car Comes Back From the Dead
description: Automotive history is littered with the noble failures of ventures whose ambitions never quite matched reality.

title: Culinary Workers Union Wont Take Sides in Nevada Democratic Caucuses
description: LAS VEGAS  When it comes to labor powerhouses in Nevada, few organizations quite match the Culinary Workers Union: 57,000 strong, more than 50 percent Latino, with an 80-year history of labor advocacy on the Strip and a record of turning out its members in political campaigns.

title: Remember That Wedding Where We Ate Elk?
description: Chicken, beef or fish: These generic dinner options are disappearing from wedding menus as newlyweds seek ways to make sure their guests remember their special day. Increasingly, food is the hook.

title: Karlie Kloss, Blake Lively and Jay Z at amfARs Fashion Week Kickoff
description: amfAR hosted its unofficial kickoff to New York Fashion Week on Wednesday night, drawing Hollywood luminaries and models including Karlie Kloss and Blake Lively. See the photos, above.

title: Mohamed Hassanein Heikal, Prominent Egyptian Journalist, Dies at 92
description: CAIRO  Mohamed Hassanein Heikal, an Egyptian journalist and historian who was an alter ego to President Gamal Abdel Nasser and for a time became an informal adviser to President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, died here on Wednesday. He was 92.

title: Readers Respond: A Mothers Reckoning
description: Susan Dominuss review of A Mothers Reckoning by Sue Klebold, the mother of one of the two boys who killed 12 classmates and a teacher, and then killed themselves, at Columbine High School in 1999, has drawn more than 900 comments from Times readers. Ms. Dominus posits that the central question of the memoir is how parents can prevent a tragedy like the Columbine shooting. Some readers said there was no way. We are all just trying to do our best and there but for the grace of God go I, said The Writer Stuff of Missouri.

title: Knicks Look Within as the Trade Deadline Comes and Goes
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  As other teams made modest upgrades ahead of Thursday afternoons N.B.A. trade deadline, the Knicks gathered for practice with the same roster that had lost 10 of 11 games entering the All-Star break. The growing sense among the players was that improvement would need to come from within.

title: Zika Virus Rumors and Theories That You Should Doubt
description: Here is a look at the most prominent rumors and theories about Zika virus, along with responses from scientists.

title: That (Very, Very) Old Black Magic in The Witch
description: Its not long after The Witch begins that things get very, very dark. Within the first 10 minutes, the infant son of an isolated 17th-century Puritan family goes missing, snatched away and taken into the woods by the menacing title character. Lets just say she has no plans to keep the little boy safe.

title: Zika May Increase Risk of Mental Illness, Researchers Say
description: A baby with a shrunken, misshapen head is surely a heartbreaking sight. But reproductive health experts are warning that microcephaly may be only the most obvious consequence of the spread of the Zika virus.

title: How Have Pope Francis Comments About Donald Trump Affected Your Views?
description: Were interested in hearing from our Catholic readers about whether the back-and-forth between the pope and Mr. Trump has influenced how they think about the 2016 election.

title: Review: In The Cherry Orchard, the Myopia of an Aristocratic Family
description: Nothing happens in the plays of Anton Chekhov. But everything happens, too. People complain about restaurants, sing comic songs, make speeches in praise of bookcases even as theyre loving and losing and dying. Youll feel that paradox acutely in the Maly Drama Theaters The Cherry Orchard, Chekhovs final play, adapted and directed by Lev Dodin in ways both frustrating and wonderfully exciting.

title: Two Reunions, Bittersweet and Foreboding, in The Brothers Size
description: Early in The Brothers Size, I stopped trying to analyze why this play felt so alive. Instead I just trusted my emotions, and that made this production, at Luna Stage in West Orange, still more satisfying. Indeed, its easy to list the shows qualities: an outstanding cast, a powerful script, smart staging. Whats harder is describing its magic.

title: Movie Review: Race
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Race.

title: New Works From Kirsten Childs, Debate Society Will Be Part of Playwrights Horizons Season
description: The six plays and musicals making up the 2016-17 Playwrights Horizons season will feature new works by Adam Bock (A Small Fire), Dan LeFranc (The Big Meal) and Kirsten Childs (The Bubbly Black Girl Sheds Her Chameleon Skin), the Off Broadway theater company announced on Thursday.

title: Calvin Klein: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Francisco Costas latest collection for Calvin Klein.

title: Same Expectations for Yankees, but Further From Reach
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Jennifer Steinbrenner Swindal sat quietly in the back of a conference room Thursday at the ballpark that bears her fathers name. The Yankees manager, Joe Girardi, gave his annual spring training address, hopeful his team could do better after three years in a row without taking part in a playoff series. Nobody asked about his job security.

title: Movie Review: Embrace of the Serpent
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Embrace of the Serpent.

title: New Databases Offer Insights Into the Lives of Escaped Slaves
description: When slaves fled American and British farms and townhouses, their owners often placed detailed newspaper ads offering rewards to anyone who returned the fugitives. The written notices described the runaway slaves mannerisms, clothes, hairstyles, skin markings, teeth and skills, as well as information about plantations that the escapees might have tried to reach, hoping to reunite with family members or less cruel past owners.

title: Volkswagen Memos Suggest Company Misled U.S. Regulators
description: FRANKFURT  Volkswagen internal memos and emails suggest that company executives pursued a strategy of delay and obfuscation with United States regulators after being confronted in early 2014 with evidence that VW diesel vehicles were emitting far more pollutants than allowed.

title: Trump vs. Pope, Round 2
description: The headlines are blazing, Twitter is lit up, the political press is all hot for the kind of story it loves to tell: two huge celebrities attacking each other.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: Art in review, from Times critics.

title: Review: In The Witch, a Familys Contract With God Is Tested
description: A finely calibrated shiver of a movie, The Witch opens on a scene of religious wrath. On a New England plantation, around 1630, a true believer, William (Ralph Ineson), and his family are facing a grim assemblage. The setting is a kind of meeting house crowded with men, women and children, a congregation whose silence and unsmiling faces imply disapproval or perhaps fear. Whether theyre standing in judgment doesnt matter to William, whose arrogant faith in his own notion of Christianity is as deep and darkly unsettling as his sepulchral voice. Its the sort of soul-and-earth-quaking voice you can imagine one of the biblical patriarchs having, the kind that Abraham used on God and Isaac alike.

title: Movie Review: The Witch
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews The Witch.

title: Lively Vintage Photos of Supermodels and Superclubs
description: The photographer Nick Waplingtons new book captures a lately much longed-for cultural moment in New York Citys history, when supermodels ruled the runways and club kids held court at all hours. Waplington was introduced to the fashion designer Isaac Mizrahi by his mentor, the fashion photographer Richard Avedon, and was quickly welcomed into Mizrahis fashion fold, where he was a fly on the wall at fittings with Naomi, Christy and Linda. It was a very fun time to be in his studio, Waplington says. This was before cellphones, so various boyfriends of the models would call up on the office phone and theyd put them on speakerphone and have these funny, piss-taking conversations with them without them knowing that everyone was listening. This would happen with Spike Lee quite a lot when he was dating Veronica Webb.

title: The Isaac Mizrahi Pictures: New York City 1989-1993
description: Selections from the photographer Nick Waplingtons forthcoming photo book.

title: Supreme Court Appointment Could Reshape American Life
description: WASHINGTON  There is a reason Republican senators are so adamant in their refusal to let President Obama appoint a successor to Justice Antonin Scalia, a towering figure in conservative jurisprudence. An Obama appointment would be the most consequential ideological shift on the court since 1991, creating a liberal majority that would almost certainly reshape American law and American life.

title: Measuring the Planets Health in Vibrant Shades of Green
description: From space, Earth appears as a blue marble. But some researchers have been studying the planet through a different-colored lens: green.

title: At Wake for Staten Island Stabbing Victims, Tears and One Word: Why?
description: They were items that have no place in a funeral home: images of childrens toys, and a puppy and teddy bear made of pastel flowers.

title: Review: Twisted Sisters Hard Road and Drummer Shortage
description: We went through a succession of drummers, one member of the titular band in We Are Twisted _______ Sister! recalls at a relatively late point in this largely fascinating but arguably overlong documentary directed by Andrew Horn. That should ring a bell with aficionados of rock docs both actual and fictional, and the movie does contain further echoes of the classic comedy This Is Spinal Tap. A crucial difference is that this films subjects, and particularly the core members Jay Jay French and Dee Snider, are polar opposites of Taps pitifully un-self-conscious dim bulbs.

title: Spare Times for Children Listings for Feb. 19-25
description: How can you keep dozens of toddlers seated, quiet, focused and blissfully entertained for half an hour?

title: Review: Dmitri Hvorostovsky Sings of Life, Love and Sadness at Carnegie Hall
description: The charismatic baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky looked a little thin when he appeared at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday for a sold-out song recital. That was understandable. As the worldwide admirers of this great Russian artist know, Mr. Hvorostovsky, 53, has been undergoing treatments for a brain tumor that have caused him to cancel swaths of performances.

title: Spare Times for Feb. 19-25
description: American Museum of Natural History: Countdown to Zero (through early 2017) Smallpox is the only human disease to have been eradicated, but what about Guinea worm, polio, malaria and others? This exhibition, presented in collaboration with the Carter Center, examines international efforts to control and wipe out infection. Daily from 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m., Central Park West and 79th Street, 212-769-5200, amnh.org.

(By Calvin Klein Collection, naturally.)

title: Sugarplum Fairies and Cavaliers Move Ahead at City Ballet
description: A ballet company is a family. A retirement is a grievous loss, a role debut an exciting new stage of life. New York City Ballet presented an exceptional number of new Sugarplum Fairies and Cavaliers (in George Balanchines The Nutcracker) Christmas week; in the current six-week season (through Feb. 28), several of those dancers have acquired other new roles.

title: Schomburg Center Commemorates a 90-Year History
description: Readers of Weekend Miser know that New York City has no shortage of free and low-cost cultural events  after all, for the past five years the Miser has been highlighting them. Now the time has come to bid adieu, but not without one last column. And it seems fitting to include events through February, most with ties to Black History Month.

title: Review: A Lear With Hops, Spins and Posturing
description: This is not Lear, said the distinguished actress and dancer Valda Setterfield. She wasnt kidding. Although those are the lines written for the title character of King Lear, the Lear that had its United States premiere at New York Live Arts on Wednesday, a collaboration between Ms. Setterfield and the Irish choreographer-director John Scott, was a reduction of Shakespeares play in many senses, only one of which could be considered positive: The show lasts not much more than an hour.

description: The New York Times film critics review Embrace of the Serpent, The Witch and Race.

description: Photos from Iraq, Turkey, Yemen and Spain.

description: Proper scale has a beauty of its own.

title: Review: Love and Togetherness Capture the Arc of the Romantic Pursuit
description: In comedy, they say timing is everything. That goes double for romantic comedy. The genre is built on the tension between fate and circumstance: Two people are meant to be together, but the plot keeps them out of sync until divine order is restored.

title: Review: Rolling Papers Follows The Denver Post on the Marijuana Beat
description: Its not exactly Spotlight, but it is about journalists.

title: New West Bank Violence as Palestinian Boys Stab 2 Israelis
description: JERUSALEM  Two 14-year-old Palestinian boys fatally stabbed an off-duty Israeli soldier and wounded another Israeli man on Thursday in an Israeli supermarket in the occupied West Bank where Israelis and Palestinians work and shop together.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing: iPhone, Pope Francis, Donald Trump
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Review: Miranda Cuckson and Ekmeles Draw Links Across Time
description: Jagged lines crisscross the walls, floor and ceiling at National Sawdust, the performance space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. A visitor focusing on the white spaces in between might see a study in separation, each panel an ice floe isolated by channels of dark water. But train an eye on the black bands, and connections pop out as trajectories intersect, sometimes at wild angles.

title: Off the Runway: Final Day of New York Fashion Week
description: Sienna Miller at Ralph Lauren, Zo Kravitz at Calvin Klein and Kendall Jenner taking a break from walking the runway.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Review: Snowtime! Tells of an Escalating Snowball War
description: You dont realize how thoroughly a certain style of animated childrens movie has become the norm until you see one like Snowtime! that doesnt fit the mold. The slower pacing, the lack of authority figures who need to be defied or corrected, the subdued rather than out-front messages  this movie looks and feels quite different from most recent animated blockbusters.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Review: Risen, a Tale of Conversion Starring Joseph Fiennes
description: Unfolding like a clunky episode of Law & Order, the biblical procedural Risen confronts the Resurrection through the stiffly skeptical countenance of Joseph Fiennes, who takes on the role of Clavius, a Roman army tribune, as if it were a life sentence.

title: Capturing Human Moments Amid Chaos in Israel and the West Bank
description: In This Place, an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, life and photography and art cause sparks to fly. Its more than 600 images have been taken by 12 well-known photographers, and document life on one of the most contested stretches of land in the world: Israel and the West Bank, where Jews and Muslims, Israelis and Palestinians, Bedouins and Africans, among others, often live tensely side by side, and the threat of violence is never far away.

title: Review: In Forsaken, the Sutherlands Bond in the Old West
description: A starry father-son pairing is largely squandered in Forsaken, an old-school western that is a little too old school for its own good.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, Feb. 20 Through 28
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: This Fashion News Director Lounges Front Row in Pajamas
description: Name Anne Slowey

title: MoMA Plans a Fall Show Centered on Francis Picabia
description: Francis Picabia has always been tough to pin down.

title: Op Art Through a Latin Lens
description: In the winter of 1965, the Museum of Modern Art opened The Responsive Eye, the landmark show that introduced Op Art and related trends to the general public. It was the museums most popular exhibition to that date. Now, 51 years later, The Illusive Eye: An International Inquiry on Kinetic and Op Art at El Museo del Barrio looks back on that show and finds it wanting.

title: Lady Gaga: Marc Jacobss Most Talked About Model
description: For his fall/winter 2016 show, Marc Jacobs cast a special guest  Lady Gaga. The platform boots-habitu was slipped into the lineup of well-shod models, wearing an oversize coat with fur sleeves over a pussy-bow blouse. The designer also outfitted Gaga at Monday nights Grammy Awards in an ornate blue gown for the red carpet and a sequined white suit during her David Bowie tribute performance. (Another notable cameo in the show: Hillary Clinton, whose visage appeared on Jacobs-designed shirts worn by both a front-row Anna Wintour and the designer himself.)

title: Review: In Diamond Tongues, Leah Goldstein Plays a Flawed Actress
description: Diamond Tongues, an alternately sweet and slashing microbudget comedy from Canada, makes a great vehicle for Leah Goldstein, a musician and performance artist appearing in her first movie. As Edith, an aspiring actress who seems blind to her deficits and personal flaws, Ms. Goldstein gives a performance that requires her to swing between disarming and loathsome. She demonstrates impressive skill in slowly peeling away her characters charm.

description: LAS VEGAS  Senator Harry Reid of Nevada has had discussions with the head of the states most powerful union to make sure tens of thousands of casino workers can easily participate in the Democratic caucuses here on Saturday.

title: Citigroup Raises Chief Executives Pay 27%
description: Citigroup said on Thursday that it had granted its chief executive, Michael L. Corbat, a 27 percent pay raise, as the big bank crossed several hurdles on its way toward becoming a more profitable and stable company.

title: Review: Yo La Tengo and Alvin Lucier, With Balloons
description: The composer Alvin Lucier, now 84, is interested in repetition, long tones, overtones, music as process, music as directed improvisation, the perception of sound and any metaphorical ideas that might roll out of those perceptions like dividends.

title: Dont Knock New York, and Other Meanings of DKNY
description: What does DKNY stand for? Once upon a time it was Donna Karan New York, the younger, hipper, streetier sister of the Donna Karan collection.

title: Review: Trullo dOro Transports to Southern Italy
description: Trullo d Oro, a five-month-old restaurant in Hicksville, is the kind of warm and cozy Italian place that Long Islanders love. The homey old-world scene is set by red and white checked tablecloths, stucco walls dotted with copper pots and pans and, most of all, the friendly staff and owners.

title: Classical Music Listings for Feb. 19-25
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: An American President in Cuba
description: President Obama spoke passionately last year about the importance of term limits during a visit to Africa, where he argued that nobody should be president for life. His administration has been more muted on this issue in Latin America, where a handful of leaders have become strongmen disinclined to share or relinquish power.

title: Movie Listings for Feb. 19-25
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: The Met and a New Logo
description: Who knew a logo could cause such controversy?

title: Review: At Shell & Bones, a Sleek Space and a Dazzling View
description: What is it about a dazzling view that elevates a meal? Many of us have experienced how even humble fare, when paired with a knockout beachfront or mountaintop vista, can seem lavish.

title: Supreme Court Precedents That May Be at Risk
description: Divisive Supreme Court decisions are more likely to be re-examined  and possibly overturned  when a court changes. In the Roberts Court, 85 cases split 5 to 4 or 5 to 3 with Justice Scalia in the conservative majority, many with similar judicial themes.

title: Off the Runway: Final Day of New York Fashion Week
description: Scenes from the front row, backstage and outside the shows.

title: Review: At So Kong Dong, Korean Soups Bring Two Kinds of Heat
description: So Kong Dong in Fort Lee features only two kinds of dishes, a variety of soft tofu soups and barbecued ribs, but if youve never eaten Korean food, this is the place to try it.

title: Where the Owner Shucks and Serves
description: There is nothing about the plain-Jane exterior of the Northeast Oyster Company in Mamaroneck to suggest that culinary luxuries lie within. A utilitarian metal-frame door remains from the nail salon that occupied the space before; a hard-to-miss neon sign mounted above it advertises Puppies (the sign belongs to a pet shop in the same building). The menu is taped to a window, and if you cup your hands against the glass to peer inside, the stark walls and no-nonsense accouterments are less than promising.

title: Painting Overtakes Pixels in Aldrich Museum Exhibition
description: For the first time in more than 20 years, the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum is filled exclusively with paintings. Painting in Four Takes presents concurrent solo exhibitions of four contemporary painters: Steve DiBenedetto, Hayal Pozanti, Julia Rommel and Ruth Root. Each artist has a distinctive toolbox of motifs and methods, resulting in works that are wildly different. But considered together, the shows attest to the flourishing of painting in a culture that is saturated by digital images, and to the expressive power of paint applied in all its variations by the human hand.

title: Bernie Sanders Cuts Into Hillary Clintons Lead in New National Poll
description: Senator Bernie Sanders has made significant inroads into Hillary Clintons national lead with likely Democratic voters, according to a poll released Thursday that showed him riding a surge of momentum after his landslide victory in New Hampshire last week.

title: Dialysis Equipment Maker Settles Lawsuit for $250 Million
description: The worlds largest provider of kidney dialysis equipment and services has agreed to pay $250 million to settle thousands of lawsuits from dialysis patients and their relatives claiming that the companys products had caused heart problems and deaths.

title: In New Paltz, the Soaring Art of Andrew Lyght
description: Andrew Lyght: Full Circle, at the Samuel Dorsky Museum of Art at the State University of New York at New Paltz, soars on the arc of a simple line. Mr. Lyght blurs all distinctions between drawing, painting, sculpture, digital photography and installation art. Each iteration of his distinct style charts the personal odyssey of a naturalized African-American artist from Guyana  a small South American nation  to Montreal, to Brooklyn, to Europe and, finally, to Kingston, N.Y., the birthplace of Americas first indigenous art movement, the Hudson River School. This stunning show, a long overdue retrospective exhibition for this artist, spins the stuff of American art  its diversity, proud identity, independence and gritty determination  full circle.

title: At Marc Jacobs, Dark Makeup as Theatrical as the Clothes
description: The first thing he said was that the whole show is black, said Franois Nars before Marc Jacobss fall/winter 2016 show this evening  a directive Nars translated into makeup looks as dramatic and theatrical as the clothing itself. Nars intended, he explained, for the models to look like performers, characters and artists, rather than a monotonous army. He achieved this diversity by way of six monochromatic looks, drawing inspiration from muses ranging from Alice Cooper to New York underground club kids.

title: Why Apple Is Right to Challenge an Order to Help the F.B.I.
description: It is understandable that federal investigators want to unlock an iPhone used by one of the attackers who killed 14 people in San Bernardino, Calif., in December. And its understandable that the government would turn to Apple for help. But Apple is doing the right thing in challenging the federal court ruling requiring that it comply.

title: Young Supporter Asks for a Hug, and Gets One From John Kasich
description: CLEMSON, S.C.  The young man chosen by Gov. John R. Kasich to ask the last question at an event at Clemson University on Thursday started off by saying he did not want to get too emotional.

title: Kenneth Griffin Joins Elite Rank of Hedge Fund Art Patrons With $500 Million Deal
description: Step aside, Steven A. Cohen, there is another billionaire hedge fund manager with a voracious appetite for historic, and expensive, art.

title: Times Readers Weigh In on the Apple Debate
description: The tech industrys long-running dispute with the government over encryption practices flared when Apple this week opposed a court order for the technology company to unlock an iPhone used by one of the San Bernardino, Calif., killers.

title: Is Apple Right in Defying the F.B.I.?
description: Apple has said it will not comply with a federal court order to unlock the iPhone of one of the San Bernardino attackers. Commenters online weigh privacy versus security in an age of terrorism.

title: Specter of Corruption Hangs Over Special Elections for New York Legislature
description: From the day the men were convicted on corruption charges and stripped of their caramel leather seats in the State Legislature, it seemed safe to assume that the special elections to replace Sheldon Silver and Dean G. Skelos would come down to which of their would-be successors could offer the greatest contrast to the two politicians.

title: Turkeys, Running Amok, Are a Success Story in New Jersey
description: HILLSDALE, N.J.  In some neighborhoods of this placid New Jersey borough in Bergen County, they are seemingly everywhere  waddling by the dozen in the road, perched on car roofs, pecking at the tires of delivery trucks.

title: How Tim Cook, in iPhone Battle, Became a Bulwark for Digital Privacy
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Letters from around the globe began pouring into the inbox of Timothy D. Cook not long after the publication of the first revelations from Edward J. Snowden about mass government surveillance.

title: President Obama Is Criticized Over Funeral for Scalia
description: WASHINGTON  The White House on Thursday tried to fend off criticism of President Obamas decision not to attend the funeral this weekend of Justice Antonin Scalia, but even some administration allies lamented the move as a missed opportunity to ease the partisan warfare that has followed the justices death.

title: Marc Jacobs: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Mr. Jacobs closes New York fashion week with his latest designs.

title: Review: The White Stag Quadrilogy Hits the Way Back Machine
description: Sparely staged but unrelentingly verbose, Christopher Ford and Dakota Roses comedy The White Stag Quadrilogy, now at Dixon Place, aims to send up 1970s Hollywood (and a bit of the 1980s), but succeeds largely in skewering itself. The show, from the troupe On the Rocks, is a sequel of sorts to Wolfert, a 2015 production at Dixon Place, directed, like White Stag, by Ms. Rose and starring many of the same performers.

title: Michael Bloomberg Hints at Reasons for Candidacy, but Doesnt Announce It
description: Denouncing the corrupt gridlock in Washington and wage stagnation across the country, Michael R. Bloomberg bemoaned a lack of solutions from the 2016 presidential candidates on Thursday night, the most explicit rationale he has offered for why he is considering a third-party campaign of his own.

title: Agreement Clears the Way for Airdrops of Humanitarian Aid in Syria
description: GENEVA  Most of the Russian and American aircraft traversing Syria have been warplanes firing missiles and dropping bombs. But under an international agreement to aid Syrians trapped in the fighting, Russian planes will soon be dropping food in an operation partly financed by the United States.

title: Injury Delays Culmination of Amanda Kessels Career
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Saturday is Senior Day for the University of Minnesota womens hockey team, so earlier this week, Amanda Kessel joined the other four members of her graduating class for an on-ice photo at Ridder Arena, their home rink. Kessel smiled, though the whole thing felt a bit weird. Kessel arrived with the class of 2014, not 2016. This became her class by happenstance.

title: Terry Collins Welcomes Greater Expectations for the Mets
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  By 10 a.m. Thursday, fans lined the chain-link fences at the Mets complex here, hoping to get an autograph on the day before the teams pitchers and catchers were to hold their first official workout. One fan lit a cigar, as if he were belatedly celebrating last seasons euphoric turnaround. Inside the complex, Fred Wilpon, the Mets 79-year-old owner, shook hands and greeted players after early batting practice, making his presence known.

title: Apples Line in the Sand Was Over a Year in the Making
description: WASHINGTON  Time and again after the introduction of the iPhone nearly a decade ago, the Justice Department asked Apple for help opening a locked phone. And nearly without fail, the company agreed.

title: Francis Says Contraception Can Be Used to Slow Zika
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Pope Francis shook up an already intense debate over birth control and abortion in Latin American countries where the Zika virus is causing a public health emergency by declaring on Thursday that contraceptives could be used to prevent the spread of Zika, which researchers have linked to a spike in cases of babies born with severe brain damage.

title: Public Split Between Concern Over Terrorism and Privacy
description: The clash between federal law enforcement and Apple mirrors the divide in public opinion between the desire for security from terrorism and the fear of losing basic civil liberties.

title: Jeb Bush and Ted Cruz Have the Most to Lose in South Carolina
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  It is not yet clear which Republican presidential candidate will emerge from Saturdays South Carolina primary with the biggest boost. But it is becoming increasingly apparent which two would suffer most from a disappointing performance.

title: The Eyes Have It in Little Erik
description: Identities get twisted in strange ways in Little Erik, a new adaptation of Ibsens Little Eyolf having its premiere at the Aurora Theater in Berkeley, Calif. Written and directed by Mark Jackson, the play moves the action of the 1894 family drama, one of Ibsens lesser-known works, to present-day Marin, Calif., where tech wealth meets hippie bohemianism. What remains from Ibsen are the mysterious domestic goings on, involving a troubled couple, a sister who may not be a sister and a boy and a girl both named Erik.

title: A Gas Leak Is Capped, but Neighbors Are Wary
description: LOS ANGELES  With a mix of pride and great relief, state officials here announced on Thursday that the leaking natural gas well near the Porter Ranch neighborhood  which over the last four months had pumped thousands of tons of methane and other chemicals into the atmosphere, sickening residents and prompting more than 6,000 households to flee  had finally been capped permanently.

title: Donald Trump Fires Back at Sharp Rebuke by Pope Francis
description: In his most audacious attack yet on a revered public figure, Donald J. Trump veered into risky political territory on Thursday as he denounced Pope Francis, seeking to galvanize Republicans who worry about border security and appeal to evangelical voters who regard Francis as too liberal.

title: Days After a Win, Vaughn Taylors Head Is Still in the Clouds
description: LOS ANGELES  The last player standing at the Pebble Beach National Pro-Am on Sunday was the first in his threesome to hit at the start of the Northern Trust Open on Thursday. Without fanfare, the starter announced, From Augusta, Georgia, please welcome Vaughn Taylor.

title: Jordan Spieth Slumps to 8-Over 79 at Riviera
description: LOS ANGELES  On the 18th hole, Jordan Spieths playing competitor and friend Justin Thomas had a tap-in putt for par and a round of 70. Thomas asked the third member of the group, Fred Couples, if he would be stepping in his through line if he putted out.

title: Ukraine: Unicef Warns of Conflicts Toll on Children
description: More than 500,000 children in eastern Ukraine have been deeply affected by the trauma of living through the violent conflict between government forces and insurgents that began two years ago, the United Nations Childrens Fund, Unicef, said in a report issued Thursday, and many need psychological and social support. Two years of violence, shelling and fear have left an indelible mark on thousands of children in eastern Ukraine, Giovanna Barberis, the Unicef representative in Ukraine, said in the report. More than 200,000 of these children have been displaced from their homes, one out of five schools has been damaged or destroyed and more than 20 children have been killed, the report said.

title: Cliven Bundy and Sons Charged in Case That Gave Rise to Oregon Standoff
description: DENVER  They are accused of launching a massive armed assault on federal officials, gaining hundreds of followers by spreading lies on the Internet, and encouraging their supporters to take sniper positions on highway bridges above government agents, unarmed adults and children.

title: James Clyburn, Leading Black Politician in South Carolina, Will Endorse Hillary Clinton
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Representative James E. Clyburn plans to endorse Hillary Clinton for president on Friday, giving her campaign a powerful seal of approval from one of the most influential Democrats in South Carolina and the leading black politician in the state.

title: Study Investigates Proliferation of Plastic in Waterways Around New York
description: KEYPORT, N.J.  At the office of NY/NJ Baykeeper, an environmental group, Sandra Meola spread out her haul. For six months last year, she plied the bays and rivers around New York City, skimming the shimmering surface with a fine-mesh net in search of her nemesis: plastic.

title: Marissa Mayer Meets Yahoo Developers at a Confrontation-Free Gathering
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Many of the people attending Yahoos mobile developer conference on Thursday were not there for the traditional business of striking deals or learning more about the companys products.

title: Actors in Pornographic Films Fight Proposal to Enforce Safety Regulations
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The California pornographic film industry turned out in force Thursday to oppose regulations that would have forced actors to wear condoms and, in some cases, goggles, face shields or rubber gloves when on camera.

title: Review: Old Hats, Mime and Mayhem From Irwin and Shiner
description: The boys are back in town, with a new accompanist who gives their mild shenanigans an unexpected edge.

title: Born Composers
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Themed Friday puzzle alert! Dont panic, this happens occasionally.

title: Review: The Humans Depicts a Family, and a Country, Under Pressure
description: Doing life twice sounds like the only thing worse than doing it once, says the beleaguered paterfamilias of The Humans, Stephen Karams piercingly funny, bruisingly sad comedy-drama about an American family teetering on the edge of the abyss.

title: Unpublished Black History: Your Photos
description: Submit your own #unpublishedblackhistory photos.

title: Court Delays Officers Trials in Freddie Gray Case
description: Marylands highest court on Thursday postponed the trials of the Baltimore police officers charged in the death of Freddie Gray last year, to consider whether one officer can be compelled to testify against the others.

title: Bernie Sanders Takes Rappers Graphic Remark and Seeks a More Diplomatic Phrasing
description: LAS VEGAS  Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont on Thursday defended the rapper Killer Mikes remark this week that a uterus doesnt qualify you to be president, saying in more prosaic terms that voters should not pick candidates based on their sex.

title: Conservatives Say as No-Show, Rubio Showed True Colors
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  Mark Levin, the conservative radio mega-host, looked out on the crowd in an arena here, searching for his missing senator.

title: Donald Trump Said He Favored Iraq Invasion in 2002 Interview
description: Donald J. Trump, who has made his claim of having opposed the Iraq War in 2003 a centerpiece of his stump speech, said in a 2002 interview with the radio host Howard Stern that he favored the invasion.

title: In Defense of Trump, Some Point (Wrongly) to Vatican Walls
description: Supporters of Donald J. Trump were quick to suggest on Thursday that Pope Francis was being hypocritical to criticize as un-Christian Mr. Trumps proposal to build a wall between the United States and Mexico because the pontiff himself lives in Vatican City, a small state with sturdy walls of its own.

title: Taiwan Earthquake Search Uncovers Body of Last Missing Person
description: HONG KONG  Officials in Taiwan said on Friday that workers had found the body of the last person still listed as missing after the collapse of a 17-story building in an earthquake on Feb. 6.

title: Forget the Calendar. Its Spring.
description: Players began to report to spring training, which is baseballs version of global warming  a way to make it spring before it really is.

title: What to Watch Friday
description: A perfect couple or not? Judd Apatow and company put romance under a microscope in Love. And Michael Pollan brings his book Cooked to life.

title: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Reach Out to Latino Voters in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS  Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders each tried to prove their commitment to immigration reform at a bilingual town hall-style forum on Thursday, days before this heavily Latino state will hold its Democratic caucuses.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: A lot of people now speak with a Nigerian accent here very well thanks to Nollywood.

title: Corrections: February 19, 2016
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Donald Trump and Jeb Bush Lighten Up at South Carolina Event
description: Donald J. Trump appeared to soften his tone in his fight with Pope Francis on Thursday night during a town-hall-style forum hosted by CNN, calling the pope a wonderful guy and adding, I dont think this is a fight.

title: Photographs as Clues to a Mysterious Bohemian Life
description: Robert James Campbell died homeless and isolated in Vermont. Then Jessica Ferber spent 13 years trying to piece together his biography.

title: Truth, Reconciliation and Now, a Prosecution in South Africa
description: GEORGE, South Africa  By the standards of its time, the disappearance was almost routine.

title: Dispute Over Kurds Threatens U.S.-Turkey Alliance
description: Escalating tensions between Turkey and the United States, which now jeopardize their alliance in the Syria conflict, can be traced to the Kurds, a Middle East people who do not have a state of their own. Here are five questions about the Kurds and their role in the rapidly evolving events in Syria and Turkey:

title: Photographs as Clues to a Mysterious Bohemian Life
description: Robert James Campbell grew up wealthy and died homeless and mostly alone; only two people attended his funeral. Jessica Ferber was 23 years old, newly graduated from the University of Vermont and hanging around Burlington, working days in a photo lab and nights as a cocktail waitress. The homeless-services agency that served Mr. Campbell wanted someone to look through the boxes of photographs he left behind. What did she have to lose?

title: A Little Reality on Immigration
description: Donald Trump built his campaign on the promise to build a wall along the Mexican border. The idea is attention-grabbing (and unworkable). But the striking thing is that its not too far away from the current Republican orthodoxy.

title: In Paris, the Secular Is the Holy
description: PARIS  For most of us, Paris is a stage; we expect a performance in the scenes of daily life, from the exquisite way a tiny child is dressed to the steam rising from soupe  loignon to statues of long-dead philosophers lit by the spotlight of a winter sun.

title: Varieties of Voodoo
description: Americas two big political parties are very different from each other, and one difference involves the willingness to indulge economic fantasies.

title: How Bernie Sanders Plays in Vegas
description: Las Vegas  MARYLAND PARKWAY, a street in central Las Vegas best known for its gritty shopping centers and petty crime, is now home to a brightly lit campaign office. Cartoon portraits of an aging senator with oversize glasses and wild cowlicks hang around the main room. On the wall is a growing collage of handwritten signs explaining Why Im voting for Bernie: because Minimum wage is not enough, because College should not be a financial obstacle, because I am a socialist.

title: When States Fight to Overturn Good Local Labor Laws
description: Local government is theoretically a cornerstone of democracy. But as a practical matter, conservative state legislatures have often blocked progressive local laws. Many states, for example, have laws on their books to pre-empt local restrictions on guns and pesticides.

title: When the Public Defender Says, I Cant Help
description: New Orleans  ON an ordinary day, the Criminal District Court here begins with a parade of handcuffed and shackled defendants being led out from cages behind the judges bench by sheriffs deputies. They are clad in orange jumpsuits and are almost exclusively African-American men. They rattle and shuffle their way onto benches and into the empty jury box, waiting for the judge.

title: Lung Cancer Deaths Soar in Chinas Steel Country, Report Says
description: HONG KONG  The death rate from lung cancer in the heavily industrialized province surrounding Beijing has more than quadrupled in the last four decades, with researchers pointing to worsening air pollution as a likely culprit, according to a local cancer hospital and a report published Friday in an influential Chinese news outlet.

title: EFG International in Talks to Acquire BTG Pactuals Swiss Business
description: LONDON  The private banking and asset management firm EFG International said on Friday that it was in talks on the acquisition of BSI, the Swiss private banking arm of the Brazilian investment bank BTG Pactual.

title: My Parents, My Landlords
description: When Jessica Sanderoff graduated from college a decade ago and began searching for Manhattan apartments in her price range, she saw many things. Fourth-floor walk-ups and fifth-floor walk-ups. Apartments that seemed smaller than the boxes for the shoes she designs. Old run-down apartments and older run-down apartments. Apartments in sketchy neighborhoods and apartments that were a hike to the subway.

title: Storm Water, Long a Nuisance, May Be a Parched Californias Salvation
description: LONG BEACH, Calif.  The winter rains finally arrived in Southern California, bringing drenching relief in recent days to a part of the nation suffering one of the worst droughts in history. But the El Nio storms brought something else as well: a reminder of lost opportunity, on display in this coastal city, as millions of gallons of storm water slipped down the usually dry Los Angeles River and out into San Pedro Bay.

title: Justice Antonin Scalia Honored at Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON  Justice Antonin Scalias body arrived at the Supreme Court on Friday morning and was carried up the courthouses grand marble steps, through two rows of men and women in dark suits, to its majestic Great Hall, not far from the courtroom where he dominated the courts arguments for three decades and helped shape American law.

title: Race in Nevada, Once a Hillary Clinton Firewall, Is Now Hotly Contested
description: LAS VEGAS  In a storefront on this citys heavily Latino east side, the civil rights leader Dolores Huerta rallied a dozen volunteers for Hillary Clinton on Wednesday night, relating in Spanish a Mexican saying about people who go near a cactus only when it is bearing fruit.

title: Fighting Truancy Among Indias Teachers, With a Pistol and a Stick
description: DEORIA, India  The young man, having skipped school, was there to plead his case, but Manoj Mishra was having none of it. When the truant offered a letter from a relative of a government minister pleading for leniency, Mr. Mishra grabbed it and, with a frown, tore it in half and dropped it to the floor.

title: A Donald Trump Victory Could Clash With South Carolinas Self-Image
description: SUMMERVILLE, S.C.  Republicans in South Carolina have in recent years raced ahead of the national party in presenting an inclusive face to voters: Since 2010, the state has elected an Indian-American governor and the countrys only black Republican senator, and its Republican-controlled Legislature voted last summer to remove the Confederate battle flag from the grounds of the Capitol.

title: How Much Warmer Was Your City in 2015?
description: Interactive chart showing high and low temperatures and precipitation for 3,116 cities around the world.

title: The Timess Classic Weather Chart: Now Online with 3,000 Cities
description: Highlights from an interactive weather graphic, and a look at how the chart has evolved in the past years.

title: U.S. Bombing in Libya Reveals Limits of Strategy Against ISIS
description: CAIRO  American warplanes bombed a seaside town in Libya early Friday aiming to kill a militant commander linked to attacks on Western tourists. But the mission also highlighted the widening gap between American military operations and diplomatic efforts to bring peace and stability to a tumultuous region.

title: Lorna Borenstein of Grokker: Invest in People for the Long Term
description: This interview with Lorna Borenstein, founder and C.E.O. of Grokker, a provider of online cooking, yoga and fitness videos, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Kamasi Washington Is Coming to SummerStage in 2016
description: SummerStage, the free concert series presented each year by the City Parks Foundation, will place an emphasis on jazz in its coming season. Among the more than 130 scheduled events this summer spanning music, dance, theater and film, in parks throughout the city  there will be a higher ratio of jazz performances, including a free concert by the tenor saxophonist Kamasi Washington on June 18 in Central Park.

title: Fashion Weeks Shift Toward Diversity
description: I havent heard applause like that for one of Zacs shows in a long time, said Bethann Hardison, a former model and agent, and an industry gadfly for diversity. Zac set the tone for the rest of the week.

title: Morning Agenda: Kenneth Griffin Joins Top Rank of Art Patrons
description: KENNETH GRIFFIN JOINS TOP RANK OF ART PATRONS | Step aside, Steven A. Cohen, theres another hedge fund manager with a voracious appetite for historic, and expensive, art.
