description: Question:

title: Your Friday Briefing: Harper Lee, Apple, Antonin Scalia
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know to start your day.

title: What Luck Means Now
description: The room where Ill spend the day, if I am lucky, is fluorescent-lit, lined with hard plastic chairs, and has a reminder on the wall concerning the importance of hand sanitizer. Though friends offered to accompany me, I am here alone.

title: Conservative Planning for Supreme Court Vacancy Predates Antonin Scalias Death
description: When the word broke last Saturday that Justice Antonin Scalia had died, the field of Republican candidates had already spent time in South Carolina discussing the possibility of a vacancy.

title: In Nod to Law Enforcement in Apple Case, Obama Ends Attempt to Straddle Privacy Divide
description: WASHINGTON  For years, President Obama has struggled to reconcile a civil libertarians belief in personal privacy with a commander in chiefs imperatives for the nations security.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Fat Cats and Brain-Boosting Exercise
description: Take the Quiz

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Frankfurt

title: New York Today: Hollywood on the Hudson
description: Updated, 9:31 a.m.

title: The Rsum and References Check Out. How About Social Media?
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Battle Over Nominating New Supreme Court Justice Spills Onto Phone Lines
description: Martin Sheens most famous White House role was as President Josiah Bartlet in The West Wing. But he also played A. J. MacInerney, chief of staff to President Andrew Shepherd, in The American President. President Shepherd, portrayed by Michael Douglas, was a former governor of Wisconsin, and presumably Mr. MacInerney, the presidents longtime best friend, had fictional Wisconsin ties as well.

title: New Yorks Week in Pictures: Feb. 19
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include scenes from the Lunar New Year parade in Chinatown and a darkened Grand Central Terminal.

title: How to Lull a Grown-Up to Sleep
description: Dont do baby talk or have a parental tone, says Drew Ackerman, a librarian in the San Francisco Bay Area and the host of Sleep With Me, a podcast designed to help adult listeners fall asleep. Your subject matter can be mature, but keep it sedative in nature; avoid topics like religion, politics, sex, violence and spiders. Be careful not to overengage your audience. Im always asking myself, Do I need to make it more boring? Ackerman says. Your goal is not to get your listeners to stay with you to the finish; it is to lose them along the way.

title: The 2.7.16 Issue
description: RE: The Ethicist

title: Learning to Recycle in Switzerland, and Paying for It
description: After I moved to Bern, Switzerland, from Jaibling, Germany, some time ago, I was very careful to adapt to Swiss ways, whenever I could make them out. I paid particular attention to the garbage, dividing it into various containers to be recycled, as was required of all citizens. There were glass, metal, compost, unidentified mixed waste, cardboard and of course paper. It was quite simple, except the paper part. I didnt find any bins, and there were no special bags to be bought as for other types of trash. So I asked my friend and landlord how to go about it.

title: Threshold of the Oblivious Blossoming
description: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.

title: At Ski Resorts, a Giant Hot Tub Is a Good-Time Machine
description: Several ski seasons ago Mark Bell, the hotel manager at Sunshine Mountain Lodge in the Canadian ski resort Sunshine Village, had an idea: Lets throw parties in the propertys gigantic hot tub, which is big enough for 40 people.

title: Deborah Berke Makes a Night at a Museum a Reality
description: Deborah Berkes appointment last year as the first female dean of the Yale School of Architecture might have brought her into the limelight, but the architect and interior designer had already been getting attention for her work on 21c Museum Hotels, a small chain of boutique properties doubling as art galleries.

title: The Informant and the Filmmakers
description: When she was 15, growing up in suburban Maryland, Lyric Cabral decided on two things: She wanted to be a photojournalist, and she wanted to live in Harlem. Five years later, in 2002, she found her first apartment in the neighborhood. One afternoon, after stopping to say hello to a friend at a vegan juice bar on 125th Street, she found herself talking to a man at the counter.

title: Unfavorable Signs for Ted Cruz in South Carolina
description: The Ted Cruz campaign has made it very clear how it believes its candidate can win the nomination: by unifying the partys ideologically consistent and self-described very conservative base with the somewhat more populist, evangelical voters who make up the partys rank and file in the South.

title: A Civil Rights Warrior, Armed With Spoons and Thank-You Notes
description: In the late winter of 1961, as Willis Reed and his basketball teammates at Grambling State in Louisiana prepared for the N.A.I.A. tournament, their head coach scheduled an unusual sort of practice session. This one would be led by Mildred Moss, a professor of home economics, and it would include topics like the place settings at a formal dinner and the proper use of cutlery.

title: Last Chance for Final Arguments in South Carolina and Nevada
description: For the third time in three weeks, voters will head to polls and caucus sites on Saturday to choose a winner among Republicans in South Carolina and among Democrats in Nevada.

title: Poetry Pairing | Invitation to Love
description: Februarys Poetry Pairing features Paul Laurence Dunbars poem Invitation to Love and a 2012 City Room blog post, From a Familiar Stranger, a Poem Written on the Stars, by Bill Hayes.

title: Former Student Sues Harvard Over Handling of Sexual Crimes Complaints
description: A lawsuit filed by a Harvard graduate who said she was sexually assaulted by a fellow student and then forced by the university to live in the same dorm as her attacker accuses the institution of failing to protect her and of creating a culture of silence about sexual violence.

title: Facebook Post Revives Debate on Whether Monotheists Worship Same God
description: In December, Larycia Hawkins, an associate professor at Wheaton College, an evangelical Christian school near Chicago, posted on Facebook a photograph of herself wearing a hijab, with the caption: I stand in religious solidarity with Muslims because they, like me, a Christian, are people of the book. And as Pope Francis stated last week, we worship the same God.

title: Resort and Tour News: Ski Deals; Margaritas in Santa Fe
description: SKI DEALS ACROSS THE AMERICAN WEST ...

title: Speak Uighur? Have Good Vision? Chinas Security Services Want You
description: BEIJING  As Chinese college students return to campus after the Lunar New Year vacation, some may be fretting about their chances of finding a good job in a slowing economy. But those who speak Japanese or Uighur, have a well-proportioned physique and are not too shortsighted may be in luck: They could become state security agents.

title: Nairobi Parks Lions, a Draw for Tourists, Take a Trip of Their Own
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  This city is known as a gateway to excellent wildlife, but apparently for a pride of lions that was not quite good enough.

title: A New Yorker With a Southern Accent
description: Dear Diary:

title: Pacific Northwest Ballet Returns to City Center
description: Once upon a time, Peter Boal was a prince  that is, of New York City Ballet, where he danced until 2005. Then, he went to Seattle, to become the artistic director of Pacific Northwest Ballet. But Mr. Boal cant seem to stay away for long. The company returns to City Center with a pair of repertory programs and live music. In Contemporary Innovators, Mr. Boal pays homage to William Forsythe, whose The Vertiginous Thrill of Exactitude (1996), a ballet set to Schubert, will be performed alongside works by two of Mr. Forsythes former dancers: David Dawson (A Million Kisses to My Skin) and Crystal Pite (Emergence). The other program, dedicated to George Balanchine, shows Mr. Boals City Ballet roots with Square Dance, Prodigal Son and Stravinsky Violin Concerto. That one is a slam dunk. (All Balanchine, 7:30 p.m., Wednesday and Thursday; Contemporary Innovators, 8 p.m. Wednesday through Sunday, nycitycenter.org.)

title: When a Dream House Becomes a Money Pit
description: Any buyer knows that a dream home can become a nightmare. But most people dont expect it to happen to them.

title: Morgan Freeman, Hollywoods Voice of God, Narrates Ad for Hillary Clinton
description: The character actor Reg E. Cathey, best known for portraying Freddy Hayes of Freddys barbecue restaurant in the Netflix drama House of Cards, has narrated several ads for Senator Bernie Sanders.

title: Bound for Glory on Video: This Land Was Guthries Land
description: In 1976, an obscure, one-term Georgia governor with a progressive agenda was elected president of the United States. Appropriately enough, that year was notable for a rise in Hollywoods interest in American folk heroes, old and new.

title: Ted Cruz Closes Gap on Donald Trump in South Carolina, New Poll Says
description: The Republican race in South Carolina has edged closer a day before voters cast their ballots, according to a new poll that shows Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz neck and neck.

title: Maybe Its Time to Look at New Credit Card Offers
description: Americans tend to be loyal to their credit cards, even as better offers emerge, a new report finds.

title: 1916: Aftermath of Erzerums Fall
description: LONDON  Reverberations of the fall of Erzerum are rumbling throughout the enemy countries, the most severe shock being manifested in Constantinople, where friction between the Prussian military authorities and the Turks has almost reached the snapping point and has already resulted in the fall of several official heads.

title: Positions Become Sharper in Apple Showdown
description: The two sides of the Apple versus law enforcement debate are coming into sharper focus.

title: Yahoo Takes a Step Toward a Possible Sale
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In what may turn out to be the beginning of the end of a fabled Internet company, Yahoo started a formal process on Friday that could result in selling all or parts of its business.

title: Veterans Want Past Discharges to Recognize Post-Traumatic Stress
description: WASHINGTON  Kristofer Goldsmith was discharged from the Army at the height of the Iraq war because he was not on a plane to Baghdad for his second deployment. Instead, he was in a hospital after attempting suicide the night before.

title: Donald Trump Doesnt Need High Vote Percentages to Pile Up Delegates
description: If the polls are right, Donald Trump will win South Carolina on Saturday by a double-digit margin.

title: British Retailers Straight Croissants Leave Some Bent Out of Shape
description: LONDON  The croissant, the buttery breakfast pastry, means crescent in French. But dont tell that to the British.

title: Marketing Guns to Children
description: The gun industry markets a variety of products explicitly to children, a new report shows, from armed stuffed animals to lighter versions of rifles. And some see kids as a vital group of future gun buyers who need to be brought into the fold at a young age.

title: For Mark Rylance, Steven Spielberg to the Rescue (Sort of)
description: Its been a dazzling past year for Mark Rylance, a bona fide star of screen and stage currently in the play Nice Fish, at St. Anns Warehouse. The multiple Tony-winning British thespian wowed audiences with his Emmy-nominated turn as Thomas Cromwell in Wolf Hall, based on the novel by Hilary Mantel, and then with his powerfully understated Oscar-nominated performance as Rudolf Abel in Steven Spielbergs Bridge of Spies. Both onscreen roles also earned him Golden Globes nominations, and he won a Bafta for the Bridge of Spies performance this past weekend (He also is starring in Mr. Spielbergs coming film The BFG, based on the Roald Dahl book of that title.) At the Globes last month, the Bagger chatted with the ever amiable Mr. Rylance, who was wearing a brown fedora with his tux, as he made his jolly way down the red carpet. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation.

title: Thomas King, Head of Barclays Investment Bank, to Retire
description: LONDON  Thomas King, the American in charge of the investment banking business at Barclays, is set to retire from the lender next month, the London-based bank said on Friday.

title: Palau Gets Tough On Sea Crimes: Reporters Notebook
description: Ian Urbina shares some of the back story behind his reporting on efforts to police waters around the island nation of Palau.

title: Palau Gets Tough on Sea Crime: Reporters Notebook
description: Exploring lawlessness on the high seas opened a window into a dark world. On the Outlaw Ocean, stowaways are cast overboard and left to die hundreds of miles from land. Workers are enslaved through debt or forced onto ships, sometimes for years. Hardly anyone is held accountable for the thousands of seafarers, fishermen and migrants who die every year because of unsafe vessels, territorial disputes and violence aboard ships. Murder is committed on camera, witnesses pose for selfies, footage is posted online, but no one investigates. Ships intentionally dump more oil and sludge into the ocean every three years than the Deepwater Horizon and Exxon Valdez spills combined. Reporting this series over the past 20 months, I found that crimes at sea result not from an absence of law, but from a lack of enforcement.

title: 1941: Turkey Protests Views of Treaty
description: SOFIA  Only two days after the signature of the Bulgarian-Turkish declaration of non-aggression a heated controversy has arisen over its interpretation, involving not only the two countries directly concerned but also other Balkan nations and other powers with interests in the Balkans.

title: Harper Lee, Author of To Kill a Mockingbird, Dies at 89
description: Harper Lee, whose first novel, To Kill a Mockingbird, about racial injustice in a small Alabama town, sold more than 40 million copies and became one of the most beloved and most taught works of fiction ever written by an American, died on Friday in Monroeville, Ala., where she lived. She was 89.

title: Good, Bad and Mad: Editorial Page Editor Andrew Rosenthal on the News
description: Times Editorial Page Editor Andrew Rosenthal on Lady Gaga, Justice Scalia, the Republican Party, Beyonce and The Star Spangled Banner.

title: Ralph Laurens All-American Ease, for Day and Night
description: The designers fall/winter 2016 collection incorporated mens wear tailoring  and neckties.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Zackary Drucker
description: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is Zackary Drucker, the transgender performance artist and associate producer of Transparent, who shares her list exclusively with T. (Read more about her most prized possession, a ceramic cat, here.)

title: Recipes for the Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: The Daily Shoe: Marc Jacobs
description: Totally impractical. Highly unrealistic. Utterly absurd. And remains to be seen what the commercial version will look like. But for the love of all things fashion, these platforms outgaga-ed even Lady Gaga, who walked in the show.

title: Contaminated Property Makes for Costly Inheritance
description: VICKI TEMKIN, a lawyer in suburban Los Angeles, inherited a few pieces of property when her mother died in 1999. But she was also left with the responsibility to clean up several acres of land that had been polluted by tenants over the decades.

title: Backstage at Calvin Kleins Fall Show
description: A look at the final preparations before the houses collection  which included (faux) fur for the first time under Francisco Costa  hit the runway.

title: Behind Chinese Leaders Warm Visit, a Cold Reality
description: SHENSHAN VILLAGE, China  Sharing snacks with a ruddy-faced farming couple as a portrait of Mao Zedong presides from their mantel. Pounding rice into a doughy holiday treat with a giant wooden mallet. Warmly shaking hands with an elderly woman as an enthusiastic crowd gathers.

title: Cliven Bundy Indictment
description: Two years after standoff at Bundy ranch, five are accused of launching a massive armed assault on federal agents.

title: At J. Mendel, Minimal Fur  and Maximal Calla Lilies
description: For fall/winter 2016, the designer was inspired by two female artists.

title: Mourners Honor Justice Antonin Scalia
description: Justice Scalias body lay in repose in the Great Hall of the Supreme Court on Friday.

title: Financial Guidance for Widows Struggling Through Griefs Fog
description: My husband and I had decided life was too short, recalled Ginny McKinney, so we went shopping to buy a travel trailer to take us into an early retirement. That was three years ago.

title: The Best of Front Rows at New York Fashion Week
description: The Kardashians, Zo Kravitz, Lady Gaga and more familiar faces from the front rows of New York Fashion Week.

title: Where to Go in Beirut
description: Bistros, bars and cafes in the Badaro section beckon residents to forget their daily troubles.

title: To Keep America Safe, Embrace Drone Warfare
description: ARE you sure theyre there? the decision maker asks. They are Qaeda operatives who have been planning attacks against the United States.

title: The Best of Front Rows at New York Fashion Week
description: Last season, Kanye Wests front row was star-studded, and this seasons Madison Square Garden spectacular did not disappoint. Though technically there was no front row, there were plenty of famous friends and family.

title: $16.8 Million for a West Village Condo With Views
description: A sprawling apartment with abundant outdoor space at 150 Charles Street, the Witkoff Groups 91-unit brick and glass condominium in the West Village that sold out just a few weeks after sales opened three years ago, officially closed for $16,843,386.05, city property records show, and was the most expensive sale of the week.

title: A Look Down the Line
description: In recent days, Mayor Bill de Blasio has been at work promoting a transit plan to link developing neighborhoods on the East River waterfront in Brooklyn and Queens, a streetcar named efficiency, as his administration would have us think of it, although its riders may not. The 16-mile rail system would have the potential to take a graphic designer living in Astoria Cove to her job at an online retailer in Industry City  in over an hour. Streetcar speeds have not overwhelmingly improved since trolleys dominated American city streets in the first half of the 20th century. Even now, along the proposed route, largely deprived of mass transit, there are faster alternatives. Traveling from Dumbo to Greenpoint via streetcar would take 27 minutes; the same trip on the East River Ferry takes 15.

title: An Artists Studio in the Catskills
description: The Thomas Cole National Historic Site in Catskill, N.Y., will open its recreated New Studio on May 1 with the exhibition Thomas Cole: The Artist as Architect, through Oct. 30. The original New Studio, built in 1846, was designed by Cole and demolished in 1973 before the site became a museum. The reconstruction of the Italianate building affords the site a museum-quality space for displaying art and enhances the home of Cole, founder of the Hudson River School art movement.

title: Paperback Row
description: Paperback books of particular interest.

title: Editors Choice
description: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.

title: Letters: The Most Unkindest Cut
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside the List
description: A Tougher, Freer Writer: How is it possible to feel exiled from a language that isnt mine? That I dont know? Jhumpa Lahiris first nonfiction book  and first work in Italian  In Other Words, a memoir translated by Ann Goldstein, debuts on the hardcover nonfiction list at No.8 this week. For the last few years, Lahiri, whose first language is Bengali, has been reading and writing exclusively, if haltingly, in Italian out of fondness for the language, but also, she told NPR in an interview, for another kind of need, I suppose  a more irrational, emotional need. Although she allows shes still wobbly  I grope my way, like a child, like a semiliterate  shes found her way back to a purer pleasure in reading. After I finish a book, Im thrilled, she writes in the memoir. It seems like a feat. I find the process demanding yet satisfying, almost miraculous. I cant take for granted my ability to accomplish it.

title: Book First, Inauguration Second
description: Apparently, the requirements to become president are: to be at least 35, a natural born citizen and the author of a formulaic book telling us why you deserve our vote. Hillary Clinton got an early jump with her two hefty best sellers, Living History (2003) and Hard Choices (2014), but other 2016 presidential hopefuls have been making up for lost time.

title: Richard Montanaris Shutter Man, and More
description: Welcome to Devils Pocket, a small neighborhood of 70 or so families pleated into the eastern bank of the river, a crimp of peeling clapboard rowhouses, asphalt playgrounds, small corner stores and brown brick buildings as old as the city of Philadelphia itself. Richard Montanaris elegiac tone takes the curse off SHUTTER MAN (Mulholland/Little, Brown, $26), a blood-drenched thriller about a group of imperfectly domesticated boys who came from the same blighted neighborhood and grew up to become criminals and killers  and cops.

title: The Yid, by Paul Goldberg
description: In the opening chapter of The Yid, Paul Goldbergs debut novel, state security agents dressed in anemia-green coats come to arrest the titular yid, Solomon Levinson, a retired actor from the Moscow State Jewish Theater with a background in Shakespeare and combat experience in the Red Army. At night, Goldberg writes, Moscow is the czardom of black cats and Black Marias, and the scene that develops brings to mind the darkly satirical atmosphere of Mikhail Bulgakovs The Master and Margarita, enhanced by Goldbergs ironic commentary on Soviet history and the Yiddish theater. Its an impressive set piece, but a simple problem still needs to be solved: How is Levinson, who is almost 60, going to escape that room so the story can continue?

title: The Fugitives, by Christopher Sorrentino
description: Kat Danhoff is a reporter from Chicago. The fact that she is also Native American is, as she might say, irrelevant; although she does not deny it, neither does she profess it. The effect is that she passes as someone who is not Indian. As her childhood friend Becky puts it, You went off the reservation, thats for sure.

title: The Theoretical Foot and The Arrangement
description: Sara Porter, the woman at the center of The Theoretical Foot, a novel by M. F. K. Fisher written in 1939 and unpublished until now, glides silently in and out of the rooms of the Swiss house she shares with her ethereal, silver-haired lover, Tim Garton. Everything is arranged to delight, selected with understated and flawless good taste. Every meal sates hunger without stepping into vulgar excess. Saras instincts are always subtly, intuitively right. Those around her, particularly her brother and sister, who have just arrived for a visit, yearn to please her and are utterly reliant on her good opinion. Sara is, in short, a self-satisfied, selectively generous and frequently withholding snob.

title: The Lost Time Accidents, by John Wray
description: A few chapters into John Wrays fourth novel, The Lost Time Accidents, Waldemar Tolliver presents a kind of metaphysical accounting ledger  a reckoning, as he puts it  of his current situation. In the debit column: Im marooned in a desolate bubble of extrachronological space, without company or apparent hope of rescue. On the credit side: But Im alive, and I seem to be in fairly decent shape, which contradicts every law of physics I can think of.

title: In Pittsfield, Vermont, a Gem Behind the Store
description: From the outside, the Pittsfield Original General Store is indistinguishable from the dozens of country stores that dot Vermonts Route 100 byway. Theres the inviting front porch, the buildings circa-1888 wooden frame, and signs touting gunpowder, antiques and penny candy.

title: In Montevideo, Uruguay, Vintage Flair With Contemporary Comfort
description: Doubles start at $199, including breakfast.

title: Incarceration Nations, by Baz Dreisinger
description: Mass incarceration is synonymous with criminal justice in the United States. We are the worlds top jailer, have among the longest sentences, and tolerate shocking racial disparities in imprisonment rates.

title: David Denbys Lit Up
description: Twenty-five years ago, David Denby returned to his alma mater, Columbia University, to retake the required freshman courses in the great books of the Western world. Thirty years had passed since this seasoned film critic (then for New York, later The New Yorker) first experienced Homer, Plato, Aristotle, Rousseau, Shakespeare and the rest of the Western canon as an 18-year-old. At the time, that curriculum was at the heart of an impassioned culture war over whether the work of dead white guys  as some reformers derided them  remained relevant or appropriate for a multicultural generation of American college students. Denbys answer was an unqualified yes, an ecstatic, critically praised paean to Western thought and literature entitled Great Books: My Adventures With Homer, Rousseau, Woolf, and Other Indestructible Writers of the Western World.

title: The Most Wanted Man in China and The Cowshed
description: A couple of years ago, in what was titled Communiqu on the Current State of the Ideological Sphere, Chinas Communist Party banned, among other things, historical nihilism, by which was clearly meant writings that dwelled excessively on the partys many disastrous past mistakes. Here we have two books, both searing eyewitness accounts of past ideological fanaticism written by eminent Chinese intellectuals, that clearly fit the description of historical nihilism, though, Ji Xianlins The Cowshed was actually published in China a couple of decades ago, when things were a bit looser than they are today.

title: Pagan Kennedys Inventology and Adam Grants Originals
description: Back in the 70s, Scott Burnham was a technician working for a company that made guitar cables and accessories. While soldering parts one day, he accidentally attached the wrong resistor to a circuit board. It was a fortunate error, because the circuit suddenly produced a haunting moan  so lovely and eerie that Burnham realized it would make a fantastic guitar-pedal sound. He created the Rat, a pedal that quickly sold tens of thousands of units. Bands from Nirvana to Radiohead used it, and musicians I know today still swear by it.

title: The Firebrand and the First Lady, by Patricia Bell-Scott
description: The February 1953 issue of Ebony included an article entitled Some of My Best Friends Are Negroes. The byline was Eleanor Roosevelts, though the headline, apparently, was not. One of my finest young friends is a charming woman lawyer  Pauli Murray, who has been quite a firebrand at times but of whom I am very fond, Roosevelt wrote. She is a lovely person who has struggled and come through very well. Indeed, nothing was ever easy for Murray, a black woman born in 1910, a woman attracted to women and also a poet, memoirist, lawyer, activist and Episcopal priest. But her tender friendship with Roosevelt, sustained over nearly a quarter-century and more than 300 cards and letters, helped. It is the rich earth Patricia Bell-Scott tills for The Firebrand and the First Lady, a tremendous book that has been 20 years in the making.

title: A. O. Scotts Better Living Through Criticism
description: Was God the first critic?

title: Kimbo Slice Is Back, and Hes Fighting a High School Classmate
description: What can a smaller mixed martial arts organization do to be noticed when the talent-rich Ultimate Fighting Championship sucks up almost all the attention?

title: The New Flavor of Oatmeal: Savory
description: The notion of savory foods for breakfast, as opposed to sweet, is far from new. But, for the most part, Americans go for sugar.

title: At Marc Jacobs, Black Magic (and Lady Gaga)
description: The designers fall/winter 2016 collection, which showed yesterday, featured a mashup of many different references.

title: Kosovo Opposition Releases Tear Gas in Parliament
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo  Opposition lawmakers released multiple canisters of tear gas in Kosovos Parliament on Friday, the latest in a series of protests over corruption, unemployment and diplomatic agreements the government has struck with neighboring Serbia and Montenegro.

title: The Seven Best Shoes of New York Fashion Week
description: Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez capped off one of the best shows in New York with these boots that laced up the back. As the favorite designers of the art world crowd, their orange heel seems like an abstract nod to their girls.

title: Shopping Guide: Bookcases
description: Bookcases say as much about you as the books you read. So which style to choose? An interior designer offers some suggestions.

title: World War Is Iconic, Ironic Battle
description: One hundred years ago, on Feb. 21, 1916, 1,200 German artillery pieces began firing on French positions around Verdun, the ancient fortress town on the Meuse River in eastern France.

title: Life Insurance Buyers Guide: What Type, How Much and Who Will Benefit
description: Youve probably seen the life insurance commercials in which small children, all wide-eyed and adorable, ask questions like, Hey, Dad, whats life insurance?

title: Why Is Mitch McConnell Picking This Fight?
description: IN early 2009, as Barack Obama was about to take office, Mitch McConnell, the leader of the Republican minority in the Senate, assembled his caucus at a retreat in West Virginia. There, he laid out his strategy for taking on the new president, who was sweeping into office on a tide of popularity, historical resonance and great expectations barely diminished by the economic free fall then underway.

title: Donald Trumps Less-Than-Artful Failure in Pro Football
description: Last year, I wrote several columns about Donald J. Trumps record as a businessman. Far from mastering The Art of the Deal  the title of his 1987 best seller  Trump made real estate blunders that turned billions in potential profits into mere millions. His foray into Atlantic City brought him perilously close to personal bankruptcy. As for all his claims about owning a sprawling business empire, what he actually runs these days is a licensing company that slaps the Trump name on everything from buildings to steaks to an education company that was sued by New York State in 2013 for persistent fraudulent, illegal and deceptive conduct. My conclusion  and I say this as a grizzled veteran of business journalism  was that Trumps business acumen (not to mention his net worth) was wildly overstated, not least by Trump himself. His core business skill is self-promotion.

title: A New Hip for a Young Dog
description: Ben, a 9-month-old golden retriever, had hip replacement surgery recently at the Animal Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: An Artificial Hip Puts the Jump Into a Dogs Step
description: Ben, a golden retriever puppy with chestnut eyelashes, seemed to be an uncommonly good dog.

title: How to Make Yogurt at Home
description: Of all the do-it-yourself projects I wanted to try, homemade yogurt was not at the top of the list. After all, its a lot easier to find a decent yogurt on the market than it is to track down, say, preserved lemons or cabbage-free kimchi.

title: Lack Of Power Corrupts
description: Personally, Im sick of the Sanders/Clinton thing; I didnt want to write about it for today. But one of my mottos for column-writing has been if it feels bad, do it. If I would really like to avoid a topic because it makes life uncomfortable and will predictably lead to another wave of angry mail, thats probably a good indication that its important. Still, I hope that I wont have to do more columns like that.

title: Marco Rubios Campaign Schedule Is Altered by Plane Trouble
description: PAWLEYS ISLAND, S.C.  A prep school gymnasium packed with 500 people hoping to see Marco Rubio on Friday was disappointed to learn that the Florida senator had to pull out of the morning campaign event at the last minute because of plane trouble.

title: Oil Price Drop May Add to Tax Bills for Popular Energy Investments
description: If you own a piece of an energy limited partnership, youve suffered epic losses in recent months as the price of oil has crashed.

title: Times Insider Live: The Presidential Campaign
description: An insider look at the 2016 presidential campaign with a handful of The Timess leading political journalists.

title: This Weeks Trump Insults: The R.N.C., a Poll and (Sort of) Pope Francis
description: When Donald Trump is in the news, its often because of something he has said about someone else, but on Thursday it was the other way around.

title: For Muriel Barbery, Its Elves Who Are Elegant Now
description: For hedgehog lovers, the title of Muriel Barberys 2006 global best seller, The Elegance of the Hedgehog, was a bit of a tease. The titular hedgehog is allegorical and never appears in the prickly flesh.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks homes include a two-bedroom condo in Rowayton, Conn., and a six-bedroom house in Huntington Bay, N.Y.

description: The illustrator Damien Florbert Cuypers draws the models, designers, buyers and bloggers at the fall/winter 2016 collections.

title: In Britain, a Green Utility Company Sees Winds of Change
description: KEADBY, England  A wind farm here, along the River Trent, cranks out enough clean electricity to power as many as 57,000 homes. Monitored remotely, the windmills, 34 turbines each about 400 feet high, require little attention or maintenance and are expected to produce electricity for decades to come.

title: Industrially Inspired Condominium in Long Island City
description: Artistic renderings of the Jackson, a 56-unit condominium under construction in Long Island City, Queens, depict an industrial-inspired building that looks almost as though it was originally designed to serve a commercial purpose.

title: Good, Bad and Mad: Editorial Page Editor Andrew Rosenthal on the News
description: I dont care what the critics say, Lady Gagas tribute to David Bowie was brilliant.

title: Pope Francis, Donald Trump and a Dip Into U.S. Politics
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: A roundtable discussion on The Life of Pablo.

title: Room for Debate: Can the American Dream Survive?
description: Robert Gordon, author of The Rise and Fall of American Growth, and Jeffrey Sachs, director of the Earth Institute at Columbia University, debate whether the era of strong economic growth is over, or whether innovation can revive Americas future.

title: Psychological Suspense
description: THE FORGETTING TIMEBy Sharon Guskin357 pp. Flatiron, $25.99.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: West of Eden
description: This week, Maria Russo discusses Jean Steins West of Eden, A. O. Scott talks about Better Living Through Criticism and Parul Sehgal has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Popcast: Kanye Wests Unfinished Album
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

title: Three Terms Is Enough for Morales
description: Last year, when President Evo Morales became Bolivias longest-serving president, he celebrated with a national tour touting the progress the poor, landlocked nation had made since his election in 2005. He had much to celebrate. As the nations first indigenous leader, Mr. Morales transformed Bolivias rigid socioeconomic structure by spreading the wealth of a commodities boom. He has championed those in indigenous communities, and under his watch the number of Bolivians living in extreme poverty has decreased from 37 percent to roughly 19 percent. During the past decade, one of South Americas most politically volatile countries has enjoyed a long stretch of relative stability.

title: Arrest of Refugee Fuels U.S. Debate on Immigration Policy
description: WASHINGTON  The arrest of a California man on charges that he traveled to Syria to fight with terrorist groups, then lied about it to the Department of Homeland Security, offers new ammunition for both sides in the fierce debate over the refugee policy of the Obama administration.

title: Latinos in Nevada Cheer Hillary Clintons Responses on Immigration
description: Hillary Clintons wonky immersion in policy details paid off for her when immigration came up on Thursday night during the MSNBC and Telemundo town-hall-style event in Las Vegas for the Democratic presidential contenders.

title: The Daily Bag: Marc Jacobs
description: The clothing at the Marc Jacobs show was dramatically voluminous  which made mini, top-handled bags, spiked with gold hardware, shine all the more.

title: Highlights From S.C. and Nevada
The Daily Jewel: Calvin Klein
description: Calvin Klein revisited one of the 90s most beloved accessories: the choker. But this time, with an alluring, modern edge.

title: Last Angola 3 Inmate Freed After Decades in Solitary
description: NEW ORLEANS  Albert Woodfox, who has spent nearly all of the last four decades in solitary confinement and was facing his third trial for a 1972 murder, was set free Friday as part of a plea deal with Louisiana prosecutors.

title: Uber Drivers Up Against the App
description: On Super Bowl Sunday, a few hundred Uber drivers met in the cold in a public park in Queens, plotting to disrupt the app that thousands of New Yorkers were about to use to get in place to watch the big game. Gathered angrily on rows of wooden benches were Uzbeks, Tajiks, Russians, Kenyans, Serbs and Bangladeshis, many of them waving handmade signs. Their yellow placards attacked the ride-hailing service in the innumerable languages of polyglot New York. Shame on Uber! one announced in Spanish. Uber Broke Our Hearts! said another in Tibetan. Then in English: We Made You Billionaires! and We Are Not Slaves!

title: Standing Tall
description: Scott Birnbaum tweaked his height on his dating profile until he found the perfect formula  and love with Tracy Podell.

title: Stretching the Truth to Find Love Online
description: For Scott Birnbaum, finding Tracy Podell was akin to solving a complex math problem.

title: Prison Sentence for Driver in Death of 4-Year-Old on Upper West Side
description: The unlicensed teenage driver who was fleeing the police when he ran down a 4-year-old girl, Ariel Russo, on the Upper West Side of Manhattan was sentenced on Friday to at least three years in prison for involuntary manslaughter.

title: Where Our Political Compass Points
description: To the Editor:

title: What Questions Do You Have For Will Shortz?
description: Will Shortz, crossword editor of The New York Times and puzzler extraordinaire, is taking questions from readers.

title: Harper Lee: Her Life and Work
description: Highlights from the career of Ms. Lee, the author of To Kill a Mockingbird, who died on Friday at 89.

title: The Troll Goal: On Danny DeVitos Twitter
description: Welcome to Social Capital, a series devoted to analyzing the social-media presences of celebrities.

title: Beyonc Faces Police Boycott of Her Concert in Miami
description: Beyonc, a global superstar who has mobilized fans around the Black Lives Matter movement without a single protest speech, has drawn the ire of a police group that says it will refuse to attend her coming concert in Miami.

title: South Carolina Politicians Show Diversity in Marco Rubios Corner
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  They looked like a Benetton ad, Gov. Nikki Haley said. She meant herself, the daughter of Sikh Indian immigrants; Senator Tim Scott, who is black; Representative Trey Gowdy, who is white; and Senator Marco Rubio, a Cuban-American.

title: The Six Best Bags of New York Fashion Week
description: Only Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen could make a piece of lustrous chartreuse satin without straps or hardware the most simple-yet-desirable handbag.

title: The Six Best Jewels of New York Fashion Week
description: Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez unearthed fools gold, tigers eye and other gemstones for these artsy, totally groovy mismatched earrings.

title: What I Love | Patricia Field
description: The costume designers inspiration for her new home was fabulous hotel suites.

title: Patricia Field Downsizes, With Glamour Intact
description: Patricia Fields white poodle Sultana was standing on a glass-topped Parsons table, eagerly lapping from a china cup. Her own cup? Her owners cup? It wasnt clear, and it didnt matter.

title: Acidic Ocean Leads to Warped Skeletons for Young Coral
description: Rising emissions of carbon dioxide create twin threats for coral in oceans around the world: warmer temperatures, which can cause mass bleachings, and ocean acidification, which can hinder the animals ability to build reefs.

title: Male Sellers on eBay Have an Edge Over Women, Study Finds
description: Successful sellers on eBay know certain things matter: item description, appealing photos, strong seller ratings and, of course, price.

title: Review: The New York Philharmonic and a Quilt of Composers
description: Thematic programming, long a factor in the plotting of classical concerts, became all the rage a few decades ago. Though it could be oppressive when ideological correctness led to contrived, even nonsensical, connections, it has produced innumerable successes. But while no one was looking, an insidious countervailing force  randomness  set in, mostly on classical radio, where, it often seems, any work, played by anyone, can arbitrarily follow any other without transition or comment, so long as it is all certifiably classical music.

title: The Marc Jacobs Collection
description: Imagine Edward Gorey meets the Lady of Shalott, and youll get an idea of Marc Jacobs, fall 2016.

description: Slides for a talk next week.

title: Two Naked Mole Rats, Seemingly Immune to Cancer, Got Cancer
description: As it turns out, not even naked mole rats are totally immune to cancer.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Soho, on the Upper West Side and in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

title: Justice Department Calls Apples Refusal to Unlock iPhone a Marketing Strategy
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department, frustrated by its inability to unlock the iPhone of one of the attackers in the San Bernardino killings, demanded on Friday that a judge immediately order Apple to give it the technical tools to get inside the phone.

title: Kizza Besigye, Main Opposition Candidate in Uganda, Is Arrested Again
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Protesters clashed with the police here in Ugandas capital on Friday as voting continued and the main opposition candidate was arrested for the second time in two days.

description: When in Las Vegas  what better way to break a tie in a political caucus than a deck of cards?

title: Letter to Osama bin Laden Dated June 19, 2010
description: In 2015, a court case prompted the American government to release eight documents, including this one, from the trove of Bin Laden letters captured when he was killed in Abbottabad, Pakistan, in 2011.

title: Letter to Osama bin Laden Dated Nov. 23, 2010
description: In 2015, a court case prompted the American government to release eight documents, including this one, from the trove of Bin Laden letters captured when he was killed in Abbottabad, Pakistan, in 2011.

title: Justice Dept.s Latest Legal Filing in Apple Case
description: The Justice Department filed this motion on Friday asking a federal judge to immediately force Apple to help open an iPhone used by one of the San Bernardino killers.

title: Melissa Click, Missouri Professor, Defends Her Actions Against Student Journalist
description: In Melissa Clicks view, one of her worst moments happened to be caught on video and seen by millions of people.

title: For Catholics, Dismay and Delight Over Pope's Clash With Trump
description: The New York Times asked readers to share their reactions after Pope Francis suggested on Thursday that Donald J. Trump was not Christian.

title: Key Battles for Both Parties as Voting Nears in Nevada and South Carolina
description: SPARTANBURG, S.C.  The Republican presidential candidates hurtled across South Carolina on Friday, one day before the states primary, as polls showed the race tightening after an often nasty week of campaigning. Across the country in Nevada, Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton tried to lock down supporters in the fiercely contested caucuses there.

title: Carolyn Ryan: Unpacking the 2016 Presidential Election
description: Its a testament to the frenzy surrounding the 2016 presidential primaries that Yamiche Alcindor, a national political reporter at The Times and one of the scheduled panelists for this months Times Insider event, was unexpectedly stuck in South Carolina covering Bernie Sanderss campaign.

title: Usain Bolt Still Rules the 100, but Younger Legs Are Charging
description: BOSTON  It is another Olympic year, and Usain Bolt still rules the 100 meters, if only by a hundredth of a second.

title: Antonin Scalia Death Puts Swing State Republicans on Spot
description: HILLSBORO, Ohio  Senator Rob Portman, a mild-mannered Republican seeking re-election in the era of Donald J. Trump, has long pitched himself as a voice of reason in Washington. He points to his ability to work with Democrats, and even crossed party lines in voting to confirm Loretta E. Lynch as President Obamas attorney general.

title: Iowans Urge Senator Charles Grassley to Hold Hearings on Court Nominee
description: DEWITT, Iowa  Jim Dougherty sat in the last row of a crowded hearing room at City Hall here on Wednesday night, hands folded in his lap and a look of evident skepticism on his face, as Senator Charles E. Grassley, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, tried to defend the Republicans position that a Supreme Court nomination should be postponed until after the presidential election.

title: Philip Glass Remembers David Bowie  and Shares a Playlist
description: Its like the old story: How do you get to Carnegie Hall?, says Philip Glass. You practice. But the other way you get there is you get invited to play at Tibet House.

title: Citigroup to Sell Retail Units in Argentina, Brazil and Colombia
description: BUENOS AIRES  Citigroup announced on Friday that it would sell its retail businesses in Argentina, Brazil and Colombia, countries in which it has been trading for more than a century.

title: Gina Gershon Withdraws From Ironbound
description: Gina Gershon, the star of Ironbound, has left the coming Off Broadway play because of creative differences, according to a statement from the producers, the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater and the Womens Project Theater.

title: Price of Gas Skyrockets in Venezuela (to 38 Cents a Gallon)
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  This countrys forlorn economy has left no shortage of shortages. Milk, beans, soap, hot sauce, tampons, Tylenol  you name it, theres a line around the block to buy what little is available.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: How to Help More College Students Graduate
description: The United States has a dropout crisis. Sixty percent of people go to college these days, but just half of the college students graduate with a bachelors degree. Some people earn a shorter, two-year associates degree. But more than a quarter of those who start college drop out with no credential.

title: The Risk of a Panic in the Bond Mutual Fund Market
description: Theres a growing risk that credit woes will incite banklike runs on bond mutual funds.

title: Frances Antiterror Methods
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Win the Tax Game and Play Within Its Complex Rules
description: Various breaks can reduce tax bills. Here is a look at what helped one hypothetical suburban New York couple  and what might work for you.

title: Affluenza Teenager Will Face Court as an Adult
description: A Texas judge on Friday ordered the case of Ethan Couch to be transferred to an adult court, meaning the teenager faces jail time for a 2013 drunken-driving crash that killed four people.

title: U.S. Accuses Sports Agent of Smuggling Leonys Martin
description: The baseball agent Bart Hernandez has been indicted by a grand jury in Miami on charges of human trafficking, stemming from the smuggling of the Cuban outfielder Leonys Martin out of Cuba and into the United States in 2010. Hernandez, who has represented a number of Cuban players, including the White Sox All-Star first baseman Jose Abreu, was arrested and appeared in federal court in Miami on Friday afternoon.

title: Does Air Traffic Control Need an Overhaul?
description: To the Editor:

title: Comparing Tax Software in Search of a Painless Return
description: I told Siri, my iPhones voice-activated virtual assistant, to do my taxes for me this year. She responded by asking whether I wanted to call my father.

title: The Data Against Kant
description: THE history of moral philosophy is a history of disagreement, but on one point there has been virtual unanimity: It would be absurd to suggest that we should do what we couldnt possibly do.

title: At Marc Jacobs: New York Fashion Weeks Haunted Ending
description: The ghostly girls in their giant garb (plus Lady Gaga) came stomping into the big white space on skyscraper platforms, eyes and lips outlined in black, shoulders swallowed up by oversize black sorority sweatshirts spotted with sparkling spider webs.

title: Review: Tammy Faye Starlite, Singing It in Marianne Faithfulls English
description: Sometimes its necessary for a performer to use a character to express feelings and opinions that even the most outspoken among us would think twice about before airing them in public without the protection of a theatrical disguise. And in Cabaret Marianne, her jaw-dropping show at Pangea on Thursday, Tammy Faye Starlite went all the way: impersonating Marianne Faithfull, rock musics fallen woman, with an uncanny accuracy.

title: Consensus on Need to Revise Tax Code, but Partisan Split on Specifics
description: Washington is gripped by partisan divisions, but there is overwhelming agreement on at least one important issue: The United States is long overdue for the sort of sweeping, once-in-a-generation tax overhaul that last occurred in 1986.

title: Sunnys Bar, a Spiritual Holdout in Red Hook
description: Tim Sultan first came upon Sunnys, a waterfront saloon in Red Hook, Brooklyn, in 1995. By then, the legion of working-class bars that once populated that small peninsula had dwindled to one. The holdout was presided over by Antonio Balzano, known as Sunny. A painter and actor, he was a reluctant heir to the family business  so much so that he only bothered to open one quiet night a week. This unintentionally shrewd move made going to Sunnys a notable occasion, and the bar was soon drawing crowds. Today, Red Hook is gentrified, and Sunnys is open six nights a week. Sunny, now 81, has largely withdrawn from its day-to-day operations, but his bar remains the neighborhoods spiritual outpost. Below, an adapted excerpt from Mr. Sultans book Sunnys Nights: Lost and Found at a Bar on the Edge of the World.

title: Just Send the Tax Bill to My Personal Irish Subsidiary
description: I want to lower my taxes. Its one of my dreams, along with becoming taller. And younger. And much, much richer.

title: The Best Street Style of New York Fashion Week
description: Temperatures fluctuating from the teens to the 50s (Farenheit) produced a wide range of looks.

title: The Best Street Style of New York Fashion Week
description: Temperatures fluctuating from the teens to the 50s (Farenheit) produced a wide range of looks. Here are some of the best ensembles outside the shows.

title: The Raven, the Original Goth, Makes a Home in New York
description: We can only speculate how long ago the paths of humans and ravens first converged, but the meeting clearly left quite an impression on both. The birds are as widespread in human mythologies as they are across the habitats of the Northern Hemisphere. The ravens somber black plumage, unearthly voice and attraction to carrion inspired humans, who associated them with otherworldly forces and mysterious beings.

title: For Small Businesses and Entrepreneurs, Some Welcome Clarity
description: Small-business owners, who often consider taxes among their biggest concerns, didnt get major new tax breaks this year. But they have gotten something else: greater clarity about deductions and credits, which should help their planning for 2016.

title: Next Barclays Investment Banking Chief May Signal Staleys Strategy
description: The next chief executive of investment banking at Barclays will have to work out which area to rule.

title: Girls, on HBO: Getting It Together in Penultimate Season
description: HBO announced recently that Girls will end next year, after its sixth season, which makes Season 5 (beginning on Sunday night) a transitional period. The demands of closure, even on HBO, probably mean that the shows four young heroines will find some form of resolution amid the continual dysfunction and comic disasters of their lives. Indeed, the tagline given to the fifth season  Finally piecing it together  seems to imply just that kind of movement.

title: How Literature and Teachers Can Change Lives
description: It sounded like a setup for a joke: Guy comes up to you on the street and starts talking about an overcrowded school in a cruddy old building, but with hard-working students, ambitious teachers and lots of spirit. That conversation a few years ago led to David Denbys Lit Up: One Reporter. Three Schools. Twenty-Four Books That Can Change Lives (Henry Holt, $30).

title: Harper Lee, 1926- 2016
description: Harper Lee, whose first novel, To Kill a Mockingbird, about racial injustice in a small Alabama town, sold more than 40 million copies, died at the age of 89.

title: Tips for Fearlessly Chasing a Bigger Tax Refund
description: Whittling your taxes to the legal minimum and avoiding traps isnt always easy, but putting in some effort may save you money.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review Podcast: West of Eden
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | Stitcher

title: Libya: Americas First, and Latest, Target
description: The United States has a longer history of military intervention in what is now Libya than in any other country, dating from the Jefferson administration and Americas first foreign war.

title: Review: A Low-Key and Witty Premiere by Pam Tanowitz
description: The choreographer Pam Tanowitz is like an author who uses rigorous grammar to write nonsense verse; shes orthodox and unorthodox, eccentrically pleasing and wittily obscure. You sense different layers of reality in her choreography, but theyre so interwoven with absurdity and brainy patterning that her pieces look elegantly hermetic, good-humoredly private.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Marijuana May Be Legal, but Good Luck Filing the Paperwork
description: Marijuana is legal to buy in several states, but no law says that selling it will be free from cumbersome expense and paperwork, especially when it comes to taxation.

title: Jukebox Doctor. Pinball, Too.
description: Perry Rosen, 56, is one of the last full-time repairmen for the devices in New York City.

title: Jukebox Doctor. Pinball, Too.
description: The living room of Perry Rosens home in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, is something of a jukebox showroom.

title: For Loggings Crimes, Tougher Punishments
description: I HAVE loved wood and the smell of sawdust ever since I was a child and got to wander among the open sheds at the local lumberyard. But for years now I have had a sick feeling every time I shop for almost anything made of wood. The prices are often unbelievably good, but then I notice the words Made in Vietnam, or some other country where illegal logging is demolishing forests at appalling speed, largely for the United States and European markets.

title: Brother of Mohammed Merah, Killer in 2012 Attacks in France, May Face Trial
description: PARIS  The Paris prosecutor on Friday requested that the brother of a man who killed seven people in southwestern France in 2012 stand trial on charges that he was involved in the planning of the attacks.

title: Layers of Home and Pyramids of Couscous
description: Mombar, a restaurant in Astoria, brings a flavorful taste of Egypt to a stretch of Steinway Street.

title: In Little Egypt, Pyramids of Couscous
description: While it is still light out, Mombar appears to be a tomb. Set on the stretch of Steinway Street in Astoria known as Little Egypt, it has an exterior wall that is tiled in tattered mosaics, with the Eye of Horus, a symbol of protection, gazing out disapprovingly at double-parked cars. The blue paint on the door is bright but peeling, and its cluttered window is dark.

title: E.U. Deal Clears Path for British Referendum on Membership
description: BRUSSELS  European Union leaders agreed on Friday to a deal to overhaul their ties with Britain, opening the way for a high-stakes referendum on whether the blocs most ambivalent member country will stay within the union or quit.

title: A Jazz Singer Mixes Work and Pleasure
description: Cyrille Aime is a rising star in the galaxy of jazz singers.

title: How Cyrille Aime, Jazz Singer, Spends Her Sundays
description: A rising star in the galaxy of jazz singers, Cyrille Aime won first place in the Sarah Vaughn International Jazz Vocal Competition in 2012. The radio host Jonathan Schwartz has described her as electrifying and as a singer in Ella Fitzgeralds territory. Born in France to a French father and a Dominican mother, Ms. Aime, 31, came to the United States to study at the Purchase College Conservatory of Music. She will perform selections from the album she released last month, Lets Get Lost, on Feb. 24 at the Lyce Franais de New York. Ms. Aime lives in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.

title: Art and 3-D Magic in a German Subway
description: DSSELDORF, Germany  An escalator descends into a dense soundscape of birdsongs. Windows appear to open onto outer space. An overhead LED screen converts human movements into colorful geometric animations.

title: Cameroon Blames Boko Haram in Pair of Suicide Bombings
description: YAOUND, Cameroon  A double suicide bombing attack in northern Cameroon on Friday morning left nearly two dozen people dead and more than 50 injured, officials said, laying the blame on the Boko Haram militant group.

title: The Anger on Londons Stages Is Palpable, and Thrilling
description: LONDON  Rage ricochets in the National Theaters first-rate revival of August Wilsons great, early play Ma Raineys Black Bottom, glancing off the walls like bullets in a closed room. In this incisively staged production, which opened here earlier this month, its clear from the beginning that somebody is going to get hurt. The victim may be random, yet the cause is anything but.

title: Questionable Campaign Tactics Persist in South Carolina
description: From Lee Atwaters whispers that a congressional candidate was psychotic to rumors that John McCain had fathered a black child out of wedlock to fake Mormon holiday cards supposedly sent by Mitt Romney, South Carolina is infamous for its dirty politics.

title: Brian France on Nascars Future: We Cant Stand Around
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Brian France, grandson of Nascar founder Bill France, has been the organizations chief executive and chairman since 2003, overseeing record television and sponsorship contracts as well as implementing seismic changes, like the Chase for the Sprint Cup. Four days before the Daytona 500 kicks off the Nascar season Sunday, France, 53, sat down to discuss the state of the circuit. This interview has been edited and condensed.

title: For Costly Debt, Home Is Where the Deduction Is
description: You cannot turn the clock back to make yourself younger. But you may be able to turn it back to a time when it was easier to obtain certain income tax deductions.

title: So You Wanna Be a NASA Astronaut? Pretty Unlikely
description: More people than ever are hoping they have The Right Stuff, and more people than ever will be disappointed that they do not.

title: Proof of Zikas Role in Birth Defects Still Months Away, W.H.O. Says
description: Public health officials are nearly certain that the Zika virus is behind Brazils surge of babies being born with tiny heads and damaged brains, but they do not expect to have proof until June at the earliest, the World Health Organization said on Friday.

title: Maple Leafs Komarov Is Suspended for Hit to Rangers McDonagh
description: The N.H.L. suspended Maple Leafs forward Leo Komarov for three games for elbowing Rangers defenseman Ryan McDonagh in the head during a game Thursday in Toronto.

title: Review: The Mermaid Features Stephen Chow Behind the Camera
description: The remarkable Hong Kong filmmaker and comic performer Stephen Chow (Shaolin Soccer, Kung Fu Hustle) has in recent years opted to stay behind the camera. And perhaps it is his absence from the screen that made Sony keep his new movie, The Mermaid, low-profile for its United States release.

title: Francis and Trump: Populist Leaders Preaching Divergent Messages
description: ROME  In the cage fight of American presidential politics, the matchup is irresistible: Pope Francis, leader of the worlds 1.2 billion Roman Catholics, the pope of the poor who has knelt to wash the feet of prisoners and Muslims, versus Donald J. Trump, billionaire Republican who disparages Muslims and kneels to no one.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing: iPhone, Donald Trump, Harper Lee
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: W.H.O. Advises Caution, but Not a Halt, in Blood Collection in Zika-Affected Areas
description: The World Health Organization issued recommendations on Friday for safeguarding the blood supply from the Zika virus, but said blood collection might need to continue in some affected areas, despite concerns that the virus may be linked to birth defects and a form of temporary paralysis.

title: No Love Lost Between Ted Cruz and Donald Trump Supporters
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.  Speaking just six miles apart on Friday morning, Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas renewed their bitter personal feud, while their supporters echoed the candidates language and themes  a sign that the bitterness between the two men has now seeped deeply into the feelings of voters.

title: Review: The Reef Speaks in the Tongue of a Chamber Orchestra
description: Surfing movies tend to offer spectacular scenes of cresting seas and intrepid athletes riding perfect waves. So does The Reef, an 80-minute film by the Australian surfer-turned-director Mick Sowry, which presents a mythologized tale of a surfing trip near a marine park in Western Australia.

title: Pictures of the Day: Uganda and Elsewhere
description: Uganda and More  Photos of the Day

title: Feb. 19, 2016  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Uganda, Greece, Sicily and the United States.

title: How To Kill a Mockingbird Changed Their Lives
description: Harper Lees To Kill a Mockingbird has transported generations of readers to small-town Alabama in the 1930s and confronted them with a sobering tale of racial inequality in the Deep South during Jim Crow. Read by many students in middle school and high school, it has left a mark on innumerable lives.

title: Jordan Spieth Improves but Makes Too Many Mistakes and Misses the Cut
description: LOS ANGELES  As he stepped down from the interview stand, Dustin Johnson ran into Jordan Spieth, who was on his way to address reporters. Johnson asked Spieth how he had played. Better than yesterday, Spieth said, to which Johnson impishly replied, That wasnt hard to do.

title: WarGames and Cybersecuritys Debt to a Hollywood Hack
description: Movies rarely influence public policy, but Washingtons policies on cyberattacks, computer surveillance and the possibility of cyberwarfare were directly influenced by the 1983 box-office hit WarGames.

title: A Harvard Sociologist on Watching Families Lose Their Homes
description: The first time the sociologist Matthew Desmond rode along during an eviction, he was shocked by the suddenness of seeing your house turn into not your house in seconds.

title: What Does the Academy Value in a Black Performance?
description: When the Oscar nominations were announced last month, revealing that not one black actor was in the running, the resulting furor touched on the performances that critics said should have been considered: What about Idris Elba in Beasts of No Nation? Michael B. Jordan in Creed? Will Smith in Concussion, or one of the stars of Straight Outta Compton?

title: Hats Off to the Circumflex
description: London  FOR me, learning French a quarter-century ago at high school in Scotland, the circumflex that perched atop certain vowels () was an enigma. It lacked the flamboyance of the accent aigu () or accent grave (), modifying pronunciation so subtly I could barely discern it. Nor did it possess the utility of the trma, which divided vowel sounds in two (a). When I finally found out that the circumflex stood in for a discarded letter S, everything clicked into place: Opaque words like bte, cot and hutre now morphed into their English equivalents before my eyes, resolving themselves into beast, cost and oyster.

title: Review: Frederica von Stade, Wickedness in a One-Act Opera
description: Over the course of a long, distinguished career, the mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade went from portraying adorable youngsters  Mozarts Cherubino and Zerlina, Rossinis Rosina  to darker, more complicated women in operas like The Aspern Papers, The Dangerous Liaisons and Dead Man Walking.

title: 9 Memorable Moments From New York Fashion Week
description: Marc Jacobs goes Gaga, Rihanna exercises her designer side, the Olsen twins hold an open house, and more highlights from a jampacked nine days.

title: Mayor de Blasio Signs Measure Raising City Officials Pay
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio signed several bills into law on Friday during a ceremony in City Halls ornate Blue Room, using multiple black pens that he presented to dignitaries and advocates. But there was a pen that none of the attendees wanted to take home: the one he used to sign the bill that gave members of the City Council and other elected officials a sizable pay raise.

title: Will Democracy Follow Capitalism Into Cuba?
description: THANKS disproportionately to their mother, my kids have a gratifyingly acute sense of the urgency of addressing the dire straits in which far too much of the worlds population lives.

title: Review: The Budapest Festival Orchestra, Martial and Lyrical
description: The last time I heard the Budapest Festival Orchestra play in New York, its longtime conductor and music director, Ivan Fischer, had prepared a little joke: In the middle of one of Dvoraks Slavonic Dances, a percussionist walked past his colleagues to the front of the stage, settled down on a soloists bench set up there and reached into his jacket for a mallet and a tiny brass bell. Then he joined in the music, adding little pealing accents that suddenly seemed like the works main feature.

title: 3 Rabbis and a Judge Savor the Enduring Back-and-Forth of Tennis
description: When the three rabbis and a judge walk onto the court at a Manhattan tennis center on Wednesday nights, it is no joke.

title: Bill Cunninghams Evening Hours
description: Mr. Cunningham covers events in February.

title: Bernie Sanders Pushes Supporters to Turn Out in Nevada
description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont spent Friday crisscrossing Nevada, holding rallies in three cities hundreds of miles apart and making his final pitch to voters on the eve of the states Democratic caucuses.

title: Donald Trump Calls for Boycott of Apple in Dispute With Government
description: PAWLEYS ISLAND, S.C.  The political backlash against Apple for refusing to help the F.B.I. hack an iPhone used by one of the San Bernardino attackers escalated on Friday with Donald J. Trump calling for a boycott of the company.

title: Judge Deals Setback to Holdouts in Negotiations With Argentina
description: A federal judge presiding over a long-running battle between Argentina and a group of New York hedge funds said on Friday that he would lift an injunction that had locked Argentina out of international markets.

title: Writers, Teachers and Lawyers React to Harper Lees Death
description: Reflections on the legacy of the celebrated American writer.

title: The Life of Pablo vs. the Life of Kanye
description: How does the self-proclaimed greatest living artist measure up to Pablo Picasso?

title: Kanye West Is Fixing His Album in Public. Youll Want to Read the Edits.
description: When Kanye West first tweeted a handwritten 10-song track list for his seventh album, The Life of Pablo, late last month, the photo was captioned, So happy to be finished with the best album of all time.

title: Bill Cunningham | Finally, Something to Wear to the Office
description: Diversity in all its facets was vividly displayed on the guests attending last weeks near-300 fashion shows and presentations. At times, it seemed as if we were back in the 1980s, with the tattooed, pierced and embellished downtown kids (spotted at Jeremy Scott, Gypsy Sport, Hood by Air and Xuly.Bt) presenting a radical contrast to uptowns simplicity of style (seen at Ralph Lauren, Michael Kors and Proenza Schouler). Each group interprets taste for its lifestyle.

title: Friday Night Music: San Fermin, Methuselah
description: A lovely acoustic performance:

title: Supreme Court Wont Intervene in North Carolina Election Fight
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  The United States Supreme Court declined late Friday to stay a lower court ruling that has forced North Carolinas Republican-dominated legislature to redraw its congressional electoral maps on the grounds that the original maps amounted to racial gerrymandering.

title: Streetcar Service Proposed by Mayor de Blasio May Require 2 New Bridges
description: The Brooklyn-Queens streetcar proposed by Mayor Bill de Blasio could require the construction of two new bridges, one over Newtown Creek and a second over the Gowanus Canal, a top administration official said on Friday.

title: In Harper Lees Novels, a Loss of Innocence as Children and Again as Adults
description: Harper Lee will forever be remembered for her 1960 classic To Kill a Mockingbird  a novel that became a staple of middle-school curriculums, and for several generations of readers, a coming-of-age story that spoke to their own losses of childhood innocence.

title: After Tests in the North, Conservatives in South Korea Call for a Nuclear Program
description: SEOUL, South Korea  In the wake of North Koreas nuclear tests and satellite launches, some conservatives in South Korea are championing a strategy that was once seen as unthinkable: arming their own country with nuclear weapons.

title: Umberto Eco, 84, Best-Selling Academic Who Navigated Two Worlds, Dies
description: Umberto Eco, an Italian scholar in the arcane field of semiotics who became the author of best-selling novels, notably the blockbuster medieval mystery The Name of the Rose, died on Friday at his home in Milan. He was 84.

title: City Steps Up Gas Line Inspections After Fatal Blast in East Village
description: When Mark G. Peters, the commissioner of the New York City Investigation Department, got a glimpse of the system for reporting the unauthorized tapping of pipes that supply gas for heating and cooking, he felt like a time traveler.

title: Plausibility
Trump Shows His Inner Rabbit
description: I am sorry to note that Donald Trump no longer seems to be at war with the pope.

title: Monroeville, Ala., Remembers Harper Lee, Its Most Celebrated Resident
description: The sisters would typically come in for chicken salad and potato soup, arriving just before the Courthouse Cafe in Monroeville closed for lunch at 2 p.m., when there were few customers left.

title: Saudis Cut Off Funding for Military Aid to Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Saudi Arabia said Friday that it was stopping payment on $4 billion worth of military aid and other support for the army and security services of Lebanon because the country did not condemn attacks on Saudi diplomatic missions in Iran.

title: Obscure Kurdish Group Claims Hand in Bombing Turks
description: BAGHDAD  An obscure Kurdish militant group that is an offshoot of the Kurdistan Workers Party, which has long waged an insurgency inside Turkey, claimed responsibility on Friday for a car bombing this week in Ankara that killed 28 people. The group said the attack was in revenge for the Turkish Armys campaign against Kurdish insurgents in the countrys southeast.

title: Superdelegates, Clarify Your Role
description: Even after Bernie Sanderss overwhelming popular victory in New Hampshire on Feb. 9, some of his supporters began fretting about a new menace to his candidacy: superdelegates who  at least in theory  could deliver the nomination to Hillary Clinton in Julys convention.

title: New Chinese Rules on Foreign Firms Online Content
description: China is taking another step to restrict what can be posted on the Internet in its country by issuing new rules barring foreign companies or their affiliates from engaging in publishing online content there without government approval.

title: Tony Phillips, Whose Play Sealed 1989 World Series, Dies at 56
description: Tony Phillips, a veteran infielder and outfielder whose final defensive play sealed the Oakland Athletics sweep of the San Francisco Giants in 1989 in a World Series that was interrupted for 11 days by a powerful earthquake, died on Wednesday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 56.

title: Sabathia May Not Stay a Starter, Despite His Sobriety and a $25 Million Salary
description: TAMPA, Fla.  C. C. Sabathia still wears a brace to keep his degenerative right knee from collapsing. He still weighs 305 pounds, a few crumb cakes short of the weight he carried a year ago. In baseballs age of market efficiency, he remains a walking albatross  the highest-paid player on baseballs biggest payroll and the winning pitcher in six games last season.

title: David Wright Searches for Appropriate Balance Between Rest and Work
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  When the Mets infielders took their positions Friday for an unofficial workout, David Wright received the first ground ball at third base. The pitchers workouts had ended, and several team officials and dozens of fans gathered around to watch. What they saw was this: Wright fielded the ball cleanly and made a smooth throw to first base, with his tongue out.

title: South Carolinas Legacy, Exploited by Trump
description: The massacre of nine black citizens at a church in Charleston last summer exposed decades of dissembling by South Carolina politicians who had pretended that the Confederate flag was not an emblem of hate or slavery  but a neutral symbol of Southern pride.

title: Donald Trump in Triage Mode After Shocking Conservatives With Health Care Comments
description: He has broken with many Republicans on taxing the rich, threatening trade wars and keeping Planned Parenthood alive. On Friday, Donald J. Trump faced criticism for an even bolder act of conservative heresy: embracing the core tenet of the Affordable Care Act.

title: Discipline Near in at Least 2 M.L.B. Abuse Cases
description: BONITA SPRINGS, Fla.  Rob Manfred, the Major League Baseball commissioner, said Friday that he was close to issuing discipline in at least two of the three domestic violence cases before him. Off-season episodes involving the Yankees Aroldis Chapman, the Los Angeles Dodgers Yasiel Puig and the Colorado Rockies Jose Reyes have presented Manfred with the first test cases of Major League Baseballs new domestic violence policy.

title: After Whirlwind Arrival, Nets New General Manager Slowly Exhales
description: The Nets hired Sean Marks to be their new general manager less than five hours before the N.B.A. trade deadline on Thursday.

title: And Now, Shia LaBeouf Will Spend 24 Hours in an Elevator
description: Shia LaBeouf, the mercurial actor known equally well for box office hits and bizarre performance art, took up a 24-hour residence on Friday in a tiny, makeshift performance space at one of the most prestigious universities in the world, where he said he would chat with any visitor willing to brave the long lines and the cramped quarters.

title: Reporters Group Calls for Turkey to Release Syrian Citizen-Journalist
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Committee to Protect Journalists called on the Turkish authorities on Friday to free Rami Jarrah, a prominent Syrian citizen-journalist, who it said had been detained for unclear reasons after a recent reporting trip to Syria.

title: Single-Speed Two-Wheeler
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  When it comes to Saturday puzzle-solving, it sometimes helps to call in the cavalry, especially for those entries that are completely outside your wheelhouse.

title: Xiao Gang, Chinas Top Securities Regulator, Ousted Over Market Tumult
description: HONG KONG  Chinas top securities regulator, Xiao Gang, has been forced out, the official Xinhua News Agency announced on Saturday, after facing stinging criticism for amplifying the countrys stock market turbulence.

title: Hazing Allegations Investigated in Buffalo State Students Death
description: The authorities in western New York are investigating whether fraternity hazing played a role in the death of a 21-year-old Buffalo State College student from Brooklyn, the college said on Friday.
