description: Fractured, chaotic Libya has leapt back into the headlines this week, with a breakthrough in its tangled civil war and a vicious display of Islamist extremisms lengthening shadow.

title: Proof Needed to Enroll in Health Plan Post-Deadline
description: WASHINGTON  People who want to buy health insurance in the federal marketplace outside the annual open enrollment period will now have to provide documents to show they are eligible, the Obama administration announced on Wednesday.

title: Andrew Miller, Demoted After a Strong Season, Isnt Fazed
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Since Andrew Miller arrived in New York a year ago, he has been a model employee.

title: Workers Who Reserve Parking Spots for Film Sets Denounce Conditions in Suit
description: For Christian Pellot, most weeks begin the same way, with a text from an unfamiliar number telling him to show up at a specific address. When he arrives, he is told to sign a wage form, with the hours and pay rate to be filled in at a later date. Then his work begins, sitting for days and nights in a parked vehicle to save street spots for any one of the scores of television, movie and commercial productions filmed around New York each year.

title: Mets and Yoenis Cespedes Rev Up to Resume Title Quest
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Before he elevated the drivers side door of his black Lamborghini Aventador and vroomed out of practice Wednesday, Yoenis Cespedes celebrated a pretend birthday.

title: Treasury Plan for Puerto Rico Favors Pensions Over Bondholders
description: WASHINGTON  If its up to the Treasury Department, public employees in Puerto Rico who were promised pensions could be better off than investors who bought the islands bonds.

title: At Harvard Dorms, House Masters No More
description: The title house master as used by generations of Ivy League students to describe their residential administrators is fast becoming an anachronism. Harvard University announced Wednesday that, in a spirit of diversity and an inclusive community, the term was being replaced with faculty dean.

title: Henry Diamond, Lawyer at Forefront of Conservation Movement, Dies at 83
description: Henry L. Diamond, a lawyer who went from the vanguard of a nascent environmental movement half a century ago to become New York States first environmental conservation commissioner, appointed by Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller on the inaugural Earth Day in 1970, died on Sunday in Washington. He was 83.

title: U.N. Agency Hires Wife of Top Figure in Syrian War to Assist the Displaced
description: UNITED NATIONS  When the World Health Organization wanted to know how the war in Syria was affecting the mental health of those forced to flee their homes, the agency hired someone known less for her expertise than for her connections: The consultant, Shukria Mekdad, is the wife of Faisal Mekdad, the deputy foreign minister of Syria and a powerful defender of the governments war effort.

title: Poorest Areas Have Missed Out on Boons of Recovery, Study Finds
description: The gap between the richest and poorest American communities has widened since the Great Recession ended, and distressed areas are faring worse just as the recovery is gaining traction across much of the country.

title: Alisa Bellettini, Creator of MTVs House of Style, Dies at 61
description: Alisa Marie Bellettini, a former television producer who created the popular MTV fashion show House of Style, naming the supermodel Cindy Crawford as its first host, died on Feb. 16 in Sacramento. She was 61.

title: In Reversal, Egypt Says Terrorists Downed Russian Jet Over Sinai
description: CAIRO  After months of cautious silence, Egypt acknowledged for the first time on Wednesday that terrorists had downed the Russian jetliner that broke up over the Sinai Peninsula in the fall.

title: Elizabeth Eisenstein, Trailblazing Historian of Movable Type, Dies at 92
description: Elizabeth L. Eisenstein, a historian best known for her work on the seismic effect of printing on Western civilization  a novel contention when she began her research more than 40 years ago  died on Jan. 31 at her home in Washington. She was 92.

title: CNN Seeing Dividend From Its Investment in Politics
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Jeff Zucker scowled over a laptop in a CNN truck here recently, scouring a new report by BuzzFeed: Donald J. Trump, contrary to his campaign trail boasts, initially supported the invasion of Iraq. A wall of monitors still showed Jeb Bush, but Mr. Trump would take the stage in CNNs latest Republican town hall-style meeting in minutes.

title: Networks Seek to Breathe Life Into FIFA Presidential Election
description: Bob Ley, who will anchor ESPNs coverage of the FIFA presidential election on Friday, has a few delicious ways of describing what might happen.

title: Democrats Press G.O.P. to Consider a Supreme Court Pick
description: WASHINGTON  From the White House to the Capitol to the campaign trail, the entire Democratic power structure on Wednesday mobilized to break through Republican opposition and clear a path for President Obama to name a Supreme Court successor to Justice Antonin Scalia.

title: American in Iran Jail With Son
description: The 80-year-old father of an Iranian-American detained in Iran since last fall has himself been arrested in Tehran, his family said on Wednesday.

title: Canadian Court Says Some Can Grow Marijuana at Home, With a Prescription
description: OTTAWA  Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has not yet fulfilled his promise to legalize marijuana in Canada, but the countrys Federal Court ruled Wednesday that prescription holders could grow their own supply.

title: 25 Plead Not Guilty in Standoff at the Oregon Wildlife Refuge
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Defendants charged with leading an armed occupation at a federal wildlife refuge in rural southeastern Oregon this year formally pleaded not guilty on Wednesday in a hearing here at Federal District Court, saying little and sitting obediently  a stark contrast to the days when they drew world attention by broadcasting their view that the United States government had illegally usurped lands across the West.

title: Babysitter Tortured Staten Island Boy Who Died, Prosecutors Say
description: A babysitter charged with murdering a 16-month-old boy whose family lived in the same Staten Island building subjected him to hours of physical and sexual abuse while he was left in her care over the weekend, prosecutors said on Wednesday.

title: New Ad Promotes John Kasich, and It Makes Him Uncomfortable
description: GULFPORT, Miss.  Howard Benson, a retired middle school guidance counselor, went up to Gov. John Kasich of Ohio after an event in Massachusetts last weekend to offer some advice: His campaign should fashion a commercial out of the footage of an emotional moment Mr. Kasich had with a young supporter last week.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: This is the latest very serious attack on freedom of expression. During the Franco dictatorship, troublesome artists went to prison, but not in democratic Spain.

title: Phil Mickelson Never Met Harper Lee, but the Admiration Was Mutual
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  Shushing down a mountain run of fresh snow never gets old for Phil Mickelson, but it is not his favorite part of skiing trips with his three children. What he likes best are the chairlift rides to the top, which facilitate conversations that can take wide and wondrous turns.

title: Bolivian President Concedes Defeat in Term-Limit Referendum
description: ORURO, Bolivia  President Evo Morales, facing mounting pressure to concede defeat in a referendum that would have allowed him to run for a fourth term, accepted the loss Wednesday but said he would use the remaining years of his presidency to advance his Socialist-inspired agenda.

title: Modern Love: The Podcast | In Darkness and in Light
description: Welcome to the seventh installment of Modern Love: The Podcast. This week the actress and Tony Award winner Patina Miller (Madam Secretary, The Hunger Games, Pippin on Broadway) reads Together Always, in Darkness and in Light by Nicole C. Kear.

title: Focal Points of Many F.A.A. Investigations
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  Yesterday we merged SUBs and today we are CRASHing SITES. I may need a nap after all this activity.

title: black-ish Show Runner Kenya Barris on Police Brutality and The Cosby Show
description: In December 2014, black-ish creator Kenya Barris was watching TV news coverage of activists protesting a Staten Island grand jurys decision not to indict a white New York police officer in the death of Eric Garner, when one of Mr. Barriss five children, 6-year-old Beau, turned to him and asked, Why are these people so mad?

title: How a Commuter Rail Station Became a $4 Billion Colossus
description: The World Trade Center Transportation Hub was supposed to be a diaphanous structure that would be finished in 2009. Is only now beginning to open.

title: Carmelo Anthonys Shot Hits Air, and Knicks Chances Evaporate
description: INDIANAPOLIS  A cold rain was falling outside Bankers Life Fieldhouse on Wednesday morning when the Knicks arrived for their shootaround. Carmelo Anthony opened a door, ducked his head inside the arena and then shuffled across the court in socks. Some teammates were quietly warming up. Anthony eventually retrieved his sneakers.

title: A Key Player in Cuomos Economic Revival Plans Quits Two Nonprofits
description: ALBANY  A state university president who has been a linchpin in the Cuomo administrations efforts to stimulate economic growth has resigned from the boards of two nonprofits that manage major real estate developments aimed at building tech hubs in faded upstate cities.

title: Australia Announces Rise in Spending for Military
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Responding to the military challenge from China, the Australian government on Thursday announced a robust increase in military spending, including the biggest expansion to its navy since World War II.

title: Woman Whose Daughter, 2, Died Alone in Fire Was Under Investigation
description: A woman whose 2-year-old daughter died in a fire after being left home alone in a Brooklyn apartment was already the subject of an inquiry initiated this month by New York Citys child welfare agency that focused on whether the girl had been left unattended, a law enforcement official said on Wednesday.

title: Edward T. Foote, Who Led and Lifted University of Miami, Dies at 78
description: Edward T. Foote, who spent two decades as the president of the University of Miami lifting its academic standards, stabilizing its finances and helping dispel its reputation as Suntan U., died on Feb. 15 in Cutler Bay, Fla., near Miami. He was 78.

title: Library of Congress Puts Rosa Parks Archive Online
description: The Library of Congress has digitized the papers of Rosa Parks, enabling free online access to everything from her first-hand recollections of the Montgomery bus boycott and personal correspondence with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to family photographs, tax returns and a handwritten recipe for featherlite pancakes.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | spectrum
description: spectrum  \spek-trm\  noun

title: Milan Fashion Week: Day 2 with Prada and Fendi
description: MILAN  Proceedings kick off bright and early on Thursday with the 9:30 a.m. show by Max Mara, an Italian label long known for its steadiness, reliability and sartorial conservatism, which, as of late, has been trying to move beyond that reputation. From there, it is on to Costume National and then to Fendi at 12:30 p.m., where Karl Lagerfeld will, no doubt, offer up lashings of leather and fur for its latest fall extravaganza.

title: What to Watch Thursday
description: Steven Spielberg is in top form with Bridge of Spies, his latest best-picture Oscar nominee. The Big Bang Theory celebrates its 200th episode. And if you like your detectives female and fierce, check out Prey on BBC America.

title: Corrections: February 25, 2016
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Cuba: Some Dissidents Will Be Allowed a Single Trip Overseas, an Activist Says
description: Cuba has given some prominent dissidents one-time permission to travel overseas, weeks before President Obama is expected to visit and call for greater freedoms in Cuba. Officials contacted half a dozen dissidents who were imprisoned during a 2003 crackdown and released as part of a deal brokered by the Roman Catholic Church in 2010 and told them they could make one trip abroad, said Hector Maseda Gutirrez, one of the dissidents. He turned down the offer because it excluded four other former prisoners, including Jos Daniel Ferrer, leader of the Patriotic Union of Cuba.

title: Finding Oscar Moments From the Red Carpet to Backstage
description: Monica Almeida, a New York Times staff photographer, has been covering the Oscars since 1999, finding new positions and using new technology to keep ahead of the pack.

title: Ex-Official in China Blames Torture for Graft Confession
description: HONG KONG  A former high-level Chinese energy official accused of receiving hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes said this week that he was tortured into confessing to the crime, a Chinese news outlet reported.

title: Foxconn Hesitates on $5.5 Billion Bid for Sharp
description: TOKYO  For a few hours on Thursday, it looked as if Sharp, the ailing Japanese consumer electronics company, had secured a $5.5 billion takeover from Foxconn of Taiwan, the giant contract manufacturer that churns out products for Apple and other foreign brands.

title: Indonesias Top Court Rules Against Educators in Sexual Assault Case
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The Indonesian Supreme Court has overturned a lower courts decision to free two educators who had been convicted of sexually assaulting kindergartners at a prestigious international school, a court spokesman said on Thursday, the latest twist in a contentious case that the school and the mens lawyers say was based on false accusations.

title: Finding Oscar Moments From the Red Carpet to Backstage
description: Monica Almeida, a New York Times staff photographer, has been photographing the Academy Awards since 1999 and is scheduled to cover her 17th Oscars on Sunday. Her conversation with James Estrin about covering the ceremony has been edited.

title: Easy-Reading Road Signs Head to the Offramp
description: Durham, N.C.  STARTING this week, a familiar face will begin to disappear from Americas roadside signs. It's not particularly noticeable  certainly not as memorable as the goateed Colonel Sanders or smiling Big Boy or pigtailed Wendy pushing their fried chicken, hamburgers and French fries. Rather, it is a typeface named Clearview, which has graced many of our highway signs and directed us to our destinations since 2004, when it was granted interim approval by the Federal Highway Administration.

title: A Bad Effort in Congress to Thwart States on Food Labels
description: The Senate could soon join the House to try to make it harder for consumers to know what is in their food by prohibiting state governments from requiring the labeling of genetically modified foods. This is a bad idea that lawmakers and the Obama administration should oppose.

title: What Is Marco Rubio Waiting For?
description: New Hampshire has fallen. South Carolina has been overwhelmed. Nevada has surrendered. And the Republican establishment, like the British Empire in the darkest days of 1940, finds its strength scattered on the beach at Dunkirk, desperately awaiting evacuation and hoping for a Churchill to rise to its defense.

title: Private Prisons Are Cashing In on Refugees Desperation
description: Berlin  IMMIGRATION and Customs Enforcement calls the detention site in Dilley, Tex., a family residential center. But to the 2,000 migrant children and mothers who live there, its something else: People who say this is not a prison are lying, Yancy Maricela Mejia Guerra, a detainee from Central America, told Fusion last year. Its a prison for us and a prison for our children, but none of us are criminals.

title: The Party of No Way!
description: WASHINGTON  Perhaps the most important thing Washington will do this year is decide whether to approve President Obamas nominee for the Supreme Court. But Republicans have already announced their decision: No way!

title: The Secret Side of Donald Trump
description: Sometimes in a particularly awful presidential race youre forced to take the most bleak and cynical view of the candidates running for the most powerful job in the world. And then you discover youre overestimating.

title: The Last Train Before the War
description: There is a photograph of my father and grandfather, taken on Sunday, Aug. 27, 1939, at a spot overlooking the Rhine above the Lorelei Rock, where the chasm of the river tightens and the quickened flow makes a murmuring sound, which has mystical resonance for the Germans.

title: Does Money Really Matter in Politics?
Free Coffee? Starbucks Saves Its Loyalty for Big Spenders
description: Wheres the loyalty?

title: China Stocks Fall Steeply in Renewed Instability
description: HONG KONG  Chinese stocks dropped steeply on Thursday, days after the ouster of the countrys top securities regulator and just ahead of Group of 20 meetings in Shanghai. The drop reversed some of the gains made since the Lunar New Year holiday this month.

title: News Qs | Young Saudis See Cushy Jobs Vanish Along With Nations Oil Wealth
description: The following lesson activities are based on the article Young Saudis See Cushy Jobs Vanish Along With Nations Oil Wealth.

title: Super Rugby Sees an Exodus of Familiar Faces and an Influx of New Teams
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand  With new teams, a new format and new bonus point rules, Super Rugby has entered a new era.

title: Playing to the Edge, by Michael V. Hayden
description: If Michael V. Hayden were a businessman, he might be called a turnaround artist. When he was named by President George W. Bush to take over the Central Intelligence Agency in mid-2006, it was in wide disrepute. It had failed to break up the 9/11 plot. It couldnt find Osama bin Laden. It had rubber-stamped phony intelligence about Saddam Husseins nonexistent weapons of mass destruction, enabling the catastrophic war in Iraq. Revelations of waterboarding and other enhanced interrogation techniques carried out at C.I.A. black sites had provoked revulsion.

title: In Mix of Russian Sports, Politics and Business, a Bobsled Leader in Exile
description: MOSCOW  In December, Grigorii Bedzhamov, the president of Russias national bobsled federation, disappeared. He stopped coming to work, stopped answering his cellphone, stopped answering his emails.

title: An Actor on the Upper West Side
description: When he arrived in New York about three years ago from Knoxville, Tenn., the actor Conrad Ricamora crashed briefly with friends in Brooklyn. He then settled into a studio in a high-rise rental building in Long Island City. It cost a little more than $2,300 a month.

title: Why Women Proposing Is Still Rare
description: When uttered by a man, the words will you marry me serve to signal a tradition that is both widely accepted and ages old. Having the same spoken by a woman however  except in a leap year like 2016, when an old Irish tradition of having the woman ask is known to emerge  are still surprisingly rare.

title: 10 Enviable Oscars Looks From Years Past
description: We all remember Barbras see-through pants, Bjorks swan dress and Chers headdresses. But what about the more-wearable looks of the Academy Awards?

title: How to Watch the G.O.P. Debate
description: Heres our analysis of the Republican debate, and our fact checks.

title: As Chinas Economic Picture Turns Uglier, Beijing Applies Airbrush
description: BEIJING  This month, Chinese banking officials omitted currency data from closely watched economic reports.

title: Donald Trump to Foreign Workers for Florida Club: Youre Hired
description: Donald J. Trumps Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach, Fla., describes itself as one of the most highly regarded private clubs in the world, and it is not just the very-well-to-do who want to get in.

title: The Republican Debate: What to Look For
description: Heres our analysis of the Republican debate, and our fact checks.

title: Mother of Girl Berated in Video Assails Success Academys Response
description: Nadya Miranda thought she had found a safe haven for her daughter: a Success Academy charter school in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, where she hoped her daughter would get a good education and be put on a path to college.

title: Student Question | What Are Your Reactions to the Results of the Primaries So Far?
description: The 2016 primaries and caucuses have begun, as candidates seek to win delegates in each states contest to capture their partys nomination for the presidency.

title: A Kurdish Convergence in Syria
description: On Feb. 17, a bus filled with Turkish soldiers stopped alongside a car at a red light in Ankara. Moments later, a dark column of smoke rose over what had been considered the most secure district of the Turkish capital. A suicide car bomb had ripped through the military bus, killing 28 and injuring more than 60.

title: China Gives Glimpse of Its Solutions to Economic Problems
description: SHANGHAI  Chinese economic policy makers tugged back the curtain a bit on Thursday on their plans to stabilize the countrys economy and financial markets, even as shares plunged more than 6 percent late in the day.

title: Living With Cancer: A Farewell to Legs
description: On a bright, cold Sunday in mid-January, I returned home from visiting a frail member of my cancer support group and opened the garage to haul the recyclables up the steep driveway to the street. After a few steps, my feet started to slip and I fell with a thud on my bottom. The big bin toppled over me, scattering plastic containers and cardboard boxes, as my hands reached down to feel a sheet of ice that had been invisible on the asphalt.

title: Your Thursday Briefing: iPhone, Severe Weather, Academy Awards
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know to start the day.

title: Max Mara: Fall 2016
description: The labels fall show.

title: Morning Agenda: Foxconn Delays Takeover of Sharp
description: FOXCONN DELAYS TAKEOVER OF SHARP | The ailing Japanese consumer electronics company Sharp had agreed to be taken over by Foxconn of Taiwan for $6 billion but Foxconn postponed a definitive agreement,Jonathan Soble and Austin Ramzy report in The New York Times.

title: Battle for the Supreme Court: The Deadlock This Year, and Beyond
description: In our insiders guide, Times reporters also discuss what to expect in tonights presidential debate.

title: Our Third Annual Student Editorial Contest: Write About an Issue That Matters to You
description: Updated, March 2, 2017 | We have announced our Fourth Annual Student Editorial Contest, open to student entries from March 2 to April 4, 2017.

title: Big Health Benefits to Small Weight Loss
description: Obese individuals who lose as little as 5 percent of their body weight can improve their metabolic function and reduce the risk of developing Type 2 diabetes and heart disease, a new study has found.

title: New York Today: A Sweet Sleep for Winter
description: Updated, 9:48 a.m.

title: The New Dream Jobs
description: When the National Society of High School Scholars asked 18,000 Americans, ages 15 to 29, to rank their ideal future employers, the results were curious. To nobodys surprise, Google, Apple and Facebook appeared high on the list, but so did the Central Intelligence Agency, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the National Security Agency. The Build-A-Bear Workshop was No. 50, just a few spots behind Lockheed Martin and JPMorgan Chase. (The New York Times came in at No. 16.)

title: Tracking a Parasite That Turns Bees Into Zombies
description: Call it The Buzzing Dead. Infestations of what scientists have dubbed zombie bees have spread across both the West and East coasts in recent years.

title: The Post-Cubicle Office and Its Discontents
description: I have known the inexorable sadness of pencils, begins Theodore Roethkes Dolor, the best poem in English about the grayness of the office. All the misery of manila folders and mucilage,/Desolation in immaculate public places,/Lonely reception room, lavatory, switchboard. For a century or more, office design has been our most useful metaphor for workers frustration. The color-sapped tedium of office life runs like a flickering current through the warrens of white-collar fiction  from Bartleby impassively facing his brick wall to Frank Wheeler caged in his dark cubicle in Revolutionary Road. The fluorescence, the screens, the fabric-wrapped plywood dividers: Theyre demoralizing, humiliating.

title: Managed by Qs Good Jobs Gamble
description: Baumols cost disease is a phenomenon that economists sometimes cite when they want to underscore the unequal effects of technological change. William Baumol, the New York University economist for whom the concept is named, uses a classical string quartet as his paradigmatic example. As he points out, no matter how fast our computers become or how many people worldwide plug into broadband-Internet access, it will still take roughly 30 minutes for four human beings to play Mozarts String Quartet No. 14. If your business is playing string quartets for live audiences, theres a fundamental limit to how much more productive, in raw economic terms, your work can become.

title: What Google Learned From Its Quest to Build the Perfect Team
description: Like most 25-year-olds, Julia Rozovsky wasnt sure what she wanted to do with her life. She had worked at a consulting firm, but it wasnt a good match. Then she became a researcher for two professors at Harvard, which was interesting but lonely. Maybe a big corporation would be a better fit. Or perhaps a fast-growing start-up. All she knew for certain was that she wanted to find a job that was more social. I wanted to be part of a community, part of something people were building together, she told me. She thought about various opportunities  Internet companies, a Ph.D. program  but nothing seemed exactly right. So in 2009, she chose the path that allowed her to put off making a decision: She applied to business schools and was accepted by the Yale School of Management.

title: Rethinking the Work-Life Equation
description: Phyllis Moen, a sociologist who was widowed when her two children were young, has made a career studying the challenges of working full time while raising a family. She was an early voice calling for the government to provide paid maternity leave and offer benefits for part-time workers, but eventually, when she saw no signs of progress, she began considering instead the ways that corporations could reconfigure work to address the realities of the modern employee, who was more likely than ever to be a single parent or part of a dual-income couple. We wanted to do a field experiment at a corporation that reduced its hours, she said, but realized nobody would let us do that. We thought they would be more willing to experiment with giving workers more control.

title: Is Blind Hiring the Best Hiring?
description: A few years ago, Kedar Iyer, an entrepreneur in Silicon Valley, became acutely aware of a problem in his industry: A surfeit of talented coders were routinely overlooked by employers because they lacked elite pedigrees. Hiring managers, he thought, were too often swayed by the name of a fancy college on a rsum. To try to address the problem, he created a software company called GapJumpers, working with employers to create challenges for applicants that mimicked what people would do on the job. Companies using GapJumpers wouldnt see candidates rsums, just their names, photographs and test results. In theory, this process would shift employers focus from rsums to skills. Then, two years ago, he came across an idea that caused him to rethink his business.

title: Failure to Lunch
description: For 11 years, June Jo Lee, an ethnographer, has been traveling the country, talking to Americans about how they eat. She has often been in offices, observing white-collar workers. In one interview, a 20-something administrative assistant at an architecture firm in Seattle told her, I dont think I ate at a table at all this week if you dont include my desk at work. In Chicago, Lee talked to an I.T. specialist who lunched in front of his computer and assiduously avoided the break room; anyone who ate in there was odd. Another guy said that each week he would bring in a crudit party platter from Costco and graze from it when he got hungry.

title: The Robots Are Coming for Wall Street
description: When Daniel Nadler woke on Nov. 6, he had just enough time to pour himself a glass of orange juice and open his laptop before the Bureau of Labor Statistics released its monthly employment report at 8:30 a.m. He sat at the kitchen table in his one-bedroom apartment in Chelsea, nervously refreshing his web browser  Command-R, Command-R, Command-R  as the software of his company, Kensho, scraped the data from the bureaus website. Within two minutes, an automated Kensho analysis popped up on his screen: a brief overview, followed by 13 exhibits predicting the performance of investments based on their past response to similar employment reports.

title: Meet Is Murder
description: Early this year in the sun-streaked offices of Spring, a handsomely capitalized shopping start-up in Manhattans Flatiron district, Octavian Costache, the companys chief technology officer and one of its founders, claimed a spot near the bright new kitchen to make a speech at a weekly all-hands meeting. For several months, Id been working as a consultant to the company, and, though this was my last day, it was the first time Id heard Costache address the team. I was excited. Costache, a 34-year-old Romanian with a dimpled, affable face, previously worked at Google, where he helped build Gmails multiple-inbox capability and various features of Google Maps. He commands rapt attention at Spring. But on this morning, Costache didnt want to talk about software. He wanted to talk about meetings.

title: How Prince Ali Could Win the Election to Be FIFA President
description: ZURICH  Every candidate, in every election, tries to picture a path to victory. The  FIFA presidential election here on Friday is no different.

title: Loretta Lynn Mines a Legacy of Heartaches and High Notes
description: HURRICANE MILLS, Tenn.  I really didnt mean to knock his teeth out. Over a lunchtime bowl of chicken noodle soup in the glass-walled dining room of her modern, hillside mansion here, Loretta Lynn was recounting a scuffle she had with her hard-drinking husband a few years before she started writing and singing the succinct, forthright songs that made her the undisputed queen of country music. Her eyes, a brilliant star-sapphire blue, still blazed at the memory.

title: Think You Know the Movies? Take Our Oscars Quiz
description: Youre Leonardo DiCaprio. This quiz is a bear. Try to survive.

title: The Mississippians of Cahokia
description: John Hendrix illustrates Cahokia, the Native American Manhattan of early America and a collection of over 70 mounds and earthworks.

title: Debate Could Serve as Final Bulwark for Donald Trumps Rivals
description: Donald J. Trump will take the stage Thursday night at the CNN-Telemundo debate in Texas with a new title: three-time winner. The stakes for many of the debates have been high, but none so high as this one. It represents one of the final chances for Senator Marco Rubio of Florida to produce a galvanizing, breakout moment. And it is the last chance for Senator Ted Cruz, whose home state of Texas votes on Super Tuesday next week, to try to fend off Mr. Trump there.

title: Jimmy Savile Inquiry Accuses BBC of Failing to Report Sexual Abuse
description: LONDON  A culture of fear that persists to this day at the BBC and a permissive attitude toward stars allowed Jimmy Savile, the disgraced British television personality, to sexually abuse 72 victims, including children, according to a long-awaited report published on Thursday.

title: China, Facing Land Shortages, Encourages Saving Space 6 Feet Under
description: BEIJING  Whether you are alive or dead, the Chinese authorities have made clear that there is just not that much room for you.

title: Burundi Strife Is Turning More Sinister, Report Finds
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Security forces and their allies in Burundi have beaten people with rocks, bricks, gun butts and iron bars; they have abducted suspects and extorted money for holding them; and they have buried victims in mass graves, a leading human rights group said on Thursday.

title: The Iran Election: Whats at Stake
description: On Friday, Iranians will go to the polls to elect members of Parliament and the Assembly of Experts. Heres why this matters.

title: Desktop Dining
description: Who has time for lunch breaks anymore?

title: A Tall, Handsome Strangers Scarf
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Daily Bag: Gucci
description: No question of authenticity here  this otherwise classic, logo-stamped tote from Gucci gets a cool edge with gold graffiti.

title: Antonin Scalia Really Was A Character Out Of A Dan Brown Novel
description: Justice Scalia spent his last hours with members of this secretive society of elite hunters:

title: The Daily Shoe: Gucci
description: Now that his Gucci fur slippers have managed to find their way into nearly every stylish girls closet, Alessandro Michele has taken a break from logo-mania (at least in shoes; the bags are different story) and introduced these vaguely 40s-character shoes in zebra stripe.

title: With Police Brutality Episode, black-ish Shows How Sitcoms Can Still Matter
description: For black-ish, its characters and its audience, it was finally time to have The Talk.

title: Coast Guard Vessel Capsizes During Fishing Boat Rescue Near Queens
description: The crew of a fishing boat whose ship ran aground off Rockaway Beach in Queens overnight was airlifted to safety early Thursday after a harrowing rescue by the Coast Guard.

title: Fendi: Fall 2016
description: Karl Lagerfeld presents his fall collection for Fendi.

title: Sharps Messy Milestone
description: The deal to put Sharp in Taiwanese hands would be a messy milestone.

title: Printing Gmail Backup Codes
description: Q. I use Googles two-step authentication to protect my Gmail account, but I got temporarily locked out the other day when I was asked to re-enter my password, and the corresponding text code from Google didnt arrive until hours later. Where do I get a set of those preprinted backup codes in case this happens again?

title: South Dakota Bill on Transgender Students Bathroom Access Draws Ire
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D.  For Thomas Lewis, a high school senior who plays trumpet in the marching band and works evenings at a grocery store, South Dakotas contentious debate over transgender rights is personal.

title: Colonial Architecture Fades From Ho Chi Minh City, and Residents Mourn
description: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam  When Nguyen Viet moved back to Vietnam from Britain in 2014, he was hired to write design guidelines for a redevelopment project in downtown Ho Chi Minh City. He had just earned his masters degree in urban design and planning, and was eager to make an impact.

title: Transgender Students and Bathroom Laws in South Dakota and Beyond
description: The South Dakota Legislature approved a bill this month that would require public school students to use bathrooms and other facilities that correspond to their biological sex, defined in the bill as a persons chromosomes and anatomy as identified at birth.

title: 1941: Final Plan for Siam Peace
description: TOKIO  Japan has presented a final mediation plan for settlement of the border dispute between French Indo-China and Thailand (Siam), and expects representatives of both countries to accept the Japanese proposals without further delay, the Japanese press indicated today [Feb. 26]. A government spokesman said the Tokio plan, which was described as based on full and serious considerations of the demands of both sides, probably would be accepted and that an agreement might be reached today or tomorrow. Japans mediation of the conflict was hampered by the fact that Tokio was engaged in important trade negotiations with Indo-China and found it necessary to proceed tactfully.New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 26, 1941

title: 1966: New Regime in Syria
description: DAMASCUS Syrias new military regime tonight [Feb. 25] named a new head of state and premier to replace former President Amin Hafez and ex-Premier Salah Bitar, ousted in Wednesdays coup dtat. Damascus radio announced a decree naming Mr. Nureddin Atassi, 36, as new head of state and Mr. Youssef Zeayen as new premier. Mr. Zeayen, 35, is the youngest premier in Syrias history. Mr. Atassi and Dr. Zeayen are both physicians and longtime doctrinaire Baathists.New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 26, 1966

title: When the Apple and F.B.I. Fight Really Began
description: In many ways, the current battle between Apple and the F.B.I. really began in June 2013, when the former defense contractor Edward J. Snowden revealed the scale of government spying on domestic Internet traffic.

title: Girl Scouts Face Opposition From St. Louis Archbishop
description: The Archdiocese of St. Louis is encouraging Roman Catholics to scale back ties with the Girl Scouts, advising church members to think twice about membership and even about buying their cookies.

title: Bronx Rabbi Who Had Sauna Chats Is Quitting
description: The prominent senior rabbi of a Bronx synagogue who drew scrutiny for having naked sauna chats with boys as young as 12 is stepping down.

title: Video Review: Restoring Diesels Good Name With a New Range Rover
description: Diesel is a dirty word these days thanks to the Volkswagen scandal.

title: In Season of Upsets, No. 1 Perch Resembles an Ejection Seat
description: Remember when a No. 1 team being upset was a cause for storming the court, television bulletins and front-page headlines? This season, a loss by the top team in mens basketball seems to bring little more than a shrug.

title: Post-Enron Accounting Rule Requires Companies to Report Leases
description: The Enron accounting scandal happened nearly 15 years ago, but the announcement on Thursday of a new accounting rule shows that its impact is still being felt in corporate America.

title: Amid Gloomy Rhetoric, John Kasich Sticks With Optimism
description: The most valuable currency in politics is emotion. And the coin of the 2016 Republican presidential race has been anger and fear.

title: More Overdose Deaths From Anxiety Drugs
description: Fatal prescription-drug overdoses in the United States have increased sharply in recent years. But while most of the deaths have involved opioid painkillers like oxycodone, a new study suggests that anti-anxiety medications now are playing an outsize role in overdose deaths.

title: Jailed for Stealing Tools in 1980, Prison Houdini Is Denied Release
description: At 19, Mark DeFriest was sentenced to four years in prison after stealing some tools.

title: The Baur au Lac and Me
description: Sam Borden has a special relationship with the Baur au Lac hotel in Zurich, which has become synonymous with the FIFA corruption scandal. He returned this week.

title: Spellbinding Treasures From Japans Kamakura Period at Asia Society
description: In different times and places a combustive mix of realism and religion has given rise to some of the worlds greatest art. The European Renaissance was one such era. Another was the brief Kamakura period of Japan, from 1185 to 1333. Kamakura: Realism and Spirituality in the Sculpture of Japan, a spellbinding exhibition at Asia Society, features wonderfully vivid representations of Buddhist divinities.

title: U.S. and China Agree on Proposal for Tougher North Korea Sanctions
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United States and China reached an agreement to impose tougher sanctions against North Korea, in what appeared to be a diplomatic shift by Beijing regarding its intransigent ally.

title: The Art of War (Elevator Edition)
description: Ive come across a lot of militaristic-sounding classes at the gym lately  Boot Camp Ballet, Older Adults Special Ops  but the course I want to take is Close Combat Elevator Warfare.

title: Twin Sets, Subscription Vinyl and Laundry Room Melody
description: ORCHIDS AND VIOLENCE

title: In Milan, Fendi and Cavalli Just Say No to Athleisure
description: MILAN  Its evening in Milan  or at least on the runways it is. Forget athleisure, wellness and wheat grass (though green juice is having a moment in the land of espresso); there are other things in life to dress for. Like dark, louche nights of the soul, a cabaret in Weimar Berlin or sunset dreams of swooning and spooning in a misty cityscape  to name a few of the scenarios that showed up in early shows. We cant all be jogging all the time.

title: The Minnesota Orchestra Rebounds From a Near Death Experience
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Outside the office of Kevin Smith, the president and chief executive of the Minnesota Orchestra, a creed hangs on the wall: Enrich, Inspire, Serve. Elsewhere that mission statement  part management clich, part heartfelt philosophy  might be cast on a plaque. Not here, at an organization where permanence has been shown to be an illusion. No, these guiding principles are drawn in block letters on three large, slightly crumpled pieces of paper, as if to say that, like the medium, the message is fragile and, once damaged, a challenge to repair.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Gucci, Alberta Ferretti and Roberto Cavalli in Pictures
description: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Wednesday.

title: Emilio Pucci: Fall 2016
description: The labels fall show.

title: Americans Are Still Flying Blind on Drones
description: One of the least understood aspects of American security policy is the use of armed drones for killing alleged terrorists overseas. These covert executions have long raised grave questions of morality, legality and secrecy. Yet President Obama is failing to adequately address them despite promises to make the program more transparent and accountable.

title: Farruquito, Dance Career Interrupted, Makes His Return
description: The dancer Farruquito is heir to one of the most renowned Gypsy flamenco dynasties in Spain, but when he performs at City Center on March 10, it will be his first New York appearance in 13 years. His dancing in the 2001 New York Flamenco Festival, when he was 18, inspired superlatives and heated comparisons: a charging bull, Heathcliff from Wuthering Heights. His return in 2003 was that years hottest ticket, and soon his brooding allure was hailed on People magazines 50 Most Beautiful list. So why have his New York fans had to wait so long?

title: Sound Bite: Dylan and Hopper Penn at Milan Fashion Week
description: MILAN  After Gucci postponed its show on Wednesday for more than an hour over a late plane from London, the first day of Milan Fashion Week tipped into delay after delay with dominolike effect.

title: Leche y Miel Restaurant
description: A quiet Latin spot in Kingsbridge, the Bronx.

title: Sweet Simplicity at Leche y Miel in the Bronx
description: To begin, mofonguitos: green plantains fried, mashed with garlic and olive oil, then popped into a lemon squeezer, making rough cups that look like craters. Into their maws go knots of hot, plump shrimp and a web, quickly melting, of Parmesan.

title: Sepp Blatter, on Eve of FIFA Election, Is Exiting a Happy Man
description: ZURICH  A day before he was to relinquish his title as the most powerful man in sports, Sepp Blatter already had his final morning as FIFA president planned. He said he would wake up and dance a little, as he always does (Frank Sinatras My Way is a favorite). He would monitor the election, he said. But he turned down several offers from friends, journalists and, he said, even a priest, to give him company while his FIFA career was to officially come to a close.

title: The Whitney Will Be Alive With the Sounds of Sing Sing
description: The fearless performance and video artist Andrea Fraser specializes in satirizing the rituals and myths of the high-art world, with withering attention on its political and social blind spots. Down the River, Ms. Frasers site-specific audio installation at the Whitney Museum of American Art, consists of ambient sounds recorded at Sing Sing Correctional Facility, which is 35 miles up the Hudson River from the museums new building. Its meant to address the accelerated construction of museum buildings and prisons in the United States since the 1970s, parallel trends of cultural expression and incarceration. Running from February 26- March 13, its the first installment in Open Plan, a series of five short shows, each of which will occupy the whole of the museums 18,200-square-foot gallery, the largest unobstructed museum exhibition space in New York. After Ms. Fraser in Open Plan are renowned names in their genres: the painter Lucy Dodd, March 17-20; the sculptor Michael Heizer, March 25 to April 10; the musician Cecil Taylor, April 15-24; and the filmmaker Steve McQueen, April 29 to May 14. (whitney.org.)

title: Hank Aarons Hard Road to Baseball Glory
description: Spring training has begun, and the sports channels are turning their thoughts to baseball, but so is the Smithsonian Channel. On Monday, it begins a four-part docu-series called Major League Legends with a moving episode on Hank Aaron. Every fan knows his triumphant trot around the bases when he broke Babe Ruths major league home run record in 1974, but this program traces the difficult road he traveled to get to that moment.

title: Piotr Anderszewskis Riddles of Bach and Schumann
description: Piotr Anderszewski is an uncommonly poetic pianist, one with so awkward a stage presence that he can seem like a riddle. The program he presents for his solo recital at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday, March 3, is a riddle of sorts, too, a musical palindrome. After opening with one Bach Partita (No. 6), it moves on to early Schumann, pauses on the Impressionist-Symbolist reverie of Szymanowskis Metopes, then reverses its steps through late Schumann and back to Bach (Partita No. 1). Metopes, based on three Classical friezes depicting stages of Homers The Odyssey, are lovely works that are too rarely played and that seem to look both forward and backward. The first is inspired by Odysseuss encounter with the Sirens. It will be haunting to hear it followed by Schumanns Ghost Variations, the last work he wrote before being confined to a mental institution; according to experts, Schumann tried to drown himself in the Rhine between the composition of the fourth and fifth variations. (7:30 p.m.; lcgreatperformers.org.)

title: The Crucible Returns to Broadway
description: Its turning into the season of the witch. Earning the kind of raves for a horror movie not seen since It Follows, the period piece The Witch takes audiences back to the days when people thought covens were not just the stuff of spooky stories. The finest satire in Judd Apatows new Netflix show, Love, takes place on the studio lot of a tween-courting television series about witches with the spectacularly awful title Wichita. And theres a new Broadway revival of Arthur Millers The Crucible, the most famous play about the anxiety of witchcraft this side of Macbeth. The last time this was on Broadway, in 2002, Richard Eyre directed a worthy production starring Laura Linney and Liam Neeson. Expect something more adventurous from the director Ivo van Hove, who staged the stripped-down revival of Mr. Millers A View from the Bridge. He has an equally impressive roster to work with, including Saoirse Ronan, Ben Whishaw and Ciaran Hinds. (Previews begin March 1 at Walter Kerr Theater; thecrucibleonbroadway.com.)

title: A Dance and Music Pairing of Steps and Keys
description: Chamber-music performances  say, by a fine string quartet or trio  can be magical in the way they combine intimacy of scale with emotional expansiveness. Two dancers and a pianist will offer what could be called choreographic chamber music in Trio ConcertDance. The participants  Alessandra Ferri, a former principal dancer of both American Ballet Theater and Englands Royal Ballet; Herman Cornejo, a principal dancer with A.B.T.; and Bruce Levingston, an American pianist  are known for their expressive range. The international group of choreographers for Trio includes the French-based Angelin Preljocaj; Demis Volpi, a resident choreographer of the Stuttgart Ballet; Russell Maliphant, associate artist of Londons Sadlers Wells Theater; Stanton Welch of the Australian Ballet; and the Taiwanese choreographer Fang-Yi Sheu. All but one of their dances were commissioned for Trio. Mr. Levingstons versatility will be on display as he cycles through Bach, Chopin, Philip Glass and more. (Wednesday, March 2, through March 6; Joyce Theater, joyce.org.)

title: Vicente Amigo Plays Flamenco Guitar With a Personal Flair
description: The flamenco guitarist Vicente Amigo, from Seville, Spain, has called his engagement with his instrument beloved torture. You can imagine why when you hear him play: He reaches for depth of expression within ultimate precision, and sometimes at frightening speed. Now in his late 40s, he has worked with some of the great traditional flamenco singers of the last several decades  Camarn de la Isla, Enrique Morente, Diego el Cigala and Carmen Linares  but has also been part of the genres modernizing wave: He encompasses the tradition while trying other languages and techniques. (His last album, Tierra, combined flamenco with Celtic music.) Hes played in New York before, but his appearance this week, at Carnegie Halls Stern Auditorium, is part of his first major United States tour. It wont be Celtic or any other kind of fusion: Hes bringing a traditional ensemble, as well as the dancer Antonio Molina, known as El Choro. (8 p.m., March 4; Carnegie Hall, carnegiehall.org.)

title: Learning to Act, but Hungry for Roles to Practice
description: BOSTON  The playwright Kirsten Greenidge was in high demand. Over in the South End, her Obie-winning drama, Milk Like Sugar, was in previews at the Huntington Theater Company. A couple of miles west, at Boston University, her new play, Baltimore, was edging toward opening. In both places, there was work she needed to do.

title: Bluffers Guide to the Oscars: Best Picture
description: Everything you need to know about the contenders in one quick rundown.

title: One Cocktail, Two Spirits: Bartenders Go for a Blend
description: When youre ordering an old-fashioned, the first and main question facing you is this: bourbon or rye? At Valkyrie, a bar in Tulsa, Okla., you dont have to make that decision. You get both.

title: A Family Adds Five Children, Special Needs and All
description: Diane Stanley has seven children in her home: her biological son, Cooper, 18; her foster son, David, 22, who is intellectually disabled; and five younger children whom she and her husband adopted in November 2015. Those five include the biological siblings Demetries, 8; Caleb, 4; and Maya, 2; as well as the biological sisters Julianna, 7, and Juliette, 6. She is also the mother of two adult children and the stepmother to two adult children, and she has one stepdaughter, 14, who lives with her mother.

title: Setback for Picassos Daughter in Battle Over Sculpture
description: A French court has rejected a plea by the daughter of Pablo Picasso to void a seizure order for a valuable sculpture at the center of a dispute over ownership between the New York dealer Larry Gagosian and an agent for the Qatari royal family.

title: Donald Trump Leads in Florida, While Ted Cruz Has Edge in Texas, Polls Show
description: Donald J. Trump holds a wide lead over Senator Marco Rubio in his home state of Florida, but trails Senator Ted Cruz on his turf in Texas, according to two new polls of coming primary contests that could ultimately determine the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Sinn Fein Gains Popularity in Ireland Through a Desire for Change
description: DUBLIN  Sean Crowe, a member of the Irish Parliament, has been around long enough to remember just how tough it was to attract votes when his party, Sinn Fein, was known only as the political arm of the Irish Republican Army as it waged a guerrilla campaign against Britain in Northern Ireland, only an hours drive from his Dublin constituency.

title: Ted Cruz Fights in Texas, Hoping It Wont Be His Alamo
description: HOUSTON  Senator Ted Cruz cannot stop talking about the Alamo.

title: New Baseball Rules Take On Rolling Slides and Neighborhood Plays
description: When Chase Utleys slide broke Ruben Tejadas right leg in Game 2 of a National League division series between the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Mets, the relatively common tactic of trying to break up a double play was put under a microscope, with many assuming that a change in baseballs rules would result.

title: Jeremy McQueens Ballet Collective to Foster Black Works
description: The Black Iris Project, a new ballet collective aiming to foster and present new works about black lives and history, takes its name from a Georgia OKeeffe painting, Black Iris III (1926).

title: Technology Problems Top a List of Car Complaints
description: Craig Sakowitz could be considered a technologically adept driver. As an e-commerce project manager for the Gap in San Francisco, he often rents cars and relies on hands-free technologies to get work done.

title: Some Calais Jungle Camp Migrants Get Eviction Reprieve
description: CALAIS, France  Somewhere between the Good Chance Theater and the One Spirit Ashram Kitchen sits the School of Arts and Trades, not to mention the Hamid Karzai Restaurant and Arts in the Village.

title: Science in the National Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: Leaving Las Vegas for Natural Beauty and More
description: Las Vegas is not only about gambling, partying and making certain that everything that you do there stays there: its just mostly about those things. If youre feeling a little grimy from the previous night or need to soothe your hurt pride from losses incurred at the blackjack table, take solace in the knowledge theres a wealth of natural beauty and interesting side trips at your disposal. Last week I discussed the underappreciated gems off the Strip  but if youre willing to travel a bit farther, the rewards become a lot more beautiful. The Hoover Dam, Lake Mead and the Grand Canyon are among the most popular  but here are a few more options that are both less obvious and, in some cases, a lot closer.

title: On Assisted Dying
description: To the Editor:

title: Swedish Girl Who Ran Away to Iraq Says She Had Not Heard of ISIS
description: A Swedish teenager rescued from the Islamic State said she had never heard of the militant group known as ISIS before running away with her boyfriend to join the extremists at their base in Iraq.

title: A Ski Trip, but Work
description: My mother recently ended a long-term relationship. She and her ex-boyfriend loved skiing together, and she really misses it. Last week, my boyfriends firm invited us to a ski retreat in Park City, Utah. It is a work event with significant others only. It is also the first time my boyfriend qualified to attend. (Its a prestigious invitation; all expenses are paid by the company.) My mother asked if she could come along. We explained the context to her, but she keeps pushing to join us. What should we do?

title: What Binds a Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Tech Degrees Are Not Putting More Blacks and Hispanics Into Tech Jobs
description: Technology companies employ strikingly few black and Hispanic workers. They blame the recruitment pipeline, saying there arent enough of them graduating with relevant degrees and applying for tech jobs.

title: Pop Art International: Far Beyond Warhol and Lichtenstein
description: PHILADELPHIA  Remember how insane the 1960s felt, every day? someone asked me at a preview of the traveling exhibition International Pop, which is making its final stop here at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Absolutely I remember, and the show  brash, manic and acid-tinged  took me right back there.

title: Will Shortz: Everything You Want To Know About Crossword Puzzles
description: What rhymes with orange? Times crossword puzzle editor and self-described puzzlehead, Will Shortz answers readers questions.

title: New Movie House in Manhattan: Metrograph Theater
description: Quietly, New York City is adding movie theaters. True, the Ziegfeld has closed, but last month, Brooklyn gained the Syndicated; this week, the Lower East Side welcomes the Metrograph Theater. To mark the occasion, the Metrograph begins its life with Surrender to the Screen, 16 films whose plot lines feature the film-going experience.

title: Rachel Weisz to Star in Plenty at the Public Theater
description: Rachel Weisz will star in a revival of David Hares Plenty at the Public Theater this fall, the Off Broadway nonprofit announced Thursday.

title: Met Opera Names Ennead Architects to Redesign Lobby
description: The Metropolitan Opera has selected Ennead Architects to design the renovation and expansion of its lobby, the opera house said on Thursday.

title: Program Offers Free E-Books to Low-Income Children
description: Open eBooks, a program making thousands of best-selling books available for free to low-income children, signed up roughly 50,000 users on its first day, according a report by the projects partner organizations.

title: Luxurious Italian Pajamas, Inspired by Literature
description: Sitting on a long velvet sofa and looking out over Lake Como, Francesca Ruffini calls this her place of serenity. Her villa, perched on a steep mountainside that plunges into the lakes eastern edge, is an oasis in the grand Como style: tiled with large slabs of black-and-white marble, neatly lined with paintings, statues and books. A row of indoor palms behind arched glass doors opens to a topiary garden with sweeping views of the water and snow-capped mountains.

title: Francesca Ruffini, at Home on Lake Como
description: T visited the designer before her F.R.S presentation, which showed today in Milan, to learn about the influences for her fall collection.

title: Breanna Stewart Completes Her Run of Dominance
description: Breanna Stewarts four-year record with UConn was 151-5, and every victory but one was by 10 or more points.

title: Street Style: Milan
description: The chic set around the Italian city during fashion week.

title: ^: Off With the Circumflex!
description: To the Editor:

title: Once a Coup, Pipeline Company Deal Becomes a Nightmare
description: Over the last decade, Kelcy Warren became one of the great beneficiaries of Americas energy boom. The son of a Texas oil-field worker, Mr. Warren built a multibillion-dollar fortune amassing a 71,000-mile network of pipelines across the United States.

title: 36 Hours in Palm Springs, California
description: The city's midcentury modern architecture, which effortlessly blends desert and design, is all the rage.

title: SeaWorld Admits Employees Posed as Animal Rights Activists
description: SeaWorld acknowledged on Thursday that it had sent company employees to pose as animal rights activists to protect the company from credible threats.

title: Bill Clinton Defends Welfare Law From Bernie Sanderss Attacks
description: ROCK HILL, S.C.  A day after Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont sharply criticized Hillary Clinton for supporting a welfare overhaul bill in 1996, former President Bill Clinton mounted a detailed defense of the law on Thursday while restraining himself from attacking his wifes opponent.

title: How One Contemporary Artist Got Addicted to Finger Painting
description: The works in Mark Wallingers new exhibition at Hauser & Wirth in London, ID, span a range of methods, from the prehistoric to the very recent. For an evocative series of huge, black-and-white finger-painted iD works, Wallinger cites precedent as far back as the earliest rock art. On the newer end of the technological spectrum, several films and photographs in the show were shot on an iPhone, a tool that appeals to the artist for its ubiquity and the texture of its footage: for conveying contemporary experience, he says, its the most appropriate tool.

title: Italian Senate Approves Civil Unions for Gay Couples, but Not Adoptions
description: ROME  After months of political infighting and decades of battles by gay people for civil rights, Italys Senate on Thursday approved the countrys first law granting legal recognition to civil unions, but stopped short of giving same-sex couples the right to stepchild adoption.

title: We Should Probably Have a Conversation About Damn, Daniel
description: Every once in a while, a meme rises up from the wondrous bog of entertaining nonsense that is the Internet.

title: Nonbillionaire Candidates
description: To the Editor:

title: Do U.S. Drones Really Make Us Safer?
description: To the Editor:

title: Suffolk County Police Release Video of 2014 Shooting of Long Island Developer
description: The assassination attempt has proved as baffling as it was brazen.

title: Review: Prodigals by Greg Jackson Skewers the Elite
description: The writing in Greg Jacksons first book of stories, Prodigals, is so bold and perceptive that it delivers a contact high. You know from the first pages that, intellectually, youve climbed into a high-performance sports car. Only one question remains: Will the author smash it into a tree?

title: U.N. Envoy Prepares to Set Date for Syria Talks to Resume
description: GENEVA  Staffan de Mistura, the United Nations special envoy for the Syrian conflict, said on Thursday that he was preparing to set a date for peace negotiations to resume in Geneva, three weeks after breaking off talks between the warring parties. Mr. de Mistura said he had been encouraged by what he called serious changes on the ground.

title: At Prada, Romantic Beauty Thats Just a Little Off-Kilter
description: For Miuccia Prada, the mens show was a preview to what she was feeling for womens wear, said the hairstylist Guido Palau backstage in the hours before Pradas womens collection. And Miuccia wanted to continue the same look we created for the women in Januarys show.

title: Falsettos Is Returning to Broadway
description: Marvin and Whizzer are coming back to Broadway, to a neighborhood and a society that has changed dramatically since they last visited.

title: As Bombs Hit Syrian Hospitals, Medical Workers Fear They Are the Target
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The hospital in the northern Syrian town of Maarat al-Noaman was not just grazed, or damaged, by the airstrikes last week. It was destroyed, taking a direct hit that pancaked its three stories into one, entombing and killing 25 people, including nine staff members.

title: Artful and Stunning Cabinets of Curiosities, Decoded
description: This past weekend, the artist Mark Dion was standing in the midst of his apartment in Upper Manhattan, looking very relaxed after having just dispatched boxes upon boxes  which were filled with countless smaller boxes  from his living room down to Chelsea for his latest gallery showing. When I say this room was full, he said genially with a sweep of both arms, I mean it was full. It was mayhem. But now its calmed down again.

title: An Artist and a Poet on Coupling
description: For Ts ongoing series, the Swiss performance artist, painter and sculptor John Armleder created a response to a poem by Jericho Brown, 2015 winner of the Ainsfield-Wolf Book Award for Poetry.

title: Off-Season Setback Frustrates Mets Brandon Nimmo
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  At first, Brandon Nimmo did not notice that anything was wrong. It was mid-January, and he was training for the season with purpose after the Mets had added him to the 40-man roster. He ran through his conditioning drills, lifted weights, hit for a little while and ate lunch. Only later did he notice the pain in his left foot.

title: Prada: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Miuccia Prada shows her fall 2016 collection.

title: Netflix Aims for Family-Friendly Nostalgia With New Slate
description: Over the last couple of years, as Netflix has crashed the gates of the television industry, the service has aimed to attract all age groups. It created adult-oriented dramas like Narcos and Orange Is the New Black, developed more than two dozen original series for children and started a comedy, Grace and Frankie, starring four actors in their 70s.

title: How To Read Primary Results
description: When Nate Silver is good, hes very good. This swingometer from FiveThirtyEight is exactly what we all need to make sense of Democratic primary results. Oh, and hold the Hillary-hatred and all that, OK? Whoever you support, this is a great tool for tracking your favorites progress or lack thereof.

title: Apple Goes to Court, and F.B.I. Presses Congress to Settle iPhone Privacy Fight
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The legal wrangling over a federal court order requiring Apple to help law enforcement break into an iPhone intensified Thursday, with the company filing its formal response and asking the court to drop its demand.

title: Egypt Sentences Coptic Teenagers to Prison for Insulting Islam
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian court sentenced four Coptic Christian teenagers to up to five years in prison on Thursday after finding them guilty of insulting Islam, the latest of a series of high-profile blasphemy convictions that have drawn sharp criticism of Egypts judicial system.

title: Review: Lili Reynaud-Dewar Summons Walt Whitman in Brooklyn
description: Lili Reynaud-Dewar dancing is an amazing sight to see. Trim, androgynous and in the buff, this enormously talented French artist makes videos that show her improvising, alone, lost in private fantasies in empty public spaces. Almost always on her toes, she leaps and prances, evoking a good swath of modern dance or movement: Isadora Duncan, Nijinskys faun, Josephine Baker, George Balanchine and Merce Cunningham, but also folk dance, yoga and colloquial gestures.

title: A Strange Day With Bolivias Evo Morales
description: Last week, I was invited to spend a day with President Evo Morales of Bolivia.

title: Pradas Fall/Winter 2016 Set
description: The Rem Koolhaas-led architecture firm OMA team takes T behind the scenes.

title: Review: Amy Sillman Returns to Figurative Motifs
description: Artists sometimes move too fast, abandoning parts of a personal style that deserve development. And so, in some of the best paintings of her career, Amy Sillman steps back from abstraction to reassert the ambiguous figurative motifs from her earlier paintings, which conjure cartoons, modernist abbreviation and a persistent eroticism. Stuff Change, the shows title, bluntly suggests artistic growth, but is also a literal translation of stoffwechsel, the German word for metabolism.

title: The Making of Pradas Understated, Architectural Set
description: Each season, after the fashion masses pile into a Milanese venue or (these days) load a live-stream, the designer Miuccia Prada displays not only her latest vision, but one of the industrys strongest, and innovative, alliances  the partnership between her house and the Rem Koolhaas-led architecture firm OMA. For 15 years, theyve partnered on boutiques, branding studies, films, digital products, projects for Fondazione Prada and, of course, runway shows.

title: Scott Kellys Year in Space
description: On Tuesday, Scott J. Kelly is scheduled to return from the International Space Station, completing the longest stay in space for a NASA astronaut. Here are some ways to measure his mission.

title: Readers Respond: Do Armed Guards Make Hospitals Feel Safer?
description: Does equipping security guards with Tasers and guns make hospitals safer for staff members, visitors and patients  and under what circumstances? That was the issue raised by my article about Alan Pean, a college student with bipolar illness, who was shot in his hospital room  after a scuffle with an off-duty police officer who was moonlighting as a hospital security officer. My article was accompanied by a podcast produced by This American Life, our first such collaboration.

title: Dilone Transforms at Fendi
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in Milan.

title: Apples Motion Opposing the iPhone Order
description: The company filed its formal opposition to the federal court order requiring it to help law enforcement officials break into an iPhone connected to the San Bernardino shootings.

title: Supreme Court Fight Wont Die, No Matter How Hard Republicans Try
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans, facing fierce criticism from Democrats on Capitol Hill, insisted Thursday that they would face no political retribution from their decision to shun any Supreme Court nomination made by President Obama, expressing confidence that they would not be hurt at the polls in November.

title: F.B.I. Chief Presses Congress to Act on Data Privacy
description: WASHINGTON  The head of the F.B.I., battling Apple over unlocking an iPhone used by one of the killers in a December rampage in San Bernardino, Calif., called on Congress on Thursday to settle the question of when law enforcement officials should get access to citizens private data.

title: University of Missouri Fires Melissa Click, Who Tried to Block Journalist at Protest
description: A University of Missouri professor whose shout of I need some muscle over here, to remove a student journalist from a demonstration sparked an international debate over the limits of protest and a free press, has been fired, the university announced Thursday.

title: Breanna Stewart, UConns Wow Factor, Always Had a Sweep in Mind
description: Breanna Stewart remembered the play, and how could she not? It was one of those flashes of athletic entitlement she has been lectured on during her four-year course study at Connecticut in advanced basketball dramatic arts.

title: Mrs. Clinton, Show Voters Those Transcripts
description: Everybody does it, is an excuse expected from a mischievous child, not a presidential candidate. But that is Hillary Clintons latest defense for making closed-door, richly paid speeches to big banks, which many middle-class Americans still blame for their economic pain, and then refusing to release the transcripts.

title: The Archbishop Is Troubled By The Girl Scout Ethos, Not the Cookies
description: So far, the Trefoils and Samoas have not been interdicted. Nor have the Thin Mints and Tagalongs. Catholics in St. Louis began asking about the fate of the Girl Scout cookie sale soon after Archbishop Robert Carlson called on parishes to consider alternatives to the scouts because of a troubling pattern of behavior he finds incompatible with church teachings on such issues as contraceptionand abortion.

title: Global Finance Leaders Meet as Economic Skies Darken
description: SHANGHAI  The global economy looks shaky. Markets for things as diverse as oil and European bank shares have plumbed new lows. The tried-and-true cures no longer seem to work.

title: Merger Plans Fall Apart for Oi, Troubled Brazilian Telecom
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Shares of the Brazilian telecommunications company Oi plunged on Thursday after TIM Participaes, the Brazil operator of Telecom Italia, rebuffed an offer made by the Russian oligarch Mikhail Fridman to merge the two companies.

title: Vicente Fox and Felipe Caldern, 2 Ex-Presidents of Mexico, Say No Way Country Is Paying for Donald Trumps Wall
description: At almost all of his campaign rallies, Donald J. Trump leads a familiar refrain as he details his plan to build a giant wall along the border with Mexico.

title: Sarah Huckabee, Mikes Daughter, Joins Donald Trump Campaign
description: Sarah Huckabee, the daughter of Mike Huckabee  the former governor of Arkansas and two-time presidential candidate  joined Donald J. Trumps presidential campaign this week as a senior adviser, giving Mr. Trump a toehold in Arkansas, one of 12 states that are holding nominating contests on Super Tuesday.

title: Yogurt-Making Tips From Readers
description: Everyone, it seems, has an opinion on the best way to make yogurt.

title: Bill Gates Explains How to Make Climate Progress in a World Eating Meat and Guzzling Gas
description: Dot Earth, launched eight years and 2,700 posts ago, explores efforts to balance human ambitions with the planets limits. Follow Andrew Revkin on Facebook or Twitter at @revkin.

title: Unpaid Bills Bedevil Harlem Church Known for Its Outspoken Pastor
description: Ask James L. Manning, the pastor of the Atlah Worldwide Church, why he is involved in a legal battle to save his redbrick building in Harlem from foreclosure, and he gives the same answer he employs when talking about many of the worlds problems. Its primarily about my very vigorous opposition to the sodomy activity going on in this community, he said.

title: Dwight Eschlimans Ingredients
description: For his new book, the photographer isolated and took pictures of 75 common food additives, plus the ingredients of 25 grocery-store staples.

title: Friday File: The Whitneys 1966 Debut (Now the Met Breuer)
description: The Whitney has moved on to its fancy new digs. It has left the old place  shuttered for two years  to renters. Dont worry, the tenant wont trash the building. Its the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and it has a healthy respect for history. When the Met Breuer is unveiled next week, the building, inside and out, will be largely unchanged from when it opened in 1966.

title: Nets Waive Johnson; Curry Scores 51 Points
description: The Nets requested waivers Thursday on Joe Johnson, a seven-time All-Star shooting guard whose likeness still dominates team promotional materials.

title: A Word With: Neal Brennan
description: The set design for Neal Brennans new one-man comedy show, 3 Mics, is just as the title suggests  three microphones on one stage. The first is devoted to one-liners, which he reads from sheets of paper; the second is billed as being for emotional stuff, monologues exploring issues like his relationship with his alcoholic father and his own struggles with depression; the third is for stand-up.

title: Photos That Show What (Really) Goes Into the Food We Eat
description: Deconstruction has long been a theme in the photographer Dwight Eschlimans work. So when a chef proposed that he examine the composition of food, Eschliman decided to begin with that fabled American standby  the Twinkie. Around 37 ingredients later, Eschliman became fascinated by what exactly goes into the food we eat  particularly highly processed foods, with intimidatingly long ingredient lists. For his most recent project, Eschliman selected 75 of the most ubiquitous additives  or functional ingredients, as theyre called in the industry  to photograph individually, from yeast and caffeine to disodium inosinate and propylene glycol. He also photographed the separate ingredients of 25 grocery-store staples: Amys Burritos, Cool Whip, Red Bull and more. The result is the book Ingredients, created in collaboration with Steve Ettlinger, a pop-science writer who has also made a mission of demystifying the Twinkie.

title: Philadelphia Museum of Art Finally Gets a Hopper
description: Its hard to believe that the Philadelphia Museum of Art has never had a Hopper.

title: Review: Heidi Hahn at the Jack Hanley Gallery
description: The clock reads 12:30 in Everything Left Is Plain (2016), a pink-red painting in Heidi Hahns first New York solo show, Bent Idle, at Jack Hanley. Its impossible to tell, however, whether this means afternoon or just after midnight. The same ambiguity runs throughout Ms. Hahns other paintings, which depict young women laughing and crying  or perhaps laughing and crying at the same time  in groups and pairs, or alone with a cat or a candle.

title: The New Nouvelle Cuisine
description: Paris is entering another culinary golden age, only this time with influences as diverse as its people.

title: HSBC Hires Goldman Executive for Investment Bank
description: HSBC is adopting the just add Goldman Sachs recipe plan for its investment bank.

title: Moschino: Fall 2016
description: Jeremy Scott shows his fall 2016 collection for Moschino.

title: In College Endowment Returns, Davids Beat the Goliaths
description: In the world of money management, bigger is often considered better. College and university endowments greater than $1 billion, for example, have long outperformed their smaller rivals.

title: U.S. Soccer Will Support Prince Ali in FIFA Election
description: ZURICH  U.S. Soccers president, Sunil Gulati, said Thursday that the federation would vote for Prince Ali bin al-Hussein of Jordan in Fridays FIFA presidential election, turning away from the two front-runners to back the candidate U.S. Soccer supported last year in the previous election.

title: Viacom Chief Must Testify on Sumner Redstones Mental State
description: Philippe P. Dauman, the chief executive of Viacom, has been ordered to sit for a deposition in the legal battle over the mental competency of the media mogul Sumner M. Redstone, a New York judge ruled during a hearing Thursday.

title: Costume Design and Makeup Oscar Predictions
description: You have your artisanal popcorn and youve chosen your favorite Oscar drinking game. The only thing left to do is finish filling out your ballot. The Baggers Oscar predictions for the top categories are still to come. Until then, take some time to consider your picks in the costume design and makeup and hairstyling categories. The winners may not be as evident as they appear.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: Art in review, from Times critics.

title: Review: In Folk, Form, and Fire, Hosting a Party of Five for Prokofiev
description: Its not every day that a young superstar like Daniil Trifonov, the sensational Russian pianist, agrees to be just one of five soloists in a marathon concerto concert. But clearly he could not resist taking part in Folk, Form, and Fire, a complete survey of Prokofievs five piano concertos, performed in order on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music by Valery Gergiev and the Mariinsky Orchestra, who are in residency there.

title: Lawmakers Urge Commodities Agency to Keep Plan to Limit Futures Contracts
description: Lawmakers heaped criticism on an advisory committee report to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission recommending that the agency scrap its proposed rule on position limits in derivatives trading.

title: Sorting Out Dodd-Franks Treatment of Failed Broker-Dealers
description: All the relevant financial regulators recently got together and released proposed rules regarding the treatment of failed broker-dealers under Dodd-Franks Title II (also known as orderly liquidation authority). The proposed rules are long, and there was little attention.

title: Man Gets Life Term for Fatal Stabbing During Staten Island Home Invasion
