description: A 21-year-old Staten Island man was sentenced on Thursday to life in prison without the possibility of parole for stabbing a husband and wife in the head and neck during a home invasion, killing the husband, prosecutors said.

title: Paula Modersohn-Becker and Her Thwarted Ambitions
description: An exhibition of Paula Modersohn-Beckers art is almost by definition a bittersweet event. Its thrilling to watch this pioneering German painter restlessly experiment with color and surface in the form of portraits, landscapes, still lifes and scenes of peasant women and children she made during her short time on earth. Its sad to wonder what she might have done had she lived longer. So it is with Paula Modersohn-Becker: Art and Life, a riveting exhibition at Galerie St. Etienne, the keeper of her flame in this country.

title: Sarah Ruhl: By the Book
description: The playwright and author, most recently, of The Oldest Boy says what moves her most in literature is the writer who says: Here I stood! I loved the world enough to write it all down.

title: Playing at the New York International Childrens Film Festival
description: Images from select films in the festival.

title: A Quirky Board Game With Versions Spanning 400 Years
description: Adrian Seville has bought hundreds of board games, but he has hardly any interest in playing them. A retired university administrator living outside London, Dr. Seville has focused on collecting variants of the Game of the Goose, which was invented in the 15th century and remains in production. While its rules may be too simplistic for his tastes  players roll dice and try to beat one another to the 63rd square  he nonetheless described the collecting process as highly addictive.

title: New York International Childrens Film Festival Gives Young Heroes Their Stage
description: A film festival for children might sound, on the surface, like a safe and festive zone  sunshine, puppies, hugs and happy families. But any young reader or moviegoer knows better. From the Brothers Grimm to The Wizard of Oz to Harry Potter, some of our darkest stories are the ones we conjure up for and about children.

title: Review: Rhiannon Giddens Sings of Oppression
description: Somber, contemplative, quietly impassioned: Swimming in Dark Waters  Other Voices of the American Experience brought a concert of protest songs to the Appel Room on Wednesday evening. The 90-minute performance, a scholarly exploration of black history in folk songs and spirituals both traditional and contemporary, was a pinnacle of this seasons American Songbook series at Lincoln Center.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, iPhone, Academy Awards
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Triple 9
description: John Hillcoat Narrates a sequence from the film.

title: John Hillcoat Narrates a Scene From Triple 9
description: Corrupt police officers work with gang members and the Russian mob to pull off a heist in Triple 9, an action thriller directed by John Hillcoat (The Road, The Proposition).

title: This Weeks Movies | Feb. 26, 2016
description: The New York Times film critics review Jack and the Read Hearts, Triple Nine and Gods of Egypt.

title: Review: Pacific Northwest Ballet and Three by Balanchine
description: Pacific Northwest Ballet, by opening its return visit to New York on Wednesday night with a triple bill of three Balanchine ballets well known here, ran the risk of overfamiliarity  yet the opposite proved true. Works we thought we knew looked and felt novel, peculiar, arresting. More than that, the basic connection between music, space and dancers acquired a shocking immediacy and fullness.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Orchidelirium Explodes With Color at New York Botanical Garden
description: The orchid trail at the New York Botanical Garden burns with color like a slow fuse. Along a greenhouse walkway in the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory, refitted for Orchidelirium, this years edition of the annual orchid show, clustered plantings clamor, each more brilliant and extravagantly shaped than its neighbor. Tiny blazing-yellow Colombian buttercup orchids jostle with frilly, purply-red Pacific Sun Spots, which compete with hybrid Phalaenopsis, their petals decorated with pink stripes as fine as a hair.

title: Review: In Gods of Egypt, That Doughnut Beast Is Stepping on My Sandal
description: Bosomy damsels and brawny slabs; cheering digital crowds; a lachrymose sphinx; a bedazzled Geoffrey Rush; a galactic cruise ship; an Egyptian god played by the Dane Nikolaj Coster-Waldau; the sword-and-sandals enabler Gerard Butler; a smoky monster that from one angle looks like a fanged doughnut and from another an alarmingly enraged anus  Gods of Egypt attests that they do make them like they used to, or at least like the King of the Bs, Roger Corman, once did, except with far more money. If Gods of Egypt were any worse, it might be a masterpiece.

title: Movie Review: Gods of Egypt
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Gods of Egypt.

title: Photos of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
description: Philippines and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Feb. 25, 2016  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from the Philippines, Beirut, Greece and Germany.

title: Dead 400 Years, but Still Very Much Alive
description: Shakespeare is said to have been born, and died, on April 23. This year, the 400th anniversary of his death has prompted an outpouring of celebrations. Here are a highly curated few.

title: Dance Listings for Feb. 26-March 3
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: Jack of the Red Hearts: Trouble Babysits Trouble
description: To describe Glory (Taylor Richardson), the severely autistic 11-year-old girl at the center of Jack of the Red Hearts, as a holy terror is putting it mildly. During a full-blown tantrum, she bites and scratches, and she demands constant attention and endless patience to deal with her uncontrollable behavior.

title: Movie Review: Jack of the Red Hearts
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Jack of the Red Hearts.

title: Classical Music Listings for Feb. 26-Mar. 3
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Woman Used Daughters Medical Settlement for Liposuction, Prosecutors Say
description: A Queens woman has been accused of stealing money from her 11-year-old daughters medical malpractice settlement to pay for liposuction and a tummy tuck procedure, as well as a trip to Disneyland, prosecutors said on Thursday.

title: Movie Review: Triple 9
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Triple 9.

title: Scott Kelly Poised to Set NASA Record for Consecutive Days in Space
description: In less than a week, Scott J. Kelly will once again feel weight.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Feb. 26-Mar. 3
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: In Triple 9, an Appealing Cast Cant Rise Above the Violence
description: With its lurid red and brooding villains, the thriller Triple 9 comes dressed to kill. Directed by John Hillcoat, it purrs to a start with men plotting in near dark, a hook-y start that establishes the look and mood. Within minutes, the men are robbing an Atlanta bank in a scene filled with gunfire and rattling, visceral specifics, like the wet stains spreading under the weeping, prostrate employees. The mens camaraderie and choreography announce their professionalism while the guns and money telegraph the stakes. And all of this is gone with the wind the moment Kate Winslet swaggers in, wearing a doo-wop bouffant and flashing a blingy Star of David as big as a bagel.

title: Jazz Listings for Feb. 26-Mar. 3
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: First Uterus Transplant in U.S. Bolsters Pregnancy Hopes of Many
description: Surgeons at the Cleveland Clinic have performed the first uterus transplant in the United States, the clinic announced Thursday.

title: Telemundo to Translate Republican Debate in Real Time
description: HOUSTON  Por la primera vez este ao, el debate republicano de esta noche se podr escuchar en espaol.

title: Where to Shop on Bordeauxs Left Bank
description: Though whats for sale in each varies from shoes to chocolate, these lesser-known shops are all French brands with names that locals rely on when shopping.

title: Movie Listings for Feb. 26-Mar. 3
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Review: In Backtrack, Adrien Brody Treats Dead People
description: Buy into the idea of recovered memories, and then buy into the idea of their recovery at a pace nicely suited to a feature-length film, and youll get a decent ride from the suspenseful Backtrack.

title: Comedy Listings for Feb. 26-Mar. 3
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: Eddie the Eagle Revels in Its Underdog Status
description: Eddie the Eagle is a good-natured film about the British Olympian Eddie Edwards, but it would be better if it respected its audiences ability to recognize an underdog story.

title: Review: King Georges Chronicles a Famed Restaurants Downfall
description: Bustling about crowded kitchens, barking orders and taunts in Franglais, and measuring in at 5-foot-and-a-toque, the chef Georges Perrier cuts a cartoonish figure in Erika Frankels new food documentary, King Georges. Ms. Frankels rather humble directorial debut skips the usual drooling over dishes to play up Mr. Perrier as a lovable old sparkplug on the way out.

title: Review: The Last Man on the Moon Is the Story of Just That
description: You already know the history told in The Last Man on the Moon, but this story just never grows old.

title: Theater Listings for Feb. 26-March 3
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Tenth Republican Debate: Analysis
Review: Like for Likes, a Rom-Com Set in Seoul
description: Relationships unfold with a bright, glossy and antiseptic sentimentality in Park Hyun-genes Like for Likes, which brings abundant social media usage to shopworn rom-com contrivances.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Feb. 26-Mar. 3
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Oscar Predictions 2016: And the Winners Will Be
description: After months reporting on the awards season, Cara Buckley, the Carpetbagger, predicts the Oscar winners.

title: Alex Rodriguez Embraces the Difference a Year Makes
description: TAMPA, Fla.  A year ago, Alex Rodriguez showed up here unannounced to even the Yankees, his first news conference an impromptu event on the sidewalk outside their minor league complex and his first steps back into baseball from a yearlong drug suspension awkward and uncertain.

title: Justice, in Sketches
description: The Library of Congress has acquired drawings of trials over several decades. Here is a sampling of renderings of famous defendants and witnesses.

title: Library of Congress Acquires Drawings of Courtroom Drama
description: Bernard L. Madoff is handcuffed as he turns away from the victims of his Ponzi scheme, who applaud his arrest. Charles Manson lunges toward a judge with a pencil in his hand, agitated at being denied the chance to cross-examine a detective. Larry Flynt of Hustler magazine sits in a gold-plated wheelchair looking on from a distance as the Supreme Court debates the boundaries of the First Amendment.

title: Obama Administration Set to Expand Sharing of Data That N.S.A. Intercepts
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is on the verge of permitting the National Security Agency to share more of the private communications it intercepts with other American intelligence agencies without first applying any privacy protections to them, according to officials familiar with the deliberations.

title: Audit Finds Lapses at Safety Auto Regulator
description: Five years after an internal audit revealed serious shortcomings at the nations top auto safety regulator, the agency has failed to follow through on some overhauls, according to a new audit by the Transportation Departments inspector general.

title: Florida: Bill to Regulate Fracking Fails to Advance
description: A bill to regulate fracking, an oil and gas extraction technique that is relatively new to Florida and vigorously opposed across the state, was voted down on Thursday by a pivotal State Senate committee. The Senate Appropriations Committee rejected the measure in a 10-to-9 bipartisan vote. Floridas extremely porous geology raised fears among environmentalists and Florida residents that well stimulation could more easily lead to contamination of underground aquifers, the source of drinking water for almost all Floridians. The bill, which had passed the House, proposed regulating only two forms of well stimulation in the state but left out a third method, matrix acidizing, that is conducted with low pressure. It also would not require oil and gas companies to reveal all of the chemicals they would put into the ground because some are protected by federal law. The legislation called for a study on the potential effect of well stimulation, but matrix acidizing would not be part of the study. Local governments objected to the legislation because it would prohibit them from banning well stimulation. Nearly 80 counties and cities have passed resolutions or ordinances that banned or opposed fracking. The bill can be called up again in the Senate committee. Well stimulation is not regulated in Florida and does not require a separate permit.

title: Review: Marguerite & Julien, a Tale of Siblings in Love
description: This distressing film, directed by Valrie Donzelli from a script by Ms. Donzelli and Jrmie Elkam, has an admirable pedigree. Its roots are in an unrealized project that the screenwriter Jean Gruault had hoped to make with Franois Truffaut, and the movie is dedicated to Mr. Gruault, who died last year. Marguerite & Julien transposes the factually based, centuries-old tale of incestuous French lovers to a not-quite-modern setting (much nostalgia is expended depicting one of its characters developing photographs in a darkroom) that could be called Wes Anderson and Sofia Coppola Land, only it isnt as attractive as that sounds.

title: Spare Times for Children Listings for Feb. 26-March 3
description: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has drawn sharp criticism for its failure to embrace diversity. But on this Oscars weekend, another academy, with a smaller audience  and, for this occasion, much smaller audience members  has dedicated itself to a pursuit of equity in movies.

title: Analyzing Apples Argument That First Amendment Applies to Its Code
description: Computer code is incomprehensible to anyone without programming skills, but Apple argued in a court filing on Thursday that code is a form of speech. So, the company contends, the governments order to crack a locked iPhone used by one of the San Bernardino killers would violate Apples First Amendment rights.

title: What You Missed in the Debate
description: Heres how we analyzed the Republican debate, and fact checked.

title: Maodo Lo, an Artist With a Basketball at Columbia
description: Maodo Lo, the lissome Columbia senior attracting N.B.A. attention this season, snatched a brochure as he walked into the Susan Eley Fine Art gallery on the Upper West Side one recent afternoon.

title: With No Unified Refugee Strategy, Europeans Fall Back on Old Alliances
description: ROME  Roughly five weeks ago, Donald Tusk, one of the European Unions most powerful political figures, issued a blunt warning to its 28 countries: Come up with a coherent plan to tackle the refugee crisis within two months, or risk chaos.

title: Review: Paul Verhoevens Tricked, a Documentary and a Farce
description: Its unlikely that Paul Verhoeven, the Dutch filmmaker behind Basic Instinct, Showgirls and Hollow Man, ever directs his movies with a completely straight face. Paul Verhoevens Tricked  which consists of two parts, Tricked, a farce built from crowd-sourced suggestions, and Tricked: Pauls Experience, a documentary about how that film was made  qualifies merely as a more overt prank than usual.

title: Yolande Betbeze Fox, Miss America Who Defied Convention, Dies at 87
description: Yolande Betbeze Fox, a convent-educated Alabamian who defied convention, and set new standards, by refusing to tour the country as Miss America of 1951 in revealing bathing suits, died on Monday in Washington. She was 87.

title: Review: A Strange Course of Events
description: The unexamined life is not worth living, but A Strange Course of Events reminds us that the inspected one is not always worth watching.

title: Review: Virus of Fear, a Kiss Touches Off Child Abuse Accusations
description: Ventura Ponss stagy drama Virus of Fear tries to walk a thin line about its volatile subject  child sexual abuse  as it weighs a mans possible innocence against a mobs rage. But its attempts at ambiguity work against it. Fortunately, the film, adapted from Josep Maria Mirs play Archimedes Principle, falls on the right side of its issue, if barely.

title: Benjamin Netanyahu Rebukes David Cameron for Criticizing Israel
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has long counted his British counterpart, David Cameron, as a staunch friend in a shrinking world of dependable allies.

title: Spare Times for Feb. 26-March 3
description: American Museum of Natural History: Countdown to Zero (through early 2017) Smallpox is the only human disease to have been eradicated, but what about Guinea worm, polio, malaria and others? This exhibition, presented in collaboration with the Carter Center, examines international efforts to control and wipe out infection. Daily from 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m., Central Park West and 79th Street, 212-769-5200, amnh.org.

title: Suit Alleges Persistent Sexual Abuse of Female Inmates in New York State Prisons
description: Sexual abuse of female inmates is persistent in New York State prisons, six female prisoners claim in a lawsuit filed Thursday.

title: Anaheim Ducks Rediscover Goal and Turn Their Season Around
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  The N.H.L.s Ducks hosted Orange Countys biggest field trip on Tuesday when they welcomed roughly 16,000 elementary school students to Honda Center. Anaheim players enjoyed the task of using hockey to educate children on some basic tenets of science. But they also admitted that the event, now in its 16th year, is considerably more fun when the team is winning.

title: Gunman Kills 3 at Kansas Factory Before Dying in Shootout
description: NEWTON, Kan.  Three people were killed at a manufacturing plant in Hesston, Kan., on Thursday by a man who had driven through at least two towns shooting a gun out of his car window, the police said.

title: Review: A Room of My Own Recalls a Greenwich Village of 1979
description: Before we see Jackie, we hear him: a screaming voice in the hallway, threatening to attack a neighbor whose punk rock kept him up all night. Hes still clutching his weapon, a hammer, when he strides into his sisters apartment, where he paces the floor like a feral cat before he lets her calm him down.

title: Eviction Notification Turns Deadly as Man Fires at Police Officers in Colorado
description: BAILEY, Colo.  Martin Wirth was angry with the system. As a grass-roots activist with the Occupy Denver protests and a long-shot Green Party candidate for a conservative-held seat in Colorados Senate, he denounced social injustice and police brutality.

title: Treasury Official Urges Solution for Puerto Rico
description: A senior Treasury official urged Congress on Thursday to help Puerto Rico restructure its debt quickly, warning that failing to do so would lead to a decade of financial decline.

title: A Player Struggles, Then Vaults Into Contention
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  After four holes at the Honda Classic, Sam Saunders was at even par. Two holes later, he was four over. For Saunders, a player not known for his patience who was battling gusty winds and dark thoughts blown in by five consecutive missed cuts, the bolt into black numbers seemed to forecast a disaster.

title: U.S. Plans to Put Advisers on Front Lines of Nigerias War on Boko Haram
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The Pentagon is poised to send dozens of Special Operations advisers to the front lines of Nigerias fight against the West African militant group Boko Haram, according to military officials, the latest deployment in conflicts with the Islamic State and its allies.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Law Restricting Louisiana Abortion Doctors
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  A large blue sign stood at the entrance to the Delta Clinic, a low brick building amid the ranch houses in a neighborhood here in the Louisiana capital.

title: President Weighs In on Data From Genes
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday waded into the complex and high-stakes debate over whether patients own their genetic information, saying that he believes that his tissues and any discoveries that stem from his DNA belong to him.

title: Closely Watched Fight Over California Teacher Tenure Moves to Appeals Court
description: LOS ANGELES  A fierce battle over the future of teacher tenure in California moved to an appeals court here on Thursday. Lawyers for student plaintiffs argued that the states ironclad job protections for teachers deprived students of a quality education, while teachers unions and the state said the system helped recruit and retain teachers.

title: Swings, Slides and the Lingering Memory of a Brownsville Rape Case
description: Overhead, the clang of metal on metal. The snap hook securing an American flag to its halyard struck the flagpole, sounding a toll in the crisp wind.

title: Hillary Clinton Makes Appeals to Black Voters in South Carolina
description: FLORENCE, S.C.  Hillary Clinton began a whirlwind day in South Carolina on Thursday by taking questions from some 400 African-Americans in Kingstree, where in 1996 President Bill Clinton attended a dedication for a newly rebuilt church that had been burned by members of the Ku Klux Klan.

title: Hey, Sport! Know Your Old New York Slang?
description: Lingo of the 1920s is back on Broadway. Test your knowledge, with help from Forest Whitaker.

title: Review: In Hughie, With Forest Whitaker, Two Desolate Lost Souls
description: The dim and cavernous hotel lobby is, as one of its two inhabitants puts it, about as homey as the morgue. But for Erie Smith, the fidgety man who comes up with that desolate description, this morgue is the only place to be.

title: Review: Women Without Men, a Learning Experience of Sorts
description: The staff sitting room at the Malyn Park Private School looks snug enough. Yes, the fire is less than blazing and a few of the cushions are threadbare, but the chairs are covered in a cheerful green, the rug looks soft underfoot and the lamps cast a warm glow. You wouldnt think so much malice could lurk somewhere quite so cozy.

title: Review: Tetzlaff Trio: Music Thats Off Kilter, Even Boozy
description: Rarely is an encore so well chosen as it was at Zankel Hall on Wednesday night. The fiery ensemble made up of the star violinist Christian Tetzlaff, the cellist Tanja Tetzlaff (his sister) and the pianist Lars Vogt had burned through Dvoraks E-minor trio (Dumky) before intermission, so after a warm ovation at the end of the concert they returned to that composer with the Scherzo from his earlier F-minor trio.

title: Spooking Spelunkers
description: Administrivial Will Shortz Sighting Alert! Will Shortz sat down to answer readerss questions about the crossword on the Times Insider podcast. Non-members can listen too! Click here to listen in.

title: Review: In Pericles, Much Ado About a Lot of Things
description: What shall be next, says Gower, the sorely taxed narrator of Shakespeares complicated romance Pericles, preparing to introduce the next knot in the yarn. Well, you might reasonably think, what shall not be next?

title: Donald Trump Is Focus of Attacks in the Republican Debate
description: This Republican debate is a make-or-break moment for all candidates but Donald Trump. Among the political experts I speak to, the debate is between those who are betting on Trump and those who think that someone else (usually Rubio) still has a strong chance. The betting markets on the eve of the debate showed Trump with a 74 percent chance of becoming the Republican nominee, and Rubio with a 24 percent chance. Of course Ben Carson and John Kasich are also part of the debate, but the focus is on Trump, Cruz and Rubio as the front-runners. Heres my play-by-play from the debate, in the form not of a column but simply an assortment of my tweets during the debate. Its journalism on the fly  and here goes!

title: Mayor De Blasio Proposes Retirement Savings Plan for Private-Sector Workers
description: Amid visions of a new Brooklyn-Queens streetcar line and a repurposed Governors Island, one progressive aspect of Mayor Bill de Blasios State of the City address this month was obscured.

John Gagnon, Who Linked Sexuality to Social Influences, Dies at 84
description: John Gagnon, a sociologist who shifted the ground in sex research by proposing that sexual behavior could better be understood by looking at social forces rather than biology or psychology, died on Feb. 11 at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 84.

Trumps ascendancy and worried that his presidential chances were slipping away, unleashed a barrage of attacks on the real estate moguls business ethics, hiring practices and financial achievements in Thursdays debate, forcefully delivering the onslaught that Republican leaders had desperately awaited.

description: Days before Massachusetts votes in its Super Tuesday primary, a poll in the state shows Hillary Clinton with a slight edge over Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, but one that is within the margin of error.

title: New York Police Captain Is Put on Modified Duty for Not Helping After Shootout
description: A New York City police captain has been placed on administrative duty for declining to stay after his shift to help when two officers were injured in a shootout in Brooklyn, the police said on Thursday.

description: Under pressure from the last Republican presidential nominee to release his tax returns, Donald J. Trump used the debate stage Thursday night to debut a new reason for why he cant do so right now, and might not even be able to release them at all during the campaign: Hes been the target of curious audits for many years.

title: Who Won the Debate? Attacks on Donald Trump Help Marco Rubio More
description: Donald J. Trump faced a barrage of attacks from his Republican rivals during their debate Thursday night, the last face-off before Super Tuesday next week. Senator Marco Rubio assailed Mr. Trumps record as a businessman and his knowledge of policy. Senator Ted Cruz called him a closet liberal in a multitude of ways. Mr. Trump responded forcefully and with a torrent of schoolyard taunts. Many critics and commentators thought that Mr. Rubio was the clear winner on Thursday night, but said that his newfound toughness may have come too late.

title: Milan Fashion Week Day 3: Versace and Emporio Armani
description: MILAN  Milan Day 3 revs into gear promptly at 9.30 a.m. with Diesel Black Gold, followed by a triumvirate of catwalk shows from the secondary lines of big-gun Italian brands: Emporio Armani, followed by Sportmax and, lastly, Giamba, the little sister of the Giambattista Valli house.

title: Peering Through the Haze of Chinas Economic Data
description: BEIJING  With economic growth slowing and Chinas stock markets in turmoil, the Communist Party and central government are starting to restrict the flow of economic information and data to control the narrative. That runs counter to the needs of global investors and economists, who had been hoping that China would continue becoming more transparent with such information.

title: A Unified Theory of Trump
description: In trying to explain Donald Trump and his hostile takeover of the Republican Party, people have trotted out a host of character disorders. Narcissist. Racist. Bully. Buffoon. Tyrant. Liar. Celebrity obsessive. Fact-denier. Youve heard them all, and they all apply, in varying degrees.

title: The Governing Cancer of Our Time
description: We live in a big, diverse society. There are essentially two ways to maintain order and get things done in such a society  politics or some form of dictatorship. Either through compromise or brute force. Our founding fathers chose politics.

title: Helping Women in Africa Avoid H.I.V.
description: Every day, nearly 1,000 young women around the world become infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. More than half of the 37 million people worldwide infected with H.I.V. are women, and most of them live in sub-Saharan Africa. These women too often lack the awareness, the financial means and the power over their own lives to protect themselves from the virus. Tragically, more women of reproductive age around the world die from AIDS than from any other cause.

title: Veto South Dakotas Transgender Restroom Law
description: Gov. Dennis Daugaard of South Dakota must decide by Tuesday whether his state will become the first to designate some public restrooms at schools off limits to transgender students.

title: Twilight of the Apparatchiks
description: Lack of self-awareness can be fatal. The haplessness of the Republican establishment in the face of Trumpism is a case in point.

title: How to Reduce Crime: Stop Charging Children as Adults
description: FOR the second year in a row, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has proposed raising the age of the states Family Court jurisdiction to 18 from 16. If that legislation fails again this year, it will leave New York and North Carolina as the only states where people age 16 and older can be tried as an adult and, if incarcerated, locked up in adult prisons and jails. (In New York, children as young as 13 must be tried in adult court for certain charges, like murder.)

title: Sarah Palins Mustache
description: ITS hard to know exactly what impact Sarah Palins endorsement of Donald J. Trump has had on his campaign. We do know, however, that the sparkly Milly beaded silk bolero jacket she wore while giving her speech sold out soon after, despite its $695 price tag. But several style experts slammed her choice as inappropriate, and on Twitter a marketing executive likened her to a disco ball hedgehog.

title: Bruni and Douthat Agree: #OscarsSoPolitical
description: ROSS DOUTHAT:Frank, its a pleasure to once again be together to talk about the glorious silliness of the Oscars, and a special pleasure to engage in some prognostication that doesnt involve the outcome of either presidential primary. (It wont be Trump it wont be Trump la la la la la la I cant heaaar you.)

title: R.B.S. Reports Multibillion Dollar Loss in 4th Quarter
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland reported on Friday a multibillion-dollar loss in the fourth quarter that was worse than analyst expectations, driven by 2.21 billion pounds, or about $3 billion, in additional provisions for legal and regulatory matters.

description: The following lesson activities are based on the article What Its Really Like to Work in Hollywood* (*If youre not a straight white man.).

title: Eni, Hit by Falling Oil Prices, Reports $9.4 Billion Loss
description: LONDON  The Italian oil giant Eni reported on Friday a loss of 8.5 billion euros, or about $9.4 billion, in the fourth quarter of 2015, becoming the latest energy company to be hit by sharply lower crude prices that have slashed revenue and led to asset write-downs.

title: In Rare Appearance, Chinas Central Bank Chief Says All Is Well

title: Shedding Skins at the Zoo
description: My first serious relationship ended a week before I started my summer job at the zoo. Every morning as I drove my parents Toyota to work, Id put on a Dar Williams CD and cry. I felt as tragic as it was possible to feel while wearing an oversize blue T-shirt with gorillas printed on the front.

title: Decline of Pollinators Poses Threat to World Food Supply, Report Says
description: The birds and the bees need help. Also, the butterflies, moths, wasps, beetles and bats. Without an international effort, a new report warns, increasing numbers of species that promote the growth of hundreds of billions of dollars worth of food each year face extinction.

title: An Insurance Penalty From Postpartum Depression
description: In January, a government-appointed panel recommended that all pregnant women and new mothers be screened for depression. Public health advocates rejoiced, as did untold numbers of women who had not known that maternal mental illness even existed before it hit them like a freight train.

title: Scalia Took Dozens of Trips Funded by Private Sponsors
description: WASHINGTON  Antonin Scalia was the longest-tenured justice on the current Supreme Court and the countrys most prominent constitutionalist. But another quality also set him apart: Among the courts members, he was the most frequent traveler, to spots around the globe, on trips paid for by private sponsors.

title: Two Whirling Dervishes

title: For Two Frequent Fliers, a Trip Down the Matrimonial Runway
description: Her life revolved around research institutes and fellowships. His moved along the edges of business and government. He traveled a lot. She moved often. There were planes to catch, seminars, grant proposals, a book to write, classes to teach, a whirlwind that rarely stopped. Rebecca MacKinnon and Bennett Freeman had known each other professionally for years, had sat in the same room for meetings, but cannot recall having a single conversation outside of work.

title: The National Park Service, at 100, Gets Its Own Film

The agency is turning a 100 years old in August, and in commemoration Brand USA, the national marketing organization for the United States, has produced National Parks Adventure in partnership with MacGillivray Freeman Films and its co-founder Greg MacGillivray.

Quickly, they formed a circle, which grew to include excited 9-year-old boys and wrinkly old men. All of them were clapping, pumping one another up, preparing to fight.

Beyond the apartments themselves, the modern leather sofas, nubby rugs and factory-inspired lamps displayed in model units are all available for purchase. So are the crisp bedsheets, fluffy towels, multicolored bowls and streamlined flatware used to accessorize the spaces.

The Today show will feature an extended segment with Kathie Lee Gifford and Hoda Kotb, and Late Night with Seth Meyers will have an additional comedy sketch.

description: When the gnomes moved into a Pennsylvania state park, the children in town begged their parents to take them there.

Now she is about to become a test case in the battle over religion and gender in Israels public spaces  and the skies above  as the plaintiff in a lawsuit accusing El Al, the national airline, of discrimination.

description: Zenefits, a San Francisco health insurance start-up facing regulatory scrutiny, plans to lay off 250 people starting Friday, David Sacks, the chief executive, says.

title: On This Day in Poetry History, by Amy Newman
description: The artists job is a continual extinction of personality, T.S. Eliot said. Try telling that to John Berryman, Elizabeth Bishop, Robert Lowell, Sylvia Plath, Theodore Roethke, Delmore Schwartz and Anne Sexton, the subjects of Amy Newmans dazzling new collection of poems, On This Day in Poetry History. Speculating on his generations colossal ambitions and eventual place in literary history, in a letter that Newman quotes as an epigraph, Lowell wrote Roethke that there must be a kind of glory to it all that people coming later will wonder at. I can see us all being written up in some huge book of the age. But under what title?

title: Etro: Fall 2016
description: The latest looks from Etro.

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Brussels

title: The Right Wrong Man, by Lawrence Douglas
description: Not once but twice, in the period 1987-2012, the Ukrainian-American John Demjanjuk was tried and convicted of offenses committed as a World War II death camp guard. Following each trial, one in Israel, the other in Germany, he appealed. The first appeal was successful: The Israeli prosecutors had charged the wrong man. The second appeal was not heard: The 91-year-old Demjanjuk died before the court could be convened, though the German prosecutors were confident his appeal would fail.

title: Should Democrats Fear Trump?
description: My insta-take on last nights debate isnt particularly original: Marco Rubios shrinking violet actthis week turned out to be a head fake, he battered and  above all  mocked Donald Trump in ways that Republicans should have beenbattering him and mocking him all along, and Trumps counterpunches were weak and Rubio did what poor Jeb Bush never managed and talked over him, denying him the chance to let his punchlines land. Between Rubio and Ted Cruz, who was also on offense, there was still probably too much talk about how Trump is not a real conservative, and too little in the way of efforts toactually co-opt the valid parts of Trumps critiques of organized conservatism and the Republican Party. And if Trump somehow wins that will be the deepstory  that his rivalsjust couldnt grasp how disaffected their voters were from the Bush-and-after record and the present party line. But what we saw last night was at least, and at last, the obvious way of taking down Trump, the way that Ive assumed will work all along. Now well find out if its too late.

title: Letters: Love and Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Talents Changing the Red Carpet Glamour Game
description: A former model who styles Alicia Vikander, a makeup artist who works with Lupita Nyongo and a Hollywood insider are changing the typical notion of celebrity allure.

title: Reimagining the Record
description: In 1974, Gore Vidal told The Paris Review: By and large, history tends to be rather poor fiction  except at its best. The Peloponnesian War is a great novel about people who actually lived. Yet Vidal turned to history as the source for his own fiction time after time. (In this weeks Shortlist, Maxwell Carter reviews three new novels based on the real lives of artists, including Michelangelo and Georgia OKeeffe.)

title: 1941: Bulgaria Denies Nazi Rumors
description: SOFIA  Tension in Sofia reached the highest point in a month of crisis as unconfirmed but alarming and persistent rumors flew wildly from mouth to mouth today [Feb. 26]. These rumors, which were flatly denied in government circles, described the entry into Bulgaria of trainloads of German soldiers, followed by hundreds of tanks. According to one version circulating in Sofia tonight, crossings had been made into Bulgaria at the Danube River points of Vidia, near the Yugoslav frontier, and Nicopol, across the river from Turnu Magurele, Rumania. However, when the reporter tried to check the reports by telephoning to these towns, he was told that no troops had arrived on the Bulgarian side of the river. At both places, however, movements had been observed on the Rumanian side and on the river itself, he was informed. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 27, 1941

title: Judge in Dewey & LeBoeuf Fraud Case Whittles Down Charges
description: An accounting fraud case at a once-prominent New York law firm that captured front-page headlines in 2014 is now looking more ordinary.

title: Threes a Trend: Sheer Silhouettes, With a Bit of Fantasy
description: A few runways in New York and London have featured black lace dresses with a goth feel  while others have shown light, romantic versions covered in otherworldly designs. At Alberta Ferretti (left), a sheer dress came embroidered with flowers growing up the sides; at Gucci (center), motifs included swans covered in marabou feathers. And at Alexander McQueen (right), several fantastical references converged in a single garment: flowers, unicorns  even a sun.

title: Recipes for the Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Wreck and Order, by Hannah Tennant-Moore
description: If you count drinking a bottle of wine by yourself and crying in public parks as going to school in Paris, then yes, I definitely went to school in Paris, the narrator of Hannah Tennant-Moores debut novel, Wreck and Order, notes by way of describing her education. And Paris is only the beginning of her travels. Once this would have been called the Ive been to Europe story, but the current trend seems to be the Ive been to the developing world novel, and Tennant-Moores book is exactly that.

title: Doubts in Asia Over Whether New Sanctions Against North Korea Can Work
description: SEOUL, South Korea  As a new set of sanctions against North Korea circulated at the United Nations Security Council, analysts in South Korea and China expressed doubts on Friday that the measures would be tough enough to force the pariah state to give up its nuclear weapons.

title: Turning Polluted Properties Into Profits
description: Decades ago, Ideal Uniform Rental operated a dry cleaner in Garden Grove, Calif., and some of the solvents it used leaked into the ground and the water supply.

title: 1916: French Retake Douaumont
description: The battle in the region to the north ofVerdun continued yesterday without respite. The slow, regular withdrawal of theFrench forces has apparently ceased, theFrench troops driving back the Germans,from the position round the fort of Douaumont, which after several costly attempts, they had carried.

title: Feds 3 Mandates: Price Stability, Jobs and ... Wall Street?
description: Suppose a visitor from the future comes and tells you these facts about the financial markets in the year 2030: The stock market has fallen sharply, as have the price of oil and investors expectations for interest rate increases over the next couple of years.

title: Paperback Row
description: Paperback books of particular interest.

title: James Burke, Ex-Suffolk County Police Chief, Pleads Guilty
description: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y.  The former police chief of Suffolk County pleaded guilty on Friday to federal charges stemming from accusations that he beat a suspect in custody, threatened to kill him and then coerced his fellow officers into covering up the misconduct.

title: Germany Chooses New Eurovision Singer After Outcry
description: LONDON  The 17-year-old singer Jamie-Lee Kriewitz will represent Germany at this years Eurovision song contest with her song Ghost. She was elected on Thursday night by public vote.

title: Editors Choice
description: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.

title: Be Frank With Me, by Julia Claiborne Johnson
description: Early on in Julia Claiborne Johnsons first novel, the wise reader  or, perhaps, the forgiving reader  will find a clue that will suggest how best to read this book. Mimi Banning, the reclusive writer at the center of its plot, explains to her new assistant, Alice Whitley, that her 9-year-old son, Frank, was once obsessed with gangster epics but has moved on to screwball comedies.

title: The Book of Memory, by Petina Gappah
description: With the advent of social media, forgetting can seem like an obsolete danger: Facebook timelines and chat logs have externalized the burden of remembering. But a different and more pernicious kind of forgetfulness looms in Petina Gappahs first novel, The Book of Memory, whose narrator grapples with the threat of erasure.

title: The Slaves Cause: A History of Abolition, by Manisha Sinha
description: Without question, the most important liberation movement in American history  from Jacksonian democracy to gay rights  was the long struggle against slavery. Abolition established the principles and rhetoric, while setting the strategies and tactics, that have guided all subsequent reform movements  even those that have stood opposed to one another like prohibitionism and antiprohibitionism, or pro- and anti-abortion rights. Recently, historians have been taking a new look at the struggle against slavery as a way of examining contemporary movements for securing human rights, expanding democracy, liberating colonials and criticizing capitalism.

title: Ways to Disappear, by Idra Novey
description: A novel starring a novelist can often seem a little pleased with itself, as if the author is looking over her shoulder, eager to make a great drama from a greatly uneventful thing. So it was with some trepidation that I picked up Ways to Disappear, the first novel by the poet and translator Idra Novey. The protagonist, Emma Neufeld, is a Portuguese-to-English translator devoted to the work of a cult-classic Brazilian writer. Novey herself translates from Portuguese to English, most recently the work of Clarice Lispector, the cult-classic Brazilian writer.

title: Weatherland, by Alexandra Harris
description: In Virginia Woolfs novel Orlando, every century of the title characters long life is marked by distinctively different weather and changes in the air. The days and seasons of the Elizabethan age are full of sharp contrasts (its either hot or cold, bright or dark), while for the Victorians the light and sun of the 18th century turn damp, moist and shadowy. All was darkness, Orlando observes at the stroke of midnight on the last day of 1799, the 19th century had begun.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Marcus Samuelsson
description: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is Marcus Samuelsson, the chef behind Red Rooster in Harlem and Kitchen & Table, a concept restaurant with Clarion Hotels in Sweden and Norway. He shares his list exclusively with T.

title: Could the Internet Do What the Euro Couldnt?
description: ROME  WHEREVER you look in Europe, the 60-year project to unite the Continent is starting to show its age.

title: Review: Full House Sequel Is a Forced March Down Memory Lane
description: Netflixs Fuller House is not good, but thats arguably the best thing the show has going for it. To make a Full House sequel good  less formulaic, more innovative  would be like baking an artisanal, organic Hostess CupCake: You could do it, it might be delicious, but it would be a betrayal of the product. This is, after all, a franchise whose theme song begins, Whatever happened to predictability?

title: Artists in Fiction
description: OIL AND MARBLEA Novel of Leonardo and MichelangeloBy Stephanie Storey345 pp. Arcade, $24.99.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: A Mothers Reckoning
description: This week, Sue Klebold talks about her new memoir; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Matthew Desmond discusses Evicted; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Marco Rubio Entices a Receptive Constituency: The Well-to-Do
description: In Iowa, Marco Rubios campaign knew how to spot its supporters in a sea of locals wearing Carhartt jackets and work boots: Look for the people in Vineyard Vines and Patagonia.

title: Metropolitan Museum of Art Reaches Settlement on Admissions Policy
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art reached a settlement Friday in part of a long-running legal challenge to its admissions policy, conceding a semantic point and agreeing to change the wording on its signs to say that its $25 dollar full-admission charge is suggested instead of recommended.

title: San Francisco Wants Homeless to Leave Tent Camp, but Some Vow to Fight
description: SAN FRANCISCO  An order by the San Francisco authorities to vacate a sidewalk tent camp in a commercial district has rekindled passions over the citys longstanding homeless problem, which residents say has reached crisis levels.

title: At Etro, Practical Beauty for a Night on the Town
description: For fall/winter 2016, Veronica Etro was inspired by 90s London  and memories of growing up and going out. Backstage, where models flitted about in robes printed with the designers signature paisley patterns, the hairstylist James Pecis created a look he described as 90s grunge  but with clean hair, and a bit of Rayanne from the show My So-Called Life, he added.

title: Fresh Pasta Comes in Different Shades
description: Please never make me choose between dried pasta and fresh pasta. Theres a time and a place for each of them, and I confess to loving both equally.

title: A Side Table With Character
description: This blackened metal console has something of the hulking monumentality and elegance of a Richard Serra installation, albeit on a domestic scale. Fashioned by the design firm Uhuru in its Red Hook, Brooklyn, studio, the 250-pound table is meant to weather over time, acquiring a warmth and patina, and the dings that accompany real life. As its name  the Tack  suggests, the piece is tack-welded (soldered with small beads instead of thick strips), a technique that lends it a surprising delicacy, while also conjuring an aging freighter gliding gracefully, even despite its heft, across roiling seas.

title: Sarah Kershaw, Former Times Reporter, Dies at 49
description: Sarah Kershaw, a former reporter for The New York Times who covered real estate, the Pacific Northwest and New York City schools, died on Monday at her home in Sosa, a beach town in the Dominican Republic. She was 49.

title: Popcast: Macklemores Aesthetic Mission
description: Jon Caramanica chats with the rapper about the role of music in creating change.

title: Prada and Moschino: Burning Down the House
description: MILAN  Its such a difficult period; we dont know who we are or who we want to be. This was Miuccia Prada, backstage, trying to explain herself after a tour de force of a collection, while being divebombed by well-wishers and journalists trawling for a crumb of enlightenment like so many starving sea gulls: Give us depth, or give us damask.

title: Popcast: Macklemore on White Privilege and Sparking Conversation
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

title: Gianni Infantino to Lead FIFA Into New Era
description: ZURICH  Gianni Infantino looked out at the people who rule global soccer, the members of FIFA. Once, twice, he tried to begin his speech, clearly stunned. He had just won the FIFA presidency on Friday, but seemed to be still sorting out how it had happened.

title: Obama Points to Florida Factory as Evidence That Stimulus Worked
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  President Obama on Friday used a visit to a high-technology battery plant in Florida to argue that the hundreds of billions of dollars in federal subsidies he signed into law during his first days in office had bolstered the economy, transformed the nations energy sector, and positioned the United States for a strong rebound.

title: VWs Public Relations Responses and Flubs
description: The automaker  known for its insular culture and a carefully scripted messaging machine  has stumbled repeatedly in explaining itself.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Fendi, Moschino and Pucci in Pictures
description: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Thursday.

title: VWs Crisis Strategy: Forward, Reverse, U-Turn
description: LONDON  Someday, Volkswagens emissions cheating scandal will be studied in crisis communications textbooks. And not in a good way.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks homes include a colonial in Katonah, N.Y., and a contemporary in Westport, Conn.

title: DNA Under the Scope, and a Forensic Tool Under a Cloud
description: Marina Stajic worked for nearly three decades as director of the forensic toxicology lab at the medical examiners office in New York City. Last week Dr.. Stajic, 66, filed a lawsuit against the city, claiming she had been forced into retirement last year in part because of a disagreement with her superiors over the accuracy of certain DNA tests.

title: John Marshall Must Be Spinning in His Grave: Readers on the G.O.P. and the Supreme Court
description: Many readers expressed outrage and despair, and some showed a sense of confidence in the governments balance of powers, in response to an editorial about Senate Republicans vow not to consider any nominee to the Supreme Court until next year.

title: Inside Darryl Pinckneys Writing Studio
description: The novelist and essayists studio in Harlem, where he wrote his new novel, Black Deutschland.

title: A Republican Slugfest, Not a Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Feb. 27 Through March 6
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Greenwich Village, Murray Hill and Brooklyn Heights.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: When Another Child Wants to Be Friends and Yours Does Not
description: Sometimes every parent needs advice. For our occasional advice column, we post readers questions that we know (or at least suspect) plague more than one parent. You  the readers  provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family? I invite an expert to add to the discussion.

title: A Writers Room: Darryl Pinckney
description: The novelist and essayist on his studio in Harlem, where he wrote his new novel, Black Deutschland.

title: U.N. Security Council Endorses Truce Deal for Syria
description: UNITED NATIONS  Against the backdrop of relentless airstrikes on rebel-held positions inside Syria, the United Nations Security Council on Friday unanimously endorsed a deal negotiated between the United States and Russia for a cessation of hostilities.

title: At Essence Lunch, a Lesson in Diversity Off-Camera
description: The annual Essence Black Women in Hollywood lunch, held in Beverly Hills days before the Oscars, is always a show of spirit, talent, glamour and grit. This years event was something more: a how-to manual on wresting control of Hollywood away from white men.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, Feb. 27 Through Mar. 6
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: $28.5 Million, a Record Sale in NoLIta
description: The developer Jared Kushner, son-in-law of the presidential hopeful Donald J. Trump, sold the second of six loft-style apartments at Puck Penthouses, a luxury condominium his firm assembled atop the landmark Puck Building in NoLIta. At $28,511,000, the transaction was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records, as well as a neighborhood record.

title: Inside the List
description: O Captain: William Shatners new book, Leonard, about his 50-year relationship with his Star Trek co-star and occasional frenemy Leonard Nimoy, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 11. Readers looking for gossip about Kirk and Spock wont be disappointed  theres plenty here about contract disputes, on-set rivalries and substance abuse, along with the revelation that Nimoy, who died in 2015 at the age of 83, essentially stopped speaking to Shatner for the last several years of his life because Shatner had filmed him without permission for a documentary about the Starship Enterprise. But Shatner also devotes generous space to his friends sensitive artistic side, taking note of Nimoys photographic pursuits and seven volumes of poetry  including, in 1973, the surprisingly successful debut You & I, which went through five print runs in hardcover and had an initial paperback printing of 250,000 copies. What helped sell the book, of course, was the fact that Leonard was willing to promote it by doing bookstore signings, Shatner writes. It may have been Leonards poetry  but fans were getting Spocks autograph. What did Shatner think of the work? Trying to understand poets through their poetry requires higher degrees than I have, he writes, but it is obvious reading his work that from the beginning to the end Leonard was intent on emotionally defining grand themes like love, compassion, loss and the endless search for roots. For the man who became famous playing the ultimate dispassionate character, his poems successfully bring out the range of important emotions.

title: Big Ticket | 293 Lafayette Street
description: A ninth-floor, 5,222-square-foot apartment in NoLIta sold for $28,511,000, and was the most expensive closed sale of the week in New York.

title: Strange Gods, by Susan Jacoby
description: By the time she was 14, the writer Susan Jacoby realized that there is no God, and ever after, she has been working to share that insight. Her new book studies the phenomenon of conversion, since she is upset that people still find ways to accept goofy religious myths. Sometimes she writes as if it is a personal insult to her for people to have any religion. She resents the fact that a nun of the Dominican order, singing a tribute to the orders founder, St. Dominic, did so with a mind-numbing refrain that still pounds in my cortex as Dominiqua-niqua-niqua. She writes to prove that the so-called religious experience of conversion often has a secular explanation  then she offers a broad range to choose from.

title: Top Lobbyist for Drug Makers Threads a Thicket of Outrage
description: WASHINGTON  Few lobbyists have walked into the kind of political inferno that greeted Stephen J. Ubl when he became the top pitchman for the pharmaceutical industry.

title: Matthew Desmonds Evicted: Poverty and Profit in the American City
description: [On this weeks Inside The New York Times Book Review podcast, Matthew Desmond discusses Evicted.]

title: 92nd Street Y Announces 2016-17 Concert Season
description: The pianist Angela Hewitt will begin a four-year survey of Bachs complete keyboard works with three recitals next season at the 92nd Street Y, the Y announced this week.

title: My Kabubble, Starring Tina Fey
description: In March 2014, I took a BuzzFeed quiz called What Actress Would Play You in the Movie Version of Your Life? Among my answers to nine typically nonsensical survey questions were monkey emoji, electric guitar and penguin. With that, the results were announced: You got  Tina Fey.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, Feb. 27 Through March 6
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Chris Christie Endorses Donald Trump and Calls Marco Rubio Desperate
description: In a rollicking day of spectacle, spite and scorn, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey declared his allegiance to Donald J. Trump and war on Marco Rubio, describing the senator on Friday as desperate and unfit for the presidency.

title: Marco Rubio Does a Withering Takedown of Donald Trump
description: Senator Marco Rubio on Friday leveled the same kind of taunting, ridiculing insults against Donald J. Trump that Mr. Trump is so well-known for throwing at his rivals, reprising his feisty debate performance.

title: War Music, by Christopher Logue
description: On Mount Olympus the gods are at it again. Bickering, back-stabbing. Thetis implores Zeus, on behalf of her son, the Greek hero Achilles. Hera, the wife and sister of Zeus (you know how families can be), demands that he back her favorites. Far below, on the plains stretching from Troy to the sea, mere mortals fight and suffer in a war that has gone on far too long and will be sung forever. But for now, all-powerful Zeus has had enough. And he lets Hera and the others know it with a threat that shuts them up and silences the world. Then, we read:

title: Marco de Vincenzo: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Marco de Vincenzo presents his fall 2016 collection.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, Feb. 27 to March 6
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Some Kids Sell Lemonade. He Starts a Chain.
description: Two summers ago, Jack Bonneau started a lemonade stand to earn some cash. Instead of setting it up on a street corner in his Broomfield, Colo., neighborhood, he and his father, Steve, came up with a more ambitious plan. Jack, then 8, would peddle cups of lemonade at the local farmers market throughout the summer.

title: Palestinian Fugitive Found Dead Outside Embassy in Bulgaria
description: JERUSALEM  A Palestinian man who escaped from prison in Israel more than 20 years ago was found dead Friday outside the Palestinian Embassy in Bulgaria, his family and Palestinian officials said.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Review: At Campagna, Glamour and Grace Notes in the Countryside
description: On a recent visit to Campagna I looked over and saw Richard Gere, the owner of the Bedford Post Inn complex in which the restaurant is located, happily dining with two others a couple of tables down. No one was bothering him: A man and woman nearby had eyes only for each other, a group of six friends were laughing over appetizers and others were moving between tables to say hello to neighbors they had just noticed. But as Mr. Gere made his way out, a quiet buzz stirred through the room.

title: Raf Simons
description: In his studio in Antwerp, the mens wear designer ponders a future as an artist  or a farmer.

title: Alfajores
description: Learn to make dulce de leche from a can of condensed milk for this Latin American dessert.

title: Alfajores, a Sweet Excuse for Making Dulce de Leche
description: I ate alfajores daily when I was in Argentina, grabbing a packet of the foil-wrapped confection whenever I saw one: at cafes, markets, gas stations, the concession stand at the zoo.

title: The New Republic Is Sold
description: Chris Hughes, the owner of The New Republic, said on Friday that he had sold the magazine to Win McCormack, a publisher and editor based in New York and Portland, Ore., who founded the literary quarterly Tin House.

title: Review: Thai West Puts French Accent on an Asian Cuisine
description: At its best, fusion cuisine can be novel and refreshing; at its worst, a hard-to-decipher mash-up.

title: Review: Xarello Takes Inspiration From a Michelin Favorite
description: Look close enough at Xarello, a Mediterranean restaurant that opened late last year in Williston Park, and you will see a place where nearly every detail is perfect. The dining room is sleek and romantic, with radiant cherry-red banquettes that hark back to the Russian Tea Room. Glasses, tableware and cutlery are all four-star quality. And the service, which embraces a more formal style, is outstanding. Water glasses barely reach the halfway mark before they are refilled, and plates of food land unfailingly in front of the person who ordered them. You will not find much better service this side of the Lincoln Tunnel.

title: Raf Simons: A Look Back
description: Fresh off his departure from Dior, the influential designer pauses to consider the future of mens fashion.

title: The World (and Future) of Raf Simons
description: The Belgian fashion designer Raf Simons lives, at least part of the year, above a flower shop in one of the fancier arrondissements of Paris. His apartment is one of those expected parquet-floored affairs with carved boiseries painted chalk-white, filled with contemporary art. Theres a George Condo painting that makes the sitter look like Beaker from The Muppet Show, hung in a space once occupied, perhaps, by a 19th-century academic oil. There are good Picasso ceramics on a gray marble mantelpiece.

title: Tods: Fall 2016 RTW
description: Fall 2016 looks from Tods.

title: Review: At Abigails in Simsbury, a Ghost, at No Extra Charge
description: When a building has been around for a couple of hundred years, it is not uncommon to hear tales of ghosts inhabiting the premises. Such is the case with Abigails Grille and Wine Bar in Simsbury, in a former tavern that dates to 1803, atop the foundation of a stagecoach stop built in 1780.

title: Tony Burton, Apollo Creeds Trainer in Rocky Movies, Dies at 78
description: Tony Burton, who played a tough-talking boxing trainer in six of the Rocky movies with Sylvester Stallone, died on Thursday in a California hospital, his family said. He was 78.

title: Perry Hill Delivers a Simple Message for a Complex Task
description: JUPITER, Fla.  Baseball is awash in data, and the game is better for it. Numbers reveal truths that broaden fans understanding. Executives make better-informed decisions. Players with subtly valuable skills are appreciated more, and paid accordingly.

title: Artists Greatest Subject Was the Panama Canal
description: Not everyone sees the artistic potential in the current construction of a new Tappan Zee Bridge. But Bartholomew F. Bland does.

title: Amid Iraqi Chaos, Moktada al-Sadr, an Old Provocateur, Returns
description: BAGHDAD  They came from the slums of this citys underclass, the alleyways and the simple halls of the seminary in the Shiite holy city of Najaf, and the outer reaches of the rural south.

title: Sculptures That Find Emotion in Geology
description: This one is a caesura, the artist Liz Larner says while running her fingertips along a long piece of fired clay in her studio in the Highland Park neighborhood of Los Angeles. The piece is the approximate oblong shape of a world map, painted with yellow and black pigment and coated with a mucilaginous resin. A fracture runs down the middle of the sculpture. The caesura, or poetic line break, becomes a literal break, geologic in form, rising from the piece like a mountain range from a fault line. Its linguistic, says Larner, who this week presents nearly 30 of these wall-hung sculptures as a body of work at the Aspen Art Museum, but its also physical.

title: Review: Comic Drama in Sister Play in Summit
description: There are some promises of intriguing interactions in Sister Play, a dramatic comedy at the Dreamcatcher Repertory Theater at the Oakes Center in Summit. But those promises have been largely left unfulfilled.

title: Cut Compensation at Investment Banks, Then Take Cover
description: Long gone are the days on Wall Street when our leading investment banks were stock-market highfliers.

title: The Fashion News to Know This Week
description: See now, au revoir now

title: The Faces of American Power, Nearly as White as the Oscar Nominees
description: An all-white group of Oscar-nominated actors set off protests, but the most powerful Americans in business, culture and politics are overwhelmingly white.

title: Bill Cosby Drops Defamation Suit Against Beverly Johnson
description: Even as Bill Cosby drops a defamation lawsuit against one of his accusers in California, he is trying to delay or halt the criminal proceedings against him in Pennsylvania.

title: Appalachias Distress
description: To the Editor:

title: Voice for Latinos in Long Island Reaches Across Cultural Divide
description: It would be impossible to try to find one voice for the estimated 25,000 Latinos on Long Islands East End. Some are wealthy, some are struggling; some are undocumented, and others are American citizens.

title: The Everything-in-One Promise of a Continuing Care Community
description: Is it possible to have it all in retirement? Thats what so-called continuing care retirement communities promise.

title: The Tomb Is Never Far Away in This Gray Romeo
description: Those Capulets and Montagues, hurling insults and spittle at each other and inspiring even their servants to curl fists and brandish knives, have made Verona a bad enough environment for raising kids. Now Hartford Stage has gone further, putting Romeo Montague and Juliet Capulet at odds with the universe: Their world is backed by a stage-spanning gray wall of mausoleum vaults, and at their feet lies a rectangular pit of pebbles akin to a grave.

title: Where to Shop, Eat and Play in Milan, According to Giuseppe Zanotti
description: The shoe designer lists his favorite places to watch the sun rise, go for coffee  and totally let loose.

title: Integrating Public Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Murder in the Bronx
description: To the Editor:

title: For Black Women in South Carolina, Its Clintons Turn
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Jackie DeBose woke up early on Sunday, well before sunrise, grabbed her rhinestone-bedazzled Obama hat and her vintage Hillary for President button, loaded her suitcase in the trunk of her Lexus and headed to pick up three friends for a road trip to South Carolina.

title: Shabab Militants Claim Deadly Attack on Hotel in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Somali militants on Friday attacked a popular hotel and a nearby public garden in Mogadishu, the capital, killing at least 10 people and wounding more than 25, witnesses and officials said.

title: Group to Air Ads Featuring Ex-Students Saying Trump University Deceived Them
description: Senators Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz assailed Donald J. Trump in the presidential debate on Thursday for his involvement in Trump University, a defunct educational company that triggered a massive fraud suit against Mr. Trump.

title: Donald Trump and Chris Christie Werent Always So Friendly
description: The love-fest between Donald J. Trump and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey could hardly have been more effusive on Friday. Unveiling Mr. Christies endorsement, Mr. Trump called him a spectacular governor and a close friend whose support he coveted deeply. Mr. Christie said Mr. Trump was by far the best leader to take America forward and a true fighter.

description: To the Editor:

title: 360 Reviews Often Lead to Cruel, Not Constructive, Criticism
description: Snarky comments and ad hominem attacks may sound like the makings of a middle school social media takedown or the unmoderated comments section of a website, but those same tactics are often at play in the workplace  especially in so-called 360 reviews.

title: Mortality Rates for Whites: Opioids and Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bohemian Capitalist
description: One day during the past few weeks you may have noticed, on the subway home from work, an ad that wasnt like the others, in part because it didnt promote an app that could deliver a grain bowl, or a dog groomer, or a pack of C batteries and a gallon of Tide to your door in 19 minutes, and in part because it might have nudged you toward your essential prudishness.

title: Bernie Sanderss Jewishness
description: To the Editor:

title: Strange Candy: On Amy Sedariss Instagram
description: Welcome to Social Capital, a series devoted to analyzing the social-media presences of celebrities.

title: When Did the Red Carpet Become Prom?
description: In a literal sense, the red carpet has been part of the Oscars since 1961. But the red carpet as we know it today dates from the 1995 ceremony, when Joan Rivers and her daughter, Melissa, stood along the scarlet walkway and asked attendees the indelible question: Who are you wearing?

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review Podcast: A Mothers Reckoning
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | Stitcher

title: Is there a real Dead Dog Park in Manhattan?
description: Q. There is an Off Broadway play, Dead Dog Park, running through March 6, about a police killing in Upper Manhattan. Is there a real Dead Dog Park?

title: How to Forge Your Own Path in Hollywood
description: Earlier this week, we shared stories of what its really like to work in Hollywood when youre not a straight white man. Below, some of the 27 industry players we talked to discuss strategies for moving forward.

title: Bernie Sanders Is Getting Advice From Expert Who Cited Possible Israeli Ties to Chemical Attacks
description: Senator Bernie Sanders, looking to shore up his credentials on foreign policy, is seeking advice from a patchwork of experts, including Lawrence Wilkerson, who was chief of staff to Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and who has speculated that Israel might have carried out chemical attacks in Syria.

title: Trump Universitys Checkered Past Haunting Candidate
description: The now-defunct Trump University, the subject of one of Marco Rubios attacks on Donald J. Trump at the Republican presidential debate on Thursday night, was not a real university at all but a series of seminars held in hotels across the country that promised to share Mr. Trumps real estate investing acumen with students. It is still embroiled in lawsuits accusing it of misrepresentation.

title: The Alliance of Chris Christie and Donald Trump: What Each Side Gets
description: Gov. Chris Christies announcement on Friday that he was endorsing Donald J. Trump startled the political world. But every political marriage involves a bit of calculation, and in this case, each man has much to gain from the alliance.

title: Melissa Harris-Perry Walks Off Her MSNBC Show After Pre-emptions
description: In an unusually public flare-up, one of MSNBCs television personalities clashed with the network on Friday in a dispute about airtime and editorial freedom and said she was refusing to host the show that bears her name this weekend.

title: Ted Cruz Moves Aggressively to Court Younger Voters
description: Senator Ted Cruz quotes Scarface and boasts of his beer pong prowess.

title: Wallflower Bunny Finds a Home and a Companion
description: Tonya, always the bridesmaid rabbit, is finally a bride.

title: Jazzercise Lives On in the Age of Zumba
description: If you have an ear to the ground, you can still hear the commands  Grapevine! Step-ball-change!  in New York, where Zumba and Tracy Anderson-inspired dance cardio classes long ago trumped Jazzercise as the choreographed workout of choice.

title: How Clinton and Sanders Are Courting Black Votes
description: Charleston, S.C.  ON Thursday night, a few blocks from Mother Emanuel A.M.E. Church, Charlie Wilson, in a shimmery white blazer, was trying to get out the vote for Hillary Clinton. And trying to get the former secretary of state to do some shoulder shrugs. She bopped her head along gamely, smiling wide.

title: The Arbiter of Invention
description: Robert Quintero works out of a tiny office overlooking West 34th Street that is filled with big ideas, and bigger dreams.

title: Apple Shareholders Show Their Support for Tim Cook
description: CUPERTINO, Calif.  Even before Timothy D. Cook, Apples chief executive, began his speech on Friday at the companys annual shareholder meeting, he got a standing ovation.

title: The History of the Archbishop Whos Concerned About Girl Scouts
description: Archbishop Robert Carlsons recent caution to his parishes in St. Louis about the troubling pattern of behavior of the Girl Scouts is stirring stark recollections of the prelates past role in managing accusations against priests for sexually abusing children. In a deposition two years ago, he insisted that he was not certain sexual abuse of a child by a priest constituted a criminal act in 1984, when he was auxiliary bishop for St. Paul and Minneapolis handling sex scandal cases.

title: Japan Lost Nearly a Million People in 5 Years, Census Says
description: TOKYO  Japans population shrank by nearly a million during the last half-decade, official census figures confirmed on Friday, an unprecedented drop for a society not ravaged by war or other deadly crisis, and one that helps explain the countrys persistent economic woes.

title: Justice Scalias Death Prompts Dow Chemical to Settle Lawsuit
description: Antonin Scalias empty Supreme Court seat has cost Dow Chemical $835 million.

title: Golfers Say Trump Reneged on Deal
description: When last we left Donald J. Trump, at least here on the sports page, we were recalling the time he owned the New Jersey Generals in the short-lived United States Football League. Trump bought the Generals in 1983, after their first season, and immediately began pushing the league to move its season from the spring to the fall and take on the mighty N.F.L. His campaign generated a tremendous amount of publicity for Trump, but produced nothing but misery for the other owners. After a Trump-orchestrated antitrust suit against the N.F.L. backfired spectacularly, the once-promising U.S.F.L. went kaput.

title: Better Care or Onerous Restrictions? Texas Abortion Law Going Before Supreme Court
description: For all the furious debate over constitutional rights rekindled by the first Supreme Court  abortion case in nearly a decade, the stated goal of the law at issue is a medical one: ensuring patient safety.

title: Family Says Death of Black Woman in South Carolina Jail Was Easily Preventable
description: The chain of events that led to the death of a black woman in a South Carolina jail last July began with a desperate bid to save her life from alcoholism.

title: How Mark Norell, a Paleontologist, Spends His Sundays
description: The titanosaur recently unveiled at the American Museum of Natural History was nearly as long and heavy as two subway cars when it roamed the earth, making it one of the biggest dinosaurs ever discovered. But Mark A. Norell, 58, the curator and chief of the museums paleontology division, is just as excited about an exhibition opening March 21, Dinosaurs Among Us, which he curated and which explores how one group of dinosaurs evolved into birds. Dr. Norell says technology has brought paleontology closer to biology, allowing scientists to examine topics like the evolution of dinosaur brains, and, yes, dinosaur feathers. He lives in the NoMad neighborhood with his wife, Vivian Pan, a partner in a capital management firm. Their daughter, Inga, 20, is a student at Barnard College.

title: An Easy Fix for Vertigo
description: The first time it happened, in 2011, Bob Amberger thought he might be having a stroke.

title: Sora Choi Transforms at Versace
